DOC.HEAD: Quayle to Visit 3 Latin Nations, but Some Others Reluctant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 11-12: ``Venezuelan officials,'' with report Mexico, Venezuela among the countries objecting
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle will visit Panama, Honduras and Jamaica this month, aides said Wednesday, but one official said privately that other countries feeling resentment about the U.S. invasion of Panama were discouraging Quayle visits at this time. Quayle himself said that ``diplomatic sensitivities'' have held up scheduling his trip to Central and South America. But he denied any lingering ``deep resentment'' among Latin leaders after President Bush's Dec. 20 invasion of Panama. ``No country has said, `We don't want the vice president, period,''' he told a luncheon gathering of the Hoover Institution. However, Quayle later told a reporter, ``There are diplomatic sensitivities. There's a matter of timing on when you go. There's a matter of coordination. And these things have all got to be worked out.'' It is anticipated that Quayle, instead of actually visiting as many of the countries as he originally might have, will meet with many of their leaders when he attends presidential inaugurations in Honduras on Jan. 27 and in Brazil and Chile in mid-March. His office on Wednesday announced he would go to Panama and Jamaica in conjunction with the Honduras trip, and would make ``other stops to be determined'' on his March 10-16 South American trip for the inaugurations. Many Latin officials have said opposition in their countries to the U.S. military action is so strong that this would not be a good time for Quayle to visit, especially while the U.S. combat troops remain in Panama. One administration official, commenting only on condition of anonymity, confirmed that some of the countries have passed along to Quayle their reluctance to have him visit now. The official said that the nations have not indicated they would reject Quayle indefinitely, just that this is a bad time. ``By the end of this thing in a couple months, we will have talked to everyone,'' the official said. Venezuelan officials in Washington have told reporters they would prefer that Quayle not visit, and the head of the country's main opposition party, Eduardo Fernandez, said in Caracas on Wednesday a visit ``would not be convenient.'' Quayle aides Wednesday night declined to confirm or deny a report in Thursday editions of The New York Times that Quayle had dropped plans to stop in Venezuela and Mexico because of objections from those countries. Bush said, in assigning Quayle to visit the region, that he understood the sensitivities of the Latins to the U.S. military action in their region and was sending Quayle to explain the action was not taken lightly or without rationale. Asked if Bush had underestimated the depth of reaction to the invasion, the official replied, ``Bush spotted the problem a lot earlier than most.'' Quayle, asked about the impact of the Panama action on his trip, said of the Latin American leaders, ``I've talked to a number of these people on the phone ... and I will be very surprised if I find deep resentment. ''I do not believe that the heads of state are unhappy or resentful of our actions in Panama. I think they understand it. That's one of the reasons I'm going down, to find out what their true feelings are.'' Earlier, Quayle told the lunch group, ``My mission is not one to apologize. It is not an effort to mend fences,'' but rather, he said, to consult with the Latin leaders ``on how we make Panama a successful democracy.'' One Venezuelan official said that in addition to perceiving the timing as a problem, many people in countries Quayle might visit object to him as the messenger because of his conservatism and his role as a principal cheerleader for the invasion. The Organization of American States voted to deplore the military action and some Latin leaders have publicly viewed it as trampling on Panama's sovereignty. Peru's president, Alan Garcia, is protesting by saying he won't attend the upcoming drug summit in Colombia if U.S. invasion troops remain in Panama. He is sending a lower ranking representative of his government. Bush said Wednesday he wants to withdraw the invasion force from Panama ``as soon as possible,'' but he feels under no pressure to get them out before the Feb. 15 drug summit. Bush, in a photo session with Gen. Maxwell Thurman, the commander of U.S. forces in Panama, congratulated Thurman and his troops for ``the outstanding job they did for our country.'' He denied, in response to a shouted question, any difficulties finding countries willing to host Quayle in the region.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Picks First Military Women As Astronaut Candidates
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Three women from the military, including a student test pilot expected to be the first female space shuttle pilot, are among 23 people selected as astronaut candidates, NASA announced Wednesday. It marked the first time that female military officers have been tapped as astronaut candidates, although some have applied for the position in the past, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said. The list also includes Los Angeles native Ellen Ochoa, the first female Hispanic selection. The three military women are Air Force Maj. Eileen M. Collins, the first woman to be named a shuttle pilot candidate, Air Force Capt. Susan J. Helms of Charlotte, N.C., and Army Capt. Nancy J. Sherlock of Wilmington, Del. Helms and Sherlock were chosen as mission specialist candidates. Collins, an Elmira, N.Y., native who is a student test pilot at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., also may become the first female to command a shuttle mission. Shuttle pilots usually fly once as the pilot before being named commander of a flight. In all, seven pilot candidates and 16 mission specialists were selected from a list of 1,945 qualified applications. Last fall, 106 applicants were interviewed by NASA. The 23 astronaut candidates will train for a year beginning in July before they are given technical jobs that lead to assignments on shuttle missions. The astronaut candidates include Ronald M. Sega, the husband of astronaut Bonnie Dunbar _ a mission specialist aboard the current Columbia flight. Sega, a Cleveland native who is now a professor at the University of Houston, was named a mission specialist. The other shuttle pilot candidates and their hometowns are: Kenneth D. Cockrell of Austin, Texas; Air Force Capt. William G. Gregory of Lockport, N.Y.; Air Force Maj. James D. Halsell Jr. of Monroe, La.; Air Force Maj. Charles J. Precourt of Waltham, Mass.; Air Force Maj. Richard A. Searfoss of Mount Clemens, Mich.; and Marine Corps Maj. Terrence W. Wilcutt of Russellville, Ky. The other mission specialists and their hometowns are: Navy Lt. Cmdr. Daniel W. Bursch of Bristol, Pa.; Leroy Chiao of Milwaukee, Wis.; Army Maj. Michael R.U. Clifford of Norton Air Force Base, Calif.; Bernard A. Harris Jr. of Temple, Texas; Thomas D. Jones of Baltimore, Md.; Army Maj. William S. McArthur Jr. of Laurinburg, N.C.; James H. Newman of Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands; Donald A. Thomas of Cleveland; Janice E. Voss of South Bend, Ind.; Air Force Capt. Carl E. Walz of Cleveland; Peter J.K. Wisoff of Norfolk, Va.; and David A. Wolf of Indianapolis.

DOC.HEAD: Wave of Arrests of Roman Catholic Clergy Reported Continuing
DOC.TEXT: Chinese authorities have intensified their suppression of the Roman Catholic Church, carrying out a ``wave of arrests'' of clergy loyal to the pope, a church missionary bulletin reports. Asia News, published by the Institute for Foreign Missions, said the Chinese government ``has adopted a policy of hard repression of all dissent, especially that of Catholics.'' It identified some among those it said were recently arrested as Pietro Liu Guandong; bishop of Yixian; Giuseppe Li Side, bishop of Tianjian; Jiang Liren, bishop of Hohot; Mattia Lu Zhensheng, bishop of Tianshui; Filippo Yang Lipo, bishop of Lanzhou; Paolo Li Zhenrung, bishop of Xianxian; and Bartolomeo Yu Chengdi, bishop of Hanzhong. About 20 priests, deacons and lay people have also been arrested, Asia News said in Tuesday's report. China broke diplomatic relations with the Vatican in 1957 and allows worship only under the guise of the state-sponsored Chinese Patriotic Catholic Church, which consecrates its own bishops. The church claims more than 3 million members, but an unknown number of other Catholics remain secretly loyal to the pope. ``It is feared the wave of arrests could now extend to Beijing,'' said Asia News, adding that the state-controlled church is investigating to identify the places where the pro-Roman Catholics celebrate their Masses in secret. ``The Patriotic Catholic Church seems to actively participate in the repressive action, collaborating with the police,'' it said. The missionary organization said its Hong Kong office compiled the information from sources in China and that all those arrested had practiced their religion clandestinely.

DOC.HEAD: Military Surplus Store Owner Goes for the Big Guns
DOC.TEXT: A military surplus store owner is landing new customers with big prices on big guns. Tim Carpenter is running advertisements in a weekly shopper that tout rocket-propelled grenade launchers for $42,000 each, anti-tank weapons for $39,000 and land mines for $6,000 a pop. The only thing is, none of them pop. Carpenter admits they're also overpriced. For example, he said, an inoperable grenade launcher sells for about $2,000 at most government auctions. ``If it wasn't a gimmick, I'd be arrested. I don't see how anyone could take this seriously,'' said Carpenter, who bought the Logan Square PX store in September. ``We've had better response with this ad in a few hours than we've had in weeks with other ads.''

DOC.HEAD: Physical Reminders Gone, Emotional Scars Remain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Assault Pistols
DOC.TEXT: One year after shots from a semiautomatic weapon shattered playtime and childhood innocence at an elementary school, campus life appears to have returned to normal, but fragile immigrant families are still healing. The shootings helped lead to the nation's first and only statewide ban on the sale of assault weapons. The buildings at Cleveland Elementary have been painted and the blacktop repaved, covering the bullet holes and blood stains where five children died and 29 other children and one teacher were injured. Behind the school, two boys dribble a basketball up the steps of a classroom building near where on Jan. 17, 1989, 24-year-old drifter Patrick Purdy fired 105 rounds from his AK-47 assault rifle, then used a handgun to kill himself. But while the campus is free of noticeable scars, the students and teachers are not. Some still carry bullet fragments inside their bodies, and the wounded teacher limps from a bullet-shattered knee. About 100 children still attend weekly group therapy sessions. Many teachers also receive counseling. ``The kinds of things the kids are expressing are still some fears of strangers, fears of loud noises, difficulty sleeping and nightmares,'' said Roger Speed, program chief for San Joaquin County Mental Health Services. Those symptoms are some of the same as for post-traumatic stress disorder, a chronic ailment suffered by some Vietnam War veterans, war survivors and victims of rape and torture. ``It remains to be seen whether these children are going to have a chronic problem or not,'' Speed said. ``We don't know. Only time will tell.'' School and county mental health authorities initiated counseling for students and staff immediately after the shooting, with hopes of aiding the healing process and preventing problems later on. ``But mental health therapy is not a miracle,'' Speed said. ``It's not something that solves everyone's problems. ... We can't guarantee that all of these kids are going to be problem-free.'' For many of the children, the shooting was the latest in a series of tragedies to befall their families. About 60 percent of Cleveland Elementary's 1,000 pupils are from Southeast Asian refugee families, many of them already traumatized by war. The five children who died by Purdy's bullets were of Southeast Asian descent, four Cambodian and one Vietnamese. An official report described Purdy as emotionally disturbed and full of racial hatred. The father of slain Ram Chun, 8, frequently cries out for his dead daughter, sometimes talking of suicide and occasionally requiring hospitalization. The girl's 16-year-old brother ran away from home last April after being hospitalized for an emotional breakdown. The father of slain Sokhim An, 6, has difficulty sleeping and worries about the safety of his four other children. Speed said the county's transcultural mental health clinic has seen its clientele double from 450 last year to nearly 900. ``I can't say each one of those is directly related to the Cleveland School incident,'' he said. ``But these are all Southeast Asian folks. I know they're all aware of the shooting. I think it affects their anxiety about being separate from the community.'' A two-week teachers' strike over pay issues that threatened to continue through the anniversary of the shooting created confusion for many families, officials said. The walkout ended Monday night. Therapists also worried that widespread media attention to the anniversary could reopen psychological wounds. The attention, however, also has affected society. Last May, in the wake of the Stockton shooting and escalating street gang violence, the California Legislature passed the nation's first and only statewide ban on the sale of assault weapons. The wounded teacher, Janet Geng, has returned to teaching and become an outspoken advocate of nationwide gun control. Boon Khoonsrivong, director of Lao Kmu Association Refugee Resource Center, said community support after the shooting helped overcome some cultural barriers between Southeast Asian immigrants and other ethnic groups. ``I think at first they thought that the thing was going to happen again, that it might be discrimination, but after that they could see that a lot of people are concerned, the community is concerned about them and is doing something good about them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Villagers Unhappy With Course of Revolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs reeport.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The overthrow of Nicolae Ceausescu may herald the return of freedom in Romania, but many of this Transylvanian village's 2,200 laborers say their store shelves remain bare and leaders are still corrupt. ``Nothing has changed,'' says Vasile Grota, who works on an assembly line in a leather factory. ``We still have little to eat, and the family is often cold.'' Mayor Virgil Cernusca and other newly installed community figures depicted villagers as generally content with their lot in the wake of the revolution and with the local officials now leading them. But complaints by Grota and others in Poplaca, about three miles outside of the regional capital of Sibiu and 100 miles northwest of Bucharest, indicated that ordinary folk feel the revolution has left them in the lurch. They believe that Ceausescu's energy and food rationing should be just a bad memory, banished with the toppling and execution of the Stalinist dictator and his wife, and the plans to create a Western-style democracy. A month after the popular uprising, however, fuel for the tile stoves in Poplaca's modest houses is just as scarce as in the old days, even though rationing officially has ended. Yards are bare except for a scrawny chicken or two scratching the frozen earth, and the little food on display in the community grocery store strains small budgets to the limit. As in other villages, overt Ceausescu loyalists have been replaced by new community leaders. But angry villagers complain that appointments had been made from above _ by the region's provisional government in Sibiu _ and they had no say in the selection, just like under Ceausescu. So, they remain distrustful of the new officials. ``These are not our people,'' said Maria Luca, shaking her head wrapped in a black shawl. ``We didn't put them in office, they chose themselves.'' Many said the workplace also has changed little from the days when Communist Party appointees milked state farms and factories for personal gain. ``They made themselves millionaires but didn't give anything to the workers,'' said Grota, 59. His voice rising indignantly, Grota said the director of his enterprise had not been replaced even though he had taken $10,000 in a production bonus last year. ``And we got nothing,'' Grota said. The haggard man wearing torn shirt and trousers, his face blackened by soot from a futile attempt to light his wood stove, wept as he aired old frustrations and new disappointments at a table crowding one of two dingy rooms he shares with his wife and infant daughter. ``I had a yard full of animals,'' Grota sobbed, relating the evils of Ceausescu's 24-year tenure. ``They took them all away from me, and now I have trouble finding the 14 lei ($1.50) to buy milk for my girl.'' And the new leaders are no different, he charged. ``What have I gotten in return since the revolution? Two kilos (4.4 pounds) of wheat, and I don't have wood for the winter because I don't have enough money.'' Grota waved in resignation when asked about village leaders. ``These are still Ceausescu's people,'' he said. ``They've got to change all of them, even the teachers,'' he said, saying they had twisted children's minds with the dictator's vision of a socalist Romania. Luca, Grota's neighbor, added her voice to complaints about factory officials. ``I also want to change all the leaders of our collective because they were part of the old order, the bad ones,'' she said, suggesting that some held on to good jobs despite being in the pay of Securitate _ Ceausescu's feared special police _ less than a month ago. As the two spoke, about 30 villagers gathered in front of Grota's hovel and around the all-terrain vehicle formerly owned by the Ceausescus and now used by the local provisional government to transport foreign guests around the region. Many had marched the night before to express their general discontent with the course of the revolution. ``Give us new leaders!'' some of them shouted, as the Western visitors emerged. ``We don't have enough food.''

DOC.HEAD: Monet Cookery Notebooks Reveal Tyrannical Gourmet
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The publication of Claude Monet's cookery notebooks reveals the father of Impressionism as a tyrannical gourmet who could fly into a rage over a sauce. ``Monet's Cookery Notebooks,'' by Claire Joyes and published recently by Editions du Chene, is a delightful look at the private life of the man who immortalized haystacks in the haze and water lilies floating under a quaint Japanese footbridge. The book is to be published in the United States in the spring by Prentice Hall. A must for art buffs and food lovers alike, Monet's cookbook _ with recipes tested and adapted by award-winning chef Joel Robuchon _ is an authentic record taken from family notes. Like a social and cultural chronicle of the half century Monet spent at his Normandy country home in Giverny from 1883 to 1926, the notebooks detail Monet's likes and dislikes, what he served to his friends and what his second wife Alice had prepared for their eight children (two were his, six were hers) on ordinary days and holidays. It even tells how tables were set for picnics. Joyes, an art historian, found the handwritten notebooks tucked among letters, photographs and other Monet archives inherited by her husband, Jean-Marie Toulgouat, a great-grandson of Alice Hoschede Monet. ``Claire was the storyteller, Jean-Marie had the memory,'' said Benedicte Servignat, Joyes' editor at Chene. ``He never knew Monet, but he spent all his childhood vacations at the Giverny farmhouse and remembered the cook Marguerite and, of course, Monet's step-daughter Blanche, who carried on all the culinary traditions after Monet's death.'' Toulgouat, an artist, and Joyes live in the village of Giverny, near Vernon, but have nothing to do with Monet's renovated farmhouse, now open to the public as a museum. Monet was a solid, middle-class bon vivant, but his daily routine was strictly regimented and it revolved totally around painting. He rose before dawn to capture the variations of early morning light, took a cold shower and breakfasted English-style _ on eggs and bacon, grilled tripe sausages and cheese, toast and orange marmelade. He would spend the morning working on his studio-boat with Blanche, also an artist. Back by 11 a.m., they were ravenous and impatient to sit down to lunch. Joyes decribed Monet as ``a demon for punctuality. A first, then a second stroke of the gong would assemble the scattered family in the dining room for lunch, which was served at 11:30 precisely. Monet would cough irritably on the very half second, causing panic in the kitchen,'' she wrote. Lunch invariably was a five-course extravaganza, which included a fish course, meat dish, salad, cheese, a different homebaked dessert every day and cakes at 4 p.m. _ all prepared by the family cook Marguerite. Monet never lingered over his food. Service had to be quick so he could get back to work. He even ordered servants never to pass dishes around twice when his American stepson-in-law Theodore Butler was lunching with them since Butler's slow eating habits drove Monet mad. Lunch was a social affair, often with guests. Tea was served under the lime trees, always at 4:00. Friends were never invited for dinner because Monet was always in bed by 9:30. The uninvited, even close friends, were politely turned away. Though Alice ran the house, she consulted Monet in planning menus, which revolved around the fruit and vegetables in season and which catered to the special tastes of a roster of illustrious guests like Renoir, Cezanne and Premier Georges Clemenceau, who loved the waterlilies. Monet and his family arrived in Giverny in May in 1883. Despite their precarious financial situation, they immediately set about renovating the kitchen and landscaping the wild gardens which sloped gently down to wide meadows and a small pond. Monet was obssessed with order in his flower gardens, but he was fanatical about the picking schedule of his fruit and vegetables grown and nurtured in a 2{-acre walled kitchen garden on the other side of the town. Constantly looking to expand and improve an impressive array of herbs and vegetables, he would spend evenings leafing through scholarly publications to find new seeds to test in the rich and often wet Norman soil. Joyes described Monet as equally fanatical about the poultry he was served, spending an ``inordinate amount of time choosing ducks and hens to be used for breeding stock.'' He just didn't trust local farmers.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Steps Into Gap Left by China's Silenced Dissidents
LaserPhoto BEJ1
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: With China's best-known dissidents jailed, exiled or in hiding, a popular folk singer is trying to fill the void with protest songs and calls for democracy. ``You could say I'm the world's stupidest, most amateur dissident,'' said Hou Dejian, laughing and shaking his head in mock self-ridicule. ``I'm not a politician. I had friends who were dissidents, but . .. I'm a professional musician,'' he said, with elaborate emphasis. ``But right now, I'm trying to figure out how to become a passable dissident.'' Hou, 33, is no ordinary mainland musician: he is the Taiwanese-born son of a Nationalist soldier who fought against the Communists. Seeking his roots, Hou visited the Communist mainland as an established star in 1983 and decided to stay. The darling of the government, he was allowed to keep living like a star, with two homes and two cars, one a maroon Mercedes Benz. The skinny, chain-smoking Hou, usually clad in black leather jacket and boots, is famous among Chinese on the mainland, Taiwan and Hong Kong for his Bob Dylan-influenced songs about social concerns, such as the endangered pandas, and about the worries of youth. But he became known to Westerners when, in the final days of China's student democracy movement last spring, he and three friends began a hunger strike in Tiananmen Square to protest martial law. Many students were already leaving the square out of fear, and the hunger strike infused the movement with new spirit. Less than 48 hours later, on June 4, with tanks poised on the square's edge, Hou negotiated with the army to allow the remaining students to retreat peacefully, possibly saving hundreds of lives. Now, he is again trying to keep the spirit of democracy alive, taking advantage of his relative freedom as a defector. ``I can say more than ordinary Chinese,'' Hou said. So he has begun ``making a little noise,'' giving interviews to foreign journalists and singing for them the half-dozen songs he has written about the democracy movement, songs he knows no mainland company can record now. ``Friends who love freedom, spread our wings,'' one ballad goes. ``Listen carefully, no one can lie again. Open your eyes, no one can twist the truth again.'' Hou has not worked out any philosophy of government or theories about the relative merits of Communism and capitalism. ``I'm not a political scientist. I say, ask all the Chinese people and then decide.'' All he wants is provide an alternative to the Communist Party voice that has filled the airwaves and newspapers since June with relentless condemnation of the democracy movement. ``Because you can't hear other voices that doesn't mean there's stability,'' he said, choosing words carefully while he picked out chords on his electric guitar. ``We have an ancient tyrant culture. A real change would mean changing the slaves, not changing the tyrant. Although it's been slow, there is change. Most people in Beijing took part in the movement and ... they are not as afraid as before.'' Hou said the movement wiped away his feeling of being an outsider on the mainland. That is why during the summer, when he hid from police for more than two months in the Australian Embassy, he did not apply for asylum. He came out Aug. 15, as soon as the Foreign Ministry promised he would not be arrested or deported. Some Chinese suspected a deal when he told government television two days later that he did not see anyone killed in Tiananmen Square during the June 3-4 army attack. Authorities insist no one died in the square, while acknowledging about 300 deaths elsewhere in the city. But Hou said he made no deal. ``I can only say I didn't see anyone die. That doesn't prove no one died.'' Two of the three friends who went on the hunger strike with Hou remain jailed. One was freed in December. Hou was tailed by police for a while and has not been allowed so far to travel inside China or to Australia, where his wife, pop singer Cheng Lin, fled in June. But his main punishment has been loss of his career. Stores have been told not to sell his records, and he cannot sing his new songs in public. Hou said he has no interest in singing the old ones. He has begun selling his music equipment for money. ``I had a lot of money but I spent a lot,'' he said with a grin. ``I don't save.'' Nonetheless, he has turned his three-room Beijing apartment into a hostel for friends fired because they protested, and gives money to other former protesters who seek help. ``I don't like being a dissident _ I can't stand it,'' Hou said, self-mocking again. He remembered Fang Lizhi, China's most famous dissident, who has been hiding in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing since June. ``Maybe when Fang Lizhi comes out he can continue his dissidence and I can go back to being a musician.''

DOC.HEAD: Several Big Airlines Raise Fares Again to Pay Fuel Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with United matching fare increase, Continental studying, CLARIFY that American confirmed hike sted announced. A version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Several U.S. airlines said Tuesday they were raising air fares again to offset jet fuel costs, the second such hike in two weeks by major carriers, and one of the airlines announced a fuel surcharge. United Airlines, USAir and Northwest Airlines said they planned to increase by 10 percent selected one-way discount fares often used by business travelers. American, which on Monday confirmed plans for a 10 percent hike on similar fares, also plans to add a $6 one-way fuel surcharge effective Feb. 9 on all tickets. In addition, United, American and Northwest are adding a three-day advance purchase requirement, and USAir a seven-day advance purchase rule, for one-way discount fares that now don't require advance purchase. The changes are effective Jan. 24 for Northwest and Feb. 1 for American and USAir. Under American's changes, an unrestricted one-way fare between Chicago and Dallas, which was $314 on Jan. 1, increased to $327 on Jan. 11 and would go to $360 on Feb. 1, when it must be purchased three days in advance. Another $6 would be added on Feb. 9. Spokesmen for Continental Airlines, Delta Air Lines and Eastern Airlines said those carriers are studying the 10 percent fare hike. Earlier this month, industry leader American and other big U.S. airlines raised fares by 4 percent to help pay fuel costs while Northwest and others imposed a special fuel surcharge, the first such charge since the 1970s oil crisis. The 4 percent hike took effect on one-way tickets last Thursday, and also will apply to round-trip tickets starting Feb. 1, said Mary O'Neill, a spokeswoman for American in Fort Worth, Texas. She also said American plans a fuel surcharge of $6 one way and $12 round trip on all tickets, effective Feb. 9. Northwest previously planned a $6-$12 surcharge also to take effect Feb. 9. USAir spokeswoman Susan Young said a surcharge was under review. ``All these actions are very much related to the skyrocketing fuel costs that we are seeing,'' said Al Becker, a spokesman for American. He said the price American pays for jet fuel has jumped from an average 58 cents a gallon at the beginning of 1989 to around 96 cents as oil prices have surged. Jet fuel generally represents around 35 percent of an airline's operating budget. The fuel surcharges do not require government approval for domestic flights. Most of the airlines imposing them earlier this month said they have sought permission from foreign governments to apply them to international flights. Last week, American and United also raised most of their cargo rates to help offset fuel costs.

DOC.HEAD: `Baby Boom' Nine Months After Hugo
DOC.TEXT: Gaston County is due for a baby boom in June and early July _ about nine months after Hurricane Hugo hit, doctors say. The storm knocked out power and essentially shut down the county when it struck in September. ``Any time there is a natural disaster or snowstorm or anything that keeps people at their homes, this happens,'' said Deborah Hudson, business manager for Gaston Gynecology and Obstetrics, one of two prenatal centers in the county. By mid-January, the center already surpassed the number of new patients that showed up in December. Ms. Hudson expects to have 90 to 100 new patients this month, compared with about 50 for a normal January. Many of the expecting mothers are due in early summer. ``That's a pretty good indication that Hugo had something to do with it,'' she said. At Gastonia Women's Clinic, the county's other prenatal care center, Dr. Joseph Holman said, ``As soon as Hugo hit, we all joked about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Says Drug Law Would be ``Horrible Invasion'' of Rights
DOC.TEXT: A Senate bill to establish federal drug-testing standards for private companies is coming under fire from the chairman of a House panel as ``a horrible invasion of Americans' rights.'' Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on civil and constitutional rights, said Tuesday the measure would encourage drug testing that is ``terribly expensive and doesn't do any good.'' The bill might have support when Congress returns next week, Edwards said, ``with the drug hysteria that is being fanned by President Bush and his hard-line macho approach almost daily.'' Meanwhile, mandatory random testing for drugs and alcohol went into effect Tuesday for the 90,000 men and women who operate the nation's railroads. The bill by Sens. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, and David Boren, D-Okla., would not require businesses to test employees but give them the clear right to do so _ a provision supporters said would prevent unwarranted court challenges to drug-testing policies. Former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, endorsing the bill, said court challenges discourage companies from implementing drug-testing programs. He said such testing deters workers from using alcohol and drugs on the job. Hatch said the measure would protect privacy rights by establishing guidelines for circumstances under which businesses can test their workers. Under the measure, drug and alcohol tests would have to be analyzed at a federally certified lab. Tests could be conducted before workers are hired, during annual physical exams and any time for workers who had gone through a drug rehabilitation program. Random testing could be conducted only for ``sensitive'' employees, or workers who the employer says deal with matters connected to national security, health or safety, the environment or require ``a high degree of trust and confidence.'' The American Civil Liberties Union considers the guidelines vague and too broad, said the group's legislative representative, Gene Guerrero. The ACLU also opposes the measure because it would preempt state laws that do more to protect workers, Guerrero said. Sixteen states now have drug-testing laws, and several of those laws are more protective of workers' privacy rights than the Hatch-Boren measure, he said. The railroad drug and alcohol testing began one year after drug abuse was singled out as a factor in a 1987 Amtrak-Conrail crash near Baltimore that killed 16 people and injured 175. The testing program, delayed because a lengthy series of court battles between the government and railroad unions, requires that at least 25 percent of railroad engineers, brakemen, dispatchers, signalmen, conductors and all other railroad employees directly involved in the movement of trains be subjected to random testing this year. Half of the operations personnel of the nation's largest railroads must be tested by the end of 1991 for the presence of alcohol and such drugs as marijuana, cocaine, opiates, amphetamines, and phencyclidine, also known as PCP.

DOC.HEAD: Composer of `Twilight Zone,' Dozens of Film and TV Scores Dead
DOC.TEXT: Composer Jeff Alexander, whose scores for more than 40 movies and dozens of radio and television shows included the memorable melody from ``The Twilight Zone,'' has died at age 79. Alexander, who died of cancer Dec. 23, wrote the scores for several Elvis Presley movies, including ``Jailhouse Rock,'' and such musicals as ``Singin' in the Rain,'' ``Kismet,'' ``Seven Brides for Seven Brothers'' and ``Gigi.'' The composer, who lived on Whidbey Island northwest of Seattle, was reworking his musical, ``The Children's Crusade,'' at the time of his death. He had begun work on the show in 1975 with collaborators Yip Harburg and Larry Orenstein. He was one of the founders of the Screen Composer Guild, and served two terms on the board of governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. The Seattle native began his career in his early teens when he sang and danced on the vaudeville circuit. By his late teens, he was producing musical arrangements for several big bands. Alexander's first feature film arrangement was for the 1937 movie ``Shall We Dance.'' In addition to the ``Twilight Zone,'' his TV credits included the scores for the ``Jimmy Stewart Show,'' ``Dr. Kildare'' and ``My Three Sons.'' Alexander returned to Washington state in 1980 when he retired from films and television to compose chamber pieces and a symphony. He is survived by a daughter, Jill Alexander, of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Broken Budgets Top State Legislative Agendas
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of state legislatures are in the position of a supermarket shopper with a full cart and an empty wallet. Declining tax revenues have made budget problems the top issue facing at least 20 states this year _ and among the major issues in most other states _ even as they are pressed by such weighty matters as abortion, drug abuse, education and the environment. All but a few smaller states will hold 1990 legislative sessions, most beginning this month or next. Some states, particularly in the Northwest, have managed to avoid fiscal pitfalls, but most have fallen victim to an unexpected plunge in tax revenues. The most desperate states are in the Northeast, where lawmakers are trying to bail out of potential deficits that include $1.5 billion in New York, $500 million in Massachusetts, $400 million in Connecticut, $80 million in New Hampshire, $67 million in Maine and $30 million in Maryland. Notheastern governors have proposed: raising taxes in Massachusetts, canceling a tax cut in New York, raising ``sin taxes'' in New Hampshire and imposing a junk food ``snack tax'' in Maryland. ``The Northeast is far and away in the worst shape of any region,'' said Marcia Howard, research director for the National Association of State Budget Officers. ``I can't think of another state that is in as bad shape as any of the states in New England.'' Ms. Howard puts the blame on sluggish corporate profits that produced lower-than-expected corporate income tax revenues. ``I think the states that have the biggest problems are the states that rely most heavily on that tax,'' she said. Midwestern states generally have coped with the downturn, she said, because their expectations ``are so low that it's not difficult to meet them.'' Still, some states are having problems. Missouri's Senate Appropriations Committee chairman, Roger Wilson, has warned agencies to decide ``who gets into the lifeboat first.'' Most Southern states have taken in as much income as they expected, Ms. Howard said. But that doesn't mean they're wealthy. Louisiana is still slipping on lost oil revenues, and Hurricane Hugo blew away any hope of budget surpluses in the Carolinas. ``I think if `no frills' has ever been identified with a budget, it will be this year,'' said South Carolina state Rep. James W. Johnson Jr. ``I think we are going to do well to tread water and stay where we are.'' California's budget was shaken up by the Bay area earthquake, but several other Western states are in decent shape. Legislators in Washington and Utah face the pleasant task of deciding what to do with extra money. Perhaps the least pleasant task awaiting legislators this year is deciding whether to adopt more stringent abortion regulations. Nearly every legislature will have to confront what Alabama state Sen. Chip Bailey calls ``the most controversial issue any legislature will deal with in the next decade.'' Drug abuse is another high-profile dilemma that is expected to be a major issue in more than a dozen states. In Georgia, Democratic House leaders have prepared a package of more than 40 bills for what they call a ``Death on Drugs Campaign,'' ranging from increased penalties for drug traffickers to improved anti-drug educational programs. Republicans and Democratic Gov. Joe Frank Harris are proposing their own anti-drug packages. Several states, including Alabama, New York and Rhode Island, are considering proposals to suspend the driver's licenses of convicted drug users. ``People seem to cherish their driver's license, and I think that would be an effective penalty,'' Rhode Island Gov. Edward DiPrete said. Finances, abortion and drugs are issues that transcend local and regional boundaries, but many of the issues facing legislatures are more parochial. The big issue in Delaware is providing paramedic service to two counties that aren't already served. In Arizona, lawmakers are squabbling over the Martin Luther King holiday. In Illinois, it's a proposal to legalize Mississippi riverboat gambling to pay education bills _ what state Rep. E.J. ``Zeke'' Giorgi calls ``a conspicuous good use of bad money.'' And in New Jersey and neighboring Pennsylvania, no issue is getting more attention than high auto insurance rates. That prompted Stephen MacNett, chief counsel to Pennsylvania's Senate Republicans, to ask: ``Is there any other issue?''

DOC.HEAD: ABC's `Roseanne' Back in First Place
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``Roseanne'' is back on top of the television ratings in a week in which comedies dominated the Nielsen survey. Eight half-hour comedies were in the top 10. They were joined by CBS' ``60 Minutes'' and its post-game show after Sunday's National Football League championship playoff. ``Roseanne'' pushed ahead of NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' and ``Cheers'' to take first place. ``Cosby'' was second and ``Cheers'' third for the week ended Jan. 14. NBC had a commanding lead among the networks and CBS narrowly kept its second place position over ABC in the A.C. Nielsen Co. survey. The ratings: NBC 15.4, CBS 13.4 and ABC 13.2. Each point represents the percentage of the nation's 92.1 million television homes tuned to a show. NBC leads the season with 14.8 to ABC's 12.9 and CBS' 12.2. CBS' coverage of the football game between the Los Angeles Rams and San Francisco 49ers was listed as the top prime-time show by NBC and CBS in their version of the ratings. A portion of the game ran into prime time, but this is not counted in the official Nielsen list. San Francisco's victory in the game advanced the 49ers to the Super Bowl. The post-game show, however, is on the Nielsen list and tied for seventh place with NBC's ``Empty Nest.'' Here's the top 10: ABC's ``Roseanne''; NBC's ``The Cosby Show,'' ``Cheers,'' ``A Different World'' and ``The Golden Girls''; CBS' ``60 Minutes''; CBS' post-game NFL show and NBC's ``Empty Nest'' tied; NBC's ``Dear John'' and ABC's ``The Wonder Years.'' Eleventh place went to ABC's ``Coach,'' which is doing better on Tuesday night behind ``Roseanne'' than the canceled ``Chicken Soup.'' Two CBS Monday night shows, perhaps aided by the end of the season for ABC's Monday Night Football or by the baby boom, placed high in the ratings. ``Newhart'' and ``Designing Women'' were in a three-way tie for 13th place with NBC's ``L.A. Law.'' Stephanie had her baby on the ``Newhart'' episode, and the week before ``Designing Women'' was 10th for its one-hour special on the birth of Charlene's baby. The rest of the CBS Monday shows didn't do as well. ``Murphy Brown'' was 20th, ``Major Dad'' was 35th and ``Doctor, Doctor'' was 43rd. Another, ``The Famous Teddy Z,'' was 57th and is being replaced by Valerie Harper in ``City.'' ABC regained first place among news shows, replacing CBS, which fell from first to third. The ratings: ABC 11.9, NBC 10.9, CBS 10.8. The lowest-rated network show was CBS' ``Tour of Duty.''

DOC.BYLINE: Mexicans to U.S.: What Have You Done About Drugs? ^By CAROLYN SKORNECK
DOC.TEXT: Top U.S. and Mexican officials maintain anti-drug cooperation between the nations has never been better, but many Mexicans are still angry over their country's bad image in a TV miniseries on the slaying of an American drug agent. The Consejo Nacional de la Publicidad, the National Advertising Council, took out full-page ads in three major U.S. newspapers on Tuesday to outline Mexico's anti-drug efforts and to ask, ``What have you done in the U.S.A.?'' The miniseries on the kidnapping, torture and murder of Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena in 1985 and the subsequent cover-up by Mexican officials _ called ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story'' _ aired Jan. 7, 8 and 9 on NBC-TV. It generated a great deal of controversy in Mexico. ``I think it's obvious that the Mexicans were deeply chagrined by the NBC series,'' one Bush administration official said on condition of anonymity. The newspaper ads read, ``In Mexico we say: No a las Drogas!,'' which means ``No to drugs.'' They recount drug seizures, destruction of poppy and marijuana fields, arrests and sentences of drug-related criminals and the killing of 41 public servants in the line of duty. They conclude, ``And meanwhile, what have you done in the U.S.A.?'' ``We ran this advertisement in The Washington Post, The New York Times and The Los Angeles Times in reaction to a certain television miniseries because we wanted to rectify the damage that could have been done to Mexico's image,'' said Dionisio Ascobereta, director general of the Consejo Nacional de la Publicidad, the National Advertising Council. The council, a nonprofit organization made up of about 60 advertising agencies, is separate from the government, Ascobereta said in a telephone interview from Mexico City. The council has participated in public service campaigns in Mexico to prevent drug abuse and drunken driving and keep the streets clean. According to rates quoted by representatives of the three papers, the ads cost a total of about $124,340 to run. ``There's been a strong reaction by the Mexican government to the miniseries,'' DEA spokesman Frank Shults said Tuesday, adding it ``hasn't had any negative impact on our ability to conduct our international program with Mexico, at least not to my knowledge.'' Acting Deputy DEA Administrator Terrence Burke was in Mexico last week and ``had very productive meetings'' with people in the Mexican attorney general's office, Shults said. Fernando Arias, chief spokesman for Mexican Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, said last Friday, ``Now, more than ever, the relationship between our nations is friendly, particularly among those dedicated to fighting drug trafficking.'' The events in the miniseries occurred during the previous administration in Mexico. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who took office in December 1988, has cracked down on drug trafficking and corruption. But Mexican Embassy officials strongly criticized the show and NBC News segments that accompanied the broadcasts, contending they were inaccurate and unfairly depicted widespread corruption among Mexican authorities. Lloyd Siegel, executive producer for special broadcasts at NBC News, said Mexican Embassy officials refused invitations to appear on the discussion panels. ``We do not accept the charge that there were any inaccuracies or inconsistencies'' in the reporting, Siegel said last week. Last Friday, the government newspaper El Nacional published a front-page story accusing Camarena of being corrupt _ allegations heatedly denied by U.S. officials. ``There is not a scintilla of evidence whatsoever that Enrique Camarena was involved with the traffickers in any way other than an adversarial role,'' Shults said when that story appeared. Camarena, 37, was kidnapped Feb. 7, 1985, in Guadalajara, Mexico. His Mexican pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avalar, was kidnapped a few days later. Their bullet-riddled bodies, showing signs of torture, were found March 5, 1985, wrapped in plastic bags and buried in shallow graves on a ranch 60 miles southeast of Guadalajara. Drug traffickers Rafael Caro Quintero, 37; Ernesto Rafael Fonseca Carillo, 56; and 10 other men have been prosecuted and sentenced in Mexico for the killings. But U.S. officials believe some higher-level Mexican authorities were involved in protecting the drug traffickers and helping cover up the crime.

DOC.HEAD: ``CBS Evening News'' Third in Ratings by Narrow Margin
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``World News Tonight'' regained its winning ways in weekly ratings, but Dan Rather's once-dominant ``CBS Evening News'' was third in ratings last week, A.C. Nielsen Co. audience estimates show. ABC's newscast, anchored by Peter Jennings, easily won the week ending Jan. 14 with a ratings average of 11.9. It was the 12th time this season the program has triumphed over CBS's newscast, according to an ABC spokesman. The previous week, CBS was on top. Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Nightly News,'' which has been in third place, was second in ratings last week with a 10.9 average. Rather's newscast was third by a narrow margin of one-tenth of a point. Each point represents 921,000 homes. Last week, one major CBS affiliate, KPIX-TV in San Francisco, shifted Rather's program to an earlier 5:30 p.m. PST start time. But it isn't known yet if that was a factor in the week's Nielsen returns for the program, said Michael Eisenberg, CBS vice president for audience measurement. ``We couldn't point to that as the only reason right now,'' he said Tuesday. ``We're studying the matter and trying to find out what the reasons are.'' At a news conference in Los Angeles during the weekend, Rather and CBS News president David Burke said they were unable to explain the ratings slide. But each discounted speculation that some of it was due to Rather's much-publicized on-air confrontation with then GOP presidential candidate George Bush during a ``CBS Evening News'' interview in early 1988. Burke blamed part of the ratings problems on what he called statistical errors in the Nielsen ratings system and on the programs of other broadcast outlets such as the 24-hour Cable News Network. ``There is increasing competition from CNN, which means you don't have to make an appointment to watch the news anymore, you have it on all the time, and I think they do a fine job,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Actor Arrested on Drug Charges in Honolulu
DOC.TEXT: Japanese movie star Shintaro Katsu was arrested and pleaded guilty to drug charges after cocaine and marijuana were found in his underwear upon his arrival Tuesday at Honolulu International Airport, officials said. The 58-year-old actor, whose real name is Toshio Okumura, was fined $1,000 plus $350 in court costs after pleading guilty to misdemeanor possession of 1.75 grams of cocaine, said Elliott Enoki, a spokesman for the U.S. attorney's office. In return for his guilty plea on the cocaine charge, prosecutors dropped charges of possession and importation of 9.75 grams of marijuana, Enoki said. Enoki said the drugs were found in Katsu's underwear, but would not elaborate on what led authorities to search his clothing. After the guilty plea, officials with the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service detained Katsu for possible deportation. His attorney, James Koshiba, said Katsu was released on ``a couple of thousand dollars'' bail pending a hearing, for which no date was set.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Will Decide on Children's Testimony in Abuse Cases
DOC.TEXT: Idaho Attorney General Jim Jones says the Supreme Court now has a chance to correct ``a travesty of justice that silences some of our tiniest sex abuse victims while benefitting their molesters.'' Jones' strong reaction came after the court said Tuesday it will use cases from Maryland and Idaho to decide whether children may be forced to have face-to-face meetings with the adults charged with abusing them. Courts in both states threw out child-abuse convictions because defendants were not given a chance for such confrontations. Jones said those decisions pose ``an unacceptable roadblock to prosecution of child molesters,'' adding, ``Many sex abuse prosecutions can't be pursued without the use of incriminating statements made by young sex abuse victims.'' Many states in recent years have taken steps to protect young crime victims, such as allowing a child to testify by closed-circuit television rather than in the presence of the defendant. The court's decisions, expected by July, could spell out what steps are necessary to meet the constitutional requirement that ``in all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right ... to be confronted with the witnesses against him.'' Maryland Attorney General Joseph Curran said, ``This is a crucial case for the protection of the most vulnerable of victims: our children.'' ``We want the Supreme Court to recognize that children who have been traumatized by child abuse should not be forced to submit to additional traumatization by having to come face-to-face with their alleged assailants in open court,'' Curran said. The court's review of the two child-abuse cases marks its second venture into that area of the law within the past two years. The justices in 1988 struck down an Iowa man's sexual-assault conviction because two 13-year-old girls were allowed to testify while protected by a large screen placed in the courtroom between them and him. But that ruling, the result of splintered voting among the justices, appeared to leave unanswered whether there may be exceptions to the face-to-face requirement. In one of the new cases, Maryland's highest court threw out Sandra A. Craig's conviction, saying her 7-year-old accuser and three other young witnesses wrongly were allowed to testify against her over closed-circuit television. Mrs. Craig had been convicted of sexually molesting a girl who attended her Clarksville, Md., day-care center for two years before it was closed in 1986. She had been sentenced to 10 years in prison for her 1987 conviction on those charges. She also faces trial on charges stemming from allegations of molestation of 12 other children who attended her center. In the Idaho case, the issue is whether a defendant's right to confrontation was violated by the testimony of a pediatrician who had examined a 2-year-old girl allegedly abused by her father. Laura Lee Wright and Robert Giles were convicted in Idaho of lewd conduct committed on Mrs. Wright's two daughters, who were then 5 and 2. Mrs. Wright was sentenced to 20 years in prison, but the state Supreme Court threw out her conviction last June 13 and ordered a new trial. The state court ruled the trial judge wrongly allowed a pediatrician who had examined the 2-year-old to testify about what she told him. The girl did not testify at the trial, and therefore could not be cross-examined by Mrs. Wright's lawyer. In other matters Tuesday, the court: _Agreed to decide in an Alabama case what authority police have to stop and question someone on the basis of an anonymous tip. _Refused to let a 10-month strike by machinists against Eastern Airlines spread, through sympathy work stoppages, to commuter railroads in New York City, Philadelphia and their suburbs.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Says Congress Needs to Study Pesticides Before Legislating
DOC.TEXT: Public fear of pesticides is growing and politicians are poised to tighten regulations, but a researcher says incomplete information on the extent of agricultural chemical use could lead to bad law. ``As a nation, we are in the middle of a major assessment of the role of pesticides in agriculture,'' said Leonard Gianessi, of the Resources for the Future, a non-profit environmental research group which held a seminar on pesticides Tuesday. If lawmakers are set on making changes, they should first gather more information on the use of pesticides, he said. Otherwise, ``we stand a good chance of dropping many pesticides and thereby causing negative consequences that cannot be fully anticipated,'' Gianessi said. Gianessi said most reports on pesticides focus only on major field crops and many are out of date. ``For example, the last reports for Kansas and Missouri were done in 1978,'' he said. ``Some state have never released any pesticide use information at all.'' He said the federal government did its last multi-state pesticide use surveys for fruit and vegetable crops in 1978, and its last survey for citrus crops in 1977. Detailed information is needed to develop effective food residue monitoring programs, said the researcher. He added that because monitoring is expensive, it should be targeted to areas where pesticide use is high. Furthermore, lawmakers should have a realistic view of pesticides if they are to fashion regulations on their use. ``Pesticides have made it possible to grow high-value crops in regions of the country where such crops could not normally be produced,'' said Gianessi. Lawmakers also would benefit from better information from consumers on their specific concerns about pesticides, said Carol Kramer, another researcher who spoke at the seminar. ``There are a couple of studies of consumer reaction to extraordinary contamination of incidents where sales dropped precipitously,'' she said. ``However, there are no good studies of demonstrated routine consumer willingness to pay more for pesticide-free food products.'' She also said a number of grocery stores are experimenting with organically grown produce. But ``at this time, we cannot answer the fundamental question of how much perceived risk from pesticides consumers are willing to accept and how much they are willing to pay to get what they want,'' she said. Legislation has been introduced in both the House and Senate that would revise pesticide regulation. President Bush also has presented ideas he would like incorporated into any new law. The 1990 farm bill is also expected to contain provisions that in some way will encourage a change in the way chemicals are used in agriculture.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Cupid has a new message for lovers this Valentine's Day and volunteers are lining up to spread the word from Loveland. People around the world send their Valentines through the Loveland post office each year to get the special postmark and cachet verse. Ted Thompson, 85, has been coming up with verses since he and his wife, Mabel, started the remailing program in 1947. An estimated 300,000 people will get Thompson's latest Valentine's verse: ``It might just be a song bird, ``Or perhaps some sparkling dew, ``That brings fond recollections, ``And a timeless cupid too.'' Thompson said recently he's not sure where he got the inspiration. ``It takes the whole year for me to get something I'm satisfied with. It's a hard thing for me. Some people are born to write a verse for you, but that's far away from me.'' Since it stamped 300 pieces of mail its first year, more than 7 million Valentines have passed through the program. The mail is hand-stamped by about 50 senior-citizen volunteers. There's no charge for the extra touch, which begins Monday and continues through Feb. 14.

Some people paid $500 to go to Gov. Jim Florio's inaugural ball and ended up watching television. Organizers of Tuesday's $500-a-plate celebration planned for 3,000 guests, but more than 4,300 people showed up. ``Isn't this great? We are over subscribed at $500 apiece. Who would have thought that would ever happen at a Democratic event?'' wondered Princeton Mayor Barbara Sigmund, who also had sought the Democratic nomination for governor. Florio and his wife, Lucinda, arrived shortly before 9 p.m. and danced their first dance to ``Satin Doll.'' Florio said the ball was ``organized mayhem.'' Crews worked through the night Monday to build wood floors and two tents to handle the overflow crowd at the Garden State Convention Exhibition Center. Part of a dance floor and the cocktail area were sacrificed. But it still wasn't enough. About 500 people had to go across the street to a hotel to watch the festivities on a big screen television.

DOC.HEAD: Delay in Elections Reportedly in Store in Romania
DOC.TEXT: A leader of the opposition National Peasants Party says the revolutionary government has agreed to delay April parliamentary elections so fledgling parties will have more time to organize campaigns. ``They have promised us ... (the elections) will be postponed but they didn't give a precise date,'' said Ion Puiu, vice president of the the largest of the political groupings that have arisen since last month's revolution. Puiu said interim President Ion Iliescu gave the the assurance at a meeting when asked for a delay. The opposition would like the voting delayed at least until June. Efforts to get confirmation from Iliescu were unavailing late Tuesday. The National Salvation Front now runs Romania following the otherthrow and execution of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in a bloody popular uprising. U.S. Ambassador Alan Green Jr. praised the Front leadership on Monday, according to the official news agency Rompres. He was quoted as saying in the statement: ``The revolution is less than a month old, but the caliber of the leadership with whom I have met is very high. ``Significant progress has already been made in stabilizing the country and beginning a transition to a free society.'' Puiu said he believed the Front can guarantee free elections and is not concerned that former members of Ceausescu's Communist Party are among its leaders. The opposition leader said, ``The Communist Party is dead forever in Romania. This party has no future in this country.'' Rompres said six parties now have been given official status by the government, including the National Peasants Party, and applications from three others are pending. The provisional government has argued that swift elections are needed to put a Parliament and government in place that would avoid political missteps. The most apparent of those was Friday's hasty government ban on the Communist Party _ in response to a Bucharest demonstration _ that was rescinded Saturday pending submission to a national referendum on Jan. 28. Students on Tuesday under took a campaign to get rid of police informers in dormitories, end courses on Marxism and fire professors regarded as incompetent or party apparatchiks. It was common under Ceausescu's regime for doctorates to be awarded on the basis of party affiliation rather than academic qualifications.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Proposes Cutting US Foreign Aid to Boost Funds to Panama, East Europe
DOC.TEXT: Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, claiming the White House's blessing, wants to provide new aid to emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and Panama by trimming aid across the board to traditional allies. Within hours of the proposal, voiced at a news conference Tuesday and in an opinion column in The New York Times, denunciations came from Israel and assorted lobbyists for other countries that would lose out under the plan. But State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler called it ``well worth looking at.'' Dole said President Bush himself had told him ``he appreciated it,'' which he took as an endorsement. At a news conference, Dole proposed a 5 percent cut in U.S. aid to all countries now protected by congressional ``earmarks,'' the largest of wich are Israel, Egypt, Pakistan, Turkey, the Philippines, El Salvador, Greece and Honduras. That would free about $400 million to help encourage fledgling democracies, he said. ``Some of these countries have to realize there are fewer tensions in the world, and maybe some of their demands can be reduced ... because we have new players'' in the foreign aid field, Dole said. Dole said he already had received a call from the American-Israel Public Affairs Committee expressing alarm about the proposal. The group issued a statement calling for new aid to emerging democracies but adding, ``We believe it should not be at the expense of other vital U.S. foreign policy objectives. We must try not to hurt some allies in the process of helping other allies.'' ``Nobody will like it,'' Dole said. ``But it seems to me fair and across the board.'' Of Israel, he added: ``We have limits. Israel has gotten a lot of preferential treatment.'' The Israeli Embassy in Washington issued a statement agreeing that historic change was occurring in Eastern Europe, but noting ``the winds of change have failed to reach the Middle East, and the dangers Israel faces have even increased.'' ``Cutting military assistance to Israel at this delicate stage of the peace process will send a negative message,'' the statement said. ``Cutting economic assistance at a time Israel gears itself towards the absorption of hundreds of thousands of Jewish immigrants would make it almost impossible to meet this challenge.'' Tutwiler said further talks with congressional leaders on the proposal would be scheduled soon. But she carefully couched the administration's position as one of support for increased flexibility in doling out U.S. foreign aid dollars, and not an intent to cut any specific country's current quota. One early reaction came from Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, who suggested the money instead come from cuts in the defense budget, foreshadowing a major battle that will occupy Congress when it convenes its 1990 session next week. And Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., contended ``the United States has gotten more out of the assistance it has directed to Israel than any other foreign aid program it conducts. Israel has long been America's most dependable ally.'' Of this year's $14.6 billion foreign aid program, 92 percent has been earmarked by Congress for specific recipients, leaving just $1.2 billion for the administration to spread thinly among dozens of friendly, needy nations. As many as a dozen friendly countries will get nothing this year because of lack of money. Israel, at $3 billion, is the top recipient of U.S. aid for several reasons: strategic importance as an ally in the Middle East, participation in the Camp David peace process with Egypt, and the political clout of American Jews. The second-largest recipient is Egypt, which will get $2.1 billion this year _ also largely because of the Camp David accord. Turkey, a NATO ally, is to get $610 million. Pakistan, which has played a key role in supplying arms to the U.S.-backed mujaheddin rebels in Afghanistan, will receive $490 million; and the Philippines, where the United States has important military bases and wants to support a struggling democracy, will get $360 million.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Woman Attacked by Son's Pit Bulls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Two pit bulls mauled a 70-year-old woman, gnawing the flesh off her arms Tuesday in a bloody 30-minute attack at her grandson's home, and one of the limbs was amputated, officials said. ``She has puncture wounds on most of her torso and all the flesh had been eaten off both arms from the wrist to the shoulder,'' said police Lt. Alan Kerstein. Marjee Lilly of San Diego was in very critical condition at County-USC Medical Center. Surgeons amputated her left arm and worked on her right arm in six hours of surgery, said hospital spokeswoman Adelaida De La Cerda. ``Both her arms had been chewed to the bone. She is very critical,'' De La Cerda said. Mrs. Lilly was visiting her 34-year-old grandson, Clarence Hubbard, at his Los Angeles home, and knew the 14-month-old pit bulls, which weighed 45 to 50 pounds, said Kerstein. ``She got along well with the dogs,'' he said. Hubbard left for work early Tuesday, leaving his grandmother alone in the home. He returned at 9:50 a.m. to check up on her, the lieutenant said. ``Upon entering the house, he saw his grandmother on the kitchen floor, severely mauled,'' Kerstein said. ``Both dogs were sitting close by in the corner of the room.'' Mrs. Lilly, who was conscious, told officers the dogs attacked while she was getting food for them. The woman, who is only 4 feet, 11 inches tall and weighs 130 pounds, was no match for the frenzied animals. ``As Mrs. Lilly was attempting to feed the dogs, she was taking food out of a large 25-pound bag and the dogs became excited,'' Kerstein said. ``She apparently attempted to push them away or restrain them and they attacked. ``She told paramedics the attack lasted about 30 minutes.'' The dogs kept biting and chewing on the woman and didn't back off until they heard Hubbard entering the home. ``They were restrained just by his presence,'' Kerstein said. The dogs were taken to the city animal shelter. ``The grandson has indicated he wants them destroyed,'' Kerstein said. ``He is in shock.''

DOC.HEAD: Colonel, Soldiers Brought Before Judge in Massacre Case
DOC.TEXT: The army officers and soldiers accused of murdering six Jesuit priests made their first appearance in court, and President Alfredo Cristiani said he believed almost everyone involved in the crime was in custody. Neither Judge Ricardo Zamora nor Col. Guillermo Benavides, the highest ranking military officer to be accused of a human rights crime in a decade of civil war, had any comment after the closed proceedings Tuesday. The appearance in the 4th Penal Court was a preliminary procedure that gave the defendants a chance to tell the judge their side of the story. Cristiani, who named the suspects publicly Saturday, said he hoped the proceedings would clear up the crime. ``We have come down to the bottom of this and we hope that through the interrogation process in the judicial aspect ... that even more information might come out and ...that everybody involved will be held responsible and punished by the law,'' he told NBC-TV's ``Today'' show. He said he believes ``almost all'' of those involved in the crime are in custody. Zamora has until Friday to decide whether the evidence is sufficient to charge the eight suspects and order them held for trial in the Nov. 16 slaying of the six priests, their housekeeper and her 15-year-old daughter. Benavides, who wore a dress uniform to court, and the three lieutenants, two sergeants, corporal and soldier who faced the court were returned after dark to the military and police garrisons near the capital where they are being held. A ninth soldier who allegedly took part in the slayings deserted last month and is a fugitive. Cristiani told ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America'' that Benavides denies ordering the slayings, ``but the junior officers involved expressly have testified that they received a direct order from him.'' Benavides is director of the Military College and the others are members of the elite Atlacatl infantry battalion, which was attached to the college at the time of the massacre. Even though the killings of thousands of suspected leftists by death squads in the early 1980s have been either linked to or tolerated by the military, no officer has ever been convicted of a human rights crime. The Jesuit massacre, which took place on the fifth day of the biggest rebel offensive of the war and wiped out the leadership of the highly regarded Central American University, is a test for Cristiani's rightist government. The murders prompted an international outcry and calls in Congress for a reappraisal of the more than $1 million a day in aid sent to El Salvador. They also focused attention on the Salvadoran justice system, which U.S. Ambassador William Walker has publicly said ``doesn't work.'' Cristiani, whose government greatly depends on the U.S. aid, has presented himself as the face of a new, more moderate right in El Salvador. But extreme elements of his party and others in the far right have long regarded the Central American University Jesuits as subversives because of their belief that the civil war was the result of gross social injustice rather than international communist expansion, and their insistence on dialogue rather than military force as the path to peace.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Man Takes Control of Airliner in Austin
DOC.TEXT: A man who claimed he had a bomb took control of a jetliner at an airport late Tuesday and demanded to be flown to Cuba, but was quickly arrested, police said. No one was injured in the incident at the Robert Mueller Municipal Airport, said police spokesman Harold Elmore. Police dispatchers received a report of a bomb threat at the airport at 11:28 p.m., Elmore said. Police did not know what airline the plane belonged to.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush: `A Nice, Fat Grandmother'
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush says the secret to her popularity is that she's ``just a nice, fat grandmother'' who doesn't threaten anyone. Asked why the American people give her favorability ratings that surpass even her husband's high poll numbers, Mrs. Bush said Tuesday, ``I don't know. Maybe they think I like them.'' Does she? ``Darn near'' everybody, she said. ``I don't like racists. I don't like greedy people. I don't like hate. I like people to be positive. I like people to help each other,'' she told three reporters. People like her, Mrs. Bush said, because, ``I don't have to do anything except just be there. I don't threaten anyone. I'm just a nice, fat grandmother.'' In an interview reflecting on her first year in the White House, Mrs. Bush said she is still plagued by the double vision and irritated eyes resulting from Graves disease, an immune system disorder. She said she is ``cautiously optimistic'' that the recent radiation treatments she underwent will improve the double vision. It is particularly severe in the morning, she said. She can read, but sees double when looking up. Her eyes on Tuesday looked slightly teary, but not as puffy as in some recent days. But Mrs. Bush said her health problems ranked about 20th on the list of things on her mind over the past year, including her family, her dog's six puppies, and the fun she had with Christmas at the White House. ``If you think of others and you keep busy you really are better off in life,'' she said. Mrs. Bush said she has been surprised at how much she likes being first lady. Although security concerns prevent her from walking her dog out on the street when she feels like it, or going for a drive, she called those restrictions minor compared to the luxuries. ``Ask me how many times I have to wait at the doctor, or ask me how many times I have to hassle at the airport, or try to find a cab ... or wait for the plumber. Ask me how many times I have to stand in the grocery line. ... Everything wonderful happens to me ... I don't have any hassles.'' On other matters, the first lady disclosed: _A new mattress for the bed in the Lincoln bedroom was purchased by Bush's brothers and sister because the old one was too soft. ``They said if we're going to have to sleep here we want a better mattress, so they bought a better mattress.'' _She doesn't have a favorite former first lady, but is ``grateful to every one of them _ the Fords for their pool, the Trumans for their balcony, Pat Nixon for the beauty parlor.''' Nancy Reagan, she said, ``really saved me a lot of repair,'' by making sure the plumbing works and overhauling some of the older rooms. _She would prefer that the upcoming drug summit Bush will attend in violence-ridden Colombia be held elsewhere, although she is confident security precautions will keep him safe. ``I wish it would be right here'' _ but ``I can't change his mind or make those decisions ... I have no input on that.'' Mrs. Bush, who typically declines to comment on policy issues, was asked if women should be allowed in combat as they were in Panama recently. ``If I thought a woman physically could pick up someone who was wounded and carry them to safety, if I thought they could throw a hand grenade as far as a man, then I would say fine. Because I think certainly emotionally and mentally they are more than able to compete with a man,'' she said. ``They can shoot as well. They can fly as well.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Helen Hayes stood on a sidewalk in the theater district and picked a spot for her plaque in a ``Broadway Walk of Stars.'' ``I think stage center is where I'd like it,'' the 89-year-old actress said after looking up at an overhang to determine the center in front of a new Holiday Inn being dedicated in April. The first plaque pictures a Tony Award and includes Ms. Hayes' name; her category, best actress; the play, ``Happy Birthday;'' and the year, 1947, the first year of Tony Awards. Other plaques will be placed on sidewalks throughout the theater district, rather than in a continuous line like the Hollywood Walk of Fame, said Meredith Pillon, a Holiday Inn spokeswoman. Pillon said Tuesday the League of American Theatres and Producers, the American Theatre Wing, the Broadway Association and Holiday Inn were hoping to begin the project with about 200 plaques.

Producer Albert ``Cubby'' Broccoli, who has made 16 James Bond movies, was immortalized in concrete with a sidewalk star in the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Despite rain, about 200 fans joined actresses Britt Eklund and Maude Adams for Tuesday's unveiling of the star, number 1,907 in the walkway spanning Hollywood Boulevard and Vine Street. The 80-year-old Broccoli also celebrated another event Tuesday. It was the 28th anniversary of the start of principal photogrphy on the first James Bond adventure, ``Dr. No,'' starring Sean Connery and Ursula Andress.

Singer Stevie Wonder says the civil rights movement progressed slower than he had expected. ``We are with only nine years left in this century, and to be perfectly honest with you, I thought we would have it together by now. I guess that comes from dreaming faster than we can have reality,'' the 40-year-old musician said Tuesday at a birthday tribute to the late Martin Luther King Jr. Wonder also spoke out against drug abuse. ``In 1990, we are living among the most brutal slaveowner of our lives and non-caring of all times, and that is drugs,'' he told the audience at Johns Hopkins University.

Actor Paul Sorvino is turning again to singing, but the acclaimed opera singer says he knows better than to try to soothe the savage beast of gamblers with an aria. ``I think people who are losing $20,000 are not going to want to hear it,'' he said. Instead, Sorvino will be belting out Broadway tunes, a few Neopolitan songs and some standards this weekend at the Showboat Hotel & Casino. His singing work in the past has been sporadic. He recorded the cast album to the Broadway shows ``Carmelina'' and ``The Bakers Wife,'' 13 years ago and gave a concert at New York City's Town Hall in the mid-1980s. His acting roles include the bigoted Southern cop in the television mini-series ``Chiefs.'' He plays gangster Lips Manlis in the Warren Beatty film ``Dick Tracy,'' which is due for release in a few months; a Mafia don opposite Robert DeNiro in Martin Scorcese's ``Good Fellas''; and a renegade CIA agent in ``DMZ.''

A ninth grader is preparing for her role in the latest episode of Sylvester Stallone's ``Rocky V,'' which is being filmed in Rocky Balboa's hometown of Philadelphia. Elisebeth Fenstermaker, 12, who changes her last name to Peters when she's acting, will play a friend of Rocky's son, Rocky Jr. Elisebeth, a freshman at William Allen High School, was on the West Coast on Tuesday preparing for the role. She has appeared in ``She-Devil'' with Roseanne Barr and Meryl Streep and has had parts in television commercials. Assistant principal Dennis Springer said Tuesday the school was helping Elisebeth with tutoring while she's away. ``We'll supply her books and materials and her grades will be incorporated into her grades here,'' he said. Grades shouldn't be a problem for the young actress, who had straight A's this past term, Springer said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The following item may be offensive to readers; a version
DOC.TEXT: moved on sports wires.

A Chinese-American group is calling on Denver Broncos owner Pat Bowlen to apologize for using the term ``Chinaman.'' Chinese for Affirmative Action of San Francisco said Tuesday it had asked NFL commissioner Paul Tagliabue to fine Bowlen for his ``racist comment.'' On Monday, Bowlen, whose team faces the 49ers in the Super Bowl, offered a tongue-in-cheek assessment of the San Francisco. ``Those guys have got a great owner,'' Bowlen said. ``They've got God for a quarterback. They've got a Chinaman who plays wide receiver whose feet never touch the ground.'' Bowlen, when asked what he meant, said ```That Chinese guy. What's his name? Rice?'' referring to Jerry Rice.
