Broncos spokesman Jim Saccomano said Bowlen ``was just speaking facetiously'' about Rice, who is black. ``He was trying to be funny,'' Saccomano said. But Chinese for Affirmative Action said the term ``Chinaman'' was ``an extremely derogatory term'' to the Asian community.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Nike Inc. is making some changes in a commercial set to run during the Super Bowl. Company officials said they agreed to remove NBC's Marv Albert and Dick Enberg and Al Michaels of ABC from the commercial ``The Announcers'' because of pressure from CBS, which doesn't want rival announcers on the air during its telecast. Nike said Monday the shoe company would tape three more announcers for the spot. ``We are a major advertiser and we don't want to be in an adversarial relationship with a major network,'' said Tom Clarke, Nike's vice president and director of marketing. Sandy Genelius, a spokeswoman for CBS, said the network would make no comment on the matter.

DOC.HEAD: Government Wants Better Count of Workers Infected With Aids on Job
DOC.TEXT: Government officials say they don't know how many health care workers become infected with the AIDS virus on the job, but they are sure it's higher than the 19 reported U.S. cases. An official at the federal Centers for Disease Control said Tuesday his agency is working to expand reporting and come up with more accurate data. But critics say putting out figures that are admittedly too low ``trivializes'' the risk and lulls workers into complacency. ``If the risk is downplayed, then the it-can't-happen-to-me attitude will tend to prevail,'' said Hacib Aoun, a Baltimore physician who contracted AIDS after he cut his finger on a tube filled with infected blood in 1983. David Bell, chief of AIDS activity in the hospital infections program at CDC in Atlanta, said the agency isn't minimizing the risk of occupational exposure to the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which can occur if a worker is pricked with a contaminated needle or is splashed with blood from an infected patient. Bell said all surveillance systems, including the one tracking health care workers who become infected with HIV, are prone to underreporting. ``The number of health care workers with HIV infection, including occupationally acquired HIV, exceeds that which has been reported to us. We all know that,'' Bell said. However, he said, public health officials don't know how many health care workers have been infected in the course of their work. The CDC reports 27 cases of occupationally acquired HIV infection by health care workers worldwide, 19 of them in the United States. The agency is also investigating 34 other cases, he said. Larry Gostin, executive director of the Boston-based American Society of Law and Medicine, said the actual number of cases in which health care workers are infected on the job could be up to five times the CDC's official count. A study has determined the risk that a health care worker will become infected with HIV after being pricked with a contaminated needle is 1 in 250, Bell said. Gostin said: ``I don't want health care workers to be unduly alarmed by the risks. I think the risks are small. But they have a right and society has a right to have the numbers be as truthful as possible. ``That way, a clearer calculation can be made about the risk ... and there's more incentive to see that the risk is real and that its necessary to use precautions,'' he said. Aoun, who said his case has not yet been included in CDC's official count, said he believes underreporting is a form of ``panic control'' that ultimately will subject workers to greater risks through complacency. ``The information they provide is used to formulate policy'' to improve protections for workers and to improve benefits for workers infected on the job, he said. ``If the number is trivialized, these changes that are needed will be slow in coming.'' Aoun, who settled with Johns Hopkins Hospital in 1987, said workers need better protections against HIV infection and better benefits if they do become infected on the job. Several other lawsuits filed by health care workers claiming to have been infected on the job have been settled, and several are pending. The current suit by New York physician Veronica Prego is the first to go to trial. Sometimes workers don't report a needlestick or other possible accidental exposure, and in three quarters of the cases that are reported and HIV infection is positive, subsequent investigations turn up other risk factors, including sexual behavior and intravenous drug use, Bell said. Bell said that in the CDC's expanded reporting system, reports will be categorized according to how clear they are that infection occurred in the workplace. The center published voluntary guidelines in 1982 for hospitals and other medical institutions to follow to protect workers against HIV infection. The Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration has proposed regulations that would require hospitals to institute specific safeguards.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Long Distance Outage: Could it Happen Elsewhere?
With PM-Phone Trouble
DOC.TEXT: Officials at MCI Communications Corp. say it couldn't happen to them. US Sprint says it could happen to anybody. A day after long-distance service crashed for millions of AT&T customers, AT&T's two biggest long-distance competitors disagreed on Tuesday about whether they could suffer a similar massive computer glitch. MCI, the nation's second-largest telecommunications company, and No. 3 US Sprint use the same Signaling System 7 technology that apparently caused problems for the American Telephone and Telegraph Co. In Washington, MCI Executive Vice President Richard Liebhaber said after a top-to-bottom check of the company's equipment, ``We don't see any potential points of failure.'' But a spokeswoman for Kansas City, Mo.-based US Sprint, Terri Dunn, said, ``Essentially, it could happen to anybody.'' AT&T carries about 70 percent of the nation's long-distance calls; MCI handles about 12 percent; US Sprint has about 8 percent. Neither of the smaller companies experienced long distance outages Monday. ``I hate like hell to see it. I really feel sorry for these guys,'' said MCI's Liebhaber, noting the long-distance disturbance ``has an impact on American industry and an impact on everybody's customers.'' Signaling System 7 is a so-called common channel signal system that ``makes your network smarter and improves the calling process,'' said Dunn. The system allows equipment to see if a circuit or a phone number is busy before putting a call through and tying up a circuit. AT&T said Tuesday it traced the trouble to a bug, or ``logic'' problem, in the AT&T-designed software that runs its signalling system. It said the bug was written into the software originally and was an accident waiting to happen. Ms. Dunn said US Sprint has had the system since November 1987 and ``we have not experienced an outage such as this.'' But she said US Sprint ``is constantly checking our software and centrally monitoring of the network.'' Liebhaber said that although their technology is similar to AT&T's, the equipment is different. ``They have manufactured their own system,'' he said of AT&T. ``I don't use stuff supplied by AT&T. Our equipment is manufactured by Digital Switch and combined with our own software.'' Both MCI and US Sprint said AT&T customers could use their long-distance services by dialing the access codes of either 10333 for Sprint or 10222 for MCI. Callers will be billed through their local phone company bill.

DOC.HEAD: Aunt Bee's Home Belied Her TV Housekeeper Image
DOC.TEXT: The actress who portrayed housekeeper Aunt Bee on ``The Andy Griffith Show'' lived her last years in seclusion in a dark, dingy house and kept a 1966 green Studebaker with four flat tires in the garage. The home of Frances Bavier reflects little of the coziness of the fictional house that Aunt Bee managed for Mayberry's sheriff and his young son on the popular television series of the 1960s. The 86-year-old Miss Bavier died Dec. 6 in the spacious two-story Siler City home to which she retired in 1972. She rarely left the house, town residents say. ``She strikes me as living a sparse life in her latter years, a very quiet life,'' said Diana Hatch, communications director for University of North Carolina Center for Public Television. Of an estimated $700,000 estate, Miss Bavier left the house to a hospital foundation and its antiquated contents to the public television network. An appraisal put the value of Miss Bavier's belongings at $31,683, excluding the Studebaker, last driven in 1983 on a trip to a grocery store. The stench from the actress' 14 cats coupled with peeling plaster, frayed carpets and worn upholstery indicate Miss Bavier either was unable or unwilling to spend much time keeping up the home. Her cats evidently used a basement room and a shower stall as a litter box. Evidently, the reclusive actress spent most of her time in a large back room plainly furnished with a bed, a desk, a television and an end table, where she kept her reading and opera glasses, black licorice and a bell. ``I think she was a person who obviously valued her privacy. She ... could have had non-stop fans if she had opened her doors,'' said Ms. Hatch. Two trunks held her fan mail, letters in one and studio portraits of her ``to be signed'' in another. Miss Bavier's few costly possessions consisted primarily of some rare leather-bound books, a lace collection and a considerable quantity of table linens, said Ms. Hatch. The few mementos of the actress' television days were the dress and hats she wore in the show and a few publicity pictures. There also was a blue satin gown she may have worn when she won her Emmy Award, said Ms. Hatch. Just as the neat, matronly Aunt Bee would have done, Miss Bavier saved sewing fabric in labeled boxes in a bedroom closet. But what she made with the material was not evident in the house, which had no curtains at windows. The walls were mostly bare except for a few ordinary electric wall clocks. And while Aunt Bee was known around the ficticious Mayberry, N.C., courthouse for her tasty box lunches, there was only one cookbook in Miss Bavier's yellow and green 1950s kitchen. The belongings will be auctioned this spring, said Bob Royster, production director for the public television center.

DOC.HEAD: Three Lockheed Employees Detained in Chad
DOC.TEXT: Three Lockheed Aircraft Corp. workers in Chad have been detained in what the company Tuesday called a ``misunderstanding'' with that country's government, but a relative of one of the men described them as hostages. The three work for the Lockheed Aeronautical System-Georgia subsidiary, and are in the African country as part of a sale of C-130 Hercules airplanes built in Marietta, Ga., to the government there, said company spokesman Dick Martin. Lockheed agreed to set up an office in Chad for one year after the sale so the technicians could help maintain the planes and explain their use, Martin said. The year ended in December, and as the men packed up they destroyed some documents, including manuals on the planes. Martin said Chad's government felt the documents belonged to them, while Lockheed maintains they were company property. Martin said officials of Chad revoked the workers' passports, but said they were allowed free movement in the Marriott Hotel in the capital of N'Djamena and the surrounding area. Barbara Porter, whose brother, Irving Thrash, is one of the workers, said she learned of the matter when she telephoned her sister-in-law in Chad on Tuesday night. The sister-in-law said the Americans had been taken hostage Jan. 5, Mrs. Porter said. Mrs. Porter said Lockheed never alerted her about the matter. Martin said Lockheed immediately notified relatives and the State Department. Lockheed employees immediately flew to Chad to negotiate with officials, and copies of the destroyed documents will be sent to Chad, he said. The Lockheed spokesman said the matter ``has not been a life-threatening situation for anyone.'' Mrs. Porter said she believed Chad is ``afraid their planes are sabotaged.'' Her sister-in-law, Gail Thrash, told her she was ``starving'' and didn't know where her husband was, Mrs. Porter said. One of the other workers also brought his wife to Chad. Martin said he did not have the names of the other two workers. Mrs. Porter said she spoke with her sister-in-law by telephone Tuesday night. ``She said the phones were being monitored. She said call my Aunt Chris Curle and Uncle Paul Reynolds and mentioned the name Terry Waite, meaning she was held captive,'' Mrs. Porter said. Waite, an Anglican church envoy, is among the Westerners believed held hostage in Lebanon. Ms. Curle and Reynolds are Atlanta television reporters. Mrs. Porter took her sister-in-law's mention of their names to be a signal to call news media. On Tuesday, Mrs. Porter telephoned WAGA-TV, which reported the men had been detained. An employee at the Marriott in N'Djamena said the Lockheed employees ``were out'' when an Associated Press reporter telephoned the hotel late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks End Up Lower, Dollar Inches Down
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange gained in early trading but ended up lower Wednesday, while the dollar inched down against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 145.52 yen, down 0.23 yen from Tuesday's 145.75-yen finish. It opened at 145.40 yen and ranged between 145.37 yen and 145.55 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 29.22 points, or 0.08 percent, ending the day at 36,821.14. On each of the previous two trading days, it had fallen more than 650 points. In Wednesday morning trading, it climbed 360.66 points, responding favorably to a 23.25-point overnight gain in the Dow Jones industrial average in New York. But then it quickly fell back as the government bond price fell further following a rumor that Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev had resigned, dealers said. The index had shed 666.41 points Tuesday, the largest single-day loss since Nov. 10, 1987, when it fell 731.91 points. A slump on the Tokyo stock market in recent weeks has been caused partly by falling Japanese government bond prices. Traders said trading was generally calm, with many market players taking a wait-and-see position ahead of the release of U.S. merchandise trade figures for November, expected later Wednesday in Washington. Some economists predict the U.S. November trade deficit will narrow to $9.4 billion from $10.2 billion in October.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Art Forger to Donate Fakes to Gallery
DOC.TEXT: A judge sentenced an art forger to 10 months in prison and ordered him to donate four fake 19th century paintings to a gallery so that others could study his illegal craft. Robert L. Trotter of Kennett Square, Pa., pleaded guilty in August to one count of wire fraud for using the telephone to sell forgeries. Prosecutors said Trotter passed off 55 works he had painted as 19th century paintings by forging signatures and treating old canvasses with chemicals to make the paint crack. The paintings also were placed in old frames. They were sold in 11 states. U.S. District Judge Alan H. Nevas on Tuesday sentenced Trotter to 10 months in prison, ordered him to pay nearly $70,000 in restitution and to donate four of the fake paintings to the Yale University Art Gallery for permanent exhibition and study of the art of forgery. The FBI began an investigation in May after receiving a tip from the owners of a gallery who realized a 19th century painting they had bought from Trotter was a fake. Eugene and Mary Anne Shannon stopped payment on their $25,000 check to Trotter after consulting with another dealer and confirming the painting was not an authentic work of John Haberle, a 19th-century New Haven artist. Authorities said Trotter sold the forgeries to auction houses and art dealers in Connecticut, Massachusetts, Maine, Maryland, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Vermont and Virginia. Nevas ordered Trotter to pay $68,400 in restitution to four people who purchased fakes between February 1985 and May 1989. He also ordered Trotter to undergo psychiatric counseling, and told him to surrender by Feb. 6. Trotter's attorney, public defender Richard Reeve, did not immediately return a reporter's telephone call after Tuesday's sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force to Let Women Crew on Cargo Airdrops
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force is lifting restrictions that kept women from being crew members on cargo airdrop missions. Capt. George Sillia said Tuesday that women now may serve as pilots, co-pilots, loadmasters, flight engineers or crew chiefs on C-130 or C-141 transport planes. The spokesman said the decision will affect about 100 women among its 4,800 pilots and a like number of women among enlisted crew members. Previously, women crew members were allowed to fly on C-141 aircraft to a specific location, unload the cargo and return. However, women had not been allowed to be crew members on the C-130, except the WC-130, a weather reconnaissance plane. The decision was made Dec. 14, six days before the U.S. invasion of Panama during which Army women were reported to have taken part in combat, Sillia said. The intervention delayed the formal announcement. The command determined that airdrop missions don't fall under the Defense Department's February 1988 ``risk rule,'' which says a non-combat mission or unit can be closed to women if officials deem that the risks are equal to or greater than those of the combat mission they support.
DOC.HEAD: Court Moves Toward Computerized Opinions
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court is taking a major step into the computer age by agreeing to make its opinions quickly available via computer to The Associated Press and other members of a 24-member consortium that will provide the necessary equipment. The consortium's equipment will be used to disseminate the opinions to 10 to 15 media and legal organizations, which will then relay the information to others. A court committee overseeing the project said Tuesday it had accepted an offer from the Supreme Court Opinion Network, SCON, and soon will begin discussions to determine what kind of equipment is needed. SCON, a non-profit consortium, also includes as its members the American Bar Association, C-SPAN cable television network, Knight-Ridder, Mead Data, United Press International and The Washington Post. West Publishing Co., a major legal publisher, had made an offer similar to SCON's. The Associated Press, which was among the 14 originally submitting proposals, intends to receive the opinions electronically and make them available to its membership. The details of the AP plan have not been made final, pending further description of the court's system. The court will choose 10 to 15 middleman ``subscribers'' that, for a $500 annual fee, will receive opinions electronically minutes after they are announced and distribute them. The court describes these middlemen as ``mass disseminators'' of information. The court committee said subscribers will be ``those 10 to 15 organizations the court determines can best provide opinions to the broadest possible audience.''
DOC.HEAD: Defense Department Delays Drug Plan
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department is holding off on announcement of a White House-approved plan to involve U.S. military forces more deeply in the international war on drugs. ``Some of the aspects of that have been put off for a while following discussions with (Colombian) President Barco,'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams told reporters Tuesday as he announced that the department will not hold a news conference this week on the drug plan as planned. Williams said he expected an announcement on the drug plan after the department releases its budget for fiscal 1991 on Jan. 29. He said he was unsure whether it would be announced before President Bush goes to Colombia in February for an anti-drug summit of the leaders of Andean nations. Under the reported anti-drug effort, the Navy was to operate an aircraft carrier battle group off the Caribbean coast of Colombia on a rotating basis. Pentagon officials have said the Navy would use high-tech radar and surveillance equipment to keep tabs on suspected drug dealers' boats and planes. Peru, Colombia and Bolivia have said they oppose the use of U.S. military to police international waters.

DOC.HEAD: Man Takes Control of Airliner, Demands to be Flown to Cuba
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with description of arrest, CLARIFY sequence of events, other details, DELETE redundant 4th graf, `said police ...'; picks up penultimate graf, `Sage said ...'
DOC.TEXT: A man claiming he had a bomb took over an America West airliner late Tuesday and demanded to be flown to Cuba, but was arrested soon after the plane made an emergency landing in Austin, police said. No one was seriously injured during Flight 727 from Houston to Las Vegas, with 34 passengers and five crew members aboard, or the arrest at Robert Mueller Municipal Airport, officials said. SWAT team members overpowered the man aboard the plane, officials said. FBI agent Byron Sage identifed the man as Jose Manuel Gonzales-Gonzales, 39, and said he was believed to be from New Orleans. Gonzales-Gonzales was believed to be of Cuban descent. The flight was diverted to Austin and landed shortly before 11:30 p.m. after trouble was reported aboard, America West spokeswoman Kathy Christensen said in Phoenix, where the airline is based. ``The man said he had a bomb and had some electronic device that blinked when he pointed to the front of the aircraft,'' said passenger Herb Atwood of Cold Spring, Texas. ``He grabbed one of the stewardesses and had something around her neck,'' Atwood said in an interview with radio station KVET. ``He was shouting orders. He said he wanted them to fly to Cuba, but the pilot said that we did not have enough fuel.'' The man ordered all the passengers to move to the front of the aircraft, Atwood said. Austin police received a report of a bomb threat at 11:28 p.m., said police spokesman Harold Elmore. After the plane landed, nearly 40 police officers, including hostage negotiators, surrounded the aircraft shortly before midnight. Police Capt. Loyd Polk said he climbed up an escape hatch into the aircraft, then subdued Gonzales-Gonzales. ``I saw he had the stewardess, so I took action immediately,'' Polk said. ``I had a struggle with him, but I was able to hold him to the ground until more help arrived.'' Passengers evacuated the plane, and police began searching the airplane for a bomb. ``We doubt there was a bomb aboard the plane,'' Elmore said. Gonzales-Gonzales was taken to a hospital early Wednesday for treatment of cuts to his head suffered when he was arrested, said city emergency services shift commander Bob Gutierrez. The stewardess who was grabbed was also taken to a hospital for minor cuts and burns when coffee spilled on her, Gutierrez said. Several passengers were treated at the airport for minor injuries suffered when they evacuated the aircraft. Elmore said passengers were taken to an airport terminal for questioning. City aviation director Charles Gates said the passengers would be put up in a hotel for the night and flown out Wednesday morning. Sage said authorities intended to charge the man with air piracy and kidnapping. ``You always hear about this,'' passenger Atwood said, ``and I never thought it would happen to me. I was scared like everyone else. I was looking forward to a trip to Vegas. But my gambling ended before it started.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Backs Gorbachev's Use of Troops
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs lead to CORRECT spelling of Azerbaijanis and style for the Caucasus; 4th graf, ``At the heart xxx to CORRECT spelling of Nagorno-Karabakh and Azerbaijan; and 10th graf, ``In Moscow xxx to CORRECT spelling of Yanchenkov and fix attribution
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration supports Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's use of troops to try to restore order in the southern Caucasus and is criticizing feuding Azerbaijanis and Armenians for ``revisiting old ethnic hatreds.'' Without offering a judgment on the territorial dispute between the two groups, State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said Tuesday, ``It's time for the violence to stop and any grievances to be settled peacefully.'' At least 56 people have been killed and 156 injured in the strife in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan since Thursday. Gorbachev on Monday signed a sweeping emergency decree after intense anti-Armenian riots in Baku, the regional capital. At the heart of the fighting are conflicting claims to Nagorno-Karabakh, a predominantly Armenian area within Ajerbaijan. In response to questions, Ms. Tutwiler said the Bush administration supports ``the self-determination of people.'' But she gave no hint of backing either side's claims. As Gorbachev and the Presidum of the Soviet Parliament struggled with the violence in the Caucasus, the State Department and the White House stressed Moscow's authority to restore order. ``The distinction here is not people pressing for peaceful political change, participation, expression.'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``They are instead revisiting old ethnic hatreds.'' Describing the situation as ``a very difficult one,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said: ``We have seen ethnic tensions there for many, many years. And we certainly regret the violence that is taking place now. We understand the need to establish order in a situation where order has broken down.'' Also, Fitzwater said: ``We recognize the right of any state to ensure the safety of its citizens, and it looks like that's the primary concern at the moment.'' In Moscow, spokesman Vladimir A. Yanchenkov of the Soviet Interior Ministry confirmed media accounts that KGB security forces and army had been deployed in the region. He referred to some of the violence as ``pogroms,'' or massacres. At the State Department, spokeswoman Tutwiler said the United States regretted the violence and urged Armenians and Azerbaijanis to refrain. ``These are age-old ethnic tensions,'' she said. ``Unfortunately, the level of violence has escalated dramatically over the last several days. It's time for the violence to stop, and any grievances settled peacefully.'' The statement concluded: ``We don't encourage the use of force anywhere, and we would hope it is unnecessary. But we recognize the need to establish order where people are killing each other.'' On another subject, the State Department said Gorbachev ``may have opened the door a bit to the possibility of a multi-party system'' in the Soviet Union. ``But he is by no means calling for its establishment,'' Ms. Tutwiler said in a statement. This referred to remarks by the Soviet leader during a visit last week to Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania. There he urged rebellious Lithuanians to remain in the Soviet Union and said his fate and that of his economic reconstruction program depended on the outcome. ``We should not be afraid of a multi-party system if it serves the people,'' Gorbachev said. The State Department also registered its approval of a decision by the East German government to drop its plan for reviving a state security organization. It reflected ``the clearly expressed wishes of the East German population,'' a statement read by Ms. Tutwiler said. On another front, the State Department supported Czechoslovakia in calling for the removal of Soviet troops from the country. But the statement read by Ms. Tutwiler stressed the only way to verify a pullout is through a treaty now in negotiation in Vienna between NATO and the Warsaw Pact. It would reduce U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe and impose strict limits on how many foreign forces could be stationed in any country.

DOC.HEAD: Walter Judd Renews Praise of Chiang Kai-shek, Chiang Ching-kuo
DOC.TEXT: With the recent collapse of East European communist governments, the late Chinese Nationalists Sun Yat-sen, Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo stand out as giants of history, says Walter H. Judd in a rare appearance for the aging former missionary and congressman. The three leaders of the Nationalist Republic of China ``are giants today'' while communist leaders from Marx to Lenin to Brezhnev to Deng Xiaoping to Gorbachev are increasingly discredited, the aging Minnesota Republican said Tuesday. Judd, 91, was famous as a leader of the old ``China Lobby,'' a group of influential Americans credited with delaying U.S. recognition of the Chinese communist government for nearly a quarter of a century after its 1949 takeover in Beijing. Judd, a medical missionary in China for a decade who later served 20 years in the House, made a rare public appearance at the launching of ``Chiang Ching-kuo Remembered: The Man and his Political Legacy,'' a book about the Nationalist president who died in 1988. It was written by Ray Cline, Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Taiwan from 1958 to 1963 and later a CIA spokesman in Washington. Now retired from government, Cline heads the U.S. Global Strategy Council, a conservative research organization. Chiang Ching-kuo was the son of Chiang Kai-shek, the generalissimo who led the Nationalist' retreat to offshore Taiwan in 1949. Sun Yat-sen headed the revolutionaries who overthrew the Manchu dynasty and formed the first Chinese republic in 1912. Cline, who knew Chiang Ching-kuo for 30 years, and other speakers, credited the late president with laying the groundwork for current democratic reforms in Taiwan and for the island's spectacular economic growth. When the United States switched diplomatic relations from Taiwan to Beijing in 1979, President Chiang Ching-kuo overruled advice to turn his back on America and democracy, ``swallowing blood on his teeth,'' said veteran U.S. career diplomat David Dean, using a Chinese expression for turning the other cheek. Dean finished a tour last month as head of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, the organization maintaining nonofficial U.S. relations after derecognition. Taiwan is prepared to trade with and provide some economic aid to Poland and other newly-democratic countries of Eastern Europe, but they ``have to make the first move,'' said Stephen S.F. Chen, deputy chief of Taiwan's mission in Washington, known as the Coordination Council for North American Affairs. Taiwan law prohibits dealing with hostile countries, but such countries ``are no longer hostile,'' Chen noted. A problem is that the consortium of donor nations for Eastern Europe aid is made up of governments that, like the United States, do not recognize Taiwan and do not allow it to participate, he said. Cline said his book will be translated into Chinese by Taiwan's United Daily News group for publication in book form with excerpts in the Lian Ho Pao newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Quietly Starts Transmissions From $400 Million Communications System
DOC.TEXT: A 15-mile antenna strung out like a giant cross in the Chequamegon National Forest quietly sends radio messages to missile-equipped submarines patrolling deep waters around the world. The Navy began using the $400 million ELF system last fall, replacing smaller transmitters that had been sending messages to missile-equipped submarines since the late 1960s. The earlier project went through despite years of protests based on fears that the low-frequency radio waves would fry fish in nearby streams and produce two-headed squirrels. ``In the last two years, we have had only two protests of any significance. Those folks were strictly anti-military,'' said Lt. John Smythe, project commander. ``I think the biological, ecological and safety issues have all been addressed.'' At one point, demonstrations occurred almost weekly at the fenced-in transmitter site in northwestern Wisconsin. Nuclear-weapons opponents argued the system would make the forest a target for Soviet missiles and environmentalists called for more studies. ELF, or extremely low frequency, is the only system of its kind that sends radio waves that penetrate water. The system permits submarines to prowl undetected by radar while receiving messages several hundred feet under water. The antenna _ two strands of cable strung on wooden poles _ and a transmitter are tucked into the forest atop 20,000 feet of buried rock near Clam Lake, a quiet tourist wayside. Bears frequently climb on the poles and snowmobiles glide through a corridor carved in the trees. Jerry Holter and his wife, Tish, both 60, live about a mile from the antenna and have watched the project unfold since 1969. ``They brought in peace activists by the busloads,'' Holter recalled. ``You won't find anybody in the area that ever thought the project would do all the things opponents claimed, including make you sterile if you walked under the lines.'' Mrs. Holter served as a ``human guinea pig'' for researchers monitoring the medical effects of the system on nearby residents. ``We are both so darn healthy, it's funny,'' she said. But Mark Peterson, executive director of the Sigurd Olson Environmental Institute of Northland College in Ashland, said the project still has its skeptics. They point to studies that indicate milk production of cows that graze near high voltage electrical lines drops off, he said. The system _ and a companion one near K.I. Sawyer Air Force Base south of Marquette, Mich. _ use a total of $60,000 worth of electricity each month and employ about 75 people, mostly civilians, Smythe said. ELF is scaled down considerably from the original plan, which included a grid of 6,200 miles of buried cable and 100 transmitters built to survive a nuclear war. Independent researchers spent years studying possible environmental and ecological problems the giant antenna and its radio waves might cause, Smythe said. Scientists checked to see if sparrows laid the same number of eggs each spring. Offspring of birds and bees were measured and weighed. ``There have been no squirrels with two heads and six legs. We have not been able to detect any negative effects in the biological-ecological system,'' Smythe said. But monitoring of homes and other testing in the area will continue through 1991, Smythe said. Former Sen. Gaylord Nelson, D-Wis., raised the first environmental questions about the project in the late 1960s. ``I would say that they had resolved 90-plus percent of the concerns I had at the time, perhaps 98 or 99 percent,'' said Nelson, now an adviser with the Wilderness Society in Washington, an environmental group that specializes in public lands' issues. Holter, a wood carver, said ELF, which looks like a small radio station, is preferable to other alternatives. ``I think I feel more secure with that sitting in my backyard than tons of battleships.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Major Powers To Push U.N.-Administered Peace In Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council's permanent members _ the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France _ have agreed to move quickly to seek a cease-fire and free elections in Cambodia under U.N. administration. Officials of the five countries concluded two days of meetings Tuesday night by setting out a 16-point summary of principles, focused on ``an enhanced U.N. role'' in bringing peace to Cambodia. Representatives of the countries will meet again in New York in about two weeks, then again in late February in Paris to push the peace program ahead as quickly as possible. ``We're at least going to make a strong try at it,'' said a senior U.S. official, briefing reporters on condition of anonymity. ``We're not talking about a process that would take several years, but it's clear it will take several months.'' Much could depend on China, which arms and supplies the powerful Khmer Rouge resistance faction, and is being counted on to influence its clients to accept U.N.-supervised elections rather than seek military victory. The five countries said a special representative of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar would be in charge of United Nations activities in Cambodia during an unspecified transition period leading to elections. They called in a statement for ``an effective U.N. presence'' to assure internal security, apparently a reference to a peacekeeping force. Elections ``must be conducted under direct U.N. administration'' that would assure ``a neutral political environment in which no party would be advantaged,'' the statement said. ``An enduring peace can only be achieved through a comprehensive political settlement, including the verified withdrawal of foreign forces, a cease-fire and the cessation of outside military assistance,'' it said. ``The goal should be self-determination for the Cambodian people through free, fair and democratic elections.'' Points set out in the statement do not deal with some of the most difficult issues _ such as whether to dissolve Premier Hun Sen's Vietnamese-backed government, or what to do about Cambodia's United Nations seat, now held by the three-party guerrilla coalition led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The statement does not even refer directly to Hun Sen, Sihanouk or the Khmer Rouge, Cambodia's brutal masters for three years until the late 1978 Vietnamese invasion that ousted them. The Khmer Rouge are now allied with Sihanouk and another non-communist resistance group. It appeared to draw heavily from ideas floated by Australia and by U.S. Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., for expanding the United Nations role in Cambodia. Hun Sen's government and the three guerrilla factions have shown varying degrees of enthusiasm for the idea, but none has rejected it out of hand. Pressure to find a solution has grown with reports of stepped-up Khmer Rouge attacks in western Cambodia. Without large numbers of Vietnamese troops to help, it is not clear how well Hun Sen's forces will stand up to the guerrillas. A peace conference last summer in Paris foundered on disagreement over proposals for a temporary administration of all four Cambodian factions to run the country until elections chose new leaders. Hun Sen refused to consider letting the Khmer Rouge in. Sihanouk rejected any idea of keeping them out. The Khmer Rouge were responsible for killing hundreds of thousands of people while they were in power. The American official who spoke to reporters said Chinese participants in the meeting said they did not want to eliminate completely the proposal for a quadripartite administration but were willing to pursue the prospects for a greater U.N. role in running the country until elections are held. The statement issued by the permanent members Tuesday suggests a Supreme National Council ``might be the repository of Cambodian sovereignty during the transition process'' but does not say who might serve on such a council. Another point says ``questions involving Cambodian sovereignty should be resolved with the agreement of the Cambodian parties'' _ which seems to fall short of the effective veto power each of the four factions held at previous steps of the slow-moving peace talks in recent years. The United Nations also is asked to verify complete withdrawal of foreign forces from Cambodia. Vietnam announced in September that the last of its troops had left, but Sihanouk accused Vietnam of leaving disguised soldiers behind and intending to colonize the country.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Guard Capital After Main Opposition Figure Disqualified
DOC.TEXT: Armed troops guarded the capital today after the main opposition leader was disqualified as a candidate in May 27 elections, Burma's first multiparty vote in three decades, Western diplomats said. The decision to disqualify Aung San Suu Kyi was made late Tuesday by the military government's Election Commission, sources on the commission said. They said without elaborating that her candidacy for a seat in Parliament did not conform to the election law. Both the commission sources and the diplomats spoke on condition of anonymity. The diplomats, reached by telephone from Bangkok, said large numbers of troops who had entered Rangoon in trucks on Tuesday were guarding City Hall, where Election Commission has offices. They did not say exactly how many troops there were. A candidate in the Rangoon constituency of Bahan, Ms. Suu Kyi, 44, has been under house arrest since July 20. The government has accused her of subversion, but no formal charges have been filed. Ms. Suu Kyi is the daughter of the late Aung San, the widely revered leader of Burmese independence. She is the general secretary of the National League For Democracy, which is the largest and most popular opposition party. The co-leader of her party, Tin Oo, was sentenced last month to three years in prison on charges of subversion. Ms. Suu Kyi has strongly criticized alleged abuses by the military authorities. The military seized power after crushing a national pro-democracy uprising in September 1988, killing several thousand mostly unarmed protesters. The government has promised to relinquish power after a free and fair election, but Western diplomats say the arrests of thousands of opposition activists in recent months and harassment of politicians like Ms. Suu Kyi shed doubt on the election's potential fairness. Sources in Ms. Suu Kyi's party said it plans to appeal its candidate's disqualification to the Election Commission's central five-man body. The challenge to Ms. Suu Kyi's candidacy was raised by Labang Grong, a candidate for the the National Unity Party running in the same Rangoon constituency. The National Unity Party is the successor to the Burma Socialist Program Party, which ruled for 26 years and has close ties to the military government. Grong contended that Ms. Suu Kyi was not eligible because she was entitled to the rights of a foreign citizen and had links with a rebel student group. She is married to a Briton but holds a Burmese passport. The decision has not been officially announced. In the last multiparty election in 1960, U Nu was elected prime minister. He was ousted in 1962, the beginning of one-party military rule. U Nu was put under house arrest last month and banned from running in the May elections after he refused to dissolve a parallel government formed at the height of the 1988 uprising.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Rattles Northern California; No Injuries Reported
DOC.TEXT: No injuries or serious damage was reported after a strong earthquake struck the Northern California coast. Residents described Tuesday's temblor, which registered 5.3 on the Richter scale, as a slow, rolling motion that built up to lateral shaking. The quake hit at 12:08 p.m. and was centered about 50 miles south of Eureka, according to the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park. ``It seemed long and just kind of weaving. It wasn't real, real strong here,'' said a Eureka Police Department employee who only identified herself as Diana. The quake was felt along the coast from Point Arena near the Oregon border, south to Willits, about 130 miles north of San Francisco. Residents in the small town of Petrolia reported items being knocked off shelves, but there was no other damage, state officials said. Petrolia is near a land formation known as Punta Gorda, almost directly where the San Andreas Fault enters the Pacific. The Oct. 17 San Francisco Bay area quake measured 7.1 on the Richter scale and killed 67 people, injured 3,000 and caused $7 billion in damage. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in the strength of the shaking. A magnitude-5 quake can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: China To Amend Policy of Forced Separations
DOC.TEXT: China plans to amend its unpopular practice of forcing some married couples to live and work in separate cities, an official newspaper said today. The China Daily said the State Council, China's Cabinet, has worked out a policy to help the 300,000 state-employed couples now living apart get back together. Most Chinese are assigned jobs by the state after finishing school, and job placement officials in the past have routinely sent young married couples to different cities. Changing jobs and obtaining a residency permit in the more comfortable larger cities is extremely difficult, and many couples have been forced to spend much of their married life living apart. Senior intellectuals will be given priority in receiving permission to rejoin spouses, the China Daily said. People with doctorates or those involved in high technology jobs will automatically qualify for relocation. The Personnel Ministry said that in the future all university graduates who are engaged to be married should be assigned to the same city. The ministry said it is asking married couples to join in smaller cities rather than wait for permission to unite in overcrowded larger cities. It said 1 million couples were separated when the government first confronted the problem a decade ago, and the practice of sending couples to different cities has been a large financial burden to the state. Separated couples are allowed three to four weeks off a year to visit their spouses, with all travel expenses paid. The state loses 10 million paid work days and must budget $468 million for the visits.

DOC.HEAD: Unusual Heart Condition Mistaken For Psychiatric Disorder
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of American women are being misdiagnosed as suffering from psychiatric disorders when they are in fact suffering from an unusual form of heart disease, a researcher says. The women, who have chest pain but no signs of heart disease by conventional tests, are suffering from a treatable disorder of the small arteries, said Dr. Richard Cannon of the National Heart Lung and Blood Institute in Bethesda, Md. ``Many have been mislabeled as neurotic or hysterical women,'' Cannon said Tuesday. ``They truly have a pain syndrome.'' Cannon said the disorder afflicts up to 100,000 Americans each year, most of them women. Among their symptoms is a condition Cannon calls ``sensitive heart,'' in which they experience sharp pain when test probes are threaded into arteries near their hearts. Such probes usually are painless, said Cannon, who described his research at the American Heart Association's annual science writers' forum. Cannon's studies have shown that many of the patients are suffering from a disorder he calls microvascular angina, in which blood flow may be blocked in very tiny arteries that nourish the heart. The arteries are too small to show up on angiograms, in which dye is injected into the larger coronary arteries to look for blockages, he said. The condition has sometimes been called ``syndrome X,'' because its cause was unknown. It may be common in men, but occurs in middle age and later when many men have already developed coronary artery blockages. Those blockages hide underlying microvascular angina, Cannon said. A variety of treatments exist to relieve the pain and many are standard heart drugs, Cannon said. The patients are identified in part because they have reduced flow of blood to the heart, Cannon said. Studies have shown that the patients appear to have a disorder of the so-called ``smooth muscle'' in arteries. The smooth muscle causes arteries to tighten and relax as they help regulate blood pressure and blood flow. The patients are unusually sensitive to drugs that constrict the blood vessels, and somewhat insensitive to drugs that relax blood vessels, Cannon said. They also commonly have disorders of the esophagus and an asthma-like condition in the bronchial tubes. The esophagus and the bronchial tubes contain smooth muscle. The disorder could be caused by some defect in the smooth muscle itself, or it could be a problem in the portions of the brain and nervous system that regulate the contraction and relaxation of smooth muscle, Cannon said. Although microvascular angina is not a psychiatric condition, some psychiatric drugs appear to relieve the chest pain, perhaps because they alleviate a disorder in the nervous system's regulation of the smooth muscle, Cannon said. His current hypothesis is that the condition may be the result of improper signals sent from the body to the brain, or a problem in the brain's analysis of those signals. Panic attacks, anxiety and depression can be seen in some patients with microvascular angina, but ``the vast majority of people I see are put together pretty well psychologically,'' Cannon said.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Officials Look into Claims Murdered U.S. Agent was Corrupt
LaserPhoto MO1
DOC.TEXT: The government, stung by American TV depictions of corrupt Mexican officials who aid drug traffickers, says it is looking into claims that a murdered U.S. drug agent actually was in league with traffickers. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, meanwhile, put on a hastily arranged memorial service for 44 Mexican narcotics agents killed in the line of duty in the last 13 months. ``The first condition for attacking narcotics trafficking is to dismantle and destroy the networks of corruption that protect it,'' Salinas said at the memorial Tuesday at Mexico City's airport. Mexico has been embarassed and angered by the NBC miniseries ``Drug Wars,'' which was broadcast early this month. The miniseries, based on the 1985 killing of U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena, showed corrupt Mexican officials aiding narcotics traffickers and thwarting the investigation of Camarena's murder. Comments on NBC News programs that followed the miniseries suggested the corruption that allowed Camarena to be killed has not gone away. Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo said Mexican officials had no independent corroboration of press reports that Camarena was working with drug traffickers, although those reports first appeared in a government news service dispatch. ``We are checking the basis of those reports,'' said Alvarez, who refused to give further details in a brief encounter with reporters. The reports, which involved marijuana busts in northwestern Mexico, have been angrily denied by U.S. officials. Salinas has made an effort to remove drug trafficking as an irritant in U.S.-Mexican relations, winning praise from U.S. officials for vigorously pursuing drug traffickers. He did not mention the controversy over the NBC miniseries in his speech, but before an audience of about 400 agents and family members of the dead he emphasized that eliminating corruption was a key to defeating drug traffickers. ``We do not deny our problems, nor do we look for excuses for our errors,'' Salinas said. ``Although the great majority of our agents have demonstrated great valor in fighting drug trafficking, I repeat, we will energetically punish those who involve themselves in drug trafficking,'' he said. Elaine Shannon, author of the book ``Desperados,'' on which the NBC miniseries was based, said Mexican authorities began attacking Camarena's integrity in 1985 in order to divert attention from themselves, and even tried to set up a fake bank account to prove Camarena took dirty money. Law enforcement sources said Camarena may have been involved in activities common to U.S. agents that are technically illegal in Mexico, such as allowing informants to operate freely for the sake of gaining information and bagging bigger game. Opposition leader Cuauhtemoc Cardenas added some political heat to the ``Drug Wars'' controversy by saying the Mexican government allows U.S. agents to operate too freely in Mexico, although he said he did not know the details of their activities. Even Gabriel Garcia Marquez, a winner of the Nobel prize for literature, got into the act. ``Mexico's response to the defamation of the country was weak and inadequate, because it attacks not only this country but all of Latin America,'' said Marquez, according to the Excelsior news service. Marquez is a Colombian national but lives here. On Monday, a local radio station broadcast called for a demonstration at the local NBC office, but none materialized. The Salinas administration crackdown has resulted in the seizure of 36 tons of cocaine in the 13 months Salinas has been in office _ more than was seized the previous 10 years _ and the shutdown of several major cocaine smuggling operations. The memorial service, staged at a hangar used by the attorney general's office, was broadcast live on Mexican television and given wide play on news broadcasts. Placards listed the accomplishments of the Salinas administration, and several airplanes and helicopters used for surveillance and herbicide spraying were on display. Drug kingpins Rafael Caro Quintero and Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo were sentenced in December to 40 years in prison without parole for the Camarena murder, but an investigation continues in the United States and further indictments are expected. Mexican and U.S. officials say the controversy has not affected working relations between the two governments, especially in narcotics.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Kingpin Sentenced to Life in Prison Without Parole
With PM-Money Laundering, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A drug kingpin whose arrest in Honduras sparked anti-American riots was sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole, closing one of the West Coast's largest cocaine trafficking cases. Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, 45, was sentenced Tuesday by U.S. District Judge Pamela Ann Rymer, ending an odyssey that began in 1988 when Honduran police raided his Tegucigalpa home at dawn and swiftly extradited him to the United States. ``Matta is considered one of the godfathers who established the Colombian cocaine connection,'' said John Zienter, special agent in charge of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Los Angeles. ``His sentencing sends a message to the primary individuals involved that no matter how high up they are _ and believe me, Matta was among the highest _ they are not safe from dedicated law enforcement officers.'' Matta was in the custody of U.S. marshals, who were expected to transport him to a maximum-security prison, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Manuel Medrano. Prosecutors said Matta headed a powerful cocaine cartel based in Cali, Colombia, which funneled tons of cocaine through Mexico to the United States. Matta moved almost 600 pounds of cocaine with a street value of more than $73 million through Arizona and Southern California, prosecutors said. In a presentencing memorandum filed last month, Medrano described Matta as ``perhaps the most significant trafficker in custody in the world to date.'' Matta's lawyer, Martin Stolar, portrayed his client as a legitimate businessman and one of Honduras' largest private employers. Stolar has 10 days to notify the court if he intends to appeal the sentence. Matta's extradition from Honduras triggered deadly riots in his homeland. Some 2,000 Hondurans burned the U.S. Embassy annex, and five people were killed in the week-long disturbances. Attorneys for Matta said he was kidnaped from Honduras, which has no extradition treaty with the United States. But federal courts have upheld extraditions, Medrano said. Matta was convicted in September on seven criminal counts that included conspiracy, possession and distribution of narcotics and running a criminal enterprise. The case centered on a September 1981 DEA raid at a suburban Van Nuys apartment that netted $1.9 million in cash and 114 pounds of cocaine, at that time the largest seizure of the drug in state history. Coded ledgers that were seized in the raid were traced back to a shadowy figure called ``El Negro,'' who was identified as Matta by Hector Barona Becerra, an admitted drug trafficker-turned-government witness.

DOC.HEAD: Rumor Sets Back Stocks, Dollar Inches Down
DOC.TEXT: Another rumor about the Soviet leader set back the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index today just as it was recovering from a major two-day plunge, and the dollar inched down against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 29.22 points, or 0.08 percent, closing at 36,821.14. After losing more than 650 points on each of the last two trading days, the index gained 360.66 points in this morning's trading, responding favorably to a 23.25-point overnight gain in the Dow Jones industrial average in New York. But then it turned down as the market looked for a continued decline in Japanese government bond prices, and received another setback from a recurring rumor that Mikhail S. Gorbachev was resigning, said Kazuhiro Nomura, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. Nomura said the rumor, generated in the bond market, was transmitted to the stock market, and the Nikkei fell. Bond prices, however, rose 0.21 points today, their first increase this year after an eight-session slide that had pushed the yield up about one percentage point from last year. Dealers have pointed to the slumping bond price as a major factor in the Nikkei's decline of more than 2,000 points, or 5.4 percent, since ending last year at 38,915.87, a record high. But amid general pessimism, rumors and speculation have been moving the market, they say. Commenting recently on the rumors, Yamaichi Securities analyst Kenji Maeshiro said, ``Gorbachev will probably have to die a thousand times in such rumors this year,'' besides supposedly resigning. Analysts say investors push such rumors in an attempt to manipulate prices for profit-taking. ``The market this morning finally began to think that the Nikkei had already hit the bottom and would start recovering, but it is still vulnerable and is super-sensitive to pessimistic rumors,'' Nomura said. After substantial buying in the morning session, many investors sold back issues for profit-taking, followed by massive selling by Solomon Brothers, a major foreign securities firm, shortly before the afternoon session ended, Nomura said. Trading was thin, with an estimated 550 million shares changing hands on the first section. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 145.52 yen, down 0.23 yen from Tuesday's 145.75-yen finish. It opened at 145.40 yen and ranged between 145.37 yen and 145.55 yen. Although trading was calm as many market players awaited the release of U.S. trade figures for November, due to be announced later today, ``the dollar was basically getting stronger,'' said Yoshitsugu Hanada, a trader with Mitsui Bank. He added that the yen's weakness will continue to affect government bond prices. ``There is no immediate need to buy the yen now, because of uncertainties ahead of the major election,'' he said, referring to nationwide balloting for Parliament's upper house next month. Some $3.67 billion changed hands in spot trading today.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Concedes Campaign Took Toll on State, Family
With PM-Legislative Issues, Bjt
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said he knows many Massachusetts' residents feel angered and betrayed by his presidential loss and the damage it did to the state. ``It's clear to me now that I underestimated the amount of time and energy it takes to seek the modern presidency. Trying to do two jobs at the same time was more difficult and more grueling than I expected,'' Dukakis said in his final State of the State speech Tuesday. ``And I underestimated the toll it would take on my family, too.'' Dukakis' wife, Kitty, entered an alcoholism treatment program shortly after his loss. Mrs. Dukakis received a standing ovation and perhaps the warmest applause of the evening when she stepped onto a balcony to watch her husband's address. Dukakis said he won the Democratic presidential nomination ``swept up by the excitement and euphoria'' of what he called the ``Massachusetts Miracle.'' ``But a funny thing happened on the road to the White House. I ran a great campaign for the primary, and a lousy one for the final,'' Dukakis said. ``I lost, and in the process Massachusetts took an unfair beating. And I feel terrible about it. ``I know that many of you are angry with me. Feel betrayed. Feel that I put myself before you and the commonwealth,'' Dukakis said Tuesday. ``But there comes a time _ and I believe it has arrived _ that nobody's interest, and certainly not the public's, is served by laying on more blame,'' Dukakis said. The 56-year-old governor is serving the last year of his third, four-year term. He announced early last year that he would not seek re-election. Dukakis repeated his call for new taxes to solve the state's nagging fiscal problems, but said he was optimistic about the future of Massachusetts and of New England, both of which are suffering economic declines. The state Legislature still has not balanced the state's $12 billion budget, which is about $500 million in the red. Many legislators, including Republicans, praised the speech. ``I admire him for making the admissions that he did. I wish he had done it a year ago,'' said Senate Minority Leader David Locke. After the speech, the governor and his wife greeted lobbyists, state workers and other well-wishers. Mrs. Dukakis looked thin, and was less ebullient than she has been in past appearances. But the old warmth returned when she hugged friends and cooed over an infant. ``I'm feeling much better, thank you _ glad to be here,'' she said when asked about her health. Mrs. Dukakis said she is not sad to see the governor's term come to an end. ``I think 12 years _ 12 times is enough,'' she said, referring to the number of times the governor has given a State of the State address. ``I'm just grateful for all the wonderful experiences.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors: Noriega Smuggled Illegal Aliens
With PM-Money Laundering, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A pilot accused of flying drug money from Fort Lauderdale to Panama was part of an illegal alien-smuggling ring led by Manuel Antonio Noriega, prosecutors say. The accusations came Tuesday during a bond hearing for a Noriega co-defendant and raised the possibility the deposed Panamanian dictator could face new charges. Myles Malman, a deputy assistant U.S. attorney, told a magistrate the government has evidence that the Panamanian pilot, Eduardo Pardo, was involved in Noriega-led ring that smuggled illegal aliens into the United States. Asked whether there would be any new charges against Noriega, U.S. attorney's spokeswoman Diane Cossin refused to comment, saying any discussion of the new alien-smuggling accusations would be premature. Pardo, 44, was denied bond by U.S. Magistrate William Turnoff, who agreed with prosecutors that he was a risk to flee the United States. A separate bond hearing for another Noriega co-defendant, Lt. Col. Luis del Cid, who was identified by authorities as a former head of Noriega's secret police and one of his right-hand men, was to resume today. Del Cid, 46, has pleaded innocent to charges of collecting bribe money and acting as a liaison between Noriega and drug traffickers who allegedly used Panama as a conduit for drug shipments to the United States. If convicted on all counts, del Cid could be sentenced to 70 years in prison and fined $550,000. His wife, 34-year-old Tilsa Jimenez del Cid, appealed to Judge William Hoeveler to release her husband until his trial, saying their children rely on him for their education and religious training. ``I don't recall him ever going to bed without saying a prayer,'' she testified. Mrs. del Cid denied that her husband led Panama's ``G-2'' secret police and said he had nothing to do with drug trafficking. Del Cid's lawyer, Samuel Burstyn, complained in a motion filed Tuesday that prosecutors haven't complied with Hoeveler's Dec. 26 order to allow him access to evidence against del Cid. ``The case against Lieutenant Colonel del Cid is a very thin one and apparently rests entirely upon the uncorroborated hearsay statements of Floyd Carlton Caceres,'' Burstyn wrote in the motion. Testimony by Carlton, a former confidant of Noriega, provided the basis for much of the indictment and the convicted drug pilot is expected to be the prime witness against Noriega at his drug-smuggling trial. Outside the courtroom, a Noriega attorney, Steven Kollin, said he would need at least a year and possibly two to prepare for trial.

DOC.HEAD: Artery Balloon Helps Save Legs From Amputation
DOC.TEXT: A tiny inflatable balloon that can open arteries plugged with cholesterol could replace up to 30 percent of the 110,000 operations done each year to help save legs from amputation, a researcher says. The blockage of arteries in the legs is the result of hardening of the arteries, or atherosclerosis. When atherosclerosis occurs in the arteries that nourish the heart, it leads to a heart attack. When it occurs in the leg arteries, it can lead to gangrene and amputation. Blockages in leg arteries are treated with bypass surgery analogous to heart bypass operations. The leg operations are performed on about 110,000 Americans a year. Another 100,000 Americans undergo amputations of legs, feet or toes each year, said Dr. Eric Martin of Columbia University, who presented his findings Tuesday at the American Heart Association's annual science writers' forum. Wider use in the leg arteries of the balloon technique could save $300 million to $400 million a year, Martin said. Similar balloons are being used in lieu of heart bypass surgery in the coronary arteries that nourish the heart. The balloon procedure, called angioplasty, is as effective as surgery in leg arteries, Martin said. Depending upon which leg artery develops the blockage, unblocked arteries have a 65 percent to 90 percent chance of remaining unblocked for at least five years after angioplasty, he said. Limb problems often occur in diabetics, whose arteries are more likely to become clogged. In most cases, atherosclerosis in the legs does not occur until after blockages already have produced heart and kidney disease, Martin said. Limb problems therefore are limited mostly to elderly patients. Three new techniques may one day improve upon surgery and angioplasty, Martin said, but as yet they are unproven. The use of tiny rotors to cut away blockages inside arteries is still in its infancy, but the technique may cut in half the rate of recurrence of blockages, compared to angioplasty, Martin said. Lasers that are designed to burn away the blockages have been disappointing so far, he said. They are also extremely expensive. The machine costs $100,000. As with angioplasty and the tiny rotors, the laser machine uses a catheter, or small tube, which is threaded through the arteries until it reaches the site of the blockage. The laser catheters cost $600 apiece and must be discarded after a single use, Martin said. A third new technique is the opening of blockages with stents, tiny wire mesh tubes that are inserted into the blockage, expanded to open a clear channel, and left in place. A new blood vessel lining grows over the stent after a few weeks. Initial results are good, Martin said, but the stents can produce clots.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We can't bring ourselves to pronounce it out loud, but what is happening now ... can unambiguously be termed a civil war.'' _ O. Shapovalov, correspondent for the Soviet newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda, on the armed battles between Azerbaijanis and Armenians in the southern republic of Azerbaijan.

``It's clear to me now that I underestimated the amount of time and energy it takes to seek the modern presidency. Trying to do two jobs at the same time was more difficult and more grueling than I expected. And I underestimated the toll it would take on my family, too.'' _ Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, in his 12th and final State of the State speech.

``I don't have to do anything except just be there. I don't threaten anyone. I'm just a nice, fat grandmother.'' _ Barbara Bush, when asked why polls show that her popularity surpasses that of the president.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin Troops Try To Halt Civil War In Southern Caucasus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with today's reports, Azerbaijani demands for arms, refugees arriving in Armenia, troops instructed to get tougher, details. Pick up 12th pvs, `Internal security ...' ^By JOHN-THOR DAHLBURG
DOC.TEXT: More than 11,000 newly arrived troops struggled today to end battles between bands of Azerbaijanis and Armenians, who reportedly were armed with everything from submachine guns and grenades to commandeered artillery. The official death toll from the clashes in the southern republic of Azerbaijan stood at 56, mostly Armenians, and new clashes were reported. Azerbaijanis staged protests in their republic's capital, Baku, and elsewhere to demand they be armed and allowed to defend their claim to the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, an predominantly Armenian enclave in Azerbaijan, newspapers and officials said today. In bordering Armenia to the west, people were still breaking into police stations and other arms repositories in search of weapons, said Dmitri Seleznyov, an Interior Ministry spokesman in Moscow. Seleznyov said that in the past 24 hours there had been 64 attacks on Armenian homes in Baku, where the bloodletting exploded Saturday night with mob attacks on Armenians. ``It's a terrible thing,'' he said. The Armenian news agency, Armenpress, said some 1,500 refugees were arriving daily in the Armenian capital of Yerevan. On Tuesday, the official Tass news agency said 2,000 people armed with anti-aircraft guns and other artillery were massing on hills around Nagorno-Karabakh, the flashpoint for the neighboring groups' ethnic hatreds. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared a state of emergency in the strife-torn mountain area Monday night, empowering the government to deploy units of the Soviet army, navy and KGB to protect lives and guard vital installations such as railroads. More than 6,000 additional internal security troops were sent Tuesday to reinforce existing Interior Ministry detachments, Tass said. To assist them, more than 5,000 Red Army soldiers, who traditionally carry heavier weaponry, also were dispatched, Tass said. Soviet media did not say how many troops already were in the region. Tass said that in Armenia, ``demands are being made to arm citizens and send them to Nagorno-Karabakh.'' The government newspaper Izvestia reported 16 attacks on weapons depots in 24 hours by Armenians seeking guns. The troops have been instructed to get tougher with the fighters, Seleznyov said, and soldiers opened fire Tuesday when an armed group tried to take five armored personnel carriers near the village of Tazikend. ``Since then, attempts to take APCs have stopped, because before this they weren't used to having weapons used against them,'' he said by telephone. Combatants in the Nagorno-Karabakh region had seized stores of hand grenades, the Interior Ministry said. The flareup is the most violent between mainly Moslem Azerbaijanis and mostly Christian Armenians since their decades-old feud over Nagorno-Karabakh erupted in bloody clashes two years ago. The enclave has been ruled by Azerbaijan since 1923 and the current troubles were sparked by its demand in February 1988 to be annexed by Armenia. Internal security troops already in the region have been incapable of halting the most protracted ethnic conflict in Gorbachev's nearly five-year tenure as Kremlin leader. ``We can't bring ourselves to pronounce it out loud, but what is happening now ... can unambiguously be termed a civil war,'' correspondent O. Shapovalov wrote in the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda. The Bush administration supported Gorbachev's use of troops in the region, known as the southern Caucasus, and criticized feuding Azerbaijanis and Armenians for ``revisiting old ethnic hatreds.'' The Kremlin's emergency decree empowers local officials to ban demonstrations and strikes, impose curfews, censor the media, confiscate weapons, disband unofficial organizations and detain people for up to 30 days. Interior Ministry officials said they could not recall such measures being imposed in the country since World War II. Gennady I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, denied the decree was a backtracking of Gorbachev's reforms, which have led to greater openness and liberalization of society since he became Soviet leader in March 1985. ``I would not interpret this step as being at odds with glasnost and democracy,'' Gerasimov said. ``On the contrary, the step opposes anarchy.'' Spokesman Vladimir A. Yanchenkov of the Interior Ministry, which is in charge of police affairs, said in Moscow Tuesday that the death toll in the Caucasus had reached 56 in Azerbaijan, with 156 people injured. Two of the dead were members of law enforcement agencies, he said. Most of the victims were Armenians, the ministry said. Yanchenkov said authorities had recorded 167 ``pogroms,'' meaning ethnic attacks, and cases of arson. In Saturday night's anti-Armenian riots in Baku, people were reported burned alive and a witness said women were thrown from apartment windows. Fighting rapidly spread to Nagorno-Karabakh and nearby areas of Azerbaijan, with the belligerants using helicopters, armored vehicles, machine guns and other arms seized from government arsenals or offered by compatriots. Soviet TV on Tuesday showed Interior Ministry troops firing in the air as they rode in armored personnel carrier through an Azerbaijani village near Nagorno-Karabakh to enforce the emergency decree. The ministry said the Azerbaijani People's Front, a grassroots political group that has organized anti-Armenian protests, was preventing arriving troop reinforcements from traveling to battle areas by blocking roads. In Nagorno-Karabakh, about 26,000 people _ about a sixth of the population _ had been detained and nearly 3,000 firearms and other weapons confiscated since the conflict began, Izvestia said. Azerbaijanis were said Tuesday to be continuing a virtual rail blockade of Armenia's 3.5 million people, cutting short fuel and other supplies. Azerbaijan has 6.9 million people. In Baku, detachment of security troops patrolled the city and armored vehicles moved through the suburbs of the Caspian Sea port, Azerbaijani activist Alesker Siyabov said by telephone. Tass said 2,000 Armenians were evacuated by ferry and plane from Baku, an oil-producing center of 1.7 million. Of the 220,000 Armenians who lived there before the strife over Nagorno-Karabakh began, only a few thousand remain, it said. In February 1988, Azerbaijanis went on an anti-Armenian rampage in the industrial city of Sumgait, near Baku, and 32 people, mostly Armenians, were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Najib Gov't Sees Progress in National Reconciliation
DOC.TEXT: President Najib's government claims to have made tangible gains in its 3-year-old program of national reconciliation even though it has not succeeded in ending the country's protracted civil war. Government officials acknowledge that fighting between their Soviet-armed troops and U.S.-backed Moslem guerrillas continues to claim heavy tolls in life and property. But they also claim to be achieving success through a campaign of offering amnesty to any guerrillas who surrender and cash for their weapons. Najib, former head of the feared KHAD secret police, launched his national reconciliation program in January 1987 with the first of a series of short-lived cease-fires that have been routinely rejected by the mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors. ``The last three years have been really difficult and full of problems because of the enemies of national reconciliation, but we have made a number of fruitful gains,'' government spokesman Naquib Sameer said. He asserted that ``70 percent of armed opposition commanders have laid down their weapons and joined national reconciliation.'' Guerrilla leaders based across the border in Pakistan admit that some of their fighters in Afghanistan have struck deals with Najib's government, but they say the majority are still fighting. Azim Nasser-Zia, spokesman for the National Islamic Front of Afghanistan, one of the seven Pakistan-based mujahedeen factions, scoffed at Sameer's claim. ``Maybe 70 percent of the mujahedeen have taken Najib's arms and money _ but only to use it against him,'' he said. Kabul officials claim that 168 ``armed opposition groups'' have joined Najib's national reconciliation process and that an additional 351 groups have signed cease-fire agreements. These officials estimate that between 30,000 and 40,000 mujahedeen are still fighting the Najib government, whose combat troops number about 50,000. Mujahedeen leaders, however, claim they have a fighting force of 150,000, who move freely in much of the Afghan countryside but have failed to capture a single major city in the nearly 12-year-old civil war. The mujahedeen denounce Najib's People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan as ``Godless communists,'' and steadfastly refuse to enter into any power-sharing arrangements. Abdul Rahim, spokesman for the mujahedeen news agency MIDIA, said battlefield reports contradict Najib's claims of massive support for the reconciliation process. ``If anyone has joined the communists, it's because they were communists before,'' Rahim said. ``The real mujahedeen commander would never join Najib.'' The Afghan war started in 1978 when the People's Democratic Party seized power in a military coup and embarked upon the Marxist policies that Najib now seeks to disavow. In 1979, internal rivalries spurred another military coup within the party. By December 1979, Soviet troops swooped in to install yet a third Marxist government and stayed on to fight the growing mujahedeen insurgency. The Red Army managed only a stalemate before withdrawing its troops over a nine-month period that ended last February. Najib has since been massively supplied by Moscow with weapons and food but has not achieved a military victory over the fierce mountain guerrillas. But he has foiled American and other Western predictions that his government would quickly tumble once the Soviets withdrew their direct combat support. More than 5 million Afghans _ one-third of the country's pre-war population _ remain huddled in squalid refugee camps across the border in Pakistan and Iran. By the Kabul government's own estimates, fewer than 5 percent have ventured home in the past three years.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Blame Fatal Fire on Smoldering Cigarette
DOC.TEXT: A smoldering cigarette apparently caused a Christmas Eve fire that killed 16 people at a retirement center, according to investigators who don't expect criminal charges. The fire began in the first-floor apartment of Georgia Jones, who was described as a chain smoker by other residents of the John Sevier Retirement Center, officials said Tuesday. A senior state arson investigator, Johnny Robertson, and other investigators held a news conference to discuss their findings, but they did not say whether Ms. Jones, 67, was home at the time of the fire. ``All other causes were eliminated,'' said Robert Frost, a fire investigator for the Tennessee Department of Commerce and Insurance. ``We didn't find anything that would allow us to eliminate it (smoking),'' Frost said. The fire, the second fatal blaze in two months at the 10-floor center, spread to the second floor and parts of the third floor and smoke permeated the building before flames were brought under control. Dozens of the 145 residents were injured and 16 were killed. In October, a 76-year-old resident died of smoke inhalation in a fire at the center. Prosecutor David Crockett said he plans to present the case to a Washington County grand jury next month. ``I would be surprised if there will be any criminal prosecution,'' he said. Lawsuits for three victims have been filed against the building's owners and managers.
