DOC.HEAD: Island Blackened By Mystery Slick, Anti-Pollution Team Sent
DOC.TEXT: Residents on the tiny Atlantic island of Porto Santo used shovels and buckets to battle a mysterious 12-mile-long oil slick that blackened beaches and threatened a valuable nature reserve. Help was sent to the Portuguese island on Tuesday, when the Lisbon government sent an air force transport plane carrying an anti-pollution team armed with floating barriers, pumps and other equipment to combat the slick. Since Monday, patches of oil have washed up on the vacation island's famous six-mile white sand beach on the south coast, while more crude coated the rocky north and east coasts with thick slime. Some of the island's residents, using shovels and buckets to fight the slick, said the oil-soaked corpses of gulls, turtles and fish washed onto the island. The slick off the coast stretched over 12 miles, posing a threat to the water supply for the 5,000 residents of Porto Santo and to a nature reserve on the uninhabited Desertas islands 37 miles to the south. The origin of the oil slick was still undetermined. Portuguese Navy officers said it was unlikely the crude came from the Iranian tanker Khark 5, which leaked more than 70,000 tons into the Atlantic in the area in December, the Lusa news agency reported. The oil that washed up this week was dense and black, suggesting a more recent leak. Oil that has been in the sea longer turns yellowish and foamy, the report said. In a Portugese television interview, a merchant marine official said the oil could have been dumped from a number of tankers which passed along the busy sea lanes off the Madeira Islands. The volcanic islands, famed for their rocky beauty and sub-tropical climate, are about 625 miles southwest of Lisbon and about 435 miles west of the Moroccan coast. Madeira biologist Manuel Biscoito told Lusa he was worried the damage the slick could cause to the Desertas. The craggy islands are home to a variety of rare maritime animals, including one of the world's last breeding colonies of the Mediterranean monk seal, an endangered marine mammal. Madeira Island itself, the largest member of the achipelago and a major winter vacation destination, was not immediately threatened by the slick, officials said, but could come into danger if wind directions changed. An emergency meeting of the Madeira Regional Government called to discuss the situation was alerted to the threat to drinking water on Porto Santo. The islanders take 80 percent of their drinking water from desalination plants drawing water from the sea. The pumps supplying sea water to the system would have to be stopped if the slick approached the intake area, officials said.

A strong earthquake jolted western Australia today, less than a month after a tremor of equal strength shook the eastern seaboard. There were no reports of damage or injuries. Today's quake, measureing 5.5 on the Richter scale, was felt in Perth, the capital of Western Australia state, and as far away as Albany, 280 miles to the south, seismologists said. State Emergency Service spokesman Keith Harraway said there were no reports of damage or injuries. Perth is one of the world's most isolated cities and Western Australia is mainly desert. In the country's first fatal earthquake, 12 people were killed on Dec. 28 in the city of Newcastle. The industrial center and the country's sixth biggest city is still assessing the cost, with hundreds of buildings suffering structural damage. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 5 on the scale can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Thundershowers, Balmy Temperatures in Gulf Coast, Ohio Valley
DOC.TEXT: Spring-like temperatures today were expected to surpass average readings for January by more than 25 degrees from the Gulf states to southern New England. Showers, thunderstorms and fog stretched from the Gulf Coast through the Ohio Valley. The Southeast also was expected to enjoy sunny, warm weather. Chicago reveled in relative balminess Tuesday. On what is normally the city's coldest day of the year, the mercury hit a record 57 degrees. Tuesday's rain helped clear the air of a dense fog that socked in Chicago's airports for hours. A cold front moved into the Mississsippi Valley, spawning showers near the Gulf of Mexico and in the Midwest. Snow mixed with freezing rain fell over the Northern Plains early today. Rain over the lower Great Lakes extended across east-central New York state and central New England. Rain turned to snow in the higher elevations of central New England. Rainshowers and thunderstorms also extended from Nebraska to Mississippi. Tuesday thunderstorms left hail in parts of Illinois and Oklahoma. Small hail also accompanied thunderstorms in California's lower Sacramento Valley on Tuesday. By late afternoon Tuesday, 6 to 10 inches of snow had fallen in the mountains near Lake Tahoe, and up to 4 inches hit the Reno-Carson City area in Nevada. Tuesday's high temperature for the nation was 85 at Naples, Fla. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Steady, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was little changed against major foreign currencies this morning as traders awaited the release of U.S. trade figures later in the day, dealers said. Gold prices were lower. Traders said Tuesday's spurt of dollar-buying in the wake of unrest in the Soviet Union and Eastern Germany was probably overdone and premature. ``The problems Gorbachev is having are already factored into the market,'' said Manfred Totzauer, vice president at Citibank AG in Frankfurt. ``He'd have to fall before the dollar would do something more substantial.'' Some traders said concerns about the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe will ensure that the dollar remains fairly firm even if the November U.S. trade figures are disappointing. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.23 yen to a closing 145.52 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 145.65 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6955 West German marks, up from 1.6945 _1.5105 Swiss francs, down from 1.5160 _5.7685 French francs, up from 5.7635 _1.9137 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9195 _1,264.00 Italian lire, up from 1,261.50 _1.1653 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1648 In London, the dollar gained against the British pound. It cost $1.6455 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6560 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $410.00 a troy ounce, down from $413.25 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $410.60. In Zurich, the bid price was $410.80, down from $413.00 bid late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong fell $4.74 to close at a bid $409.03. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.23 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's $5.25.

DOC.HEAD: Largest Anti-Apartheid Group To Defy Ban
By DAVID CRARY
DOC.TEXT: The country's largest anti-apartheid coalition, forced to operate covertly since being banned two years ago, announced today that it is resuming full-scale, above-ground operations. The move is intended as a test of the white-led government's professed commitment to reform. Senior leaders of the United Democratic Front, representing more than 600 organizations with more than 2 million members, said they would re-open offices across the country and begin planning for a national conference in April. ``In what we see as a challenging period ahead of us, we have decided to claim our rights to engage in open opposition activity,'' Murphy Morobe, one of the coalition's chief spokesmen, told a news conference. ``We owe it to our people that the leadership of our movement is openly available at this crucial moment in the struggle.'' Morobe also said a delegation of 22 leaders of the front planned to meet soon with Nelson Mandela, jailed leader of the African National Congress guerrilla movement. Mandela is expected to be released in the coming weeks after nearly 28 years in prison. The United Democratic Front, which shares the ANC's goals of a non-racial democracy, was established in 1983 to mobilize resistance to a new constitution that entrenched the exclusion of the black majority from Parliament. Many leaders of the organization were detained for two to three years after a nationwide state of emergency was declared in June 1986, and in February 1988 the government listed the front among 17 organizations prohibited from engaging in any activities. ``The emergency has hurt us and at some levels disorganized us,'' said Azhar Cachalia, a member of the front's executive commitee. ``But the the main purpose of the emergency, to smash the UDF, has failed. We are probably stronger now than we have ever been.'' He said the decision to resume overt operations was intended as a challenge to President F.W. de Klerk, who since taking office in August has eased restrictions on anti-government protests and invited black leaders to help negotiate a new constitution that would extend some form of political rights to blacks. ``We are now, in a concrete way, beginning to test his intentions and his commitment to a new South Africa,'' Cachalia said. Morobe said no date had yet been set for the meeting between front leaders and Mandela, who has been conferring at his prison residence with government officials and prominent anti-apartheid activists. ``We believe he is in a historically unique position that can open up new possibilities and opportunities which can only advance the cause of liberation,'' Morobe said. Morobe said the front and the ANC agree on the pre-conditions needed before the two organizations will enter negotiations with the government. These include the release of Mandela and other political prisoners, lifting of the state of emergency, unbanning of the ANC and other opposition groups, removal of soldiers from black townships, and an end to political trials. Under apartheid, the country's 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate districts, schools and health services.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet General Sees Changes In Warsaw Pact
DOC.TEXT: A high-ranking Soviet general acknowledged today that political upheaval in Moscow's East European allies will affect the structure of the Warsaw Pact military alliance. ``There will be changes in structure,'' said Gen. Nikolaj Chervov, head of the directorate of the Soviet general staff. He spoke to reporters on the second day of unprecedented talks among the top officers of 35 nations about their military policies. The three-week meeting opened Tuesday with Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, and his Soviet counterpart, Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, outlining the superpowers' strategies. Officers from Poland, Czechoslovakia and East Germany were scheduled to speak later today. Western military experts have been anxious to hear the East bloc reports, hoping to learn more about how recent political events will shape future policies of the seven-nation Warsaw Pact. Popular uprisings have driven out the hard-line Communist leaderships in Poland, Hungary, Bulgaria, East Germany, Romania and Czechoslovakia. The United States and 15 of its allies belong to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Chervov, speaking through an interpreter, said the Warsaw Pact's top governing body, the Political Consultative Committee, will likely be disbanded. The panel is made up of the top Communist Party officials of the seven nations. The fast pace of change in those countries, he said, has led to ``the multiplicity of parties.'' ``The Communist Parties are no longer leading the states,'' he said. ``Therefore, the Political Consultative Committee will probably cease to exist of itself and perhaps there will be another supreme body.'' The new body, he said, could be made up of the heads of state of those countries. He also said the top military officers in the Warsaw Pact countries have ``confirmed their states will remain true to their (alliance) obligations.'' Western officials have been looking for hints of a dramatic weakening in the Warsaw Pact. On Tuesday, Sir David Craig, chief of the British defense staff, said he did not see signs of a collapse in the seven-nation alliance. ``Clearly, I think they would all recognize amongst the seven of them that there are changes afoot,'' he said. ``But to talk about the breakup of the (pact) was not the impression I was left with today.'' Moiseyev told the gathering the Soviet Union was trimming its armed forces as part of plans to rework its military policies. The West contends the Soviets' powerful military might could seize and hold foreign territory in time of war. The 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization argues its forces are the minimum necessary to defend against an attack. Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced in December 1988 plans to unilaterally slash 500,000 troops and reduce conventional, or non-nuclear, arms substantially. Moiseyev said half the reductions were carried out last year and the rest will be completed in 1990. As of Jan. 1, he said, Soviet armed forces were down by 265,000. He said 9,320 tanks, more than 5,050 artillery systems and 835 warplanes have been reduced in Europe. The military budget, he said, was cut by 8.2 percent last year and will be pared by more than 14 percent in the next two years. ``We also intend, if the situation permits, to drastically, by 1.5 to 2 times, reduce the share of the national income's spending on defense by 1995,'' he said. Craig said the West wanted to believe the Kremlin intends to change its military policy. ``But,'' he said, ``there is a long way to go between intentions and execution. We must wait and see how that execution is carried out.'' The meeting at Vienna's Hofburg Palace, the former imperial residence, is part of negotiations on Confidence- and Security-Building Measures, which are designed to reduce military tensions in Europe. The United States, Canada and nearly all European nations are taking part.

DOC.HEAD: Namibia's Whites-Only Schools Admit Blacks For First Time
DOC.TEXT: Black and mixed-race children were admitted to formerly whites-only schools for the first time today as Namibia prepares to end South African rule and become independent. Also today, police said that thousands of mortar rounds and other munitions are being destroyed following the winding down of the war between South African forces and nationalist guerrillas. Twenty-two black and mixed-race students enrolled at Centaurus High School in Windhoek as the new school year began, school officials said. A similar number of non-white applicants were refused admission after failing English tests, they said. ``Aside from the normal requirements, regarding uniforms and fees etc., our only requirement is that pupils must be able to speak and understand English,'' said a school spokeswoman, who declined to be named. ``It was just like any school enrollment on the first day of term.'' Education officials said they had no immediate figures on how many blacks and mixed-race students were admitted today to formerly all white schools in the territory. South African officials announced last week that whites-only schools would be allowed to admit blacks for the first time this year. Special schools and hospitals have been reserved exclusively for whites in the past. South Africa is about to end its rule of Namibia following a long bush war with the black nationalist South-West African Peoples Organization, or SWAPO, which won elections in November and is to head the government when independence is declared in the next few weeks. South Africa had ruled Namibia, also known as South-West Africa, since seizing the territory from Germany during World War I. Police officials said today that the munitions, including mortar rounds, rocket-propelled grenades and land mines, were being destroyed with explosives rather than returning them to South Africa. The munitions were used by South African and allied South-West African forces. Explosive experts this week detonated 4,000 South African-made mortar rounds in one huge blast at Kwambi in the north of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Marshals Seize Home of Drug-Issuing Psychiatrist
DOC.TEXT: U.S. marshals, acting under a federal law aimed at stripping drug dealers of their means of doing business, seized the house of a 73-year-old psychiatrist accused of illegally writing prescriptions there. Tuesday's seizure of the home of Henry Spitzer marked the first use of the forfeiture statute against a doctor in California, authorities said. Spitzer surrendered his license to practice last year after he was charged with 16 felonies in 1988. Undercover agents had concluded he was prescribing Valium and an amphetamine in cases where it was not medically warranted. Federal law provides for the seizure of a home, car or other property if the property was purchased with drug profits or used in drug trafficking. ``He was practicing in his home, issuing prescriptions from there, so this case met the test,'' said Dan Goldsmith, a senior investigator for the state Medical Board, which worked with the Drug Enforcement Administration on the case. ``We're breaking new ground here,'' Goldsmith said. ``This hits them where it hurts _ in the wallet.'' A Medical Board spokesman said Spitzer can remain in his $150,000 house pending a hearing in court. If the seizure is upheld, the house will be auctioned and the proceeds divided among agencies that participated in the investigation. Under a 1989 plea bargain, Spitzer agreed to surrender his medical license and pay restitution to the board in return for dismissal of the criminal charges. But the board decided to pursue seizure of the home. ``I think he figured this whole thing was over and done with,'' said police Lt. Lee Weigel.

DOC.HEAD: Orchestra Percussion Section Walks Out After Mentor's Resignation
DOC.TEXT: The Rhode Island Philharmonic's entire percussion section quit after its leader was told he would be fired unless his playing improved. George Goneconto, a 33-year veteran of the orchestra, said Tuesday he resigned rather than fight a notice putting him on probation. His decision led to the resignations last month of the three other percussion members, all former students of the drummer. Conductor Andrew Massey, who sent warning letters to eight members of the orchestra at the end of November, was in California and could not be reached for comment. Philharmonic manager Karen Dobbs said the resignations ``just added to the instability'' of the orchestra. ``If they end up with new people back there all the time, it's very difficult,'' she said. Goneconto said he and Massey had a ``friendly discussion'' about his performance in the fall, and he received the letter soon afterward, which he called a ``complete shock.'' Under the orchestra's contract with the Providence Federation of Musicians, players who receive warning letters have until the end of the season to improve. They can appeal to a panel of fellow orchestra members, who can overrule Massey. Goneconto, 53, joined the Philharmonic when he was 18 and has been the principal percussionist for 30 years. ``I felt it was time to look for warmer and comfortable places to perform in, where the atmosphere is less confrontational,'' Goneconto said. Dobbs said she received letters from Goneconto, Bruce Dyer, Ronald Stabile and John Beaulieu on Dec. 11, the day before rehearsals began for the Christmas pops program. The musicians offered no explanation for their resignations, she said. ``I just no longer wanted to be part of an organization like that,'' Stabile said. Goneconto played the kettle drums for the orchestra, and the three others played an array of instruments, including triangle, marimba and cymbals.

DOC.HEAD: Newspapers, Broadcasters Clash With Aoun
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to insert Aoun's statement to editors, recasts to move up reference to broadcasters, corrects spelling of impostor; Picks up 11th graf, `The leftist ...'
DOC.TEXT: Lebanese media today clashed with Christian Gen. Michel Aoun over his ban on recognizing President Elias Hrawi, with newspapers and broadcasters calling a news strike in protest of his orders. Aoun, who does not recognize the president or government chosen under an Arab-brokered peace accord, issued a directive Tuesday threatening to punish news organizations if they refer to the Syrian-backed Hrawi as president and to Salim Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, as prime minister. The army command of Gen. Emile Lahoud, which is loyal to Hrawi, quickly responded by warning the media against applying Aoun's directive or reporting any of his activity, terming him ``an impostor.'' The conservative daily Ad-Diyar defied Aoun's ban in a front-page editorial by publisher-editor Charles Ayoub. Following Aoun's instructions, he wrote, would mean ``suffocation ... it is a serious beginning to limit the freedom of the press.'' Ayoub's article was repeatedly broadcast by Moslem radio stations operating in west Beirut, which is outside Aoun's control. Aoun's 20,000 troops control the 310-square-mile Christian enclave which includes Beirut's eastern sector and a narrow strip northeast of the capital. The nation's most prestigious newspaper An-Nahar, based in Moslem west Beirut, failed to publish in an apparent protest of the ban. And Christian radio and television stations observed a news strike for a second day to express rejection of Aoun's orders, but have avoided a direct confrontation with him. Aoun, in a statement released by his office, said Attorney General Joseph Fraiha was instructed to take ``legal action'' against Ad-Diyar, which operates in an area controlled by Aoun's troops. The short statement did not clarify what legal action would be taken, but Aoun told newspaper editors Tuesday that violators of his instructions would be ``dealt with legally not under the press law but under the (criminal) code.'' The leftist As-Safir, which publishes in Syrian-policed west Beirut, said Aoun was placing ``freedom of the press under house arrest.'' A front-page banner headline said Aoun's directive was ``another separationist decision'' by the 54-year-old general who has refused to acknowledge the election of Hrawi as president by parliamentarians Nov. 24. Aoun, who was appointed by former President Amin Gemayel as head of an interim military cabinet Sept. 22, 1988, has declared the nation's one-chamber house dissolved to prevent the election of a pro-Syrian head of state. The general is on a crusade to drive from Lebanon the 40,000 Syrian troops that control much of the countryside, making Damascus the main power broker in Lebanon. Aoun's opponents said his decision to dissove Parliament was unconstitutional, noting that only a president has the right to dissolve the legislature. In addition to Ad-Diyar, four other daily papers publish in the Christian enclave and six in Beirut's Moslem Western sector. The conservative daily Al-Anwar, based in Beirut's Christian suburb of Hazmiyeh near Aoun's headquarters, followed the general's instructions. The Voice of Lebanon radio of the rightist Phalange Party and the Voice of Free Lebanon of the Christian Lebanese Forces militia did not report news for the second straight day in another apparent protest. The Lebanese Broadcasting Corp., the television station of the Lebanese Forces, also suspended its newscasts Monday. The three Christian news organizations said they were considering Aoun's directive. The strike and Ad-Diyar's defiance of Aoun reflected a growing split within Christian ranks over an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end the 14-year-old Moslem-Christian civil war that has killed more than 150,000 lives. Hrawi was elected president under the peace plan, worked out by Lebanese legislators in Saudi Arabia. The internationally recognized Hrawi immediately dismissed Aoun as prime minister and army commander, but the defiant general held out in the Christian enclave, refusing to hand over the presidential palace to Hrawi.

DOC.HEAD: Affidavit: IRA Suspect Claimed Link to Thatcher Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A suspected Irish Republican Army terrorist bragged that the group's next target would be British helicopters once it had control of a Stinger anti-aircraft missile, according to court papers. Kevin McKinley, who also allegedly told federal undercover agents that his group was responsible for a 1984 assassination attempt against British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and other bombings, was arrested Friday in a Palm Beach parking lot as he tried to wedge a 5-foot Stinger missile in his car. Three other men were also arrested. The four remained in prison today after a bail hearing was postponed until Friday at the request of both sides. ``All have a viable defense and it will be pursued to the highest degree,'' said Roger Colton, a lawyer for McKinley, 33; Seamus Moley, 30 and Joseph McColgan, 39, all Irish citizens. Colton would not give details of a possible defense but said entrapment is ``a possible avenue.'' Co-defendant Sean McCann, 34, a Canadian, was represented by attorney Michael Salnick. Agents posing as arms dealers arrested the men shortly after Moley handed over $47,500 for a hand-held Stinger missile and McKinley was taken to a West Palm Beach warehouse to inspect the weapon, authorities said. Agents had planned to follow McKinley from the warehouse, but he was arrested on the spot after he discovered the Stinger did not fit in his car, the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said Tuesday. The three other men were arrested in North Palm Beach, about 65 miles north of Miami. The Stinger, which weighs about 35 pounds, is used to launch a single surface-to-air missile. The weapon was on loan from the Marines and had no warhead. McKinley said the Stinger was to be used by the provisional wing of the IRA against British helicopters in Northern Ireland, according to court papers filed by Customs and ATF. McKinley also told agents ``his people'' were responsible for a 1984 bombing of a hotel in Brighton, England. The IRA claimed responsibility for the bombing, which killed five people, including two senior Conservative Party figures. Mrs. Thatcher escaped unharmed. During several meetings from Nov. 20 to Jan. 12, the suspects also said they were seeking .50-caliber rifles, C-4 explosives and grenade launchers. All are charged with violations of the Arms Export Control Act and Neutrality Law and other weapons violations. Assistant U.S. Attorney Barbara Patras said they each could receive up to 30 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines if convicted. The IRA, a mainly Roman Catholic guerrilla group outlawed in Britain and Ireland, is fighting to end British rule over Northern Ireland and unite it with the Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Leader Says Group Must Keep Up Military, Political Pressure
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Walter Sisulu today said the group should increase its military and political pressure in the fight against apartheid, although racial tensions are easing in South Africa. Sisulu told about 1,000 exiled ANC members that they should work toward negotiations with the South African government but pursue their armed struggle to maintain pressure for rapid change of racial laws and societal structures. Sisulu and seven ANC colleagues, all of whom served lengthy prison terms in South Africa, are on a visit to Lusaka, the guerrilla movement's exile headquarters. They came to help coordinate ANC strategy in the face of a fast-changing political climate in South Africa. The ANC's political and military wings, and the international community, should ``intensify the struggle against apartheid, even though there may be an easing of tensions at home,'' Sisulu said. ``The political struggle and the armed struggle go side by side,'' he said. The 60- and 70-year-old men received a rousing welcome from the ANC members who chanted, sang freedom songs and gave clenched fist salutes. The hall was draped in the green, black and gold banners of the ANC, and many members wore ANC scarves. Since South African President F.W. de Klerk assumed power in August, he has allowed opposition groups to protest openly and has urged negotiations on a new constitution that would include a political voice for the black majority. But de Klerk says the ANC, the main group fighting to undermine the white government, must commit itself to peaceful solutions and end its military campaign before participating in negotiations. The ANC says the government must lift the state of emergency, legalize the ANC, and end trials and hangings of guerrillas before talks begin. Sisulu and his colleagues campaign openly for their organization in South Africa, but the ANC remains outlawed. Sisulu praised the ANC and its ally, the South African Communist Party, for ``taking the initiative'' and setting down conditions for talks. The ANC has an estimated 15,000 members, many of whom are at guerrilla camps in Tanzania and Uganda. The organization has no offices or military bases in countries bordering South Africa, but it has millions of supporters inside the country. The ANC meetings occur amid widespread speculation that the group's best known figure, Nelson Mandela, will be freed within weeks after more than 27 years behind bars. Mandela and the recently released ANC leaders no longer hold formal titles in the organization, and leadership is a major issue facing the organization. The current president, Oliver Tambo, 71, is in a Swedish clinic recovering from a stroke. Sisulu said he intends to visit him before returning home. The ANC in Tanzania said the leaders were expected there Jan. 23.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Says Human Rights Improvements in Korea Reversed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to INSERT accusations in South Korean media today. Pickup 6th graf, `Some alleged...'
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International today accused South Korea of reversing a two-year trend of human rights improvements, citing mass arrests and the reported torture of prisoners. The worldwide human rights organization said 800 political and trade union activists have been arrested in major cities in a crackdown on political opposition by President Roh Tae-Woo's government. Thousands more were briefly detained for participating in demonstrations or industrial strikes, the London-based group said, and leading dissidents and students leaders went into hiding to escape arrest. Kwang Sik Kim, press attache at the South Korean Embassy in London, said officials had not seen the report and could not comment on it. In South Korea today, several newspapers quoted unidentified government intelligence officials who accused North Korea of holding more than 150,000 political prisoners in concentration camps called ``dictatorial districts.'' ``The situation (in North Korea) is much worse than that of the notorious Stalinist era in the Soviet Union,'' the national Yonhap news agency quoted one official as saying. In April, South Korea banned from political activity people with ``unacceptable views'' on reunification with North Korea or labor activities. Amnesty said many people who have since been arrested were denied regular access to lawyers and relatives. Some alleged they were tortured or ill-treated. Amnesty said the arrests reverse a trend in human rights improvements that had resulted in presidential amnesties in 1987 and 1988 and the release of more than 1,000 political prisoners. Hundreds of prisoners were believed being held for political reasons at the end of 1989, and another 200 political prisoners have been held for between one and 39 years, the group said. It called for the release of 100 prisoners of conscience believed to have been arrested for the nonviolent exercise of their fundamental rights. Amnesty alleged that Roh's government has done little to review the cases of long-term political prisoners or to investigate human rights abuses under the previous government. It said the majority of political prisoners have been charged with ``anti-state activities'' under the National Security Law that provides for long sentences for illegal travel to North Korea, contact with groups supporting North Korea or even possessing books about or from North Korea. ``The mere fact of traveling to North Korea, without evidence either of espionage activities or of the use of advocacy of violence cannot justify imprisonment,'' Amnesty said. The report said many of South Korea's 200 long-term prisoners were convicted of being North Korean spies or agents. It said the definition of espionage is so broad that some may actually be prisoners of conscience. The country's National Assembly discussed amendments to the law in 1989 but no changes were made, Amnesty said. The group said it was also concerned about reports of torture and ill-treatment of prisoners, despite government measures to prevent torture after the death of a student under torture in January 1987. It said prosecution authorities investigating allegations of torture made by several former political prisoners have begun judicial proceedings against police officers for assault in only one case. Amnesty said seven prisoners were executed last year in a bid to curb an increase in violent crime, after two years of no executions.

DOC.HEAD: Two Sailors Slain at Navy Base in Latest Seattle-Area Shootings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf pvs, `Hoyer's practice ...' to DELETE extraneous `Friedman.'
DOC.TEXT: Two sailors were found shot to death in the bachelor enlisted quarters of a tightly guarded Trident submarine base, the Navy said. The shootings were the latest in a string of apparently unrelated slayings in the Puget Sound area since Sunday in which eight people were killed. The sailors' bodies were found Tuesday morning at the Bangor base on Hood Canal. The victims' names were being withheld pending notification of families. The enlisted quarters are in the base's community area, along with family housing and recreational facilities. Law enforcement officers and the Naval Investigative Service were investigating the slayings, the Navy said. Also Tuesday, a clerk was killed and another seriously wounded when someone walked into their Bremerton pawn shop and shot them, police said. No money was taken and the only thing believed missing was a handgun, said Capt. Dennis Plumb. Julie Michaels, 32, was killed. Her brother, Alan, 35, was in critical condition today at Harrison Hospital in Bremerton. Bremerton and the Trident base are on the Kitsap Peninsula west of Seattle. On Monday, two Seattle lawyers were found shot to death in a house they were fixing up just south of the city. Capt. T. Michael Nault, King County police major crimes commander, said the lawyers were not killed at random and that at least one of the victims might have known the assailant or assailants, the Seattle Post-Intelligencer reported today. The county medical examiner's office said the two, Eric A. Hoyer, 34, and Steven M. Dorobis, about 36, were killed sometime Sunday. Hoyer's practice was mostly commercial law, but he also handled some family law cases, said Peter Friedman, a law partner of Hoyer's. Dorobis practiced general law, said a receptionist. In other incidents, a Seattle homeowner killed a man and wounded another in a shootout with intruders who broke into his home Sunday, police said. The homeowner was wounded in the hand. Two brothers were killed, a third brother was injured and a fourth man held for investigation of homicide and assault in a shooting spree Sunday outside an apartment complex in Des Moines, south of Seattle. Police said they believe the shootings may have been the work of a jealous boyfriend.

DOC.HEAD: Head of State Security Service Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The chief of state security has resigned following allegations that his agency illegally monitored opposition activities, the official MTI news agency reported today. The report did not say when Jozsef Horvath resigned. Horvath, in a letter sent recently to Interior Minister Istvan Horvath, asked to be relieved of his post because of the ``loss of confidence in the service and in himself,'' MTI said. The two men are not related. Horvath rejected allegations that his service carried out illegal activities, including monitoring of opposition leaders as they prepare for elections March 25. Leaders of the League of Free Democrats and the Alliance of Young Democrats last week showed reporters copies of documents they said belonged to the Interior Ministry's State Security Service containing information on their organizations and their campaign strategies. The opposition leaders refused to say where or how they acquired the documents. Jozsef Horvath said the loss of public confidence would do ``great damage'' to the secret service operations in the future. ``I deem it unfair that at the very beginning of the investigations we were subject to prejudice and were pronounced guilty,'' he said in the letter, according to MTI. The opposition groups said they had asked the state prosecutor's office to launch an investigation and criminal proceedings against ``persons unknown'' for violating the constitution and the penal code. Hungary's security organs regularly monitored dissident activities during four decades of Communist rule. In October, the Communist Party formally disbanded, reconstituting itself as the Hungarian Socialist Party and aspiring to democratic ideals. Parliament rewrote the constitution to incorporate multiparty democracy and adopt laws allowing several parties to contest this year's elections.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Protester Freed After Year in Jail
DOC.TEXT: An abortion protester who faced no more than 30 days in jail but wound up spending a year behind bars because he wouldn't give his name has been released, his identity still in question. ``I did what I think was right,'' the man, who has identified himself only as Baby John Doe, told Judge Randall Nichols at a hearing Tuesday in which he won his freedom. Nicholls ordered the protester, who had been in custody since his arrest exactly year ago for blocking the doors to a Knoxville health clinic, to pay $12,547 to the county for the cost of jailing him. The protester said he hoped his demonstration to make abortion illegal in Tennessee had advanced his cause. ``Maybe not (with) the Legislature,'' he said, ``but the hearts of some people.'' The protester was charged with criminal trespassing after refusing to leave the clinic during a protest by the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue. The charge carried up to 30 days in jail. Nichols convicted him in September but refused to impose the sentence until the man, who was booked as Baby John Doe and is reportedly 25 years old and from out of state, identified himself. On Tuesday, Assistant District Attorney David Jennings recounted his office's unsuccessful efforts to determine the man's identity and said a guard at the penal farm where the man was held told authorities his name might be Gary Christopher. When asked if that was his name, the protester said, ``I cannot comment on that, sir.'' The judge agreed to release the man under the names Baby John Doe and Gary Christopher, saying his decision was affected by nightly questions from his 8-year-old son on the protester's fate, letters from all over the United States on his behalf and overcrowding in the county jail. Asked how the court will be able to track down the man if he fails to pay the $12,547, the judge said it was a valid question. ``I would hope to be able to use the powers of the state of Tennessee to find out,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: A Fresh Start is Demanded _ But Costly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS word to environmentalists sted environments in pvs 5th graf, Now environmnents
DOC.TEXT: A quarter of Poland's farmland is so polluted with lead, zinc, cadmium and mercury that it might be dangerous to grow vegetables in it. Ninety-five percent of the country's rivers are undrinkable _ and half so toxic that the water can't even be used in industry for fear of destroying equipment. In Hungary, air pollution accounts for one in 17 deaths. A quarter to a third of the forests in four of the six countries of Eastern Europe show signs of dying from air pollution. Small wonder then, say American environmentalists, that in the upheavals which have thrown out the old regimes of Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Romania one of the persistent demands has been for environmental repair. ``Pollution was part and parcel of the system that molested the people in their daily lives,'' says Jeffrey Leonard of the World Wildlife Fund, author of several books on Eastern Europe's pollution problems. Now environmentalists take hope that the new leaders of Eastern Europe _ site of some of the world's worst pollution _ will seek to alleviate the conditions which are turning their countries to ruin and threatening the health of the people. ``Environmental conditions are so bad they affect the very possibility of having economic growth,'' said Jessica Tuchman Mathews of World Resources Institute, a research organization. ``How does a country rebuild a shattered economy when it can't breathe its air, till its soil or drink its water?'' Said Richard Liroff, director of the Eastern European Environmental Affairs Program of the Conservation Foundation, ``People there are saying, `We've had enough. Our health is being threatened, our lungs damaged, our forests destroyed, our children harmed by lead and heavy metals in the environment.''' But the question remains whether East Europeans, having to cope with unemployment, inflation and bankruptcy as they move toward market economies, will be tempted to put environmental concerns aside as they struggle to remodel their economies and political structures. ``They're going to have to make some extremely hard choices,'' said Liroff. ``A lot of their industry, especially in Poland, is antiquated. Rather than trying to place pollution control equipment on it, it might be better to shut it down entirely and eventually replace it with modern equipment that is energy and resource efficient and doesn't pollute as much. But that means unemployment. Is society willing to accept that cost? I just don't know.'' Civic Forum, which formed the basis of the new government of Czechoslovakia, appeared to provide its answer in laying out its program for the nation last fall. ``We all must seek a method of restoring harmony between man and his environment,'' Civic Forum said. ``We will strive (for) a gradual repairing of the damage which has been inflicted upon nature during recent decades. ... We are aware that this will mean sacrifices on the part of all of us. This will require a change in value scales and lifestyles.'' Said playwright Vaclav Havel upon taking office as the new Czech president: ``We have laid waste to our soil and the rivers and the forests that our forefathers bequeathed to us, and we have the worst environment in the whole of Europe today. Adults in our country die earlier than in most other European countries.'' William Chandler, senior scientist with Battelle's Pacific Northwest Laboratories, and he is confident the Poles will make the sacrifices necessary to build an energy-efficient and environmentally clean industrial plant for its future. U.S. environmentalists say the attempt to combat the air pollution that leads to global warming could be undermined unless the pollution of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union is curtailed. ``What happens in Eastern Europe is very important for global warming because they burn so much coal,'' said Liroff. ``The Eastern European countries need to be put on an energy diet in much the same way as the United States and other industrialized nations need to be put on one.''

DOC.HEAD: Boulder County Commissioner Says She'll Run for Senate
DOC.TEXT: Boulder County Commissioner Josie Heath, an activist in women's organizations, has become the third person seeking the Democratic nomination for the U.S. Senate seat being vacated by Republican Bill Armstrong. Heath, 52, announced Tuesday that she will run this year. Former state Democratic party leader Buie Seawell and Alamosa lawyer Carlos Lucero also are campaigning for the Democratic nomination. Rep. Hank Brown is the only Republican seeking the Senate seat. ``We will be discussing critical environmental issues, jobs and the economy, improving education, and the important issues affecting families and children,'' Heath said. Heath is in her eighth year as Boulder County commissioner. She is a former high school teacher, community college administrator and regional director for ACTION, which includes the Peace Corps, VISTA and senior citizens programs. She was chairwoman of the Colorado Commission on Women and a founder of Colorado and Boulder County women's organizations. Armstrong has said he is leaving after two terms to return to private life and devote himself to religious activities and family. Tim Wirth, a Democrat, is Colorado's other senator.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Parties to Be Formally Legalized
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's Communist government said today that it will ask Parliament to approve legislation that would legalize opposition parties. The proposal would allow independent political parties and citizens' associations to register with authorities to gain official recognition, the state-run Tanjug news agency reported. But groups ``advocating the violent overthrow of the constitution, violations of ... guaranteed human rights, or spreading national and religious hatred'' still would be prohibited, according to the draft law. Tanjug did not say when the draft would be submitted to Parliament. Prime Minister Ante Markovic, who has moved to introduce sweeping market-oriented economic reforms since he took office in March, has said he also wants democratic reforms in Yugoslavia. Earlier this month, the Communist leadership announced the nation's first free parliamentary elections in 45 years, tentatively scheduled for April 8-12. When they came to power in 1945, the Communists abolished all opposition parties. But last month the party leadership unveiled a draft declaration that pledges full support for the establishment of a multiparty parliamentary system. The Communist Party is to adopt the declaration at a national congress on Saturday. Despite a lack of official recognition, several dozen political parties and independent citizens' groups have been formed over the past 18 months. The liberal leadership of Yugoslavia's northern state of Slovenia has led the drive for democratic reforms. Communist hard-liners in some southern regions, particularly Serbia, at first strongly opposed the drive but later gave their support for reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Man Overpowered Aboard Airliner After Demanding to be Flown to Cuba
Ed: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with comments from suspect to reporters. PICKS UP 6th graf, `Authorities said ...'
LaserPhotos AT3,4
DOC.TEXT: A man claiming he had a bomb tried to hijack a jetliner to Cuba but was overpowered by a police officer who sneaked up an escape chute after the plane made an emergency landing, authorities said. No one was seriously hurt late Tuesday during the America West flight that was supposed to fly non-stop from Houston to Las Vegas. The Boeing 737 carrying 39 people landed in Austin shortly before midnight after the pilot told the would-be hijacker the plane needed to refuel, authorities said. Passenger Robert Martin said the man had been sitting two rows in front of him, complaining loudly about American TV programs. Authorities identified the man as Jose Manuel Gonzalez-Gonzalez, a 39-year-old Cuban native who lives in New Orleans. FBI agent Byron Sage said he expected the man to be charged with air piracy and kidnapping. Gonzalez-Gonzalez told reporters as he was being put in a police car that he tried to hijack the plane because he thought he was in danger ``because of my political beliefs.'' When asked what those beliefs were, he said, ``I feel this country is in peril.'' He was driven away before he could comment further. Authorities said police Capt. Lloyd Polk climbed into the jetliner after Gonzalez-Gonzalez released the 34 passengers and three of the five crew members, allowing them to slide down an emergency chute to freedom. Polk said he had hoped to negotiate with the man. But once inside, Polk said, it appeared that a flight attendant was in danger. ``I saw he had the stewardess so I took action immediately,'' Polk said today. ``I had a struggle with him, but I was able to hold him to the ground until more help arrived.'' No bomb was found. Several passengers said it appeared the man carried a flashlight and a rope, which he used to choke flight attendant Stacy Wood, 26. The attempted hijacking of Flight 727 began after takeoff when Gonzalez-Gonzalez grabbed Ms. Wood and took her to the rear, announcing he had a bomb and wanted to fly to Cuba, police said. The other passengers were ordered to the front. The pilot, Capt. Dick Nelson, told Gonzalez-Gonzalez he had to land at Austin's Robert Mueller Municipal Airport to refuel. Nelson, who helped Polk as he entered the plane, said the officer tackled Gonzalez-Gonzalez, striking him with either a flashlight or nightstick. Ms. Wood and another flight attendant were treated at a hospital for minor injuries and released. Gonzalez-Gonzalez was taken to a hospital for treatment of cuts to his head suffered when he was arrested, said city emergency services shift commander Bob Gutierrez. Crew members and passengers said Gonzalez-Gonzalez appeared extremely agitated before and during the flight. Martin, 24, of Fontana, Calif., said Gonzalez-Gonzalez had been a nuisance at the terminal in Houston and several passengers complained to airline officials about him. Another passenger, Herb Atwood of Cold Spring, said Gonzalez-Gonzalez had been acting strangely. ``You always hear about this,'' he said. ``And I never thought it would happen to me. I was scared like everyone else. I was looking forward to a trip to Vegas. But my gambling ended before it started.'' The passengers were put up in a hotel and were to be flown out later.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Suspected Liberian Rebels Arrested in Ivory Coast
DOC.TEXT: Thirty men suspected of being part of a band of rebels that launched attacks in Liberia have been arrested in neighboring Ivory Coast, a newspaper said today. The Daily Observer said the suspected rebels were arrested in the town of Danane, 25 miles from Liberia's border. The story quoted unidentified diplomats as saying the men were being questioned in Abidjan, capital of Ivory Coast. Fighting was first reported in Liberia's northeastern Nimba County on Dec. 24, after Liberian officials said about 100 dissidents entered the country from Ivory Coast in an attempt to overthrow the government. An estimated 20,000 Liberians have fled to Guinea and Ivory Coast since then to escape fighting. Ivorian President Felix Houphouet-Boigny said this month that 8,000 to 10,000 Liberians had entered his country. Liberian authorities say rebels killed about 200 people, including 16 government officials, before troops brought the situation under control. However, the human rights organizations Amnesty International and Africa Watch have accused Liberian soldiers of killing unarmed civilians during the unrest. Jenkin Scott, Liberia's justice minister, admitted last week that soldiers had killed civilians but said they acted in self-defense. Daniel Sio, chief of the small Liberian border town of Butuo, where rebels first attacked, told the Observer a different story. Sio said troops rounded up all local officials on arrival and accused them of failing to repulse the rebels. Then the soldiers opened fire and set the town on fire, he was quoted as saying. Sio, who was shot in the right leg, was left for dead and later fled to Ivory Coast, the Observer said. The United States on Tuesday expressed concern over the civilian casualties caused by the dissidents and the troops. The West African nation of Liberia was founded in 1847 by freed American slaves and maintains strong cultural and economic ties with United States. Liberia's military placed Nimba County under a state of emergency and last week evacuated about 5,000 people from the village of Karnplay and surrounding areas, where the fighting was heaviest. The dissidents, who call themselves the Liberian Patriotic Front, are led by Charles Taylor, a former Liberian civil servant. Taylor said Tuesday his fighters had launched a new offensive but gave no indication of its size. President Samuel Doe, a former master sergeant who seized power in a 1980 bloody coup, has accused Ivory Coast of harboring the dissidents, a charge Ivory Coast denies.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Hunters Describe Family's Searches
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `This is ...' to CLARIFY that Delonis was quoted last week.
DOC.TEXT: The grandsons of a prospector killed in 1949 in a dispute over a buried treasure plan to resume the search in what is now an Army missile range. Even if it proves to be fool's gold, Terry and James Delonis hope their as yet unscheduled expedition will remove the stigma attached to their family for 30 years. ``This is more exciting than I can describe,'' Terry Delonis said last week. The Delonises' grandfather, Milton E. ``Doc'' Noss, claimed to have discovered a cache of gold bullion and coins inside a cavern on Victorio Peak while he, his wife and some friends were hunting deer in 1937. Noss and his wife, Ova, said they made several efforts to recover the gold but accidentally sealed the entrance while trying to expand it. During World War II, the Army took over the area, and it now lies on the restricted White Sands Missile Range. Noss was shot to death during an argument with a backer in a treasure hunt in 1949. Ova Noss died in 1979, but the grandsons plan to continue the quest for the fabled treasure. The brothers said they grew up hearing tales of the buried treasure from their grandmother, who told the stories in great detail. ``She also had a good mind for numbers,'' James Delonis said. ``She could recall depths, distances, degrees, etc.'' The Army allowed a professional treasure-hunting company, Expeditions Unlimited of Florida, onto the range in 1977. The company, which represented several claimants to the treasure, found nothing, but said ground radar did indicated a cavern beneath the peak. The company, headed by Norman Scott, ran out of time before the cavern could be excavated. Two previous searches also failed to turn up any gold, and the Army said after the 1977 hunt that the range would be closed to searchers. But Rep. Joe Skeen, R-N.M., sponsored an amendment to the 1989 Defense Authorization Act to allow Noss family heirs to dig for the legendary treasure, although they must pay the expenses. Skeen said anything found would be turned over to the courts to decide ownership. The brothers hired Expeditions Unlimited to head the operation, and announced they have formed a foundation to help in searching for the treasure. Terry Delonis said recent ground radar readings again revealed a cavern in the same place indicated by the 1977 expedition. No date for the search has been announced. But the Army has agreed to take reporters to the site Jan. 25. The gold, according to various stories, was said to have been stored in the peak by Spanish conquistadores who mined it nearby, or was loot gathered by the Apache Chief Victorio, for whom the mountain was named. Some have contended the federal government found and removed the gold years ago, but the Army has denied those stories.

DOC.HEAD: Drop in 1989 Domestic Oil Output Called Largest Ever
DOC.TEXT: Domestic oil production in 1989 took the steepest yearly fall in history, and petroleum imports rose to a 10-year high, the industry said today. The American Petroleum Institute, the trade association of the major oil companies, also said that while U.S. oil consumption increased only slightly, imports rose to 46 percent of total supplies. That was the second-highest level on record. The figures confirm a continued decline of the domestic oil industry and are expected to add heat to a debate in Congress this year over whether exploration and production companies should get new tax breaks to stimulate drilling activity. The Bush administration has argued that declining U.S. oil production and increasing reliance on foreign producers is undermining national energy security. In its year-end report, the petroleum institute said U.S. crude oil production averaged 7.6 million barrels a day in 1989. That was the lowest in 26 years and a decline of 553,000 barrels per day, or 6.8 percent, from the 1988 total. Alaskan oil production, which had increased almost every year since the start of production from the huge Prudhoe Bay field in 1977, fell by 140,000 barrels per day in 1989. The report said the Alaska decline was exaggerated by maintenance work and traffic restrictions following the Exxon Valdez oil tanker spill last March, and that the ``underlying decline trend'' in Alaska was about 100,000 barrels per day. Oil imports rose to 7.9 million barrels a day last year, up 8.2 percent from 1988 and nearly 60 percent above the 1985 level, when imports sank to a low of 5 million barrels a day before prices collapsed on the world market in 1986. The report said that while imports from Western Hemisphere sources still accounted for about 43 percent of total imports in 1989, imports from the Persian Gulf continued to grow to 21 percent of the total. Total imports accounted for 46 percent of oil consumed in the United States last year. That was the second-highest ever, after the 47.7 percent level of 1977. As recently as 1985, imports' share of domestic consumption was only 31.5 percent. The rise in total U.S. energy consumption last year slowed to 1.9 percent after increases of 3.5 percent in 1987 and 4.0 percent in 1988, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Criticizes Shamir's Claim to West Bank, Gaza
DOC.TEXT: Yasser Arafat today denounced a statement by Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir that Israel must retain the West Bank and Gaza Strip to settle Jews from the Soviet Union as ``racist and expansionist.'' In Jerusalem today, Vice Premier Shimon Peres prepared for a meeting with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak in Cairo next week in an effort to break the stalemate in Middle East peace efforts, a Peres aide said. Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said Shamir's claim on the status of the occupied territories poses a threat to Palestinians, Arabs and the international community. ``We (the Palestinians) are going on with our resistance to the Israeli occupation ... but it is a challenge to all Arabs which we should confront,'' Arafat told The Associated Press. Shamir declared Monday that Israel needs to retain the West Bank and Gaza, the focal points of the Middle East conflict, to settle an influx of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union. ``For a large immigration we need the Land of Israel, a great and strong Israel,'' Shamir told the Likud. ``We will need a lot of place to absorb everybody.'' The term ``Land of Israel is used by members of the right-wing Likud bloc in references to Israel and the occupied territories, which were captured from Jordan and Egypt by Israel in 1967. Arafat said Shamir's statement clearly demonstrates Israel's ambitions and Shamir's unwillingness to accept a peace settlement. ``This reveals the true, ugly face of Israel which wants to swallow more land and reject all peace efforts,'' Arafat added, calling Shamir's statement ``impudent, racist and expansionist.'' Arafat claimed Shamir's latest statement and his rejection of a PLO role in peace talks reflect a crisis in Israeli policy toward peace efforts in the Middle East. ``Shamir is swimming against the tide of history. He doesn't understand new developments in the world ... he cannot go on with his occupation of our land,'' Arafat said. He also lashed out at the United States for its support of Israel and alleged failure to pressure Shamir to get involved in a peace process in the Middle East. ``Without American support ... Shamir wouldn't have dared to make such a statement'' on the status of the territories, Arafat said. The U.S. State Department said Tuesday it had asked Israel to explain Shamir's comment that the occupied territories should be used to settle Jews from the Soviet Union. The meeting between Peres and Mubarak on Jan. 24 will be the first top-level encounter between Israeli and Egyptian officials since Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin held talks with Mubarak in Cairo in September. Peres spokesman Avi Gil said the Middle East peace process will be at the top of the agenda. He refused to elaborate, saying only: ``When you're in Egypt, you don't just talk about the pyramids.'' U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker is urging three-way peace talks that would include the foreign ministers of Egypt, the United States and Israel as the first step toward organizing elections among Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Since the Palestinian uprising in the occupied lands began 25 months ago, Israelis have killed 648 Palestinians, Palestinian vigilantes have killed 170 fellow Arabs suspected of cooperating with Israel, and 43 Israelis have died.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Bush-State of the Union, 1st Ld-Writethru, a0421,630
DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush Offers Sneak Previews of State of the Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, The president, to CORRECT speech site to Atlanta sted Orlando
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is offering sneak previews of his maiden State of the Union address in speeches and appearances around the country that seek to highlight his agenda for ``a world at peace.'' Bush has been laying down the basic themes that aides say he will sound in the annual presidential speech to a joint House-Senate session on the evening of Jan. 31. He highlighted key domestic priorities _ strengthening the Clean Air Act, a lower capital gains tax, the war on drugs and crime, education and an overhaul of farm programs _ in a kickoff speech last week to the American Farm Bureau in Orlando, Fla. A few days later, Bush's address to the Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce laid down his basic defense position: he would not ``naively cut the muscle out of our defense posture'' despite a relaxation of tensions in Eastern Europe. Bush said Congress shouldn't expect a ``peace dividend'' as some Democrats have urged, in which military savings can be diverted directly into domestic programs. The president is to further outline his agenda for 1990 in a speech on Friday to the National Association of Homebuilders in Atlanta. He also has been staging events to bolster selected parts of his program _ for instance, Tuesday's unannounced visit with Housing Secretary Jack Kemp to a public housing development to push his war on drugs and his proposal to make it easier for public housing residents to buy their dwellings. The president today was spotlighting his anti-crime program at a luncheon with law enforcement agencies. And, he has clearly set the stage for confrontations with the Democratic-led Congress. Although he has vowed to repeat the offer of an extended hand to Congress, made in his inaugural last year, th president complained in Orlando about Democratic ``demagogues'' who oppose his capital gains cut. And he told the Chamber of Commerce in Cincinnati that many of his first-year programs remain ``bogged down in the jungles of Capitol Hill.'' Bush also has saluted developments in Eastern Europe, praised U.S. troops who fought in Panama, talked about the ``daybreak of a new decade'' and reveled over ``the opportunity and optimism of a world at peace.'' Bush's speeches leading up to the State of the Union address are largely focusing on ``the issues that remain unfinished in some cases from last year's legislative session,'' said White House communications director David Demarest. But the State of the Union is likely to be more forward-looking and expressed in more lofty language. The president won't have to share the billing when he delivers that address. But that wasn't so on Tuesday when he and Kemp dropped by the public housing development in Alexandria. The president sat mostly impassive as Kemp delivered a long and impassioned exposition on public housing, the drug problem, community involvement, the desirability of home ownership and the civil rights movement. When the housing secretary finally yielded the floor, Bush observed: ``When the Berlin Wall came down, they said I wasn't enthusiastic enough.'' ``How do you follow this?'' Bush asked, pointing at Kemp. A community activist complained of a lack of funds for fighting drug pushers. Kemp reached into his wallet and jokingly held out a wad of bills. And, as he took one question after the other, Kemp kept patting the president, seated beside him, on the sleeve. When the former Buffalo Bills quarterback, former House member and unsuccessful 1988 Republican presidential contender finally got around to introducing Bush, he began: ``Ladies and gentlemen, the next president ...'' Kemp stopped mid-sentence, looked at Bush and laughed at his mistake. Then, he added quickly: ``I used to be `the next president' one time, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Foreman Selected in Trial of John Who?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `He told ...' to CORRECT that Super Bowl is Jan. 28.
DOC.TEXT: A prospective juror in the assault trial of reputed organized crime boss John Gotti said she thought she was being called to judge the case of subway gunman Bernhard Goetz. ``You mean you confused Mr. Gotti with Mr. Goetz?'' Bruce Cutler, Gotti's lawyer, asked the young woman, who appeared to be in her 20s. ``Yes,'' she said, adding that she has lived in New York about five years. She was dismissed Tuesday, as were all but one of the 21 potential jurors who participated in the session. Their names were kept confidential. Chosen as foreman was a high school teacher who appeared to be in his 40s and who said he was aware of Gotti's ``notoriety'' and alleged involvement in crime. He will be sequestered immediately and remain in court custody _ sleeping in motels _ until trial's end, said the trial judge, Acting State Supreme Court Justice Edward McLaughlin. The juror, selected at the end of the day, said Gotti impressed him as ``dignified'' and a sharp dresser. McLaughlin told the rest of the pool of about 170 that he expects to complete jury selection by Thursday and that there will be Saturday sessions. He told them he will permit the sequestered panel to have a party with soft drinks and popcorn after the Super Bowl on Jan. 28. Gotti, 49, and co-defendant Anthony Guerrieri, 60, are being tried on assault and conspiracy charges in connection with the shooting of John F. O'Connor, vice president of Carpenters Union Local 608. Prosecutors say the defendants arranged the shooting because O'Connor allegedly ordered the trashing of a restaurant owned by a Gotti associate. If convicted, Gotti could receive a prison sentence of 25 years to life because of his felony record. One of those excused from the case was an actress, carrying a book of plays, who said it was ``God's will'' that she was called to serve on the jury of ``one of those Italian Mafia guys.'' ``I'm from California,'' the woman told McLaughlin. ``I knew that,'' the judge replied as he excused her from consideration.

DOC.HEAD: Two Mines Continue Strike as Polish Government Seeks Solution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD number of strikers, background on previous strikes. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A delegation of coal miners met with the finance minister today to discuss the demands of more than 6,000 striking miners, the PAP news agency said. Workers were striking at the Czerwone Zaglebie and Niwka Modrzejow mines near the industrial city of Katowice, 185 miles south of Warsaw, PAP reported. All 6,000 workers stayed off the job today at the Czerwone Zaglebie mine, and another 40 continued their strike at Niwka Modrzejow. But miners at two other locations near Walbrzych, a city 12 miles from the border with Czechoslovakia, suspended their strike because of the talks, the pro-Solidarity daily Gazeta Wyborcza said. A delegation of workers met with Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz in the morning in Warsaw, said Andrzej Moroz, a spokesman for Balcerowicz. He said details of the talks were not immediately available. The miners' main demand is higher pay, and the strike is the biggest over wages since radical reforms to introduce a market economy took effect in Poland on Jan. 1. Part of the plan calls for a tight wage policy to bring down inflation, which soared to about 900 percent last year after some price controls were lifted in August. Almost all the remaining price controls were lifted Jan. 1 and prices again are racing ahead of wages. Mine strikes late in the summer of 1988 led to widespread labor unrest that forced the Communist authorities who ruled at the time to start talks on political reform. The talks led to the legalization of Solidarity last year and to partially free elections in June. Solidarity's sweeping victory in those elections paved the wave for the election of Solidarity editor Tadeusz Mazowiecki as the first non-Communist head of government in 40 years.

DOC.HEAD: Scorer of `Twilight Zone,' Dozens of Film and TV Shows, Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to CLARIFY meaning of scoring a production; PICKS UP 11th graf, `Alexander was ...'
DOC.TEXT: Composer Jeff Alexander, who scored more than 40 movies and dozens of radio and television shows, including ``Singin' in the Rain,'' ``Gigi'' and ``The Twilight Zone,'' has died at 79. Alexander, who wrote or arranged background music, transitions between songs and other incidental music, died of cancer Dec. 23. The native of Seattle returned home in 1980 after his retirement from films and television to compose chamber pieces and a symphony. He lived on Whidbey Island northwest of Seattle. At the time of death, he was reworking a musical, ``The Children's Crusade,''' which he had begun in 1975 in collaboration with Yip Harburg and Larry Orenstein. He began his career as a teen-ager when he sang and danced on the vaudeville circuit. By his late teens, he was producing musical arrangements for several big bands. His first feature film arrangement was for ``Shall We Dance.'' His film-score credits included the Fred Astaire movie ``Shall We Dance,'' Elvis Presley's ``Jailhouse Rock'' and ``Kid Galahad,'' and the musicals ``Kismet'' and ``Seven Brides for Seven Brothers.'' In television, he scored such series as the ``Jimmy Stewart Show,'' ``Dr. Kildare'' and ``My Three Sons,'' in addition to ``The Twilight Zone.'' Alexander was one of the founders of the Screen Composer Guild and served two terms on the board of governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. He is survived by a daughter, Jill Alexander, of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Dies After Mauling from Grandson's Two Pit Bulls
DOC.TEXT: A 70-year-old woman died today after being mauled by her grandson's two pit bull terriers as she tried to feed them, authorities said. ``Both her arms had been chewed to the bone,'' said County-USC Medical Center spokeswoman Adelaida De La Cerda. Surgeons had amputated Marjee Lilly's left arm and operated on her right arm Tuesday. The dogs mauled Mrs. Lilly on Tuesday in the kitchen of her grandson's home, breaking off the attack when the grandson returned, police said. ``As Mrs. Lilly was attempting to feed the dogs, she was taking food out of a large 25-pound bag and the dogs became excited,'' said police Lt. Alan Kerstein. ``She apparently attempted to push them away or restrain them and they attacked.'' Mrs. Lilly, of San Diego, was visiting her grandson, Clarence Hubbard, 34, Kerstein said. Hubbard told officials he has owned the 14-month-old dogs, which weigh 45 to 50 pounds, since they were puppies and they had never attacked before. The animals were taken to an animal shelter, and Hubbard said he wanted them destroyed, Kerstein said. The lieutenant said it isn't illegal to own pit bulls, and the animals were on private property. ``We see no criminal aspect here.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Announce Formula For New Leadership
With PM-Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: Afghan rebels today announced a formula for a new leadership despite bitter divisions within their own ranks. The announcement coincided with U.S. Undersecretary of State Robert Kimmitt's three-day visit. He is the highest-ranking State Department official to visit Pakistan since February's Soviet troop withdrawal from neighboring Afghanistan. Rebel sources said the formula was an offering to Kimmitt, who was reportedly in Pakistan to take a new look at the politically troubled rebels. He is expected to meet the guerrilla leadership Thursday in Pakistan's rugged frontier city of Peshawar, 30 miles from the Afghan border. Abdul Rahim, a spokesman for a joint rebel news agency, said Kimmitt wanted something to give Secretary of State James A. Baker III to take to next month's meeting with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. The complicated formula provides for a grand council or ``shura'' of between 2,000 and 3,000 people selected from inside Afghanistan. These people will also represent the estimated 5 million Afghans living in squalid refugee camps in Pakistan and Iran. However, it does not allow for participation of Afghanistan's ruling Communists, something Moscow has repeatedly demanded. The grand council would then choose 200 to 300 people, who will form a national assembly or Parliament. The assembly, according to the formula, will select a new leadership or give a vote of confidence to the existing self-styled government, criticized for its bitter infighting and narrow composition. The renegade among the major rebel groups headquartered in Pakistan, Gulbaddin Hekmatyar's Hezb-i-Islami, rejected the formula, demanding elections. Other smaller groups also have denounced it. Nasrullah Mansoor, who represents a small guerrilla organization based in Pakistan, said his group as well as those headquartered in Iran want no part of the newly announced formula. A rebel source, who asked not to be identified, said the Iranian-based guerrillas rejected the formula because they had no part in its creation. Most war refugees living in Iran belong to Afghanistan's minority Shiite sect of Islam, which is practiced by most Iranians. Those in Pakistan are Sunni Moslems. The rebels, who have fought for 11 years to topple successive Communist governments in Kabul, formed their own government about a year ago. But it has been wracked by internal feuding, unable to entice the Iranian-based guerrillas or other minority groups to join. Afghan sources in Pakistan said the United States has come under heavy criticism for its support of this rebel government, which they charge was created by Washington and Islamabad.

DOC.HEAD: Child Submerged for 40 Minutes Listed in Critical Condition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, The boy, to delete repetitive matter and insert that incident was Monday
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old boy who was submerged in an icy pond for 40 minutes remained ``unconscious and unresponsive'' in critical condition today and his chances for survival were slim, doctors said. ``His heart and lung functions are improved somewhat but he is going through a period of brain swelling now, as was expected,'' Dr. Craig Futterman, a pediatric internist at Fairfax Hospital, said of George Sader. ``He has a 2 to 10 percent chance to survive at all and about a 2 percent chance to survive neurologically intact.'' The boy was playing on an ice-covered pond in Centreville, Va., with two older girls on Monday when he fell through a crack into six feet of water. Futterman said doctors would perform a CAT scan today to determine whether the boy suffered brain damage. There have been about two dozen reported cases of people surviving submersion in cold water for long periods, some up to an hour, officials said. Futterman said on NBC-TV's ``Today'' program this morning that the reason why some people survive and some don't remain unclear. But he said it is believed that the way people cool down is linked to their chances of survival. ``If the temperature of their tissues cools down to a very cold temperature prior to their heart stopping, it's felt that that's the most physiologic way to preserve those tissues,'' Futterman said. ``If, however, the heart stops prior to cooling down, then their chance of surviving are much lower.'' George, whose body temperature had dropped to 90 degrees, was in cardiac arrest when he arrived at the hospital and was hooked up to a heart-lung machine to warm his blood.

DOC.HEAD: Union Miner Killed in Shootout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with miners' conditions, apparently first such fatality in region since 1984; PICKS UP 9th graf pvs, `The union ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A union member was killed and two others were wounded in a shootout in West Virginia coal country between picketing miners and gunmen in the woods, authorities said. State Police said they had no suspects or motive in the shootings, which occurred Tuesday on a highway running through the hills of McDowell County in southern West Virginia. The slaying was apparently the first fatality linked to labor violence in the Kentucky-Virginia-West Virginia coal country since the shooting of a non-union truck driver in Kentucky in the 1984 A.T. Massey Coal Co. strike. ``It sounded like World War I out there _ bullets ricocheting and you could hear them hitting houses,'' said James Chapman, who runs a mission nearby. State Police spokesman Ric Robinson said troopers are not sure who started the shooting. Robinson said shots were exchanged between gunmen in the woods above the highway and the miners on the road. The United Mine Workers union said the pickets were demonstrating against several coal companies over back pay and medical benefits. Union officials said the picketing was not related to the UMW's strike against the Pittston Co. John McCoy, 42, was shot to death. Darrell Morgan, 41, was listed in stable condition today at Bluefield Regional Medical Center, as was Steve Morgan, 33. The Morgans are not related. The union issued a statement condemning the attack. ``As mine workers, they face many dangers, whether the hazards inherent in coal mining, the hardship caused by coal company economics or the threats of bodily harm at the hands of gun thugs,'' UMW President Richard Trumka said. Jim McNeely, a union official in District 29, which includes McDowell County, said the area is rife with conflicts. ``There are creditors' disputes,'' he said. ``There are personal disputes. There are a multitude of disputes. It's not just there is a union-non-union dispute down there.''

DOC.HEAD: 12 Aliens Found Locked in Boxcar
DOC.TEXT: Twelve undocumented Mexicans locked for two days in a boxcar were caught by railroad police as they tried to cut their way out with an ax, officials said. Two of the aliens Tuesday were slightly injured when metal frames inside the boxcar fell on them. Joseph de la Cruz, in charge of the Border Patrol's anti-smuggling unit, said his office is working with Mexican officials to identify and arrest those who locked the aliens inside the boxcar on Sunday. ``The smuggler left food, water, a little bit of beer and an ax and told them he would see them in San Antonio,'' de la Cruz said.
