He said the aliens might have died if the weather had been warmer. It was their sixth attempt to reach the United States. ``This method of locking people in boxcars is inhumane and totally unacceptable,'' de la Cruz said. ``This is the first such case we see this year and I hope we don't have any more.'' The injured men were taken to a hospital. The other aliens, including a 14-year-old, were deported. Eighteen aliens locked in an airtight boxcar suffocated in 1987 at Sierra Blanca, 90 miles east of El Paso. One man survived the ordeal. The Border Patrol monitors railyards daily, but de la Cruz said it would be almost impossible to check every boxcar. He said more dogs are needed to inspect boxcars.

DOC.HEAD: The Programmers Begin Looking for the Hot New Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT title to National Association of Television Program Executives; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `Finding them ...'
DOC.TEXT: When the doors opened on the world's largest marketplace for syndicated TV shows, the rush was on to find the hot new show. The National Association of Television Program Executives convention is where your local TV station sends its program director or general manager to buy old ``Star Trek'' shows or ``Geraldo,'' or hot new shows from the big studios or small independents. Finding them Tuesday, the first day of the exhibition, was the trick. When the showcases of more than 200 vendors, producers and their ilk crowd their illuminated showcases inside the vast New Orleans Convention Center, the place begins to look like the inside of a jukebox. The exhibitions of the big studios _ Paramount, Warner Bros., Disney _ look like cathedrals in the service of weird new gods. How do you find the hot new syndicated shows in this morass of video? Go to the people responsible for the hot, old ones: King World Productions Inc., a powerful, wealthy syndicator, and its star producer, Merv Griffin, who created the megahits ``Jeopardy'' and ``Wheel of Fortune.'' They are the first and second highest-rated syndication shows of all time. By mid-afternoon, with two days remaining in the convention, ``Wheel'' and ``Jeopardy'' had signed in markets comprising more than 40 percent of the U.S. audience. Griffin, former host of the ``Play Your Hunch'' quiz show and a talk show host and whose empire includes an Atlantic City casino, is creating ``Monopoly,'' a 22-minute facsimile of the board game, for a fall debut. ``What can I tell you? It's the most valuable license in the game the world has ever known,'' said Griffin, settling into the burgundy velvet cushions of King World's conversation pit beside the illuminated fountain. Griffin isn't worried that a TV ``Monopoly'' might be tampering with an American institution like apple pie or Classic Coke. ``The box game would never hold up on television,'' he said. ``What would be thrilling to sit home and watch somebody push a little car and watch other people throw dice?'' Monopoly is a game of luck and some intelligence in the way the player acquires property, said Griffin, who has bought some Atlantic City properties in his time. ``We used it as a scoring device and inserted a game in front of it.'' A small person moves the token used by the players. ``Everybody's mad at me because I used a little person,'' he said. ``My answer is, didn't you have a childhood? What do you think the Munchkins were in `The Wizard of Oz.''' Griffin said he is pleased because ``Monopoly'' is a unique game design. ``Whatever you see now is always a clone of `Wheel' or `Jeopardy,''' he said. ``In one way it kind of makes me laugh. ``There must be a billion dollars in this convention, with all the shows they do and pilots. And when you ask yourself, `What are they doing here?' They're all here to try and get me,'' he said with a big smile. If ``Monopoly'' isn't to your taste, here's a random sampling of other syndication offerings, as advertised: ``Trump Card,'' from Warner Bros. _ ``We're been saying it's `Jeopardy' on Bingo cards,'' said marketing vice-president Jeff Hubbard. ``The Puzzle Game,'' a CBS-Tribune Entertainment co-production _ ``The teams earn money by solving humorous, yet challenging video puzzles. Every time a team correctly identifies a puzzle, they win money and get a chance to earn even more money by solving a `Super Puzzle,' which is hidden behind nine jigsaw pieces.'' If game shows aren't your cup of tea, consider: ``Reunion,'' from Blair Entertainment _ ``Capturing real human drama, the half-hour strip program ... reunites people in a myriad of situations, from long lost friends and loves to missing children and parents.'' ``Not for Men Only,'' from Viacom Enterprises _ ``Emmy Award-winning host Ross Shafer will involve members of a studio audience in sometimes heated discussion on a wide range of topics from `Jealousy ... the Relationship Killer' to `Fifty Lies Men Tell Women.' ``House Party with Steve Doocy,'' from Group W _ ```House Party' is a lively and unique daily hour of useful information presented in a humorous and entertaining way.'' It begins Jan. 22 in 30 markets. ``Dracula: The Series,'' also from Blair _ ``The series focuses on Carl Dau (Dracula), billionaire international power broke, who seeks global domination through the building of a high-tech network of white-collar vampires.'' ``Home Again with Bob Vila,'' Group W _ Vila, who left PBS' high-rated program, `This Old House' ``will feature many of the same program elements for which Vila won a wide following while emphasizing affordable restoration, repair and remodeling hints for average Americans on a limited budget.'' ``Super Cop'' from Viacom Enterprises _ ``James A. Kelly, a member of a law enforcement family dynasty, becomes the only person able to wear a special suit equipped with futuristic technology designed to fight crime by giving him extraordinary tactical capabilities.''

DOC.HEAD: Communique Says Drug Lords Accept Government Victory in Drug War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD details of communique. CORRECTS day of church leaders' message to Monday. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A message purported to be from Colombia's drug lords today declared the government the winner in the war on drugs and offered to halt illegal activities in exchange for an amnesty. The communique was given to Patricia Echavarria, who was set free today after being kidnapped with her daughter Dec. 16. Mrs. Echavarria is the wife of a prominent doctor in the drug capital of Medellin. ``We accept the triumph of the state,'' said the communique from The Extraditables, the armed wing of the nation's powerful drug lords. ``Thus we will lay down our arms and abandon our objectives for the benefit of the highest interests of the fatherland.'' The communique came in response to a call Monday by the Catholic Church and political leaders for drug cartels to release their hostages and end drug trafficking. ``We submit to the existing legal establishment in the hope of obtaining from the government and from society respect for our rights and our return to our families and communities,'' it said. ``We have decided to suspend the shipment of drugs and surrender the weapons, explosives, laboratories, hostages, the clandestine landing strips and other effects related to our activities at such a time as we are granted constitutional and legal guarantees,'' the communique continued. Their statement appeared to demand an amnesty that would guarantee they would not face criminal charges. The drug barons have previously demanded a full amnesty and an end to extraditions of drug suspects to the United States. While President Virgilio Barco said Tuesday he would not rule out talks with drug traffickers, Interior Minister Carlos Lemos Simmonds said Colombian law does not allow an amnesty for common criminals. Barco began his crackdown on the cocaine cartels after the assassination in August of a leading presidential candidate. As part of the crackdown, he revived an extradition treaty with the United States, which drew up a list of the 12 most-wanted drug traffickers. The Extraditables take their name from the list. The communique said Mrs. Echavarria and her daughter, Dina, had been freed as proof of the cartels' desire to make peace. The two were released in a neighborhood built by Medellin cartel leader Pablo Escobar Gaviria for the poor people of Medellin. In the 11-point message, The Extraditables said: ``We undertake that there will be no explosive bombings in any part of the national territory and have ordered the suspension of all type of executions of political figures, government and labor officials, members of the judiciary, newsmen, policemen and the military.'' They also offered to act as mediators in efforts to end activities by other groups operating outside the law, ``for the sole purpose of ending the violence which harms and shatters our Colombian fatherland.'' So far, Colombia has sent 11 drug suspects to the United States to face charges, but none is on the most-wanted list. In an effort to stop extraditions, traffickers responded with a campaign of bombings and other violent attacks that killed at least 209 people. The government also believes drug traffickers bombed a Colombian passenger jet that crashed outside Bogota in November, killing 107 people. The traffickers also are believed responsible for many of 85 kidnappings in Colombia in the last 45 days. For its part, the government has seized millions of dollars in property and arrested hundreds of people to try to destroy the private army of the leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel. It also has killed one of the leaders of the cartel, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, who died in a shootout with police Dec. 15 on Colombia's north coast. On Tuesday, Barco for the first time said he would not rule out the possibility of negotiating to end the drug war. At a news conference, Barco said in answer to a question about the possibility of talks, ``We in the government are not inflexible.'' The communique Monday by the church and political leaders stated openly what many Colombians have been saying privately: that the nation does not have the resources to fight a long war against the billionaire traffickers. The church and political leaders, including two former presidents, suggested that in return for drug lords halting their campaign of terror, they might expect ``less rigorous'' treatment from the government.

DOC.HEAD: Former Acting Council President Sentenced
DOC.TEXT: Ben Woods, former acting City Council president, was sentenced to eight years in prison today for taking more than $47,000 in payoffs to steer business to city contractors. U.S. District Judge Alan Bloch also placed Woods on three years' probation after his release. During that period, he may not serve as a public official. ``Your downfall is your greed and lack of character,'' the judge said. ``This is not an individual who made a simple mistake or fell to temptation. You are the author and manager of a complex plan to extract bribes from people who wanted to work for the city.'' Woods, 47, had faced up to 201 years in prison and $3.6 million in fines. Hours after he resigned from the council Nov. 6, a jury found him guilty of charges including conspiracy, extortion, racketeering and tax evasion. He was convicted of accepting $11,000 from Michael Hartman to help the contractor get housing contracts and to expedite payments on a project. The two-term councilman also was convicted of accepting $36,727 from businessman Joseph Wozniak to help him sell concrete sealants to city agencies. On Nov. 7, Bloch ordered Woods to forfeit the money. Hartman, 38, of suburban Pittsburgh, was convicted of conspiracy, racketeering and filing a false corporate tax return, and faces up to 28 years in jail and $750,000 in fines at sentencing Thursday. Wozniak testified for the government under a grant of immunity. Woods became acting council president when Sophie Masloff left the post. She became mayor in May 1988 upon the death of Mayor Richard Caliguiri.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Wants Panama Invasion Troops Home As Soon as Possible
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gave a Rose Garden welcome today to Gen. Maxwell Thurman, commander of U.S. forces in Panama, and said he wants the invasion troops there brought home ``as soon as possible.'' But, Bush said, ``There are still some security considerations.'' ``I want to do what's right for Panama. I want to do what Panama wants,'' the president told reporters. ``It's Panama's show now,'' said Bush, standing with Thurman and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney outside the Oval Office. Bush, before heading inside for a National Security Council meeting to discuss Panama and its needs, said the new government of President Guillermo Endara ``is strengthening their democracy.'' ``Democracy is on the move. ... We want to give them economic help. We want to offer hope to the individuals there who are out of work, some of it because of the sanctions we had imposed on Panama,'' said Bush. ``So we're committed.'' ``It's my objective to get the troops out and get back to the levels before this military action,'' said Bush. He wants that done ``as soon as possible,'' Bush said. The United States more than doubled its forces to nearly 27,000 for the Dec. 20 invasion that toppled strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega, now in jail in Miami awaiting trial on drug-trafficking charges. There were 12,000 troops there prior to the invasion. Thurman said that as of this morning, 18,900 U.S. troops are left in the Latin nation, with 8,000 having already returned to the states. ``Eight out and we've got about four or five (thousand) to go,'' said Bush. Asked if he wanted them out before the Feb. 15 drug summit in Colombia, Bush indicated that was not a consideration, despite the refusal by the president of Peru, Alan Garcia, to attend the summit if the invasion troops are still in Panama. ``It has nothing to do with the summit in Cartagena at all,'' said Bush. He also denied that there have been difficulties lining up Latin countries for Vice President Dan Quayle to visit on a fence-mending mission to the region. Bush said he expects Quayle will go to Panama. Quayle is due to attend a presidential inauguration in Honduras next week, and is planning two other trips to Latin America. The details of his itinerary have not yet been announced. Bush thanked Thurman and his troops ``for the outstanding job they did for our country and Panama.'' ``They did a dynamite job,'' the four-star general agreed.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Commander Celebrates 47th Birthday in Orbit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `Lead flight ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with false alarm reported.
DOC.TEXT: The strains of ``Danny Boy'' awakened Columbia commander Dan Brandenstein on his 47th birthday today, and a chorus of ``Happy Birthday'' filled the cabin as the shuttle circled Earth 200 miles in space. The astronaut corps serenaded him, and basketball star Larry Bird radioed congratulations as the shuttle's five-member crew settled in for another day of scientific experiments on the eighth day of the 10-day mission. ``Congratulations to you and the crew on the slam dunk with LDEF. Happy birthday and have a safe landing,'' said Boston Celtics' star Bird. LDEF is the Long Duration Exposure Facility, the 11-ton science laboratory the astronuts plucked from space on Friday and tucked into the shuttle's cargo bay. The control center also played a recording made by the astronaut corps, singing ``Happy Birthday'' to the ``Boss.'' Brandenstein is chief of the 90-member corps. ``I was hoping that flying Mach 25 you didn't age and that this wasn't going to happen this year,'' quipped Brandenstein. The shuttle is flying 17,400 mph _ Mach 25, or 25 times the speed of sound. Bird recorded his message on the spur of the moment earlier this week when the Celtics toured Cape Canaveral between games with Miami and Orlando. After the birthday wakeup, Columbia's crew plunged into its last full day of experiments, growing protein crystals, melting and resolidifying a metal in zero gravity and learning how the body adapts to weightlessness in preparation for longer space trips. Shortly after 11 a.m., one of two smoke alarms went off in a bay where computer equipment is stored. But the astronauts found no evidence of smoke or damage to the equipment, which includes the shuttle's guidance systems. ``A very unexpected and unattributable alert ... at this point considered a false alarm,'' Mission Control commentator Jeff Carr said. Earlier, lead flight director Al Pennington at NASA reported the spaceship was ``operating just beautifully. We're in good shape.'' Pilot Jim Wetherbee and mission specialists Bonnie Dunbar, Marsha Ivins and David Low joined Brandenstein in working quietly, with communications between ground and spaceship kept to a minimum, so they could concentrate on their work. On Thursday, the astronauts will start packing up the experiments and other equipment for Friday's return to Earth. A darkness landing is scheduled at 2:55 a.m. PST at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported that some of Edwards' dry lakebed runways were not useable because of recent rains, but the concrete strip Brandenstein planned to touch down on was fine. Good weather also was expected.

DOC.HEAD: President to Visit Kansas City Next Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will travel to Kansas City, Mo., on Tuesday to speak about crime and his national drug strategy, the White House said today. ``He will also visit several facilities related to the war on drugs,'' spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Fitzwater did not say what group Bush would be speaking to or provide other details of the trip, saying they will be announced later. The president will leave the White House on Tuesday morning and be back in Washington by late afternoon. The administration is due to send Congress an update of its national drug strategy at the end of the month. Bush will also submit his proposed fiscal 1991 budget, including an expected hefty increase in funds for anti-drug efforts, on Jan. 29.

DOC.HEAD: Pricetag of Up to $50 Million Put on Renoir
DOC.TEXT: The owner of a Renoir dance hall scene lauded as ``a page of history'' is seeking to sell the painting for $40 million to $50 million. Sotheby's on Tuesday said ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' will be auctioned May 16. The painting is being sold by Betsey Cushing Whitney, widow of investor John Hay Whitney, who bought the work in 1929. Whitney was an ambassador to Britain and publisher of The New York Herald Tribune. He died in 1982. ``Au Moulin de la Galette,'' painted in 1876 and acclaimed for its light, shadow and movement, depicts an outdoor dance hall in Montmartre, the bohemian area of Paris frequented by avant-garde writers, painters and actors. The painting was Renoir's first crowd scene, and many of his friends are in the background. Biographer Georges Rivere, who is depicted in the work, described the painting as ``a page of history, a precious moment of Paris life depicted with rigorous examination.'' A larger version is in the Musee d'Orsay in Paris. The most ever paid for a work was $53.9 million in 1987 for van Gogh's ``Irises,'' bought from Mrs. Whitney's nephew, John Whitney Payson. Although Payson got paid, Sotheby's recently announced the deal fell through because Australian tycoon Alan Bond could not repay a loan to the auction house.

DOC.HEAD: Harlem's Death Rate Higher than Bangladesh's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Men in Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest countries, have a better chance than men in Harlem of living past age 40, a study shows. When adjusted for age, the death rate in Harlem, a poor black neighborhood in upper Manhattan, was the highest in New York and more than double that of U.S. whites, the researchers found. The report, compiled by Drs. Colin McCord and Harold P. Freeman of Harlem Hospital, was published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. The findings were based on an analysis of New York's central Harlem health district, where 96 percent of the population is black and 41 percent live below the poverty line. The researchers found that 6,415 people died in Harlem from 1978 to 1981. If the death rate in Harlem had been the same as for whites across the United States, 3,994 would have died. Eighty-seven percent of the 2,421 excess deaths were in people under age 65. To dramatize their figures, the researchers noted that in Bangladesh, 55 percent of men and 50 percent of women live to age 65. In Harlem, 40 percent of men and 65 percent of women live this long. Cirrhosis, homicide, accidents, drug dependency and alcohol use were considered to be the most important underlying causes of death in 35 percent of all those under 65. For Harlem residents over age 75, the death rate was essentially the same as for U.S. whites. The study also found that the rate of hospital admissions in Harlem was 26 percent higher than in the rest of the city. ``A major political and financial commitment will be needed to eradicate the root causes of this high mortality _ vicious poverty and inadequate access to the basic health care that is the right of all Americans,'' the authors wrote. In a separate letter to the editor, Christopher J.L. Murray of Harvard's Center for Population Studies said a World Bank study also shows that blacks nationwide have a substantially elevated risk of dying at an early age. Sixteen percent of American males die between ages 15 and 60, compared with 30 percent of black men. Nine percent of white females die between those ages, compared with 16 percent of black women. He said the high death rate among black men exceeds the rates in Gambia, India and El Salvador. He said a major reason for the excess deaths among American black men was injuries, most of them homicides. However, they also had a higher risk of dying from some diseases, such as cancer and heart disease.

DOC.HEAD: One Charge Dropped
DOC.TEXT: Hanging dead cats from an outdoor Christmas tree and failing to care for a pet goat landed members of a Louisiana Tech University fraternity in court, officials said. The local animal control official, Stuart Hitt, said the two dead cats found during a Dec. 13 investigation apparently were killed by cars, not by fraternity members. So a charge of failure to dispose of a carcass was thrown out Tuesday by Municipal Judge Robert C. James. ``It was a tasteless pledge-class prank,'' said Matt Saurage, president of the Delta Kappa Epsilon chapter. ``Only a couple of guys were involved, and they've been reprimanded.'' The same December investigation led to an animal cruelty charge when it was found that a fraternity mascot, a goat called ``Wool E. Goat,'' had heartworms and hadn't received treatment. James said that case would be suspended without a trial date if the chapter paid for the goat's care, accepted the university's sanctions of probation until mid-May and 100 hours of community service, and allowed no more animals at the house.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Won Right to Die Now Looking for Job
DOC.TEXT: A quadriplegic who won a court battle for the right to turn off the ventilator that keeps him alive is leaving the machine running and is looking for a job. After discussions with staff members at United Cerebral Palsy of Greater Birmingham and other advocates for the disabled, Larry McAfee has entered an employment program run by UCP for people with disabilities. ``The amount of time they're spending with me is impressive,'' McAfee said Tuesday from his bed at the Briarcliff Nursing Home in Alabaster, outside Birmingham. ``Their sense of total commitment has been stimulating.'' McAfee, a mechanical engineer and sportsman before a 1985 motorcycle accident left him paralyzed below the chin, called job-hunting ``an avenue I wanted to explore.'' He said Brenda Carson, an employment specialist with the Birmingham cerebral palsy group, and her colleagues ``have not only caught my interest but stimulated my desire to give it a real good try. If it doesn't work out, then it doesn't work out.'' McAfee, 33, came to Briarcliff from Atlanta in August because of its special unit for ventilator-dependent patients. He decided life dependent on a machine was not worth pursuing and asked a judge in his home Fulton County, Ga., for permission to turn off his breathing system. Judge Edward Johnson ruled in McAfee's favor in September, and the Georgia Supreme Court upheld the decision in November. By that point, however, several people in the Birmingham area who work with the disabled had befriended him and offered him hope of something other than life in an institution. Ms. Carson said McAfee's experience, which includes designing industrial conveyor belt systems and other equipment, gives him marketable skills. Though he no longer can visit job sites, he would be able to do computer-assisted design, she said. McAfee said he already has the necessary computer equipment and software. ``We feel there is a very good prospect of finding an employer who can use his talents,'' Ms. Carson said.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Says US Beefing Up Beef Exports
DOC.TEXT: When it comes to agricultural exports, beef used to be the puny kid on the block. But lately, says the Agriculture Department, beef has put on some muscle and is still growing. According to the latest USDA estimates, beef exports jumped about 57 percent last year to nearly 1.07 billion pounds from 680 million in 1988. An additional increase of at least 12 percent to 1.2 billion pounds is expected in 1990. Japan, which accounts for about two-thirds of all U.S. beef exports, opened its doors wider last year and has agreed to boost the 1990 quota by an additional 60,000 metric tons, approximately 132.3 million pounds. ``The U.S. will have to share this market with the Australians, who are expected to price their beef very competitively,'' said Steve Reed of the department's Economic Research Service. Although Australian beef output was down last year because of cattle herd rebuilding, production is expected to rise in 1990 _ and a larger share probably will be earmarked for the Japanese market. Reed, writing in the January issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, said Japan's storage facilities for frozen beef are strained because of large inventories. A substantial amount of U.S. beef is frozen, he said, and a larger portion of Australian beef is fresh chilled. ``Some beef stockpiling in Japan likely occurred at the beginning of 1989 under the expectation of strong consumer demand,'' he said. ``Retail beef prices do not yet reflect the lower prices for imported beef under the new system.'' Reed said also there are ``apparently some problem in developing outlets for frozen U.S. beef'' in Japan. According to a USDA supply-and-demand analysis last week, exports estimated at 1.2 billion pounds this year will comprise 5.1 percent of U.S. beef output projected at 23.5 billion pounds. In 1989, the 1.07 billion pounds exported were equal to about 4.6 percent of total U.S. beef production. The 680 million pounds exported in 1988 was 2.9 percent. Despite the increase in overseas sales, the United States is still a net importer of beef. This year's shipments, primarily from Australia and New Zealand but also more than a dozen other countries, are forecast at 2.08 billion pounds, nearly twice the amount of exports.

Agriculture Department scientists are looking at some foreign grasses to see if drought-resistant livestock pastures can be developed to help U.S. cattle and sheep producers. A prairie brome grass called Matua from New Zealand shows promise for the eastern United States. It was brought to the United States in 1986 as a cool-season grass _ spring and fall _ for grazing or hay. Gerald A. Jung of the department's Agricultural Research Service said Matua ``was slowed down by the 1988 drought'' in central Pennsylvania but added that ``it thrived compared to other cool-season grasses.'' Jung works at the agency's regional pasture research laboratory in University Park, Pa. His findings were reported here recently by the department. ``In our tests in Pennsylvania last year, Matua prairie grass remained green and growing into December,'' he said. ``That's about a month after other cool-season grasses went dormant for the winter.'' Jung said Matua is not readily available in the United States and that about five more years of tests will be required. Plant explorers also have returned from two expeditions to the Soviet Union with more than 1,000 forage and grass seed samples, the USDA agency said. The eventual payoff could be new varieties of range grasses that come up annually and also extend the grazing season in the fall and winter. Kay H. Asay, plant geneticist at the agency's forage and range laboratory in Logan, Utah, said he and other scientists collected the samples over the last two summers. Many of the collections will be grown from seed and evaluated this summer, he said.

The United States will allow a 14 percent increase in the amount of foreign sugar that can be imported by U.S. processors from 39 countries. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Tuesday the increase boosts the sugar import quota to 2,584,865 metric tons for the period Jan. 1, 1989, through Sept. 30, 1990, an increase of 325,000 tons. ``This change in the level of the quota is necessary to counter the tightness in domestic sugar supplies caused by the unexpectedly low production of beet sugar and damage to the Florida and Texas sugar cane crops resulting from the December freeze,'' Yeutter said. Quotas are used to restrict the amount of foreign sugar that can enter the United States, thus protecting domestic producers from lower-priced foreign sugar being dumped on the U.S. market.

DOC.HEAD: Strikes by Public Sector Workers Spread
DOC.TEXT: Nationwide public sector strikes spread Wednesday, raising fears that cities and towns will be inundated with uncollected garbage. Municipal employees began a five-day nationwide strike in solidarity with about 17,000 temporary colleagues who have been off the job for six days and are demanding permanent employment. The temporary workers extended their walkout until Monday. In addition, 87,000 temporary civil service employees have been on strike since last week. The temporary municipal and civil service workers were hired by the outgoing Socialist government prior to general elections in the summer. A government formed in November to tackle Greece's $1.9 billion budget deficit has pledged to freeze public sector hiring. The permanent municipal employees are demanding higher wages and improved fringe benefits. Monthly salaries for municipal employees range from $375 to $438. In Athens, garbage blocked sidewalks and sidestreets downtown, as well as in suburbs. The government asked residents to store their garbage on their balconies until the walkout ended.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Blames New Forum for Rampage at Police Headquarters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Late today...' to CORRECT number of seats party holds in Cabinet. Insert graf after 7th, `Christian Democratic...' to ADD that same party threatened to quit last week. Pickup 8th pvs, `The coalition...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: East German Communists said today the country's peaceful revolution has taken a dangerous turn that could threaten free elections planned for May. The warning came in a newspaper editorial that denounced the storming on Monday of secret police headquarters in East Berlin and blamed it on the New Forum opposition group. New Forum, which organized the demonstration that led to the rampage, denied it was to blame for the violence, although the flier calling for the protest did call on people to bring stones. ``The stones that were to be taken along were meant only to symbolically seal up the doors of the building,'' New Forum spokesman Rainer Rodenwald said. ``The fliers we sent out clearly said `no violence,''' the spokesman said. ``There is no one from New Forum who wanted or planned the violence.'' Late today, the Christian Democratic Party threatened to bring down Communist Premier Hans Modrow's coalition government by leaving it. The Christian Democrats, who control three of the 27 Cabinet seats, object to the Communists' continued grip on power before the May 6 elections. Christian Democratic spokesman Lothar Lueck said his party's leadership was showing ``a very strong tendency to leave the government.'' West Germany's ARD television said a decision was expected during a party meeting on Friday. The party also threatened to quit the Cabinet last week. The coalition has been running the country since a popular uprising ousted the nation's hard-line Communist government, and the coalition is supposed to step down once it can be replaced by a freely elected government. New Forum, East Germany's largest pro-democracy movement, has more than 200,000 members nationwide. The movement has repeated its call to avoid violence and has promised to investigate Monday's incident. The official Communist Party daily said today the autumn revolution has ``lost its innocence.'' ``Is the revolution eating its own children?'' Neues Deutschland asked in its front-page editorial, recalling the line from playwright Georg Buechner's account of the violence of the French Revolution. ``No one should underestimate that question, since violence has increased and so has fear,'' the newspaper said. ``Voting freely on May 6 also means voting free of fear.'' Free elections are scheduled May 6. The newspaper called for ``a security partnership'' linking government, opposition and law enforcement officials to guarantee free elections. It said the rampage at the secret police headquarters caused hundreds of thousands of dollars in damage. Since the fall of hard-line leader Erich Honecker on Oct. 18, East Germany's leaders routinely have called for calm and warned that violence could hurt efforts to establish true democracy in the country. Nationwide, protests have continued by hundreds of thousands of people who have demanded that the Communists give up their virtual control of the government, media, bureaucracy and economy. The unrest apparently prompted Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany to scrap plans for negotiating stronger ties with the government. Kohl said Tuesday the talks could wait until after free elections. Kohl said the East German situation has become ``more difficult,'' adding that ``quick and effective measures'' were needed to shore up the economy. Modrow's government has called for scrapping centrally planned socialism and replacing it with a free-market system. It has thus started to abolish state subsidies by raising prices for children's clothes and related articles. Apartment rents and prices of other essentials are also to rise. The price hikes have sent panic through a population accustomed to decades of rock-bottom prices for goods, services and housing. Modrow, visiting West Berlin on Tuesday, blamed the pro-democracy opposition for Monday's incident. ``I hope the storming remains a one-time event and isn't any kind of signal,'' Modrow said during his visit, the first by an East German premier to the Western sector. He complained he had been greeted with shouts of ``red pig'' after he rushed to the storming scene in an attempt to halt the rampage. Tens of thousands of people took part in the rampage Monday night after a demonstration against the dreaded secret police force, which Modrow has promised to have completely dismantled by June 30. Many of the demonstrators looted the building, carrying away clothing, bottles of wine and various pieces of equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sentences Some to Hard Labor at Knitting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS overline of a0579 and 2nd graf to fix spelling of `purl.'
DOC.TEXT: Needles are the newest criminal sentence in Marquette County. A few people convicted of misdemeanors have been handed knitting needles and told to knit and purl away their debt to society. ``I tell them this is a way to help make up for (their crimes),'' said District Judge Patricia Micklow. With yarn donated by a church, six offenders are knitting afghans, hats, scarves, mittens and the like for the needy. ``These are things I can use anytime,'' said Sister Johnice Borer, a Franciscan nun assigned to the Marquette Catholic Diocese Outreach office that is distributing the knitted goods.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Holds General Audience But Still Feeling Effects of Flu
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II bounced back from a bout of flu and held his general audience Wednesday, but he admitted he was still feeling the effects of the illness that has struck millions in Italy. John Paul, 69, was down with fever and canceled his activities Monday and Tuesday. Wednesday's audience was shortened by 30 minutes, and he refrained from picking up and embracing children. ``The Italian press has written that the pope has the Chinese flu,'' the pope told 4,000 pilgrims and tourists, including about 300 from the Soviet Union. ``This explains the brevity of the speeches and salutes. ``I must behave as a person still not completely well,'' he said. The flu began hitting Italians in December, starting mainly in northern Italy and moving down the peninsula. The pope greeted 300 people from Leningrad and another delegation from Lithuania, a heavily Roman Catholic area, praising the Lithuanians' ``deep faith and fidelity'' to the Vatican.

DOC.HEAD: Government Criticized for Using Chinese Photo in Ad
DOC.TEXT: Government officials were criticized Wednesday for using a photo of a wounded Chinese student to illustrate a voter registration campaign. The ad, published by the Scottish Office which governs Scotland, showed a student being carried away prostrate on a delivery bicycle. It was taken after Chinese troops crushed pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing on June 3-4. The picture appeared in several Scottish newspapers in September above a caption that said: ``You'll only have to give your name and address.'' The Advertising Standards Authority, an independent watchdog organization, said in its latest report that it received 20 complaints from people who believed it was in ``appallingly bad taste.'' It said the Scottish Office defended it as being a reminder to the public of the importance of the right to vote in a free society. But it believed the argument ``did not justify this deplorable approach.'' The Scottish Office said: ``We regret that some people found it distressing. It was never our intention to shock or offend. The advertisement will not be used again.''

DOC.HEAD: 113-Year-Old Woman, Japan's Oldest Citizen, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Mitsu Fujisawa, Japan's oldest citizen at age 113, died of natural causes Wednesday at her home in central Japan. Born on April 9, 1876, Mrs. Fujisawa had been the country's oldest citizen since May 1986. Japan's oldest citizen now is Waka Shirahama, a 111-year-old woman in Miyakonojo in the southern prefecture of Miyazaki, according to the Health and Welfare Ministry. The oldest man in Japan is Kiichi Fujiwara, 109, of Zushi, near Tokyo. Mrs. Fujisawa, of Shimosuwa, was one of 3,078 centenarians at the end of September. The total was up 410 from a year earlier, according to the ministry's statistics. The average life expectancy for Japanese women is 81.30 years, while that for men is 75.54 years.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes in Multi-Story Car Park
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded Wednesday in a parking garage in central Belfast, but no one was wounded, police said. Police said they received a warning 45 minutes before the blast and managed to clear the area. No immediate claim of responsibility was made, but the new shopping complex has been a target of the Irish Republican Army several times. The IRA is fighting to rid Northern Ireland of British rule and unite the province with the Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli, Egyptian Leaders Hold Separate Talks with U.S. Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 7th graf, That was, with 2 grafs to include Tuesday night meeting; inserts new 10th graf, Also, Lebanese, with Lebanese official visiting
DOC.TEXT: Israeli and Egyptian leaders held separate talks today with U.S. officials about peace efforts in the Middle East amid reports that a three-way meeting could take place next month. Secretary of State James A. Baker III would like a meeting that would include himself and the foreign ministers of Egypt and Israel as the first step toward organizing elections among Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Egypt, the only Arab country that has a peace treaty with Israel, is acting as a channel for the Palestine Liberation Organization, which the Israelis want to exclude from the peace process. In Jerusalem, Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu quoted Baker as saying the trilateral meeting he has been pushing for could take place in Washington by the end of February. In a telephone conversation Tuesday with Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, Baker estimated ``the trilateral meeting of foreign ministers will be held by the end of February,'' Netanyahu told Israel's parliament. ``I had a very interesting and useful discussion with Secretary Baker and we are going to see each other again, and then maybe at the end of the visit, probably on Friday, I'll have something more to say,'' Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid told reporters here Tuesday. Baker met again Tuesday night with Abdel-Meguid at the foreign minister's hotel. Details were not disclosed. Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin had appointments today with national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, Vice President Dan Quayle and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Rabin was scheduled to see Baker on Thursday. Also, Lebanese Finance Minister Ali Khalil arrived today amid news reports that his Syrian-backed government was seeking weapons from the United States to build up its military strength against Maronite Christian holdouts. State Department officials refused to discuss the reports. Meanwhile, Israel Television reported that Vice Premier and Finance Minister Shimon Peres will meet with Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak in Cairo on Jan. 24 in an effort to break the stalemate in the Middle East peace process. The talks would be the first top-level encounter between Israeli and Egyptian officials since Rabin's trip to Cairo and talks with Mubarak in September 1989. Aides to Peres could not be reached for comment. Abdel-Meguid said he had no plan for a three-way meeting in Washington. At the Israeli embassy, spokeswoman Ruth Yaron said it would take place if any of the three sides wanted it. The Egyptians also were concerned with money matters. Salah Hamed, governor of Egypt's central bank, came with Abdel-Meguid and was meeting with the International Monetary Fund to discuss getting a new loan for Egypt. The World Bank said the country's debts had reached almost $50 billion by the end of 1988, one of the largest figures in the Third World. A new loan from the fund would be seen as a sign of confidence in Egypt's government and could help it get a postponement of payments on what it already owes. Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, wants a cut in Egypt's budget deficit and other difficult policy measures by Mubarak's government before he will agree to lend more. Egypt gets $2 billion in aid a year from the United States and Israel receives $3 billion. Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, suggested on Tuesday that Egypt, Israel and other favored recipients take a 5 percent cut _ $100 million for Egypt and $150 million for Israel _ so the United States can contribute more to help Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Army Officer to Stand Trial on Charges of Assaulting Wife
DOC.TEXT: An Army major whose wife fell over an eighth-floor hotel railing while he was carrying her has been ordered to stand trial on assault in the incident. Maj. David Schneider, 34, told police at the time of the Nov. 4 incident that he had picked up his wife in a romantic gesture but stumbled. The prosecutors' sole witness at Tuesday's preliminary hearing, Chantel McCutchen, 15, of Blue Springs, said she saw Schneider flip his wife over the 3-foot, 7-inch railing overlooking the hotel's lobby. Deborah A. Schneifer, 34, suffered multiple fractures to both legs and a broken pelvis in the 80-foot fall. She landed on a restaurant table. Platte County Associate Circuit Judge Ward Stuckey ordered Schneider, of Fort Leavenworth, Kan., to stand trial and set a Jan. 25 arraignment. Mrs. Schneider, who uses a walker, apparently has no memory of the incident, prosecutors said. She no longer lives with her husband.

DOC.HEAD: Council Tells City Attorney to Fight Presidential Parkway
DOC.TEXT: A new roadblock has been thrown up in the 7-year-old battle to build the Presidential Parkway that would link downtown Atlanta to the Carter Center, the presidential library on the outskirts of the city. The City Council voted 15-2 Tuesday to oppose construction, even though the Georgia Supreme Court already has ruled the city cannot rescind its support first voted by the council in 1982. Council member Bill Campbell, a parkway foe who represents the district through which the 2.4-mile road would run, sponsored the legislation. The state Department of Transportation is pushing the project to provide better access to surrounding suburbs. Opponents of the road contend it is too expensive, unnecessary and would damage historic Atlanta parks and neighborhoods.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. Jan. 16 The News-Leader, Springfield, Mo., on Soviet Unrest: Mikhail Gorbachev has come face to face with the horror of blind hatred in two Soviet provinces. One is Christian: Armenia. The other is Shiite Moslem: Azerbaijan. They share one attribute: hatred for its own sake. Thus what began as a territorial dispute over Nagorno Karabakh _ an Armenian enclave within Azerbaijan _ has become the latest threat to Mikhail Gorbachev's goodwill and perhaps to his future. The hideous carnage of Armenians in a section of Baku, Azerbaijan, is precisely the kind of religious hatred that has destroyed entire cultures. Earlier in this century, Armenia was the target of one of the most severe acts of genocide in history. The questions for Americans is a simple one: Where is the outcry? From Americans, most especially Christians? From Americans of Armenian descent? From the world?

Jan. 16 The Wichita (Kan.) Eagle on El Salvador: President Alfredo Cristiani, to his great credit, has taken the pivotal first step in bringing to justice the killers of six Jesuit priests and two Salvadoran witnesses in a Nov. 16 massacre in El Salvador. Never before has a military officer ranking as high as Col. Guillermo Alfredo Benavides Moreno been accused of a human rights crime. The arrests so far undoubtedly have sent shock waves through the military's ranks. This could precipitate a confrontation with the civilian government, and with ... Cristiani's own human rights feelings. The president had to have known the risks he was taking in pursuing the case thus far, and may have chosen this way to assert civilian control over the military. ... How the priests' murder is resolved will determine whether El Salvador is a nation of laws and whether it's deserving of the free world's continued favor.

Jan. 12 The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune on China: The People's Daily says China has been restored to ``complete normality.'' Sadly, what's normal to Beijing's official press is a climate of intense political repression that mocks the recent lifting of martial law. It was disturbing, then, to find the Bush administration welcoming the news about martial law as if it were a move of substance. The president praised the announcement by Prime Minister Li Peng as a ``very sound step'' and ``very positive'' _ without noting that China's rulers have actually tightened their grip on society. For years after Richard Nixon reopened diplomatic ties to Beijing back in 1972, Americans overlooked human rights abuses in China. Only last summer's images of tanks crushing the bodies of peaceful protesters cured the American public of its romance with this totalitarian regime. Curiously, George Bush alone remains all discretion, too polite to publicly criticize the country where he served as President Gerald Ford's ambassador. Bush is right to keep an eye on long-term relations with China. That legitimate purpose doesn't mean he should laud a cosmetic move as if it were a win for liberty.

Jan. 12 The West Central Tribune, Willmar, Minn., on Noriega: Anybody who thinks General Manuel Noriega walked out of Panama to spend the rest of his life in a U.S. jail cell is either very naive or does not understand politics. The general, obviously a multimillionaire, maybe a billionaire, is accustomed to the best in life. And there's no question he either has arranged, or fully intends, to ultimately return to that lifestyle. Had he thought otherwise, he undoubtedly would have flown the coop, as have other dictators, and taken up residency in a country of one of his buddies. The money he stashed away is probably still hidden. It is either under secret bank codes or entrusted to former aides. His hierarchy also is not only still in Panama, but probably remains in positions of authority. The former general is unquestionably a guy who raped his country. But dumb he ain't. And in politics, as we all know, there are deals and counterdeals, many of which are secret. Some ultimately surface, but many never do. As the saying goes, ``If we were betting people, we'd hock the farm,'' that before many years pass, the general will undoubtedly be out and about.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: and about.
DOC.TEXT: Jan. 11 Mail Tribune, Medford, Ore., on defense spending: Despite changes worldwide that signal a thaw in the Cold War, President Bush doesn't appear ready yet to cut into the fat of the Pentagon's budget. Congress may have to play the role of butcher to ensure that the bloated defense establishment created in the 1980s doesn't continue to gorge itself in the 1990s. Bush and Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney reportedly favor a five-year defense plan to increase spending from the $293 billion level in the 1990 budget to $312 billion by 1995. The argument used to support this approach is that the amounts actually represent a 2 percent annual reduction after inflation. ... In Washington ... this is known as cutting a budget. ... This costly war machine is a legacy of former President Ronald Reagan. In 1981 he began an eight-year defense spending spree that was unparalleled in U.S. history. He said the buildup was necessary to stay ahead of the Soviet Union ... and to protect U.S. interests around the globe. Today, the Soviet Union is in a state of economic collapse. Its fighting force, the armies of the Warsaw Pact nations, has disintegrated in the face of the pro-democracy movement sweeping Eastern Europe. ... Based on recent events, defense spending in the $200 billion range for the '90s should be adequate.

Jan. 15 Idahonian, Moscow, Idaho, on airline threats: It is as refreshing as it is rare to see candor from an airline, especially when such openness affects revenue. One sterling example is the manner in which Northwest Airlines handled a bomb threat to an international flight over the New Year's weekend. The action stands in stark contrast to Pan American's fatal silence a year earlier. When Northwest was threatened with sabotage to its Paris-to-Detroit DC10 flight, it promptly informed potential passengers of the danger. Stepped-up security precautions notwithstanding, it allowed ticketed passengers to postpone their flights or book passage on a competing airline. About three dozen people did so. The flight made it safely to its U.S. destination. A week later, a Belfast teen-ager was arrested on a charge of making the threat. A year ago Christmas, Pan Am flight 103 from Frankfurt to New York also was under a bomb threat information known only to Pan Am and the U.S. State Department. Fearing loss of business if the flying public knew of the threat, the information deliberately was kept confidential. We all know, of course, what happened over Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988. Northwest took the responsible route, even when it most certainly would mean a loss of fares. Travelers nearly always have a choice of air carriers. They might consider rewarding Northwest for its special concern for our safety the next time they fly to a destination served by that airline.

Jan. 11 The Register-Herald, Beckley, W.Va., on disposable diapers: Vermont Gov. Madeleine Kunin has stirred considerable controversy with her proposal to ban all disposable diapers. The move may be a signal of what is to come nationwide. Last year Kunin was successful in making Vermont the first state to ban the sale of vehicles which use ozone-depleting chemicals in air conditioning. If the diaper ban becomes law, Vermont will be the first state to prohibit all disposable diapers. Nebraska has a similar ban, although it permits sale of biodegradable diapers. Kunin argues that while disposables have a usable life of ``a few hours,'' their decomposition takes hundreds of years in dumps. According to estimates, about 85 percent of all parents use disposable diapers exclusively, and the disposables account for about two percent of the nation's waste. Vermont officials estimate that in their state alone some 43 million diapers go to the dump annually. America is largely a ``throw away'' society. Convenience has supplanted prudence and many reusable resources are discarded rather than re-employed in the manufacturing process. While today's society may find that affordable, future generations may find it regrettable. ... The Bush administration has backed off from a proposal to tax paper, glass, plastic and metals that aren't recycled. That was done to make sure the president lived up to his ``no new taxes'' pledge. But Bush also promised to gear the nation into a mindset of recycling and conserving. He needs to act on that immediately. Gov. Kunin may be paving the way for him.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Bush First-Year Record Comes Under Fire from Liberal Group
DOC.TEXT: The Americans for Democratic Action, long considered the nation's leading liberal group, said Wednesday the Bush administration failed in its first year to be kinder and gentler to the poor and threatened the Constitution with its invasion of Panama. ``Americans should be prepared to fight and die for what is right,'' Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., told a news conference. ``The question I ask is whether it was morally and constitutionally right.'' Rangel, president of the 47-year-old liberal group, said that the Democratic leadership of the House as well as the news media have failed to be critical enough of President Bush's record. The comments came as part of what ADA billed as a report card on the first year of the administration. The Harlem congressman acknowledged Bush scores high in nationwide polls but faulted the president on education, minority rights, the environment, homelessness, drug addiction and abortion. He said poverty is worsening. Rangel said that as a former congressman, Bush is often treated as a friend by House leaders and thus his policies do not come in for sufficient criticism. He said the news media liked the Panama invasion and as a result, ``the press hysterically supports the tattering of the Constitution of the United States.'' He said national drug policy director William Bennett has been ``a real disappointment'' and was skeptical about the administration's war against drugs. ``I don't see anything to knock, I don't see anything to support. I don't know where Bill Bennett is.'' ``Obviously the president has done a lot of things right if you are middle class and white and really involved in military maneuvers,'' Rangel said. ``I give the president an A for military preparedness, holding down the minimum wage and staying out of getting involved with the homeless. ...'' Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., a former ADA president, told the news conference that ``in civil rights, Mr. Bush has not been kinder and gentler.'' He said the civil rights division of the Justice Department has a vacancy in its top position and as a result ``people who have been discriminated against, whose civil rights have been violated, have no champion.'' The Democratic-controlled Senate Judiciary Committee killed the administration's nomination of former Wayne County, Mich., sheriff William Lucas for that position, calling the Democrat-turned-Republican unqualified.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Snakes are popular here, or at least the boa constrictor is that slithered its way into a second-floor apartment and was found wrapped around a toilet. ``I had no idea so many people were all that attached to snakes,'' said police spokesman Jerry Fisher after the department in this Houston suburb took more than 100 calls from people wanting the snake. ``The phone has not stopped ringing for five seconds around here.'' The snake was first spotted by a stunned Chris Atkinson, when he got out of bed to use the bathroom at 4 a.m. Monday. The boa was coiled in and around his commode. One of those wanting to adopt the 6-foot-long snake was Bob Miller, director of the Living Materials Center at La Porte High School, located in another Houston suburb. Miller said he would like the snake for a breeding program. Fisher said the police department will wait a couple of days to see if the snake's owner surfaces. Atkinson has said he has no plans to keep the snake, joking that he probably could only use it as ``a new pair of boots, maybe.'' If the snake is adopted, Fisher said he may hold a drawing for all those who want it and give it to the winner. But they won't be able to keep it in League City. Owning a wild or exotic pet is illegal and punishable by fines of up to $200.

The director of a Dallas high school marching band is doing more than just putting his students through rigorous workouts in anticipation of a trip to Ireland to march in the St. Patrick's Day Parade. ``I'm also looking for a good discount on 80 pairs of longjohns underwear,'' said Derle Long, director of the W.T. White High School band. ``It can be cold, damp and very uncomfortable in Dublin in mid-march.'' Long underwear isn't often needed in the North Texas city. So Long is scouting around, trying to get a good, affordable deal. ``We hope we won't need them,'' said Long, who is still trying to raise funds for the trip. ``We're praying for sunshine.'' The band director said he intends to wear battery-powered hunting socks to keep his feet warm during the parade.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: for him.
DOC.TEXT: Jan. 15 The Seattle Times on the exclusionary rule: As Eastern Europe struggles with the concept of individual rights, the U.S. Supreme Court continues to make the gritty decisions that convert ideas into a way of life. Last week the court affirmed a principle known as the exclusionary rule, which requires that illegally obtained evidence be excluded from criminal trials. For 75 years, the court has said society has more to fear from police misconduct than the consequences of letting a guilty person go free. Very narrow exceptions have been allowed over the years, most recently in 1984. The latest challege involved an Illinois murder case and the use of illegal evidence to impeach the credibility of a defense witness. A majority of the court, including a justice who had written an earlier narrowing of the exclusionary rule, said the conviction must be overturned. Justice William Brennan said that while arriving at the truth is important, the suppression of valid but illegal evidence is necessary to protect constitutional rights: ``So long as we are committed to protecting people from the disregard of their constitutional rights ... inadmissibility of illegally obtained evidence must remain the rule, not the exception,'' Brennan wrote for the 5-4 majority. Living up to tough rules is the test of a true democracy.

Jan. 15 The Milwaukee Journal on the NCAA convention: The National Collegiate Athletic Association recently held what its executive director aptly called a ``convention of the student-athlete.'' The meeting was dominated not so much by debate over the rules of sport as by concern over the intense and often competing social pressures that are put upon student-athletes and the schools they attend. With one important exception, the convention delegates confronted these issues in a way that will ease such stresses. That single exception was the NCAA's adoption of Proposition 26, which significantly undercut a controversial measure the NCAA enacted last year in an effort to encourage scholastic achievement. That measure, called Proposition 42, denied athletic scholarships to incoming freshmen who failed to meet basic academic requirements while in high school. Prop 42 had sent a much-needed message to these young people: If you want an athletic scholarship to college, better start hitting the books now. Proposition 26 does not repeal Prop 42's restriction on athletic scholarships, but does allow universities to grant aid based on financial need to freshmen athletes who fail to cut the mustard in their high school classrooms. In short, the NCAA created a giant loophole in Prop 42. At some schools, the new measure might also mean less scholarship money for poor but academically motivated students who happen not to be athletes. But at its meeting, the NCAA did reduce the length of the basketball season and spring football practice. That will make it possible for students to give more attention to their most important responsibility, intellectual development. The NCAA also approved a plan to conduct random, year-round drug testing of players in major football programs. The link between big-time sports and big-time money has become so intimate, and competition has become so ferocious, that many athletes have resorted to drugs that they think will let them run a little faster, grow a little stronger, hit a little harder. But these performance-enhancing drugs have dangerous side-effects. They belong in doctors' offices, not in athletes' lockers, and testing is one of the few ways to help make sure of that. The mere fact that academics, drugs and other social issues dominated the NCAA agenda shows that the major universities are aware of the problems they face. However imperfectly, the NCAA has begun to confront that new challenge and opportunity.

Jan. 12 The Westerly (R.I.) Sun on the America's Cup: The America's Cup is again generating news, not a result of tautly-set, wind-filled sails driving sleek hulls through white-capped waves, but because of litigation in the New York State Court of Appeals. At issue is the San Diego Yacht Club's use of a 6,000-pound catamaran manned by a crew of five and powered by a high technology air-foil and rigid sail in a successful 1988 American defense of the Cup. (A group of former America's Cup compeition skippers) contend this premier sailing competition will become purely an exhibition unless the New York Court voids the ``Stars and Stripes'' victory. ... They are right. The spirit of the America's Cup is one of honest competition involving men and boats, seamanship and design, skilled crews and the vagaries of the wind and sea. A catamaran sailing against a sloop is akin to a 12-meter yacht sailing against a barge unfurling a bedsheet _ no contest. May the 12-meter yachts that have been entered in fair and honest competitions since their development in the years shortly before and after World War II return to the sea in glorious pursuit of the America's Cup and what it was meant to stand for.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
People in the News

DOC.TEXT: Princess Anne, daughter of a reigning monarch, says she wishes her children had better role models. ``I look around and wonder what sort of examples they have to look up to now,'' the daughter of Queen Elizabeth II told a BBC radio interviewer Wednesday. ``That worries me. I don't think there are very many ... I think their elder generation is to blame for that.'' Anne, 39, who separated from her husband, Capt. Mark Phillips, in August, said she is not very strict with her 12-year-old son and 8-year-old daughter. ``I don't go along with the `seen and not heard.' It would be very nice but I think it's rather an impractical suggestion really,'' said the princess. She said her travels on behalf of the Save the Children's Fund, of which she is president, have made her more concerned about what she sees at home. ``You find if you go to any number of countries where the small rural communities have very strict codes of behavior you don't find much thieving and pilfering, and murder is almost unheard of,'' the princess said.

A man who slipped and fractured his kneecap at a Rod Stewart concert has sued the Cajundome, Stewart and his promoters, claiming it was a disabling, permanent injury. Charles K. Falterman, 27, filed the lawsuit Tuesday, saying he was injured April 22 when Stewart began kicking soccer balls into the audience and the crowd ``reacted almost as an uncontrollable herd of animals.'' Falterman said he was near the stage at the time and one soccer ball came near him. The suit said he slipped on something that had spilled on the Cajundome floor.

A Top 20 radio show will soon carry Milli Vanilli and Madonna to Moscow, Tone Loc and Tiffany to Tashkent and Phil Collins and Fine Young Cannibals to Kiev. Soviet rock fans will be able to hear those and other pop stars on ``USA Top 20,'' which will make its debut on Soviet government-owned Gosteleradio Feb. 9 and air twice a month, according to Westwood One, the Culver City-based company producing the show. Host of the 90-minute show will be Stuart Detmer, 26, a Chicago native who speaks fluent Russian, Westwood One Chairman Norman J. Pattiz said Tuesday. The show will be produced in Los Angeles. Foreign companies will be able to buy advertising time. Westwood One also will produce two other music programs, ``America on Record'' and ``American Musical Classics,'' for broadcast in the Soviet Union. ``American Top 40,'' produced by ABC Radio with host Shadoe Stevens, also will be heard on Gosteleradio, but no debut date has been set, said Tom Rounds, president of Radio Express, which handles the program's international distribution.

A 68-year-old mansion in fashionable Highland Park has been listed for sale by Caroline and Nelson Bunker Hunt, who emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings earlier this month. The asking price on the six-bedroom, six-bath mansion overlooking Turtle Creek is $2.8 million. The house has marble fireplaces and a garden room with an Italian tile floor. Mrs. Hunt said in a recent interview that her family intends to move into a smaller home. Because of the bankruptcy proceedings, the Hunts were forced to turn over holdings valued at more than $220 million. Hunt also had to give up his annual salary of $300,000 and income from widespread holdings, the Dallas Times Herald said. Because Texas law grants homeowners an unlimited exemption for a homestead in bankruptcy proceedings, the Hunts won't have to give any proceeds from the sale to creditors.

University of Mississippi officials say a trust fund for paralyzed Ole Miss football player Roy Lee ``Chucky'' Mullins has reached more than $697,000. School officials attribute the most recent contributions to a plea broadcast during the nationally televised Liberty Bowl game Dec. 28 when the Rebels defeated Air Force. More than $12,000 was received by mail on Jan. 3, the first day the university's Office of Development was open after the game. Mullins, 20, of Russellville, Ala., fractured his spine Oct. 28 in a game against Vanderbilt. He is paralyzed from the neck down with little chance of recovery.

Late-night radio talk-show hosts work strange hours and rarely see prime-time television, says one member of that select group. Mutual Broadcasting System's Jim Bohannon doesn't mind the hours and doesn't care about the missed television. ``They tell me I'm not missing a great deal,'' said Bohannon, whose day usually begins at 12:45 a.m. In addition to subbing on Mutual's ``Larry King Live'' talk show for the past seven years, Bohannon is host on the ``Jim Bohannon Show,'' which takes King's slot on Saturday nights. The veteran of 30 years in broadcasting also is host and does feature stories for Mutual's daily ``America in the Morning'' show. Bohannon was in Lincoln Tuesday for the taping of a pilot segment of a proposed Nebraska Educational Television series in which high school students discuss political issues. He was the moderator.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Nominate Pentagon Official to Arms Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he will nominate a Pentagon official, Susan Jane Koch, to be assistant director of the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Koch, 46, would succeed William H. Fite in the arms control post if confirmed. She is a former Central Intelligence Agency analyst who has worked for the Defense Department since 1982, most recently as director of an office on nuclear forces and arms control under the assistant secretary for international security policy. A native of Bridgeport, Conn., she is a Mount Holyoke College graduate with a Ph.D. in political science from Harvard. She taught political science at Mount Holyoke and the University of Connecticut from 1970 to 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Control Advocates Seek Ban on Assault-Style Handguns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs new to UPDATE with Stockton teacher calling for ban on domestically produced assault weapons; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, The importation.
DOC.TEXT: A year after a bloody massacre at a California elementary school, a teacher wounded in that attack called today for a ban on all assault-style weapons, domestic and foreign. ``How many more people, how many more children must face the power of a bullet before something is done?'' asked teacher Janet Geng, who was wounded in the Jan. 17, 1989, attack by a man wielding an AK-47 assault-style rifle in Stockton. ``How many more must die? How many more must be disabled before Congress will act?'' Mrs. Geng asked at a Capitol Hill news conference called by the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence. ``The gun violence must stop now.'' Mrs. Geng, still limping from the wound in her leg, said she would lobby Congress for bills outlawing some domestically produced assault-style weapons. Her bid to meet with President Bush was unsuccessful, said coalition Executive Director Michael K. Beard. The Bush administration responded to the public outcry following the Jan. 17, 1989, shootings in Stockton by banning imports of 43 types of semiautomatic assault-style rifles, including the AK-47. In the incident, drifter Patrick Purdy opened fire at the school playground, killing five children and wounding 29 others and Mrs. Geng. The Coalition to Stop Gun Violence says the government must go further and ban the manufacture and sale of all assault-style rifles, including domestically produced models unaffected by the import ban. Beard said the coalition also supports a ban on imports of semiautomatic assault-style pistols, as advocated by Handgun Control Inc. in a petition today to the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. ``The importation of significant numbers of semiautomatic assault pistols and their increasing use by drug traffickers and other hardcore criminals is a relatively new phenomenon,'' says the petition prepared by Handgun Control Inc.'s legislative counsel, David G. Mengebier. ``All of the factors which ATF considered persuasive in banning the importation of semiautomatic assault rifles are present and applicable to semiautomatic assault pistols,'' the petition says. Handgun Control is concerned about the Israeli Military Industries Uzi pistol, the Heckler and Koch HK-94 pistol _ smaller versions of the Uzi carbine and HK rifle that were banned last July _ and the Australian Automatic Arms SAP pistol, the F.I.E. Spectre P. pistol and the Sterling Mark 7 pistol. Semiautomatic assault pistols are virtually identical to semiautomatic assault rifles in terms of development, design and intended use, the petition said. ``In fact, because semiautomatic assault pistols have similar firepower but are more concealable than their assault rifle counterparts, they present an even greater danger to public safety.'' The ATF and the National Rifle Association said it would be extremely difficult to ban the handguns because rules enacted under the Gun Control Act of 1968 were designed to rule out cheap Saturday Night Specials, not well-made, sophisticated semiautomatic pistols. ``I don't know how one would design criteria that would exclude the firearms they're talking about and not exclude all the other firearms,'' said Jim Baker, the NRA's director of governmental affairs. ``I think that Handgun Control would like to ban anything that there's a political or emotional opportunity to ban, and this is consistent with that policy,'' Baker said. ATF spokesman Jack Killorin said he could not comment on the Handgun Control petition since he had not seen it. All imported weapons must be considered suitable for sporting purposes. Killorin said that because of the extensive legislative history and longstanding regulations for handgun imports, it would be more difficult to ban styles of handguns than to ban the assault-style rifles, for which there was virtually no legislative history. ``One of the things that drove the issue of the semiautomatic assault (rifles) were the astonishing numbers that were beginning to appear for importation,'' he said. ``We may take a look at how many of these are coming in. These may not be a significant import item.'' Mengebier said his organization did not have access to import figures for 1989 because they are considered proprietary information. But he said, ``It's safe to say that thousands have been authorized for importation or are being imported.'' Added Susan Whitmore of Handgun Control: ``Even one is too many. These are killing machines.'' Mengebier said the semiautomatic assault-style pistols represent a new phenomenon, and that regulations should be changed ``to satisfy the statutory requirement that firearms have a sporting purpose.'' A study by Cox Newspapers last year of almost 43,000 gun trace requests submitted to the ATF from police departments nationwide found that the top five guns used by criminals were all handguns produced in the United States, including the TEC-9 assault-style weapon. Three handguns made the list of the top 10 assault-style weapons found in crimes, but all were manufactured domestically _ the Miami-produced TEC-9, and the Atlanta-made Mac-11 and Mac-10, according to the Cox study.

DOC.HEAD: Police Stumped by 17 Killings in Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates figures throughout with three more deaths in last 24 hours; inserts new 6th graf, At a, with comment from mayor
DOC.TEXT: Police in the nation's capital said today they have no idea what has caused a surge in homicides that has left 17 people dead since last Friday. The latest victims include a high school athlete, three teen-agers and an automobile dealer. Of the 28 homicides this year, police said, arrests have been made in five cases. The District of Columbia's homicide toll stood at 18 at this time a year ago and totaled a record 438 for all of 1989. ``We keep searching for the answer,'' said Lt. Reginald Smith, a police spokesman. ``If we had all the answers, we could certainly bring this under control a lot sooner.'' At a news conference, Mayor Marion Barry said he planned to meet with Police Chief Isaac Fulwood to plan new strategies. Barry noted that the homicide rate last January was the worst month in the city's history. Of the latest surge, four deaths were on Friday and Saturday, two on Sunday and four on Monday, two on Tuesday and one early today. Homicide detectives have complained about their heavy workload. ``We might as well surrender,'' one unidentified detective told The Washington Post. ``At least that would be taking action.'' Smith said community involvement is a key element of the police department's plan to battle the increase in homicides, of which 60 percent are drug-related. ``They (community members) have to be a part of our eyes and ears,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Event Moving to Los Angeles After 17 Years in Vegas
DOC.TEXT: The Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon, an entertainment fixture here for 17 years, will move to Los Angeles this year, officials of the Muscular Dystrophy Association said Wednesday. ``It's really a matter of economics,'' Jerry Weinberg, director of field organization for the MDA, said in a telephone interview from the association's New York City headquarters. ``We've always brought most of the talent in from Los Angeles and there was a cost involved. It was much more cost-effective to move to Los Angeles.'' In recent years there had been ``less and less talent in Las Vegas that we could tap into,'' Weinberg said. The telethon has raised more than a half-billion dollars during its Las Vegas run, including a record $42,209,727 in September. ``We really feel sort of sad to be leaving Las Vegas,'' said Bob Ross, MDA executive director and vice president. He said the city that helped make the telethon a Labor Day entertainment event will continue to play ``a very important part'' in the show, with some remote broadcasts planned from Las Vegas. Ross said MDA officials met several weeks ago with Lewis, a longtime Las Vegas resident, ``and he understood the rationale.'' Lewis, 63, did not immediately return calls made to both his home and office for comment on the move. Mayor Ron Lurie and other city officials were at a city council meeting and not immediately available for comment, the mayor's secretary said. Frank Sain, executive director of the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority, said the move came as a surprise but he didn't think it would hurt the city. ``It gave us the dateline, but it didn't pull any people into Las Vegas,'' he said. The Lewis telethon began in New York City in 1966, emanating from a single TV station and raising $1 million. It moved to Las Vegas in 1973 and raised $13.5 million that year. The telethon is now carried by 200 stations and is viewed annually by an estimated 100 million people. The MDA fights 40 neuromuscular diseases that kill and cripple thousands of people annually, most of them young people.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Police Can't Make Random Drug Searches on Buses
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday ruled that police officers may not make drug arrests and search for narcotics by climbing aboard buses and randomly questioning passengers. U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin declared that the ``indiscriminate stopping and questioning'' of people on interstate buses as part of the nation's war on drugs ``seems to have gone too far.'' Sporkin's opinion came in the case of Dennis S. Lewis, a bus rider arrested in Washington, D.C., and accused of carrying drugs from New York. The judge said police made an illegal seizure in their questioning of Lewis and granted the defendant's motion to suppress as evidence drugs taken in the arrest. On Oct. 19 in the bus terminal at Union Station, Lewis denied carrying narcotics or weapons when he was approached by an officer of the Metropolitan Police Narcotic Interdiction Unit. Lewis consented to a patdown search by the plainclothes detective, who found a packet of cocaine stuffed in one of Lewis' socks.
