Subsequently, marijuana was found in Lewis' jacket pocket and heroin was found in a bag on the floor at Lewis' seat on the bus. The detective testified at a Dec. 14 hearing that he had no particular reason for questioning Lewis and that ``sometimes I'll just walk up to anyone who may be on the bus and ask to talk to them.'' ``The specter of passengers riding on a public vehicle of mass transportation being approached by police officers and searched on a strictly random and indiscriminate basis really does not square with the rights protected under the Constitution,'' said the judge. Sporkin said a passenger would not feel free to walk away when approached by police officers in the cramped interior of a bus. A federal appeals court has upheld searches of baggage that occurred in the concourse of Union Station where a citizen confronted by police would not feel constrained from walking away. To walk away from this encounter, Lewis, who was waiting for the bus to continue to Richmond, Va., ``would have had to stand up from his seat, work his way out of the narrow row in which he was situated and ... negotiate his way past'' the plainclothes detective, Sporkin said. ``Even in our drug-infested society it is clear that our legal system demands the existence of some cause before a police officer will approach a citizen to determine whether that individual may be engaged in some illicit activity,'' said the judge.

DOC.HEAD: Sisulu Urges Intensifying the Fight Against Apartheid
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Walter Sisulu on Wednesday urged intensifying the political and military fight against apartheid even though racial tensions are easing in South Africa. Sisulu told about 1,000 exiled ANC members that they should work toward negotiations with the South African government, but pursue their armed struggle to maintain pressure for rapid change of racial laws and societal structures. He called on the ANC's political and military wings and the international community to ``intensify the struggle against apartheid, even though there may be an easing of tensions at home. ``The political struggle and the armed struggle go side by side,'' Sisulu said. Later Wednesday, Sisulu spoke at the U.S. Information Center at a ceremony marking the birthday of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. U.S. Ambassador Jeffrey Davidow spoke about King's commitment to non-violence. ``He understood that violence in the pusuit of justice provides the proponents of injustice the rational to continue oppression,'' Davidow said. The U.S. government supports the ANC's aim of a non-racial democracy in South Africa but opposes its use of bombs, sabotage and military attacks on police and civilians. ``In Martin Luther King, we saw a prophet for African liberation,'' Sisulu said. ``Martin Luther King provided us with a glorious vision, a sense of self-confidence, the assurance of the certainty of victory.'' Sisulu and seven ANC colleagues, all of whom served lengthy prison terms in South Africa, are on a week-long visit to Lusaka, the guerrilla movement's exile headquarters. They came to help co-ordinate ANC strategy in the face of a fast-changing political climate in South Africa. The 60- and 70-year-old men received a rousing welcome from the ANC members who chanted, sang freedom songs and gave clenched fist salutes. The hall was draped in the green, black and gold banners of the ANC and many members wore ANC scarves around their suit collars. Since South African President F.W. de Klerk assumed power in August, he has allowed opposition groups to protest openly and has urged negotiations on a new constitution that would include a political voice for the black majority. But de Klerk says the ANC, the main group fighting to undermine the white government, must commit itself to peaceful solutions and end its military campaign before participating in negotiations. The ANC says the government must lift the state of emergency, legalize the ANC, and end trials and hangings of guerrillas before talks begin. Sisulu and his colleagues campaign openly for their organization in South Africa, but the ANC remains outlawed. Sisulu praised the ANC and its ally, the South African Communist Party, for ``taking the initiative'' and setting down conditions for talks. The ANC has an estimated 15,000 members, many of whom are at guerrilla camps in Tanzania and Uganda. The organization has no offices or military bases in countries bordering South Africa, but it has millions of supporters inside the country. The ANC meetings occur amid widespraed speculation that the group's best-known figure, Nelson Mandela, will be freed within weeks after more than 27 years behind bars. Mandela and the recently released ANC leaders no longer hold formal titles in the organization, and leadership is a major issue facing the organization. The current president, Oliver Tambo, 71, is in a Swedish clinic recovering from a stroke. Sisulu said he intends to visit him before returning home. The ANC in Tanzania said the leaders were expected there on Jan. 23.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Ex-Con Stalked, Killed Prison Pen Pals
DOC.TEXT: An ex-convict suspected in the slayings of four gay men in two states preyed on pen pals he made while in prison, police said. Keith Eugene Goodman, 30, was arrested with two companions Sunday while visiting another of Goodman's pen pals, Peter G. Jones, a Carnegie-Mellon University professor on sabbatical in Laguna Beach, Police Chief Albert C. Ehlow said Tuesday. ``If we had not arrested Goodman, I do believe the man Jones would have been the next victim,'' said Sgt. Richard E. Downing. Goodman, Jon Christopher Mead, 22, and Tracy Holland, 21, all of Anderson, Ind., were arrested Sunday for investigation of the killings of a New York man and three Mississippi men, Ehlow said. ``The victims all were gay. The suspects allegedly would befriend the victims before they were murdered and robbed,'' the police chief said. Jones was among an estimated 20 to 25 pen pals Goodman had while serving time in an Indiana prison for burglary and sexual assault on an 80-year-old woman, authorities said. ``It's very frightening,'' Jones said in an interview. ``I see myself as very lucky because the police told me I was the next victim.'' The New York victim and one Mississippi victim were pen pals, Ehlow said. ``It's a con's con game,'' Ehlow said. ``They write to people to tell them how bad off they are, asking for money to help them through, get a better defense lawyer, that sort of thing. And people send them money and befriend them.'' Authorities say Goodman and Mead left for New York on Dec. 16 to meet Harold D. Williams of Windsor, N.Y., one of Goodman's pen pals. Williams, 60, was found shot to death Dec. 21 in an upstairs bedroom of his house. ``They probably intended to hit him up for money and rob him. They ended up killing him,'' said Ehlow. In Fulton, Miss., R.C. Vaughn, 47; Tommy Mayhall, 37, and Richard Thomas, 30, were shot to death Jan. 6 or 7. One victim was Vaughn's roommate and another apparently was a potential witness to the slayings of the first two, authorities said. San Clemente police arrested the three on a tip from New York authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Stronger Sanctions May Be Needed, Lawmakers Say
DOC.TEXT: Changes in South Africa's white-dominated society have been largely cosmetic and the United States should prepare to impose tougher sanctions, three members of Congress said Wednesday. Pronouncing themselves disappointed after a six-day trip to South Africa that included a meeting with President F.W.de Klerk, the lawmakers said all the significant components of the apartheid system of racial inequality remained in place. ``The government seems to be clinging to the fantasy that somehow conflict in South Africa can be reduced and the pressures from without will be eased while the white minority continues to hold to power and privilege,'' said Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa. Unless far-reaching reforms are made soon, ``there will be a growing movement in the Congress and internationally to intensify sanctions,'' said Rep. Alan Wheat, D-Mo. The Africa subcommittee will begin hearings next month on proposals to further restrict U.S.-South African economic ties, Wolpe said. Congress in 1986 barred the importation of South African coal, steel and agricultural products, imposed banking restrictions and cut direct air links between the two countries. Rep. Ronald Dellums, D-Calif., has introduced a bill that would prohibitvirtually any commercial links with South Africa. A version of the bill cleared the House in 1988 but died in the Senate, lacking the support of Republicans who had backed the 1986 sanctions. Another House bill would impose credit restrictions. The Bush administration has spoken against tightening sanctions as long as de Klerk, who assumed power in August, appears to be moving toward reform. But Wolpe said he was encouraged by the attitude of administration officials who had agreed to discuss the matter. ``We've been speaking much more with one voice'' than during the Reagan administration, which had an ideological aversion to sanctions, Wolpe said. There have been improvements since de Klerk assumed power in August, said Wolpe, Wheat and Rep. Constance Morella, R-Md., who were in South Africa Jan. 4-9. Some political prisoners have been freed and the government is allowing opposition rallies, they said in a joint statement. But hundreds of political prisoners remain in jail, some under death sentences, and politically motivated trials continue, they said. Likewise, purported relaxation of speech restrictions have been offset by harassment of opposition voices in the media, they said. For that reason, even the expected release of jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela would be little more than a ``public relations gimmick'' without genuine reforms, Wheat said. There is ``an enormous gap between some of the highly publicized initiatives taken and the much broader reality that is still in place,'' Wolpe said. He said discussions with leaders of a cross-section of South African society, including government and opposition figures, led the Americans to believe forms of persecution were getting worse. There have been recent reports of political assassinations by death squads ``that appear to be operating under the direction and sanction of police and government authorities,'' Wolpe said. De Klerk has said he wants to negotiate a new constitution that would bring blacks into the national government within five years. However, he opposes black majority rule and envisions a mechanism that would give whites veto power on major policy decisions.

DOC.HEAD: European Community Urged to Boost Aid To Eastern Europe
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 12 nations in the European Community must greatly boost financial and economic aid to the newly emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, the president of the EC Commission said Wednesday. In a proposal one official termed ``very ambitious,'' commission President Jacques Delors suggested the trading bloc provide an extra $22.8 billion annually for five to 10 years to East European countries. That is what the community pays annually to improve conditions in its own poorest regions, he said. By comparison, the EC has so far given less than $3.6 billion to Hungary and Poland, with some of these funds to be spread across three years. Addressing the European Parliament, Delors said he will make firm aid proposals for Eastern Europe later this year and the figures he mentioned here were widely seen as indicating the scope of those proposals. Delors said the EC states must renegotiate the community's funding rules. They did this in February 1988, when EC spending on regional development was raised and spending on runaway farm subsidies was curtailed. ``Another `February 1988' _ equally significant, equally historic _ is needed to demonstrate our solidarity with Eastern Europe,'' Delors said. The EC's 1990 budget totals $56 billion, up 4.7 percent from 1989. Under current spending rules, the EC budget has $4.8 billion in uncommitted funds which could be used for aid to Eastern Europe. Delors' plea that the EC nations make available almost $23 billion a year for Hungary, Poland, East Germany, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia and Romania was received with disbelief by some officials. ``It is very ambitious,'' said a British source who asked not to be named. ``He asks for a lot probably hoping he will end up with half of that.'' A Dutch source called the proposal a ``trial balloon.'' The trade and economic cooperation accords that have recently been signed with the six Eastern European nations, or are now being negotiated, ``are unlikely to meet our requirements and their individual needs,'' Delors said. Also, he said, more money must be forthcoming over a five- to 10-year period if the EC aid is to be effective given the backward nature of the East European economies. Delors, in a speech outlining the work program of the EC executive Commission, also said the EC nations must forge ahead with plans for political and monetary union for the sake of stability across Europe. The community can ``only meet its destiny if the structures, the decision-making methods and the democratic control of European unity are thought about at the highest levels of political debate before the end of this year.'' Delors said the community had helped to inspire the millions in Central and Eastern Europe who had revolted against their Communist regimes in recent months. ``Let us not forget that it was our prosperity, our freedom, our community governed by the rule of law ... that served as a pole of attraction.'' Delors said the Community must reach its goal of economic and monetary union by the end of 1992, before accepting new members. He made an exception for East Germany. ``I must repeat clearly today,'' he said, ``that (East Germany) has its place in the Community, if it asks for it.'' He said East Germany could join if the decision to do so was taken ``through free self-determination, peacefully and democratically, respecting the principles of the Helsinki Final Act, in the context of an East-West dialogue and in the perspective of European integration.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Flight Attendants Injured During Dallas to Boston Trip
DOC.TEXT: An American Airlines flight from Dallas to Boston hit unexpected turbulence Wednesday, injuring three flight attendants, authorities said. Nancy John, a flight attendant based in Dallas, suffered neck injuries during turbulence on Flight 928, said American spokesman Ed Stewart. The other two women, who were not identified, suffered minor injuries, Stewart said. The 767 jetliner, carrying 85 passengers and eight crewmembers, left the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport at 7:53 a.m. Stewart said the plane hit ``clear air turbulence'' over Texarkana, Ark. That kind of turbulence, he said, does not show up on radar screens and can affect a plane unexpectedly. The plane landed at Logan Airport without incident, and the incident was not considered an emergency by airline officials, Stewart said.

DOC.HEAD: Warm, Dry Weather Raises Winter Wheat Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Unseasonably high temperatures and dry soil conditions in much of nation are adding to worries about the 1990 winter wheat crop, the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility reported Wednesday. The facility, an operation of the Commerce and Agriculture departments, reported on crop and weather conditions for the week of Jan. 8-14. ``Snow cover on winter wheat fields was scarce across the Great Plains and Corn Belt, continuing grower concerns over potential freeze damage,'' the report said. ``Warmer-than-normal temperatures during the week in most winter wheat states created concerns of wheat breaking dormancy too early, making (the crop) vulnerable to a freeze.'' Winter wheat is planted in the fall and normally is dormant during midwinter cold before starting to grow again when warmer weather returns. The crop is harvested in the summer. Little or no precipitation was reported in winter wheat areas during the week, except in the Pacific Northwest where a strong storm system packing high winds and heavy precipitation caused flooding in some areas. ``Virtually all winter wheat states are anxious for precipitation to help replenish short subsoil moisture supplies,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Edward Strong, Former UC Berkeley Chancellor, Dies at 88
DOC.TEXT: Edward Strong, chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley during the early 1960s, has died. He was 88. Strong, who died at home Saturday after a long fight with cancer, was chancellor from 1961 to 1965. The period marked some of the university's most rapid growth and the birth of the Free Speech Movement. Strong, whose special interests were the philosophy of history, medieval thought and contemporary tendencies in philosophy, was Mills Professor of Philosophy at Berkeley. He also was chairman of the Department of sociology and social institutions, and was an associate dean of the College of Letters and Science from 1947 to 1955. Strong helped found the Journal of the History of Philosophy and was president of the American Philosophical Association in 1952. Shortly after retiring as chancellor in 1965, Strong said of rebellious students: ``They want the sanctuary of the university to stage political action, but to be exempt from having to answer to the university for accompanying or resulting offenses committed on or off the campus. They want to have it both ways.'' He is survived by his wife, Gertrude; a daughter; two sons; 10 grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren. No formal services are planned.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted East German Leaders Takes Blame for Past Misdeeds
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's former Communist Party chief, Egon Krenz, said Wednesday he misjudged dissidents in the past, but he denied being responsible for the brutal suppression of fall pro-democracy protests. Krenz appeared before an investigating commission of the East Berlin city government that is looking into police brutality during Oct. 7-8 street protests. The protests, coinciding with the visit of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, provided a turning point in the pro-democracy movement that led to the ouster of hard-line leader Erich Honecker 10 days later. Krenz said he accepted ``joint responsibility for misjudging dissident citizens and dissident groups for years.'' ``From today's viewpoint, it is incomprehensible that there was no general Politburo discussion about the negative developments then taking place in society,'' said Krenz, an influential Politburo member even before Honecker's fall. Krenz succeeded Honecker and himself was ousted six weeks later. Krenz added that he and other Politburo members at the time failed to realize that the Roman Catholic and Lutheran churches were ``not working against but rather for the German Democratic Republic.'' Krenz, who was in charge of many police functions at the time of the October protests, criticized the attacks by club-swinging officers. ``The excessive action of law enforcement authorities was neither politically nor morally justifiable,'' he told the panel, but he said he was not personally responsible for orders to attack protesters. Another ousted Politburo member told the commission Honecker himself ordered the attacks. ``Honecker took things into his own hands,'' Guenter Schabowski said. Like Krenz, Schabowski denied personal responsibility for the orders to attack the demonstrators, most of them young people. The panel members are investigating the possibility of filing criminal charges against the ousted leaders. Communist Premier Hans Modrow is struggling to hold together the coalition government formed to govern the nation until elections May 6. The Christian Democrats, one of the non-Communist parties in the coalition, threatened Wednesday to pull out to protest the Communists' continued tight grip on power. Party spokesman Lothar Lueck said the party leadership was showing ``a very strong tendency to leave the government.'' The party holds three of the 27 Cabinet seats. Leaders of the same party threatened to pull out of the coalition last week over Modrow's plans to create a new internal security agency. Modrow dropped plans for the security agency in the face of widespread opposition. A protest outside the East Berlin headquarters of the Honecker-era security agency, which is being dismantled, turned into a rampage Monday night. The Communist Party daily Neues Deutschland on Wednesday blamed the opposition group New Forum for the rampage and said the popular revolution had taken a dangerous turn. New Forum denied responsibility for the rampage, although it said the fliers it distributed in advance of the demonstration called on people to bring stones. ``The stones that were to be taken along were meant only to symbolically seal up the doors of the building,'' said New Forum spokesman Rainer Rodenwald. ``The fliers we sent out clearly said `no violence,''' he said. ``There is no one from New Forum who wanted or planned the violence.''

DOC.HEAD: Frank Probe Continues in Secret as Congressman Works to Restore Image
DOC.TEXT: While a House panel investigates in private, Rep. Barney Frank has been working to show his public career can survive the scandal surrounding his relationship with a male prostitute. The five-term Massachusetts Democrat has regained visibility as one of the House's better-known liberals. And, with no well-known challengers set to run against him, Frank supporters have been raising funds at a healthy clip for his campaign and legal defense. ``Barney Frank has weathered the storm,'' said Larry Rasky, a Democratic consultant in Boston. ``The whole incident has almost become a non-issue.'' But the private work of the House ethics committee into his case continues, with no indication yet what the panel's next move might be. And Massachusetts Republican Executive Secretary Alexander Tennant said Frank's ``credibility has been irreparably damaged,'' though Tennant concedes the GOP has had a hard time coming up with a strong opponent for Frank if he decides to run for re-election. In Washington, legal activist John F. Banzhaf III, with the financial backing of the Conservative Caucus, filed a lawsuit Tuesday seeking to force Frank into court for allegedly tolerating a prostitution operation that Stephen Gobie contends he ran out of Frank's Capitol Hill apartment. Late Tuesday, D.C. Superior Court Judge Harold L. Cushenberry dismissed the request for an injunction. Frank admits he paid Gobie $80 in 1985 for sexual relations and later hired Gobie with personal funds as a housekeeper and driver. But he says he dismissed Gobie in August 1987 when he learned Gobie was using his apartment for prostitution. Gobie told his story to the ethics committee for more than four hours behind closed doors on Dec. 5. Borrowing a line from Shakespeare's ``Julius Caesar,'' he told reporters afterward, ``I came to praise Congressman Frank today, not to bury him.'' Frank hinted strongly in a recent interview that he has testified before the ethics committee. Meanwhile, Frank is leading a Democratic move to cut defense spending and shift the funds into deficit reduction and domestic programs. Even President Bush singled Frank out at a recent bill-signing ceremony for his work on housing legislation. ``If you're being complimented by the president you must be doing something right,'' said Rep. Joseph Moakley, D-Mass. With few exceptions, Frank has not commented at length on Gobie since the scandal broke last summer. ``I won't discuss it,'' he said recently when asked about the case. ``I'm not going to contribute to a non-story.'' Penthouse magazine is to publish next month an interview with Gobie, purchased by the magazine for a reported $50,000. ``There's some sense that there's going to be another wave that will coincide with the Penthouse publication and the results of the ethics hearing,'' said Rasky, the Bay State political consultant. ``But at this point, unless there's something startlingly new revealed, and I don't see any reason to expect that there will, it's just going to be treated more as the final act of last season's play.''

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Demands Halt to U.S.-South Korea Military Exercises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to ADD dropped word ``Wednesday.''
DOC.TEXT: North Korea on Wednesday demanded the United States and South Korea call off their annual joint military exercises, saying the war games pose a nuclear threat to the divided peninsula. During a meeting of the Military Armistice Commission in this truce village, chief North Korean delegate Choe Ui Ung also urged South Korea to remove an alleged concrete border wall to ensure free travel between the nations. U.S. Rear Adm. Larry G. Vogt refused to discuss the demand for an end to the annual ``Team Spirit'' exercises, saying the matter was ``outside the purview'' of the commission. He told North Korea to take the issue up directly with Seoul. As in the past, Vogt invited Choe to visit South Korea and observe the ``defensive'' nature of the exercises, set for March. He also asked North Korea to reciprocate by inviting U.S. and South Korean officials to its exercises. Choe did not respond. Pyongyang has rejected all such invitations in the past, and last year it protested the military exercises by suspending talks between lawmakers from both nations that were aimed at improving relations. North Korea traditionally has opposed the exercises as a sign that South Korea and the United States are preparing to attack. This year, however, it said it was concerned about a nuclear threat. The 43,000 U.S. troops based in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty are believed to have nuclear forces but Washington has refused to confirm or deny this. North Korean President Kim Il Sung first raised the issue of a concrete border wall in his New Year's speech and called for talks with South Korean political leaders on demolishing it. Kim claimed his nation had not built such barriers on its side of the Demilitarized Zone and was ready to remove ``barbed wires which mark a boundary.'' Vogt, speaking for the U.N. Command based in Seoul, denied the existence of a concrete wall on the southern side of the Demilitarized Zone and urged Choe to go with him to the site to verify this. Under the armistice that ended the 1950-53 Korean War, the Demilitarized Zone is not supposed to be fortified by either nation, and only a limited number of lightly armed troops are authorized to police it. Outside the 2{-mile zone, however, the border area on both sides is sealed and heavily fortified by fences, concrete bunkers, mine fields and hundreds of thousands of heavily armed troops. Vogt displayed pictures that he said showed North Korean bunkers, barbed wire fences and other barriers in the Demilitarized Zone on the northern side. He proposed joint investigations, but Choe again did not respond. South Korea has welcomed Kim's call for talks on ensuring free travel across the border. But Seoul has accused North Korea of making a false claim regarding a concrete wall to mislead world opinion, perhaps to try to head off pressure on the authoritarian nation to carry out democratic reforms similar to those that have swept Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Kennan Sees Dangers in Hastily-Reunified Germany
DOC.TEXT: Political instability in East Germany combined with talk of a reunified Germany are potentially dangerous situations that threaten a new European order, a foreign policy expert said Wednesday. Former Amb. George F. Kennan, 86, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee it would be foolish to reunify Germany until the Soviet Union, the United States and Germany's neighbors agree on a new framework. ``The security arrangements existing today in much of Europe ... the presence of foreign military forces on the territories of both parts of Germany, the existence of powerful indigenous German forces in both parts of Germany ... are totally incompatible with an immediate reunification.'' Kennan, a professor emeritus at the Institute for Advanced Studies at Princeton, N.J., said developments in East Germany should not been allowed to serve as a catalyst for a hasty reunification. East Germany is a ``very, very delicate, dicey and dangerous situation,'' said Kennan, saying that in a few more days the situation could disintegrate to the point there is no central government. ``It's hard to talk to crowds on the street,'' he said. Opposition has been mounting to East Germany's Communist-led transition government, which has scheduled elections on May 6. This week, the police said opposition figures were involved in the ransacking of the state security headquarters on Monday. Kennan said East Germany's political crisis and the ensuing talk of reunifying Germany ``present the greatest potential danagers.'' As a first step, Kennan suggested the four powers that govern Berlin _ the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union _ establish a unified government. That entity would not jeopardize any future reunification and a timetable could be worked out for combining the two Germanys, he said. More generally, Kennan said the situation in all the Eastern European countries is ``unstable and not without dangerous aspects.'' Those countries now governed by reform Communists face economic problems and upcoming elections. It will be ``at least a year or two before the emerging democratic establishments can be smoothly functioning.'' As for Soviet leader Mikhael Gorbachev, Kennan said the United States could help him survive recent upheaval in his country by removing trade impediments and proposing further reductions in conventional arms in Europe. Kennan, an architect of the Cold War ``containment'' theory in the 1940s, has long advocated that the superpowers withdraw their troops from Europe. In 1981, he was criticized by hard-line conservatives for suggesting both countries cut their nuclear arsenals by 50 percent. But that position basically was endorsed by Gorbachev and President Bush at their Malta summit in December.

DOC.HEAD: Stockton Massacre Turns Teacher Into Gun Control Advocate
DOC.TEXT: Elementary school teacher Janet Geng, wounded a year ago when a drifter opened fire at her California school, said Wednesday ``The emotional trauma is still with us. Many of us walk in fear.'' She remembers the smallest details of Jan. 17, 1989, when Patrick Purdy fired more than 100 rounds from a semiautomatic assault-style AK-47 rifle in the schoolyard of Cleveland Elementary in Stockon, Calif. Purdy, 24, killed five children and wounded 29 others as well as Mrs. Geng in less than two minutes before he killed himself. ``My wounded leg rested on my good one,'' she told a Capitol Hill news conference. ``The pressure of the wound was tremendous. I tried to get hold of the blacktop to pull myself, but I couldn't move either leg. I tried to look out on the playground, but all I saw was the sparks and the popping of the gravel coming closer. I was going to die.'' She spent 31 days in the hospital and underwent four operations in an effort to fix what was called a ``grapefruit'' size hole in her left leg. At the time, she wasn't involved in the gun control movement. Today, she is a committed member, appearing at a news conference called by the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence and lobbying Congress to approve pending legislation that would ban the sale and manufacture of certain domestically produced, assault-style weapons. ``We're not talking about just a simple little gun anymore that's out there,'' she said. ``We're talking about ... a war weapon.'' Last July, in part as a response to the outcry over the Stockton shootings, the Bush administration banned the imports of 43 types of semiautomatic assault-style weapons, including the AK-47. That action was taken by the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, which has control over firearms imports and requires that the weapons be suitable for sporting uses. The coalition wants President Bush to call for legislation that would limit or ban production or sale of similar domestically produced weapons. Coalition members argue that without a clear sign from the president that he will sign such a bill, Congress won't act. Meanwhile, Handgun Control Inc. petitioned the government Wednesday to prohibit imports of semiautomatic assault-style pistols, including the Uzi and HK-94 handguns, which are similar to the rifle-size Uzi and HK-94 weapons banned last July. Asked Wednesday about White House reaction to the petition, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We don't have any reaction. We'll be guided by ATF.'' A study by Cox Newspapers last year of almost 43,000 gun trace requests submitted to the ATF from police departments nationwide found that the top five guns used by criminals were all handguns produced in the United States, including the TEC-9 assault-style weapon. Three handguns made the list of the top 10 assault-style weapons found in crimes, but all were manufactured domestically: the Miami-produced TEC-9, and the Atlanta-made Mac-11 and Mac-10, according to the Cox study. ATF spokesman Jack Killorin said Tuesday that it would be much more difficult to ban pistol imports than it was to ban the rifle imports because there have been two decades of regulations and legislative history covering what handguns may be imported. The rifles, he said, reflected relatively new technology not covered by the rules developed since the Gun Control Act of 1968. Jim Baker, the NRA's director of governmental affairs, said, ``I don't know how one would design criteria that would exclude the firearms they're talking about and not exclude all the other firearms.'' But the Handgun Control petition said ``All of the factors which ATF considered persuasive in banning the importation of semiautomatic assault rifles are present and applicable to semiautomatic assault pistols.'' Mrs. Geng had wanted to present Bush a petition signed by 59 staff members from Cleveland Elementary asking for federal legislation that would match California measures banning sales of assault-style weapons. But White House aides said Bush did not have time to meet her, according to coalition spokesman Jeffrey Muchnick. The White House press office did not immediately respond to a request for comment Wednesday. Elsewhere, the Center to Prevent Handgun Violence at a news conference unveiled eight public service TV advertisements to enhance awareness of handgun safety and to keep the weapons away from children. Dewey Stokes, national president of the Fraternal Order of Police, urged all gun owners to purchase a box with a combination lock for their weapons at home: ``This is where all guns belong, in a locked box.'' The commercials feature Stokes; Lyle W. Swenson, president, National Sheriffs' Association; Charles Gruber, president, International Association of Chiefs of Police; Kathy Burke, president, International Association of Women Police; Robert Scully, president, National Association of Police Organizations; Sylvester Daughtry, National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives; Rick Darling, chairman, National Troopers' Coalition; and Mack Vines, president, Police Executive Research Forum.

DOC.HEAD: Miniature Generator Sharply Cuts Heart Attack Death Rate
DOC.TEXT: A tiny generator placed in the body to deliver life-saving electrical shocks to the heart has dramatically cut the death rate in people with heart rhythm disorders, a study shows. Patients who have been given the device faced a 25 percent chance of dying each year without it, and practically none would have survived five years. With the device, 94 percent survive five years and 85 percent survive 10 years, said Dr. Levi Watkins Jr. of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. Each year, 600,000 Americans die suddenly from heart attacks that trigger abnormal heart rhythms, the American Heart Association says. About 50,000 to 100,000 Americans each year could benefit from the device, Watkins said. They are patients who have already survived one cardiac arrest or have been diagnosed with severe heart rhythm disorders. Additionally, their disorders have been shown not to respond to drug treatment, Watkins said. He spoke Wednesday at the American Heart Association's annual science writers' forum. The device, which is inserted under the skin of the abdomen, is connected to the heart by means of two flexible electrodes. It monitors the heart's rhythm continually. When it detects an abnormality it quickly delivers a shock powerful enough to restore normal heart rhythm, Watkins said. The device is a miniaturized equivalent of the large generator or defibrillator with two paddle-like electrodes that is used in hospitals to correct abnormal rhythms. The small version is called an automatic implantable cardioverter defibrillator. It differs from a pacemaker in that it operates only when it detects an abnormality. A pacemaker delivers a steady stream of pulses to the heart to cause it to beat. And a pacemaker cannot correct the kinds of rhythm disorders that lead to sudden death. The implantable defibrillator has been put into more than 7,000 patients worldwide ``with remarkable results,'' Watkins said. The Hopkins team has used the defibrillator, which is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, in more than 310 patients, mostly men, Watkins said. About 4 percent of the patients died during the surgery to implant the defibrillator, he said. ``The 85 percent 10-year survival free of sudden cardiac death must be regarded as the most significant advance in the treatment of malignant cardiac arrhythmias in this decade,'' Watkins wrote in a paper describing the research. The defibrillator costs $15,000 and its implantation requires an additional $15,000 to $20,000 worth of hospital care. But it may be cheaper than the costs of the long-term hospital care needed to find suitable drug treatments for the patients, said Dr. Myron Weisfeldt, president of the American Heart Association. Improvements in the device _ coupled with growing doubts about the effectiveness of some anti-arrhythmia drugs _ should lead to much greater use of the device in the near future, Weisfeldt said.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Miners See Light at Tunnel's End
DOC.TEXT: Striking coal miner Kenny Wallace says he's worked underground long enough to know when you see the light at the end of the tunnel, and it always takes longer to get out than you think. While the United Mine Workers on strike against Pittston Coal Group are frustrated by a delay in getting to vote on a contract, Wallace said Wednesday they're confident the settlement negotiated two weeks ago by union leaders will bring an end to the labor dispute. ``It's just like being down in a mine,'' said Wallace, a 38-year-old electrician from Haysi. ``You see the light and it takes time to get there. It just takes time.'' When UMW and company negotiators worked out the tentative settlement, they agreed to try to dissolve hundreds of legal actions that arose during the two years the miners have been without a contract, including $65 million in fines against the union for illegal strike activities. The mountain of litigation is proving harder to dig through than union officials originally envisioned. UMW President Richard Trumka, badgered by reporters to make an estimate on New Year's Day, said the contract might be sent down to the miners in eight to 10 days. Now, no union official will estimate when the vote will take place and won't even talk about a timetable on the record. ``It's not that we want to keep people in the dark; we're just not ready to ballpark it,'' one union representative said. Copies of the contract haven't even been printed yet. Attorneys for the union and company were still ``tying up loose ends'' Wednesday, the representative said. Hearings before the judges who levied the fines have not been scheduled. Trumka sent a letter last week to each of the 1,700 striking miners in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky explaining the delay, praising them for forcing Pittston to make concessions they sought and urging them to remain patient. While the terms of the contract remain a secret, industry analysts with second-hand knowledge of it have said the union won on their two key issues: better health and retirement benefits and improved job security. ``I don't think Mr. Trumka will send down a contract we can't live with,'' Wallace said. But the delay is starting to frustrate some of the miners, such as Clifford ``Redbone'' Steffey of St. Paul, who is known for his good humor and flatfoot dancing to bluegrass music. ``I makes it hard after we struggled this hard to get a contract and it just lingers on; I'd like to get back to work,'' Steffey said at a rally Tuesday at the union's Camp Solidarity in Russell County. ``It's aggravating knowing you've got a contract and can't see it.''

DOC.HEAD: Strikes Continue at Coal Mines
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A delegation of coal miners met with the finance minister Wednesday to discuss the demands of more than 6,000 striking miners, the PAP news agency said. The strike began Tuesday at five mines in southern Poland and is the most significant labor protest since Jan. 1, when a radical reform plan took effect to create a market-oriented economy and check inflation. Since then, prices have gone up dramatically and the miners are demanding higher pay. Tomasz Gorski, a spokesman for the Solidarity trade union in the Katowice region, said a delegation of miners met with Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, but neither Gorski nor a spokesman for Balcerowicz could provide details. About 6,000 workers were on strike at the Czerwone Zaglebie mine and another 40 at the Niwka Modrzejow mine, both in the city of Sosnowiec just outside Katowice, a major industrial center 185 miles south of Warsaw. Workers returned to work at Kazimierz Juliusz, another mine near Katowice, PAP said. Strikes also continued at three small mines in Walbrzych, a city 12 miles from the border with Czechoslovakia, the news agency reported. The pro-Solidarity newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza had reported Wednesday that workers at two of the mines had suspended their strikes. Telephone calls to the Walbrzych area could not be put through. The miners at Czerwone Zaglebie were demanding a $26 supplement to their wages for December. The 130 workers on strike at the Thorez mine in Walbrzych were demanding higher pay, and Polish TV earlier reported that the demands were similar at the other two mines in the city. The workers also are demanding a reduction in mine office employees and assurances that the strikers will not face retaliation. The economic reforms being carried out include a tight wage policy as part of the attack on inflation. Prices are soaring, however, because they are no longer controlled by the government or kept artificially low by budget subsidies. Top Finance Ministry officials say it will take at least six months for prices to stabilize, and that the interim period will be difficult for workers. None of the mines involved in the current strike participated in the August 1988 walkouts that led to the widespread labor unrest that forced the Communist authorities who ruled at the time to start talks on political reform. The talks led to the legalization of Solidarity last year and to partially free elections in June. Solidarity's sweeping victory in those elections paved the wave for the election of Solidarity editor Tadeusz Mazowiecki as the first non-Communist head of government in 40 years.

DOC.HEAD: Profit-Sharing Boosts Productivity, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: Profit-sharing plans, coupled with giving workers a say in day-to-day decision-making, can boost productivity at little or no cost to businesses, a study suggests. ``You can get productivity on the cheap, if it works,'' said Alan Blinder, an economist at Princeton University and editor of ``Paying for Productivity.'' The book is a collection of studies examining ways to boost U.S. productivity, considered by many to be a crucial issue facing the country as it struggles to compete with Japan and other rising economic powers. Allowing workers to participate in decisions and rewarding their efficiency with part of the profits can boost productivity at little, if any, cost to the employer, Blinder said. Other methods of boosting productivity, such as improving education and capital investments, use many resources, he noted. The studies, published this month by the Brookings Institution, a generally liberal think tank, explore whether flexible pay, employee stock ownership, profit-sharing and incentive bonuses make workers more productive by linking pay to performance. Evidence offered by the economists suggests that extra pay is likely to be most effective when businesses also encourage employee participation in the day-to-day decisions of the workplace. ``Putting the two together as a package in the workplace creates a good environment where workers have incentive and the inclination to do things that are good for the company,'' Blinder said. Between 15 percent and 20 percent of American firms have some sort of profit-sharing plans for their employees, he said. Productivity, or the amount produced by each worker for every hour he or she is on the job, increased at an annual rate of nearly 3 percent between 1947 and 1973, but since then has averaged a gain of only about 1 percent. Blinder said management and labor have been reluctant to shift to allowing more worker participation partly because it upsets ``the strong hierarchical boss-to-worker relationship.'' ``There's an atmosphere of distrust there ... some workers view anything as a plot to make them work harder,'' Blinder said. Robert Litan, director of Brookings' Center for Economic Progress and Employment, said labor has been slow to back profit-sharing plans because ``there's a perception that profit-sharing is not gravy, that it's coming out of their paycheck.'' Masanori Hashimoto, an Ohio State economist, studied Japanese management techniques that enlist workers in so-called shop floor decisions. He stopped short of recommending a wholesale import of those techniques to the United States, citing differences between the two nations' economies. ``Part of the explanation is that in the past, managers felt threatened by dilution of their power ... but the American industry seems to be heading in that direction,'' Hashimoto said. He noted that some firms have begun experimenting with worker participation techniques. For instance, at the New United Motor Manufacturing Inc. or Nummi plant in Fremont, Calif., a joint venture by General Motors and Toyota, teams of six to eight workers are responsible for job rotation, balancing work assignments and equalizing workloads. Nummi spokesman Michael Damer said plant officials believe worker participation is at least partly responsible for a huge drop in absenteeism. At the old GM plant, 20 percent to 25 percent of the work force would fail to show on any given day _ now the absenteeism rate is 4 percent, he said. Some workers have balked at the team concept, but Frank Joyce, a spokesman for the United Auto Workers, said the UAW ``has traditionally pushed for more worker input.'' ``Management is too important to be left just to managers,'' Joyce said. At the same time, he said the union has been keenly interested in who benefits from the fruits of increased productivity, noting it is not in labor's interest to make jobs so efficient that certain workers aren't needed anymore.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted of Murder of Man Who Hassled Waitress
DOC.TEXT: A man who went into a rage after another customer berated a waitress about a cheeseburger served without lettuce and tomatoes was found guilty Wednesday of murdering the complaining customer. A jury deliberated five hours before finding Ronald J. Longo, 45, of Saratoga Springs guilty of second-degree murder. Longo argued he was acting in self defense when he stabbed William McEntire, 27, of Weatherford, Texas, during an argument Nov. 5, 1988. Witnesses testified they heard Longo threaten McEntire after the argument at the Spa City Diner counter over McEntire's treatment of a waitress. Longo was ordered out of the restaurant and was lying in wait for McEntire and allegedly brandished a knife during a fight outside the diner in Saratoga Springs, according to testimony. McEntire was working on a construction project in the upstate New York community. Longo was remanded to the Saratoga County Correctional Facility, where he has been there since turning himself in after the incident. Sentencing is scheduled for Feb. 8.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Trumpeter Swan Sighting in Mississippi
DOC.TEXT: A trumpeter swan, a huge bird with a booming call and wingspan wider than a bald eagle's, has been seen in Mississippi for the first time since records started being kept and perhaps for centuries. Birdwatchers speculate a harsh winter that froze northern lakes drove the bird this far south. ``The trumpeter swan is not even on our checklist,'' said Nona Herbert, a member of the Mississippi Ornithological Society. The trumpeter, a snow-white black-billed birds that weighs about 25 pounds with a wingspan of 5 to 6 feet, has apparently settled with smaller tundra swans in a flooded bean field four miles from Herbert's home in the Choctaw community of Bolivar County. Trumpeter swans are among the biggest birds in North America. In flight they stretch about 4{ feet from the tips of their bills to the tips of their tails. They normally winter along the Alaskan and Washington coasts or in the northern Great Basin and can be seen year-round at Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming and Montana. Herbert and Don Simon, an Arkansas wildlife expert, identified the bird as a trumpeter swan Sunday and spread the word to other birders. ``I've been out seeing them every day, taking somebody to see them every day,'' Herbert said, estimating that at least 100 birders have come to glimpse the trumpeter and tundra swans. Marvin Davis of Oxford, president of the state's bird-watching society, said he had been skeptical of Herbert and Simon's claim until he saw the bird for himself. ``It is all improbable, but that's what makes bird-watching so exciting. Birds have wings, so they fly where books say they shouldn't be. Birds haven't read the books,'' Davis said. The species has never been sighted since the society's Bird Records Committee began keeping a formal list in 1962. Davis said trumpeter swan bones have been found among 500-year-old Indian artifacts, but it's not even certain that the birds were in Mississippi even then because the bones could have been traded among Indians from across large geographic areas. ``There's no definite record of live birds being in Mississippi before now,'' he said. ``As far as I know, this is a first.'' Davis said he knows of a book that mentions a 19th-century sighting but he said that sighting was ``questionable.''

DOC.HEAD: Harkin Says Red Tape Eating Up Funds To Fight Swine Pseudorabies
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Tom Harkin said Wednesday that too much of the money meant for eradicating the deadly swine virus pseudorabies appears lost in ``a black hole'' of administrative costs. Harkin's state, Iowa, is getting only $6,000 more funds to fight the disease this year, despite the $600,000 overall increase in the federal program. Some states are actually being cut back. ``Where's the black hole?'' the Iowa Democrat said. ``It's my intention to work with the inspector general and the GAO (General Accounting Office) to get some accounting breakouts,'' Harkin told a Senate hearing. The 10-year federal program to rid the nation's swine population of pseudorabies began last January with $3.1 million for 1989. The amount was increased by $600,000 for fiscal 1990. The program also calls for state and pork industry contributions. Over 20 percent of the Iowa swine herds are infected with pseudorabies and nearly 47 percent of the nation's infected herds are located in Iowa, said Harkin. Rep. Tom Tauke, R-Iowa, who says he represents the leading pork-producing district in the nation, also has blasted the Agriculture Department for spending so much on administration instead of testing, vaccination and other efforts directly related to getting rid of the virus. ``This vital federal program dedicated to eradicating deadly swine disease has been rendered virtually useless by bureaucratic red tape,'' Tauke said in a press release Monday. Under questioning Wednesday from Harkin, two Agriculture Department officials admitted a greater percentage of the appropriated funds was going to administration than Congress intended. But they defended the use as necessary and said there still was enough money to make progress in the eradication program. Lonnie King, deputy administrator at USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said that in 1989 other programs within the agency helped support the administrative costs of running the pseudorabies program. ``Because pseudorabies will pay its fair share of expenses and because of the consolidation of purchases to save money, some state allocations will be reduced,'' King said. ``We are confident that the funds allocated to the states are adequate to further the progress of the national eradication program.'' But Harkin wasn't satisfied. ``This confirms everyone's worst fears about government,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Withdrawal of Soviet Troops Major Topic Next Month
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The withdrawal of all Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia by the end of 1990 will be a key issue when President Vaclav Havel visits Moscow next month, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Wednesday. ``We consider the Soviet pullout to be a key issue in the relations between our two countries,'' said spokesman Lubos Dobrovsky. Earlier this week, Soviet and Czechoslovak delegations failed to produce a tangible result in their talks in Prague, despite of a draft agreement proposed by the Czechoslovak side. The talks ended Tuesday. Dobrovsky said he believed the Soviet delegation ``did not quite fully comprehend the depth of transformations that took place in Czechoslovakia.'' ``The Czechoslovak delegation left no doubt on the Soviet side that it will seek the withdrawal of Soviet troops with utmost consistency,'' Dobrovsky said. ``We have reasons to believe that a solution satisfying both sides will be found as soon as possible.'' Dobrovsky also confirmed Czechoslovakia would seek a complete Soviet pullout by the end of 1990 and the withdrawal of ``a decisive part of Soviet troops'' before scheduled elections in June. ``The dates we have proposed were neither accepted nor rejected by the Soviet side,'' he stated. The Soviet Union stationed 75,000 soldiers in Czechoslovakia after the 1968 Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion crushed the ``Prague Spring'' liberal reforms of Alexander Dubcek.

DOC.HEAD: Morris Frantic When Program Replicated Wildly, Friend Says
DOC.TEXT: A graduate student was frantic when the worm program he designed went berserk and he couldn't stop it from paralyzing a federal nationwide computer network, a friend of his testified Wednesday. Paul Graham, a 25-year-old graduate student at Harvard University, testified that defendant Robert T. Morris designed the worm to break into the Internet system, but it wasn't intended to replicate wildly as it did or cause any damage. ``It was just supposed to go from computer to computer to see how far it could get. Once it got in, it wasn't supposed to do anything,'' said Graham, a witness for the government in the federal trial. Morris is charged with designing and setting loose the program that crippled an estimated 6,000 computers linked to Internet in November 1988. If convicted, Morris, 25, of Arnold, Md., a suspended Cornell University student, faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Graham, who met Morris when he was an undergraduate at Harvard, told jurors that Morris deliberately added safeguards to limit the growth of his program to ensure it would cause no permanent file damage to the computers it attacked. ``He put in a wrong number and instead of just allowing a few copies every once-in-a-while, it made lots of copies every time,'' said Graham. Morris telephoned Graham from Cornell the night of the attack after realizing his worm was out of control, Graham testified. ``He sounded like he had a final the next day that he hadn't studied for. He sounded miserable. He sounded in a state of shock and horror,'' Graham told the jury, adding that the usually ``puritanical'' Morris was even using profanities. Morris tried to regain access to his computer at Cornell to try to stop the worm, but his program already had immobilized Cornell's computers, preventing him from getting back into the system, said Graham. ``We thought maybe we could send out another program that could eat the worm and stop its processes,'' he said. ``But there was no way to send something after the virus. It wouldn't get through. It was pointless.'' Graham said Morris first told him about designing the worm when the Cornell student visited Harvard for a weekend in late October 1988. Morris, whom Graham said could do anything on a computer, first mentioned his plan to design a virus to infect Internet after discovering a software bug, or flaw, in Harvard's UNIX system that would allow unauthorized entry. Graham told the jury that UNIX was widely regarded as an insecure system. Graham said he never told anyone about Morris' worm because the plan was mentioned to him in confidence and he hadn't realized Morris was so close to having it finished. Graham said he saw nothing wrong about what Morris was doing because breaking into systems is a common practice of fledgling computer security students.

DOC.HEAD: Big Thaw Thwarts Winter Activities in Milwaukee
DOC.TEXT: An extended January thaw featuring spring-like temperatures has melted the usual snow here, but planning and technology have kept the city's annual winter festival on ice. Organizers of the month-long Big Cool Winterfest were prepared for an uncooperative forecast, building a refrigeration unit for the skating rink and stockpiling snow for the collegiate snow sculpting contest. The city, which sponsors the festival, spent $150,000 to ensure the Olympic-size rink would remain cold after four years of warm Januarys ruined past festival events, said Winterfest executive director Elizabeth Black. ``With this warm weather, we wouldn't have been able to open the rink. It would have been a Big Cool pond if we wouldn't have refrigerated,'' she said. Temperatures Wednesday, the 21st straight day Milwaukee exceeded its seasonal norms, peaked into the low 50s, threatening to break a century-old temperature record. The thaw is forecast to continue at least through the weekend. Rain has covered most of Wisconsin this week and Milwaukee thus far has received just 1.8 inches of snow in January, well below the monthly average of 13 inches. Luckily, the festival organizers had taken precautions against that development, stockpiling snow that fell in December and storing the piles under tarps and plywood boxes to keep it fresh for the sculptors. The student captain of a 25-member sculpting team from the Milwaukee School of Engineering said they decided to adjust the theme of their submission in this weekend's snow sculpting competition. Mark Piszczek, 21, of Glendale Heights, Ill. said the crew of architectural engineering students plan to create a snowman sitting in an open refrigerator roasting a marshmallow over an campfire. The balmy weather has cut sales for snow removal businesses like Blizzard Wizzard and Snowbird Plowing Service and shops that sell skis, snowmobiles and other seasonal equipment. Several Wisconsin ski areas have begun to report concerns about the unseasonal weather. At Crystal Ridge near Milwaukee, a 5-foot snow base which formed in mid-December has melted to 10 inches in some areas. ``Obviously, it hurts. People don't think about skiing when it's raining,'' Crystal Ridge manager Daphne Reed said. Kay Decker, a Chamber of Commerce spokeswoman in Hurley in northern Wisconsin, said the continued warmth would hurt the economies of communities like her own that depend on winter tourism.. ``They call us the snow-belt. Our Januarys are usually cold. For us to have 20 to 30 degrees isn't natural. Thirty degrees is like spring,'' Ms. Decker said.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Says Some Lens Solution Contains Dangerous Bacteria
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday that some bottles of Wet Cote contact lens solution contain a bacteria that could cause serious eye infections. The contaminated batch carries the lot number W3028 and the expiration date 6-91 on the label. It was distributed in Texas, Florida, Georgia, Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, Ohio, North Carolina, Maryland, Tennessee and Illinois, the FDA said. Wet Cote, made by Occumed Inc. in Sarasota, Fla., is a wetting solution designed for use with hard contact lenses. Seven of 20 bottles of Wet Cote from the batch that were analyzed were found to be contaminated with a bacteria called Pseudomonas cepecia, which can cause serious eye infections that are difficult to treat and in rare cases lead to blindness, the FDA said. The manufacturer recalled the product, but only about a third of the 1,500 bottles produced were recovered, the agency said. The FDA advised consumers who have bottles of Wet Cote to check the label and if the lot number shows it was from the contaminated batch, not to use it but return the product to the place of purchase. The contaminated liquid looks the same as the safe product, the FDA noted.

DOC.HEAD: `Dr. Flush,' An Engineer, Designs a Better Space Toilet
With AM-Space Shuttle
LaserPhoto HF1
DOC.TEXT: When the shuttle Columbia returns to Earth on Friday, scientists will spend weeks debriefing the astronauts, but an engineer dubbed Dr. Flush will be interested in only one thing: How did the toilet work? Don Rethke, a mechanical engineer at Hamilton Standard for 27 years, is hard at work refining a space toilet that he says will solve the delicate problems that have plagued astronauts since the early days of space exploration: how to cope with zero gravity, limited storage and, well, the smell when answering nature's call in space. ``We wanted it to be more earthlike,'' Rethke said recently as he showed off a prototype of his commode during an interview in his cramped research trailer _ about half the size of the shuttle cabin. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has already given Rethke's design its preliminary approval, but the five Columbia crew members will be quizzed when they return and their reports passed on to Rethke so he and his assistants can further refine the commode. ``It's going to be a pretty user-friendly type system,'' said Eugene Winkler of NASA's shuttle support team at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. ``We've put the best minds in the country together on this new potty, so I think it should work out pretty well.'' Hamilton Standard, which has been designing space suits for NASA since the 1960s, last year won a $35 million contract to design a toilet that will meet the demands of larger crews and longer missions. Rethke's commode will be installed on the ``extended-duration orbiter'' shuttle to be launched in March 1992 for 16 days, but is ultimately headed for the space station Freedom, an orbiting laboratory where astronauts will live for months at a time later this decade. The aeronautics division of the giant defense contractor United Technologies Corp., Hamilton Standard lost a fierce competition with General Electric to design space commodes in the early 1970s, but got a second chance after GE dropped out of the space-waste game. The firm last year also won the maintenance contract for the disposal system now in use. Things have come a long way since that day in 1961 when Alan B. Shepard Jr. wet his space suit as he sat helplessly strapped in his Freedom 7 capsule atop a Redstone rocket, waiting to become the first American launched into space. During the Gemini and Apollo programs, astronauts urinated into cups that were just dumped into space; they used stick-on plastic bags for solid waste they carried back to Earth, Winkler said. It was all very messy, smelly and uncomfortable, and ``zero hygiene for the astronauts who went to the moon,'' Rethke said. The shuttles have had improved commodes that resemble portable toilets, but the accommodations are still pretty Spartan. Capacity is a problem and the astronauts have to use the same bowl that can't be flushed, Rethke said. Rethke's aim for the space toilet was simple: make it comfortable and clean. His commode looks much like the ordinary toilet, but instead of water, there are individual collection bags for solid waste. Urine is funneled into a separate container and will be chemically treated for ``hygienic use'' _ washing, but not drinking water. The commode, in a closet similar to the cramped restrooms on commercial jetliners, has biodegradable wipes, a rearview mirror to help astronauts with delicate manuevers and padded bars to hold them in place. A vacuum-like device solves the zero-gravity problem by drawing the waste downward, also controlling ordor and bacteria. Instead of flushing, the astronauts will simply press a button after they are done. The collection bags are then automatically sealed, moved along a metal track and dropped into a compacter that can hold a week's worth of waste from four astronauts, Rethke said. When full, the 25-inch, fiberglass cannister is stored on board and replaced with a fresh one. Each astronaut inserts a fresh bag for the next user. Rethke's devotion to his space toilet has spurred more than a little ribbing from colleagues and he rarely makes it through the day without hearing a potty joke. He frequently appears at company functions with his ``Dr. Flush'' kit, including a taped bathroom noises, a white jacket emblazoned with his ``Dr. Flush'' logo, and a toilet seat featuring a stained-glass image of the shuttle. ``It has a lot of personal satisfaction from the point of view that you're helping mankind,'' Rethke said. ``And it is extremely serious for the astronauts. ... We have to make extremely sure it works right.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sends Top Aide to Philippines In Show of U.S. Support
DOC.TEXT: President Bush sent a senior White House aide to the Philippines on Wednesday ``to make sure there is no question'' about U.S. support for President Corazon Aquino amid fears of a new coup attempt against her. Robert Gates, Bush's deputy national security adviser, will be in the Philippines through Friday, holding talks with Mrs. Aquino and Fidel Ramos, the Philippine defense secretary. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Gates would convey Bush's ``continuing strong commitment to democracy'' in the Philippines. Fitzwater said the United States ``very strongly'' supports the Aquino government and noted that Bush ordered air support to help put down a failed coup attempt in December. ``This trip is to make sure there is no question'' about U.S. support for Mrs. Aquino, Fitzwater said. Referring to reports that another coup may be attempted soon, Fitzwater said, ``There, of course, are continuing reports of problems in terms of security forces and so forth. She is taking measures to deal with those, to prevent future coups. We simply want to consult with her on those efforts.'' Fitzwater said he would not speculate whether the United States would come to her aid again with military support, but added, ``You know how we have responded in the past.'' Gates, one-time deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, is the chief deputy to Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser. Fitzwater said Gates has a relationship with many Philippine leaders and personally knows Ramos. During the December coup attempt, Gates was a key figure orchestrating the U.S. response while Bush was in the air, flying to Malta for talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Fears of a another coup attempt have swept the Philippines in recent weeks. Most of Manila's newspapers published front-page editorials last week condemning military coup plotters and stating support for democracy and peace. Mrs. Aquino, in a speech a week ago, said ``armed power-brokers'' had not abandoned hope of toppling her government and that another coup attempt would lead to a ``nightmarish bloodbath.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Chief Sees Changes in Warsaw Pact, But No Disbanding
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States' top military officer said Wednesday the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact was undergoing change but no member has yet suggested pulling out of the alliance. ``Clearly there is a transformation taking place in the Warsaw Pact,'' said Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, after two days of unusual talks with his East bloc counterparts. ``I had no discussions with any member of the pact that suggested they were considering ... leaving the formal structure of the Warsaw Pact,'' he told a news conference. Gen. Nikolaj Chervov, head of the directorate of the Soviet general staff, acknowledged earlier that ``there will be changes in (the alliance's) structure.'' He disclosed that a key policy-making body of top Communist Party officials would likely be disbanded. The high-ranking military officers were in Vienna for the start of an unprecedented meeting of 35 nations to discuss East-West military strategies. The aim is to lift the secrecy surrounding military activities and ease tensions in Europe. Western experts were eager to hear whether any of the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe was considering leaving the seven-nation Warsaw Pact. East European officers, speaking on the second day of the meeting, stressed the importance of their national defense interests, rather than those of their military alliance. ``We proceed from the fact that our national interests are fundamental,'' said Gen. Anton Slimak, chief of Czechoslovakia's general staff. ``The principles of our military doctrine are being adapted to the newly created realities on the domestic and international scale,'' he said. He said money was tight and that troops and weapons were being trimmed. Starting Feb. 1, he said, ``we shall reduce by one-third the number of forces and equipment trained to fulfill combat tasks.'' East Germany's military chief, Gen. Manfred Graetz, said his nation was drafting a new military policy based on protection against foreign aggression, according to the East German news agency ADN. Powell said some of the East-bloc governments appeared to be making ``unilateral judgments' about their armed forces and weapons production. ``Yet, they continue to say they are part of an alliance,'' he said. ``So I think the Warsaw Pact alliance is shifting in its character to a more political institution.'' Those nations, he said, generally were cutting their armed forces because of economic problems and an assessment of defense needs. The West has long complained about the military might of the Warsaw Pact. The Soviets' top military officer, Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, said Tuesday the Kremlin was sharply reducing arms, troops and spending as part of a new military doctrine. Chervov, speaking through an interpreter, said the Warsaw Pact's governing body, the political consultative committee, would likely be scrapped. The panel is made up of the top Communist Party officials of the seven nations. He said political changes in some of the countries has led to ``the multiplicity of parties.'' ``The Communist Parties are no longer leading the states,'' he said. ``Therefore, the political consultative committee will probably cease to exist of itself and perhaps there will be another supreme body.'' The new one, he said, could be made up of the heads of state of those countries. Powell said Moiseyev indicated in private talks that the Soviets did not intend to use military force to reverse the events in Eastern Europe. Powell also said the changes were contributing to smaller U.S. defense spending. ``There's a general feeling ... we can take more of a chance (and) that we can cut back on our spending because the world does seem to be moving in a new and positive direction,'' he said. The three-week meeting is part of negotiations on Confidence-and Security-Building Measures, designed to reduce military tensions in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: New ABC Elvis Presley Series to Premiere
DOC.TEXT: Elvis Presley is still dead. But ABC will dramatize the singer's early years in a new half-hour series, ``Elvis.'' The series will have a special premiere Feb. 6 at 9:30 p.m. EST, the network said Tuesday. Filmed in Presley's hometown of Memphis, Tenn., and starring Michael St. Gerard, ``Elvis'' will start its regular Sunday night run Feb. 11, succeeding ``Free Spirit,'' which ABC has canceled. ABC said ``Free Spirit,'' a comedy that premiered last September, will have its final broadcast Sunday. Special programming will fill its time period on Jan. 28 and Feb. 4, ABC said.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Dies of Gunshot Wounds
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian died Wednesday of gunshot wounds from an earlier confrontation with troops, and a police officer was removed from his job for using unnecessary force in breaking up a peace rally last month. Palestinians staged a general strike in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to protest what they perceive as anti-Arab U.S. policies. There were scattered stone-throwing clashes in the territories and troops shot and wounded at least nine Palestinians, Arab hospital officials said. The army confirmed six wounded. Yousef Hatem Shusha, 19, of the West Bank village of Husan died at Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem after being shot in the head and back during a clash Tuesday night, Arab reports said. An army official confirmed the death and said the circumstances were under investigation. The death brought to 648 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis during the 25-month Palestinian uprising against the Israeli occupation. Palestinian vigilantes have killed 170 fellow Arabs suspected of cooperating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died as well. Israeli Police Commissioner David Krauss ordered an unidentified officer removed from his post after viewing film of police dispersing a demonstrators on Dec. 30, police spokesman Uzi Sandori said. ``We saw in the film that the policeman was beating two people, without any need, with a billy club,'' Krauss said on army radio. More than 50 people were injured in the melee. The European Community and peace activists criticized police for using ``unjustified'' violence during the demonstration. At the time, police said officers acted only after outlawed PLO flags were waved and stones hurled at police. ``I can understand that an innocent citizen in this situation felt very bad. He saw people running about, heard explosions, saw horses and maybe was sprayed with water and tear gas. ... But after you see the film you understand that police had to do it,'' Krauss said. Stores were shut and transportation came to a halt throughout the territories as Palestinians heeded a strike call by the PLO-backed Unified National Leadership of the Uprising. The underground leaders ordered the strike to ``condemn American policy which is against the rights of our people,'' according to a leaflet circulated this month. The PLO has accepted the United States as a mediator in Middle East peace efforts, but many Palestinians believe Washington favors Israel in the conflict. In other developments, troops bulldozed a house in Gaza City because the owner's son was suspected of killing a Palestinian allegedly collaborating with Israel, the army said. The chief of police in northern Israel, Albert Musafia, reported a 30 percent rise in politically motivated attacks by Israeli Arabs in 1989 over the previous year. He did not provide figures. ``The events in Judea, Samaria and Gaza exercise an influence on nationalist radicalism among Israeli Arabs that is expressed in firebomb attacks, painting of slogans and Palestinian flags,'' he said, using biblical names for the West Bank. But Musafia attributed most of the attacks to ``marginal groups of youths.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Extends Emergency by Six Months
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers on Wednesday extended Zimbabwe's 25-year-old state of emergency by six months to meet what they say are military threats from neighboring South Africa and Mozambique. The laws give authorities the power to arrest without warrant, detain indefinitely without trial and search without authority. Parliament approved their renewal by a vote of 73-3. The other legislators in the 100-member National Assembly where absent. Home Affairs Minister Moven Mahachi, arguing for an extension, cited several reasons for retaining the powers: _ An escalation in offensives across Zimbabwe's eastern frontier by right wing guerrillas of the Mozambique National Resistance in which 60 Zimbabweans were slain in the last six months; _ Reports that young Zimbabweans belonging to opposition political parties were being trained by the guerrillas to fight against the government; _ Threats by South Africa to attack neighboring states; and _ The need to give security forces flexible powers so they can maintain law and order. Mahachi recalled that South African Defense Minister Magnus Malan recently said South Africa might raid Zimbabwe and other countries in the region. ``I do not regard these threats as hollow,'' he said. ``This has been proved by past events,'' he added, apparently referring to sabotage attacks in Zimbabwe by South African soldiers and agents. Opponents, including the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace, and independent newspapers, contend emergency powers were unnecessary in a relaxed security climate, and that the laws were often abused. Alexio Mudzingwa told parliament that under the regulations, the government was committing the same human rights violations as South Africa, as well as under the former white minority government of Ian Smith. ``Can we have the audacity to condemn South Africa when we are guilty of the same?'' he asked. Mahachi accused the Catholic Commission, a watchdog on human rights, of being a spokesman for South Africa. Commission chairman Mike Auret later said the charge was ``patently absurd.'' ``The commission is ... concerned by the fact that the state of emergency created by the Smith government still pertains today in what should be a free and democratic Zimbabwe,'' Auret said. ``The powers of the state of emergency have been abused on many occasions.'' Smith introduced the emergency in 1965, shortly before he unilaterally declared the white-ruled British colony of Rhodesia independent to forestall black majority rule. The laws were largely used against black nationalist politicians and parties which, a decade later, wages a seven year war for independence. When President Robert Mugabe came to power in 1980, he retained the emergency powers.

DOC.HEAD: Theology School President Dies at 58
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. George Peck, president of Andover Newton Theological School and a leader in the Protestant church, died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 58.
