A native of Australia, Peck died at his home in Little Compton, R.I. His books, articles, sermons, book reviews and translations have been published in the United States, Australia and Asia. Peck lectured and preached extensively in churches, college chapels and at denominational conferences around the world. Peck served on the board of managers of the American Baptist Board of International Ministries from 1966 to 1975, and he was also a leader in the United Church of Christ. Before moving to the United States in 1963 to serve as a fellow at Harvard University, Peck was a theology professor in India. In 1966, he was appointed dean of Andover Newton, and in 1983 he became president of the school, in suburban Newton. Peck is survived by a wife, Mary, and four daughters. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Detains 3 Lockheed Employees in Tiff Over Maintenance Manual
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Aircraft Corp. said it was negotiating with the Chadian government for the release of three U.S. technicians detained nearly two weeks ago for destroying a maintenance manual. ``We are very close to a resolution of this misunderstanding,'' said Len R. Webb, the company's regional manager for Africa and the Middle East. ``And we hope the men will soon be freed to leave the country.'' Irving Thrash, Marvin Gambill and Ernest Ruse, all from the Atlanta area, were detained Jan. 5 after they completed a year of training Chadians to service a Lockheed C-130 transport plane, company officials said. The aircraft, built in Marietta, Ga., near Atlanta, was the first of several the government of President Hissene Habre bought for his air force. Lockheed spokesman Dick Martin in Atlanta said when the year ended in December, the men packed up and destroyed some documents, including manuals on the aircraft. Martin said the Chadian government felt those documents belonged to it, while Lockheed maintains the papers were company material. Martin said Chad officials then confiscated the technician's passports pending resolution of the conflict. Essentially, the dispute was over a single ``high-level technical overhaul document,'' said Webb. He said the document was not needed for the day-to-day maintenance of the aircraft and, in any case, Lockheed did not have the State Department export permit for it. This authorization has now been obtained and the Chadians have been given another copy of the document, he said. Webb and another technician, Paul A. Lanegger, were flown to N'Djamena by Lockheed after the men were detained. The pair had several high-level meetings with Chadian authorities to resolve the issue and Webb said they were ``very close.'' Webb, who is based in Amman, Jordan, stressed that the men were not held hostage and had not been mistreated or harassed. Two of them, Thrash and Ruse, were accompanied to Chad by their wives, but the wives were not detained or mistreated, Webb added. The three men, held in a Chadian police compound until Monday, have since been put under house arrest in N'Djamena's biggest hotel, La Chadienne, part of the French-owned Novotel chain, Webb said. Thrash's sister, Barbara Porter of Marietta, has called the incident a ``hostage situation'' and expressed fear for her brother's safety. But Martin said Wednesday that Thrash had not been separated from the others and the five Americans were well-fed. ``They have not missed a meal,'' he said. ``No one is starving and no one is threatened.''

DOC.HEAD: Key Colombian Pleads Guilty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT to five others, sted four.
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian who prosecutors say ran a network to help traffickers hide the source of their drug money pleaded guilty Wednesday to his part in a $32 million global money-laundering case. Gonzalo Mora Jr. was considered a key player in a sophisticated money-laundering ring that prosecutors say had ties to Panamanian Gen. Manuel Noriega. One of the remaining six defendants in the case is Amjad Awan, a former official for the Latin American division of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, or BCCI. He once told a U.S. Senate committee that he was a personal banker to Noriega who, according to court documents, controlled accounts the fallen Panamanian leader kept at BCCI banks. The government accused Mora of helping traffickers hide the source of their money by funneling cash from smugglers to an undercover agent posing as a high-stakes launderer. Mora switched his plea to guilty on all 33 counts _ one each of drug trafficking and money-laundering conspiracy, plus 31 charges of specific laundering activities. Defense attorney Joel Rosenthal told U.S. District Judge W. Terrell Hodges there was no agreement with prosecutors. ``There were no deals, no promises, no nothing,'' Rosenthal said later. He said Mora has never denied laundering activities, but ``he always denied the legal conclusion that there was a drug-trafficking conspiracy.'' Rosenthal said the plea came over the objections of prosecutors, but they had no grounds to fight the plea since it included all the charges. However, Mora's admission to the trafficking count came reluctantly, Rosenthal said. Hodges agreed to allow Mora the opportunity to withdraw the guilty plea to that count if during trial the court decides there is insufficent evidence to support it. Hodges also said Mora would not be sentenced until after the trial ends and appeals are exhausted. The drug-trafficking conspiracy charge carries a possible term of up to life in prison and $4 million in fines. He could face up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on the money-laundering conspiracy count and 20 years plus a $500,000 on each of the remaining counts. His plea came as defense attorneys fought to suppress statements from remaining defendants after BCCI pleaded guilty to participating in the money laundering conspiracy. In a deal with the government Tuesday, BCCI S.A. and BCCI Overseas Ltd. admitted laundering $14 million in drug profits and agreed to forfeit the cash. The money was put in an escrow account when the bank was indicted in 1988. The account has accumulated more than $1 million in interest which the government also gets to keep. BCCI, one of the world's largest private financial institutions, became the first international bank to admit U.S. money-laundering charges. The bank also agreed to cooperate in undisclosed investigations, making available information, books and documents ``relating to relevant matters.'' Prosecutors also agreed Tuesday to drop conspiracy charges against one bank officer, citing lack of evidence. Trial continued for five other BCCI officers and another Colombian.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Prods TV Execs to Aim Shows, Ads At Minority Audience
LaserPhoto NU1
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson on Wednesday urged television executives to pay more attention to programming and marketing aimed at minority group viewers. ``Not only is racism painful, it is unprofitable,'' Jackson told a workshop audience at the National Association of Television Program Executives convention, the prime marketplace of syndicated TV programs. Jackson, a civil rights activist and a Democratic presidential candidate in 1984 and 1988, and other panelists contended that blacks and other minorities constitute a billion-dollar market that is not effectively targeted by programmers and advertisers. Jackson said, ``African-Americans suffer from five rather deadly stereotypes every day'' on television. ``We are projected as less intelligent than we are, less hard-working than we work, less universal than we are, less patriotic than we are and more violent than we are,'' Jackson said. ``So we say to programmers, `Give the audience a chance. Don't use your brain as a strainer, a kind of way of denying people the option to make judgment,''' he said. Don Jackson, no relation, who produces ``Soul Train'' and many other black-oriented TV programs, told the workshop that when he entered the business 12 years ago, he got conflicting signals from the marketplace. ``The advertisers, including the black agencies and the general market agencies, said to me, `If you don't have the stations and the time periods, we cannot advertise on your show.''' And when he went to programmers, ``I found that I did not have the clout to get the stations nor the time periods. Time periods that I did get were close to midnight.'' The problem is common among black producers, he said. Only a joint venture with Tribune Broadcasting Co. gave him the clout, he said. ``You have to reach out, entertain what's in the marketplace and then when you run it, don't embarrass yourself or that market by putting it on at 1:30 or 2 in the morning,'' Don Jackson told the programmers. ``Take a look at the advertisers who are willing to support our shows. And finally, take a look at our shows. They are no longer public affairs or urban affairs shows. They are great, dynamic entertainment vehicles,'' the producer said. Jesse Jackson is entering the syndication market with Warner Bros. to produce an issues-oriented talk show, ``Voices of America.'' The show has commitments in 64 markets, despite trade magazine reports of ``anxiety'' among programmers. ``Let's call that anxiety `creative tension.' We're winning,'' Jackson said. ``Communication is the key to walls collapsing,'' Jesse Jackson said. ``As I witnessed the celebration of Dr. King's birthday these last few days, I wished so fervently that when he was alive Americans could have heard him in life, and not just in sound bites, for the biters control the sound.''

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners Killed in Plane Crash Were to Visit Tropical Forest
DOC.TEXT: Most of the Canadians and Americans killed in the crash of a Costa Rican plane were on their way to visit a tropical forest reserve, newspapers said Wednesday. All 23 people aboard died Monday morning when the twin-engine propeller plane crashed into the 7,450-foot Pico Blanco mountain, about 10 miles southwest of San Jose, minutes after taking off in a driving rain. The seven Canadians on board and two of the five Americans had planned to spend a week at a hotel in the Ventanas de Osa tropical forest reserve on the Osa Peninsula in southern Costa Rica, the daily La Nacion said. The group was led by Paul Tapscott, 50, of Edmonton, Canada, a frequent visitor to Costa Rica, the newspaper said. ``He was enamored of Costa Rica and its people,'' the newspaper quoted Tapscott's brother Dean as saying. Gabriel Sanchez Fernandez, a Costa Rican tourist guide who was waiting for the group in Palmar Norte, the plane's destination, said he had known Tapscott for years. ``He came to Costa Rica to escape the bitter cold this time of year in his country because he had had polio,'' the newspaper quoted Sanchez Fernandez as saying. Fred Ross, also a Canadian, owns the reserve and knew most of the visitors, the newspaper said. The airline, Servicios Aereos Nacionales, a subsidiary of the national airline Lineas Aereas Costaricenses, S.A. (Lacsa), identified the Canadians, in addition to Tapscott, as Bill MacKenzie, Helen MacKenzie, Ian Emmot, Karen Emmot, Gaetan Miliard and Jean Batiste Perron. The U.S. State Department has identified three of the five Americans as David Ulland of Austin, Minn., Lester Ross of Lancaster, Pa., and Norman Baltimore of East Smithfield, Pa. The airline identified the other two Americans as Hanson Dum and his daughter Patricia Dum. Their hometowns were not known. Lester Ross, 4, and his mother, Magda Ross, a Panamanian, were traveling from their home in Virginia to visit relatives in Panama, the airline said. The other 10 on board were Costa Ricans.

DOC.SECOND: AM-AP Arts: Dollar Theaters, 1st Ld-Writethru, a0588,0959
DOC.HEAD: For Some Movies, Buck May Stop at Dollar Theaters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 14th graf to CORRECT that Hester is director of corporate development, sted owner, of Cinemark. Original also moved in advance as b0319 Jan. 15
DOC.TEXT: Vicki Peterson, a school teacher and full-time college student on a tight budget, loves to see movies on the big screen. But with first-run movies going for $5.50 or more, she has turned to a cheaper alternative _ discount theaters. Running older movies and sometimes double features, these cost-cutting movie houses cater to a more dollar-conscious crowd. ``I only go to 99-cent movies,'' said Peterson at Paul Sanchez's four-screen Flowers 99 Cent Theater in Takoma Park, Md., near her home. ``You can bring the whole family,'' said another filmgoer, Stu Jarboe. ``You don't always have to eat the food and save some money.'' But moviegoers such as Peterson and Jarboe might face more limited choices because of a dispute between Paramount Pictures Corp. and discount theater operators. Paramount has raised its rentals, and some operators have responded by ceasing to show Paramount pictures. It's either that, they say, or tell customers that the buck stops here. Since last spring, Paramount has been charging operators $1.05 for each adult ticket and 75 cents for each child's ticket. Prior to that, the annual charge was a flat 35 percent of gross ticket sales. Paramount says the new pricing is a more equitable way of spreading the high cost of making movies. However, Paramount's action might threaten the discount theater industry. ``If any of the other companies go ahead with the same type of thing, discount theaters are either going to have to close or raise the price,'' says Sanchez, who owns four theaters in the Washington area. Jack Clark, president of the National Association of Discount Theaters, said the new pricing by Paramount caused him to lose money when he ran a discount theater in Pullman, Wash. He showed ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' and under the new policy made $1,641 in a week, charging customers $1.50 per ticket. Under the old price scale from Paramount, he made $3,148 in a week showing the same movie. Clark said he was $269 in the hole after expenses with Paramount's new rates. Discount theater operators, who number several hundred nationwide, are fighting back, with a lobbying and public relations campaign aimed at forcing the company to cut prices. Board member Randy Hester of the National Association of Discount Theaters, a trade organization based in Seattle, urges moviegoers and even members of Congress to write letters of protest to Paramount. Hester, director of corporate development of the Dallas-based Cinemark USA chain, hopes lawmakers will see what this is going to do to many moviegoers and will try to take action to stop it. ``There are many, many people in the country that can't afford more than a dollar for a movie ticket,'' he said. ``It wouldn't take long after visiting a discount theater to see that this is not the same group of people that are shelling out $5, $6 or $7 for a first-run movie ticket.'' There are no lines for movies at dollar theaters. That's because dollar theaters show movies long after they've had their first run at pricey movie palaces and multiplexes. Some discount movie theaters are rundown, with dimly lighted lobbies, worn carpets and floors sticky from spilled soft drinks and gooey candy. That's moviegoer Les Anderson's biggest complaint. ``It costs a lot in shoes, because they stick to the floor and they don't leave when you leave.'' Still, the theaters are havens for the elderly, the poor and students. At the request of the discount theater association, Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, has asked the Justice Department to investigate possible antitrust violations, to see if Paramount may be hiking rates in conjunction with other studios. Paramount's pricing system has a negative impact on the poor, senior citizens and others on fixed incomes, says Metzenbaum, who is chairman of a subcommittee on antitrust, monopolies and business rights. Barry London, president of Paramount Pictures, denies any antitrust violation, saying the company's change in its rental policy is in no way ``conspiratorial.'' London says his company is just trying to make discount theaters bear their fair share of the cost of production, distribution and marketing. He says the overall success of the movie is ``the engine that pulls the whole locomotive.'' Hester, however, considers this a form of buck-passing to the dollar theaters. He insists the cost of making the movie is already recovered from many sources. ``We pay the film shipping cost both ways. They make no additional prints for us and give us no money for advertising,'' he says. ``We get the print after the first-run exhibitor has told us they can make no more money.'' He says the higher rental charges are nothing but ``extra income'' for Paramount. London counters that Hester's charges are ``ridiculous.'' And, he says, dollar movie houses aren't in business as a public service. ``What they're basically doing is using our product to attract patrons so they can charge them concession prices equivalent to first-run movie houses,'' he says. Concession prices vary from movie house to movie house. Sanchez, for example, charges $1.50 for popcorn and $1 for drinks. Hester says his prices are comparable to regular theaters. Clark charged $1.50 for a large soda and $3.25 for a large popcorn. Sales of popcorn and other goodies, London said, generate the profits that keep the discount theater business popping.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Investigating Pit Bull Killing of Elderly Woman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: The owner of two part-pit bull dogs that fatally injured his elderly grandmother in a half-hour attack wants the dogs destroyed, but authorities said Wednesday the animals' deaths must await an investigation. Marjee Lilly, 70, died Wednesday at County-USC Medical Center despite six hours of surgery that included the amputation of her left arm. ``She had puncture wounds on most of her torso and all the flesh had been eaten off both arms from the wrist to the shoulder,'' police Lt. Alan Kerstein said Tuesdsay. The dogs gnawed on the woman for about 30 minutes. The San Diego woman had been visiting her grandson, Clarence Hubbard, when the dogs attacked Tuesday. Mrs. Lilly, who remained conscious during the mauling, told police the dogs attacked while she was trying to feed the 45- to 50-pound animals. Hubbard, 34, who found his 4-foot-11, 130-pound grandmother on the floor, said he's owned the 14-month-old pit bull terrier-boxer mixed breed dogs since they were puppies and they had never attacked anyone before. Hubbard told police he wanted the dogs destroyed, but city Department of Animal Control Lt. Michael Burns said the dogs would remain in quarantine at the North Central Animal Care and Control Center. ``Our investigation is far from being complete,'' Burns said. ``We are going to hold the dogs for two reasons: First, we don't know if they have bitten anyone else so we are holding them on a 10-day rabies quarantine, and second, we have to see if there is any kind of negligence.'' Kerstein said there apparently was no criminal violation because the dogs were on private property. Gov. George Deukmejian said during a morning news conference on another subject that he would be willing to consider legislation restricting ownership of pit bull terriers. ``I'm as disturbed and distressed as anybody,'' the governor said. ``We have to have some kind of law against owning them or some other way of completely controlling them.'' Burns said he would never own a pit bull terrier or recommend one for a pet because of their unpredictable, vicious nature. ``They have a greater propensity for harming, for injuring an individual. They will continue to attack where another dog will just bite and run away,'' Burns said. ``A pit bull has a propensity for viciousness but some people like breeds for a vicarious experience. They identify with tough, big, aggressive dogs,'' he added Because there are more of them, German shepherds are the nation's No. 1 biting dog. ``But per capita, you will have greater injuries with pit bulls,'' Burns said.

DOC.HEAD: Duke of Windsor's Valet Dead at 69
DOC.TEXT: Sydney Johnson, longtime personal valet to the Duke of Windsor, died Wednesday in Paris. He was 69. Johnson, who spent more than 30 years in the service of the former King Edward VIII, made his last public appearance greeting guests Dec. 10 when the Windsors' Paris mansion was reopened by Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of the Ritz Hotel in Paris and Harrods department store in London. ``I feel on top of the world,'' Johnson was quoted as saying at the party, where he was dressed as of old in gold and red livery. ``The restoration is so authentic I expect to see the duchess stepping down the staircase asking, `How do I look?''' A Ritz Hotel official, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed Johnson's death and said he had no information about its cause. Al Fayed was quoted by the British domestic news agency Press Association as saying Johnson ``was truly a gentlemen's gentleman. We shall miss him very much.'' Johnson was born in Nassau, The Bahamas, and entered the Windsors' service when the duke was governor-general of the islands off Florida during World War II. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Troop Withdrawal in Panama Not Tied to Drug Summit
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, Bush said... to UPDATE with Quayle itinerary and 19th graf pvs, Quayle is ... with 2 new grafs with further Quayle travel details, quotes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he still wants the rest of U.S. invasion troops withdrawn from Panama ``as soon as possible,'' but he feels under no pressure to get them out before next month's drug summit in Colombia. Bush, posing for pictures in the Rose Garden with Gen. Maxwell Thurman, the commander of U.S. forces in Panama, congratulated Thurman and his troops for ``the outstanding job they did for our country.'' Bush denied that the United States was having difficulties finding countries willing to host Vice President Dan Quayle on a fence-mending mission to the region. Quayle will visit Honduras, Panama and Jamaica Jan. 27-29. Peruvian President Alan Garcia, perhaps the most outspoken critic of the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion that toppled Manuel Antonio Noriega, has said he won't attend the Feb. 15 drug summit unless the U.S. invasion force is out of Panama before then. Garcia plans to send a minister in his stead. The United States sent nearly 15,000 troops to Panama for the strike against Noriega and his Panamanian Defense Forces, more than doubling the 12,000 troops on permanent duty there to defend U.S. bases and the Panama Canal. ``We want them out of there as soon as possible,'' Bush said. ``It's my objective to get the troops out and get back to the levels before this military action.'' But he emphasized, ``It has nothing to do with the summit in Cartagena at all. This is prudent, it is right. ... I'm not driven by the summit.'' ``I want to do what's right for Panama. I want to do what Panama wants,'' the president told reporters. ``It's Panama's show now,'' Bush said before going into a National Security Council meeting with Thurman and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to discuss Panama and its needs. Bush said the new Panamanian government of President Guillermo Endara ``is strengthening their democracy.'' ``We want to give them economic help. We want to offer hope to the individuals there who are out of work, some of it because of the sanctions we had imposed on Panama,'' said Bush. ``So we're committed.'' Noriega is jailed in Miami awaiting trial on drug-trafficking charges. He surrendered to U.S. authorities on Jan. 3 after 10 days in the Vatican Embassy in Panama City. Thurman said 18,900 U.S. troops are left in Panama, with 8,000 having already returned to the United States. ``Eight out and we've got about four or five (thousand) to go,'' said Bush. The president praised ``the dedication of those kids'' who carried out the invasion. ``They did a dynamite job,'' the four-star general agreed. The invasion drew fire Wednesday from the liberal Americans for Democratic Action. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., the ADA president, said the news media had enjoyed the spectacle of the invasion and ``hysterically supports the tattering of the Constitution.'' ``Americans should be prepared to fight and die for what is right,'' said Rangel. ``The question I ask is whether it was morally and constitutionally right.'' Quayle will attend a presidential inaugural in Honduras on Jan. 27. The White House announced later Wednesday he will also visit Panama and Jamaica on that trip, and it said he will travel to South America March 10-16 to attend inaugurals in Chile and Brazil and make ``other stops to be determined.'' An administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press that some Latin countries have quietly discouraged Quayle from visiting. Quayle told a Hoover Institution luncheon Wednesday that ``diplomatic sensitivies'' had delayed the trip scheduling, but added, ``No country has said, `We don't want the vice president, period.''' Bush announced the Quayle mission Jan. 5, saying, ``I want to assure all of the countries of Latin America that United States policy remains one of a friendly, supportive and respectful neighbor.'' He said the Panama invasion was a ``unique situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Annenberg Foundation Ends Funding for TV College Courses
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf pvs, bgng: `It was, to UPDATE with CPB official saying no future commitment made to project. Picks up 7th graf pvs, About $50
DOC.TEXT: A $150 million project that allows students to earn college credits using public television and videos has lost its main source of funding from a foundation created by former Ambassador Walter Annenberg, officials said Wednesday. The Annenberg Foundation recently informed the Corporation for Public Broadcasting that it will end its regular quarterly payment of $2.5 million to the Annenberg@CPB Project because of a recent Internal Revenue Service ruling altering its tax status, CPB President Donald Ledwig said. ``Further discussions will take place concerning the foundation's action,'' Ledwig said. The project was created in 1981 to expand opportunities for ``independent learners and working adults,'' as well as college students, to acquire a quality college education. It was launched when Annenberg gave CPB a $150 million gift to be paid in increments of $10 million for 15 years. The foundation's decision came as a surprise to the CPB and wider public broadcasting community, according to Communications Daily, a communications industry newsletter that on Wednesday reported on the foundation's Jan. 2 notification to CPB. ``It was a shock,'' acknowledged one official involved with the project. ``CPB made an immediate commitment to the project, so it is not going to end'' but it is uncertain what changes will be made. Mara Mayor, project director for six years, said ``We were surprised'' but that it was ``too soon to say'' what will happen. About $50 million in projects have been funded through 1993, the official said. Ledwig said ``In its nine years of operation, the project has won extraordinary acclaim for the quality and impact of its work benefiting higher education and the nation's learners.'' The courses generally air on local public television stations and through national cable systems, including The Learning Channel. Last September, the project introduced an audio-print course collection, which offers a series of half-hour audio programs, textbooks, study guides and instructor's manuals. All of the courses are designed for students seeking a baccalaureate degree in the liberal arts and sciences. The project also funded demonstrations of new applications of telecommunications and information technologies in higher education, including programs at Brown, Harvard and Boston universities and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Of the 3,000 colleges and universities nationwide, 1,600 use Annenberg@CPB project course materials. Project courses have been offered for credit by 700 colleges across the country, and 125,000 students have received college credit for project courses. In an average week, officials said nearly 5 million people watch project courses and programs on public TV or cable channels. Annenberg, the former owner of TV Guide and U.S. ambassador to Britain during the Nixon administration, has donated millions to charities and the arts, and founded the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg School of Communications. CPB is a private, nonprofit corporations authorized by the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967 to develop noncommercial radio and television services.

DOC.HEAD: FEC: PAC Registrations Down 90 In Past Year
DOC.TEXT: The number of political action committees registered to participate in federal elections declined by 90 last year to 4,178, the Federal Election Commission said Wednesday. The FEC, to which all PACs that spend money on presidential and congressional elections must report, said there has been a net gain of 160 political action committees during the last five years. That rate of growth is meager compared to the mushrooming growth of federally registered PACs in the five-year period from 1979 to 1984, when their number more than doubled from 2,000 to 4,009. The number of federally registered PACs rose steadily throughout the 1980s until peaking at 4,268 as of Dec. 31, 1988, before falling by 90 last year, the FEC said. The FEC data covers only those political action committees registered to participate in federal elections and not all PACs registered with the FEC remain active financially. Thousands more PACs are registered at the state level.

DOC.HEAD: Mediterranean Fruit Flies Found in Central Chile
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Wednesday banned the transport of all fruit out of central Chile's Aconcagua Valley after the discovery of at least 12 Mediterranean fruit flies in the area. The government Agricultural Service chief, Juan Carlos Sepulveda, said the flies were found in a residential neighborhood in Los Andes, a city 48 miles northeast of Santiago. He said none had been detected in the fruit-growing areas. Nonetheless, Sepulveda said, an emergency plan was immediately implemented that included banning the transport of all fruit out of the valley. Grapes, peaches, nectarines and kiwis are grown in the Aconcagua area. About 16 million crates are expected to be harvested this year in the valley, virtually all for export to the United States, Japan and western Europe. Police roadblocks were established to enforce the quarantine, which coincides with the start of fruit harvesting in the Southern Hemisphere's summer. Regional governor Raul Celis said authorities believe the problem _ the first time Mediterranean fruit flies have been found in Chile since 1978 _ will be resolved quickly. The emergency plan, Sepulveda said, includes fumigation of fruit and trees with chemicals. Harvested fruit will be placed in cold storage three to four days, a common procedure to kill the fly and its larvae. Sepulveda said the Mediterranean flies found in Los Andes are believed to have been come from neighboring Argentina, where outbreaks of the insect, which is harmless to humans, has occurred. He said the finding had been reported to the United States, Japan and to the United Nation's agricultural agency, the FAO. Ronald Bown, president of the Chilean Fruit Exporters Association, called the situation ``seious, but controllable.'' Last year, Chile's fruit exporters suffered a major blow when two grapes laced with cyanide were found in a Chilean shipment in Philadelphia. The finding prompted the Food and Drug Administration to temporarily ban the sale of Chilean fruits in the United States. The government estimated the losses sustained by Chile at $300 million. Fruit exports have boomed in recent years, earning about $900 million annually. As part of an agreement with the United States to resume the sales of its fruits, Chile allows FDA officials to check security measures in the entire export process, including harvesting, packing and transport of the fruit. Two FDA experts however who came to Chile this month to check the security measures were killed last Wednesday when the small police plane they were flying crashed in a remote Andean mountain in northern Chile.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Groups Say Nicaragua May Be Blocking Voter Education Efforts
DOC.TEXT: Republican and Democratic organizations Wednesday charged that Nicaragua's government may be intentionally blocking the creation of programs to educate the country's voters about democracy before next month's national elections. The groups, which use U.S. government funds to promote democracy overseas, said Nicaragua has thrown up bureaucratic roadblocks to the groups' efforts to fund what they described as non-partisan programs to educate voters and to scrutinize the election process. ``We are seriously concerned that this pattern of delay is the result of a political decision taken by your government to inhibit action on programs designed to support the democratic process,'' the two organizations wrote in a letter to Victor Tinoco, Nicaragua's deputy foreign minister. The letter from J. Brian Atwood, president of the National Democratic Institute, and Keith Schuette, president of the National Republican Institute, appeared to be an effort to break loose money intended for IPCE, a civic group affiliated with the political opposition to the ruling Sandinista party. The delay ``will seriously undermine Nicaraguan and international confidence in the electoral system,'' they wrote. The charge comes on the heels of reports of electoral intimidation and violence by Sandinista supporters and the denial of visas to a presidentially appointed U.S. observer group for the Feb. 25 national elections. The two institutes are seeking to provide a total of $1.5 million to IPCE to pay for training of poll watchers, pay workers to comb through voter registration lists looking for errors or fraud, and air television spots explaining how to vote. ``These are voters who've either voted in crooked elections, or never voted before in their lives,'' said one institute official, speaking to reporters only on condition of anonymity. But by Wednesday, all efforts to get the money to local officials had been thwarted, said officials of both institutes. ``There is already a significant deterioration in what we expected to accomplish,'' said one. There has been relatively little trouble getting equipment bought and delivered directly to UNO, the opposition political coalition, the officials said. Some $800,000 in equipment _ mostly vehicles and office machines _ is in the process of being delivered, they said. Meanwhile, an Organization of American States report submitted by an OAS observer group said that as of Dec. 15, 191 non-Sandinista candidates had dropped out as candidates in the Feb. 25 elections because of intimidation or harassment. Slightly more than half of the dropouts represented the UNO coalition, the largest opposition grouping. Most of the 191 had been candidates for municipal council posts; the remainder had sought seats in the National Assembly, said the report, which was signed by OAS Secretary General Joao Baena Soares. The study calls intimidation one of the biggest problems of the electoral process and said both pro- and anti-Sandinista partisans have been affected. It said that at times the problem consists of threats of loss of benefits or employment, of phone calls or anonymous messages, of damage to personal property, or of physical threats or death threats. The report also said there have been incidents of violence at campaign rallies but added that it has not been easy to uncover the causes. The report was issued a day after Elliot Richardson, the personal representative of the U.N. secretary general for the Nicaraguan elections, said he believed the Feb. 25 voting will be carried out fairly. But, like the OAS report, he expressed concern about the atmosphere surrounding the campaign, citing use of government assets by the Sandinistas for campaigning.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Going Ahead With European Base Relocation
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is moving forward with plans to relocate a U.S. tactical wing from Spain to Italy despite congressional calls for reducing active forces overseas, a lawmaker said Wednesday. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, said she received a letter from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney indicating that he is ``going full speed ahead on Crotone,'' the planned site for the tactical wing. In January 1988, the United States accepted Spain's demands that the Air Force withdraw its 401st Tactical Wing of 72 F-16 fighter bombers from the joint U.S.-Spanish air base at Torrejon de Ardoz, just east of Madrid. Italy agreed to provide a new home for the jets, approximately 3,600 troops and 600 civilians at Crotone. ``The average person seeing everyone pulling out ... will be astounded,'' Schroeder, a longtime opponent of relocating the tactical wing in Italy, said in a telephone interview. ``This isn't even a warfighting base.'' The Pentagon has estimated the total cost of Crotone at $885 million. Under the administration plan, the United States would pay $470 million, or 55 percent of the total cost, with NATO picking up the remainder of the expense. Historically, the United States picks up 28 percent of the costs of such base construction under the NATO Infrastructure program. House and Senate negotiators, who had agreed on differing numbers for the U.S. cost, compromised in the fiscal 1990 defense bill and capped expenditures at $360 million, limiting U.S. payments to 40 percent and forcing the administration to renegotiate with NATO on the remaining cost. That provision was included in the defense bill that President Bush signed into law late last year. In May 1989, the relocation came under attack as Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, raised the possibility of returning the unit back to the United States and turning it into a reserve unit. Levin noted that former Defense Secretary Frank Carlucci had announced withdrawal of the wing before NATO offered to help. John A. Woodworth, deputy assistant secretary of defense for European and NATO policy, warned against that step, saying, ``We will harm ourselves seriously with the allies.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Vetoes Resolution on Ransacking of Nicaraguan Residence
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Wednesday vetoed a Security Council resolution that would have denounced the ransacking of the residence of Nicaragua's ambassador to Panama by U.S. troops. The United States, as a permanent member of the Security Council, has veto power over resolutions. There were 13 votes favoring the resolution; Britain abstained. Alejandro Serrano Caldera, Nicaragua's U.N. envoy, asked the Security Council to denounce the U.S. search of the residence on Dec. 29, saying it violated international agreements of diplomatic immunity. He called the U.S. actions a serious threat to international peace and security in the region and accused the United States of trying to provoke the Nicaraguan government. The attack on the residence came amid heightened tension in the region following the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama. Thomas Pickering, U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, called Nicaragua's request for Security Council action on the issue ``an effort to turn the council into a propaganda exercise, nothing more or nothing less.'' Pickering said the United States has expressed public regret over the events that occurred at the Nicaragua ambassador's residence in Panama. He said the ransacking by U.S. troops occurred while ``the situation in Panama was indeed extraordinary.'' President Bush has called the assault of the Nicaraguan ambassador's residence a mistake _ a ``screwup'' _ but noted heavy weapons were discovered there and questioned why a diplomat needed them. The permanent members of the Security Council are the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France and China. The current temporary members are Canada, Colombia, Ivory Coast, Yemen, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Malaysia, Rumania and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Kemp Cancels Reagan-Era Program Blamed for Billion-Dollar Losses
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf after graf 4 pvs, bgng, Kemp's decision ... with reaction; INSERTS 1 graf after 14th grav pvs, As an ... with add'l reaction
DOC.TEXT: Housing Secretary Jack Kemp on Wednesday killed a program that allows private lenders to commit the government to insuring mortgages and that has cost taxpayers nearly $1 billion because of sour loans. Because of projects in the approval pipeline, Kemp said the program would have to be phased out, a period Department of Housing and Urban Development officials said was likely to last several months or perhaps longer because of necessary regulatory approvals. In the interim, Kemp ordered, effective immediately, that private lenders preparing to approve a co-insured loan first submit all documentation to HUD for approval. Kemp's decision comes four months after HUD officials said the co-insurance program would be reformed and revived. It was one of many HUD programs investigated during last year's allegations of mismanagement and influence peddling at HUD during the Reagan administration. Democrats in Congress have told Kemp not to use the scandals as an excuse to kill programs, but a key congressional aide said he expected no battle over ending the troubled co-insurance program. But the aide, Donald Campbell, staff director of the Senate housing subcommittee, said Democrats likely would question whether HUD has enough qualified staffers to oversee another insurance program Kemp promoted as an alternative to co-insurance. The co-insurance program, created in 1983, was part of the Reagan administration's effort reduce the federal bureaucracy by turning over work to the private sector. The program allows private lenders to process mortgages for multifamily housing developments and unilaterally commit HUD to insuring roughly 80 percent of them in the event of default. Audits by HUD's inspector general have criticized many of the co-insurance lenders for approving bloated mortgages that far exceeded the value of the property. The General Accounting Office has estimated that defaults and other related losses have cost taxpayers at least $960 million. The most notorious case _ which Kemp cited in his statement announcing the decision _ was the HUD-backed loan for the Colonial House apartment complex in Houston. The development was co-insured for $47.2 million and ultimately defaulted because of vacancy problems blamed on rents that were too high for the depressed Houston real estate market but necessary to cover the mortgage. HUD was forced to take over Colonial House and recovered just $8.9 million when it auctioned the development last year. Kemp suspended the program last summer as evidence of shoddy mortgage underwriting mounted, and he has suspended six participating lenders and placed seven more on probation. Kemp had placed a moratorium on admitting new lenders into the program pending a restructuring. In September, HUD officials said privately that the department was on the verge of announcing reforms to the co-insurance program. They then said the announcement was on hold because of delays in drafting the necessary regulations. But in his statement Wednesday, Kemp said extensive reviews of the program by HUD staff and outside auditors had convinced him to kill it. ``The co-insurance method is structurally flawed and fundamentally unsound as well as administratively unfixable,'' Kemp said. ``In comparing the losses resulting from co-insurance to the housing it provided, it is clear that co-insurance has been a bad deal for the American taxpayer.'' As an alternative financing method, Kemp promoted HUD's full insurance program, under which the government fully insures multifamily housing mortgages. In this program HUD is 100 percent liable in the event of default, but the department handles the underwriting _ as opposed to the private lenders in the co-insurance program _ presumably giving it the oversight necessary to identify risky or bloated mortgages. ``The problem here is that they are going back to full insurance and there is no evidence that the have the staff to handle the demand,'' Campbell said, noting that the Bush administration resisted attempts by Democrats to boost HUD staffing levels this year. Kemp said he was taking a number of steps to restructure the full insurance program, including allowing private lenders to process and service those loans in exchange for a fee. But only HUD would have the authority to issue the insurance necessary for the loans to be approved and it also would receive 100 percent of the mortage insurance premiums. Kemp said the restructuring of the full insurance program would be completed by year's end. Among the revelations concerning the co-insurance program made last year during congressional hearings and through documents released by HUD was that one company, DRG Funding Corp., had a co-insurance loan portfolio that included nearly $600 million of the more than $900 million in losses. DRG had been placed on probation during the Reagan administration by then-HUD Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. and required to submit all of its proposed co-insurance loans to HUD for approval. But Pierce lifted the restrictions after being lobbied by Carla Hills, a former HUD secretary who at the time was in private law practice and now serves as the Bush administration's trade representative.

DOC.HEAD: Portugal Speeds Help to Fight Madeira Oil Slick
DOC.TEXT: Environment Minister Fernando Real and antipollution experts flew to Porto Santo Wednesday in the fight to contain an oil slick that blackened tourist beaches here and threatened a nature reserve. Authorities flew dissolvants, floating barriers, pumps and other equipment from Lisbon to this Atlantic island, part of Portugal's Madeira archipelago. The Madeiras lie 625 miles southwest of Lisbon and about 425 miles west of Morocco. More than 50 tons of crude oil washed up on the island since Monday, mostly on Porto Santo's rocky north and east coasts, said a Portuguese naval official. Witnesses said the oil-soaked bodies of gulls, turtles and fish washed onto the island. Oil patches covered about one mile of white sand on the vacation island's famed 6{-mile south coast beach. The Portuguese news agency Lusa said public health authorities banned the sale of fish in Porto Santo and desalination plants producing 80 percent of the drinking water were shut down because of fears of oil contamination. The origin of the oil spill remained a mystery. Ensign Adriano Queiros of Madeira naval command said by telephone that small amounts of oil reached the north coast of Madeira island, 28 miles southwest, but that Madeira was in no immediate danger of major polution. He said the 12{-mile slick was lying stationary off Porto Santo. Raimundo Quintao, president of the Madeira Ecological Club, said he saw 15 oil-covered turtles dying at Porto Santo and many more may have died at sea. ``These are endangered animals. Because of this alone, it's an environmental disaster,'' he said in a telephone interview. Portuguese navy officers said it was unlikely the oil came from the Iranian tanker Khark 5, which leaked about 19 million gallons into the Atlantic last month, Lusa reported. They said the oil that washed up this week was dense and black, while oil that has been in the sea for some time turns yellowish and foamy. Officials said the oil could have been dumped from tankers that passed along the busy sea-lanes off Madeira. Navy spokesman Cmdr. Antonio Monteiro Coelho said oil samples would be analyzed to try to find the origin of the spill. Porto Santo had few resources of its own to fight an oil spill. Residents scraped up oil with shovels, brooms and buckets. Ecologists accused Portuguese authorities of reacting slowly to the crisis. ``The ways they have of dealing with it are ridiculous. ... It's been very slow,'' said Quintao. Madeira biologist Manuel Biscoito told Lusa he was concerned over the damage the slick could cause to a nature reserve on the Desertas islands, 37 miles south of Porto Santo. The craggy islands are home to rare maritime animals, including one of the world's last breeding colonies of the Mediterranean monk seal, an endangered marine mammal.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in the Western Mountains, Rain in the East
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell in the mountains of the West on Wednesday, dumping more than a foot in California. Rain was scattered across the eastern half of the nation, where temperatures soared to record highs. Snow was falling at midday on the mountains of central California, the mountains of western Nevada, southwestern Utah, northwestern Arizona, the Idaho Panhandle, central and southern Montana, and Wyoming. By Wednesday morning, snow accumulations in California included 8 to 12 inches at Big Bear, 1{ feet at Lake Arrowhead, and 10 inches at Bear Valley. In western Nevada, about a foot of snow fell in the area of the towns of Fernley and Fallon, east of Reno. A winter storm warning was posted through Thursday across northern and eastern Arizona above at elevations over 5,000 feet, and a winter storm watch was in effect into Thursday for much of New Mexico. At lower elevations, scattered rain fell over southern Nevada and southwestern arizona. Rain showers and thunderstorms extended from Missouri to Arkansas, eastern Oklahoma, eastern Texas and western Louisiana. Morning thunderstorms produced small hail east of Fort Worth, Texas, and three-quarter-inch diameter hail at Lindsey, Okla. Elsewhere, snow fell over North Dakota, northeastern South Dakota, and the northern half of Minnesota. Freezing rain was scattered over east-central South Dakota, southeastern Minnesota and northern Wisconsin. Rain extended from Michigan to northern Indiana, Ohio, central Kentucky, central Tennessee, northern Mississippi, northern Alabama, western West Virginia, western Pennsylvania and western through north-central New York state. Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours up to noon EST included 1.4 inches at Fort Campbell, Ky., and 1.02 inches at Jackson, Tenn. Record highs included 67 degrees in Baltimore; 61 at Beckley, W.Va.; 53 at Binghamton, N.Y.; 65 at Harrisburg, Pa.; 47 at Houghton Lake, Mich.; 71 at Huntsville, Ala; 62 at Newark, N.J.; 63 at New York City; 57 at Syracuse, N.Y.; 53 at Rockford, Ill.; and 55 at Williamsport, Pa. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 4 degrees below zero at Houlton, Maine. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 17 degrees at International Falls, Minn., to 86 at McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Developments in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Wednesday's developments in Eastern Europe: _ Soviet leaders said soldiers could open fire if necessary on Armenians and Azerbaijanis fighting in AZERBAIJAN. At least 58 people, mostly Armenians, have been killed and 169 injured in five days of civil warfare. _ Food officials in ROMANIA said meat shortages have become critical and short-term rationing has been imposed in some areas to fight hoarding. Government officials announced that public, televised trials would begin next week for six top henchmen of ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. _ In EAST GERMANY, former Communist Party chief Egon Krenz denied responsibility for the brutal suppression of fall pro-democracy protests. The non-Communist Christian Democrats threatened to pull out of the coalition government to protest the Communists' continued tight grip on power. The chief Supreme Court judge resigned and the deputy chief prosecutor was fired for allegedly moving too slowly to prosecute corruption. The Communist Party newspaper blamed the opposition group New Forum for Monday's rampage through secret police headquarters in East Berlin. New Forum denied responsibility. _ A spokesman for WEST GERMANY's opposition party said the government should discourage East Germans from resettling in the West. _ A foreign ministry spokesman confirmed CZECHOSLOVAKIA will seek a complete pullout of Soviet troops by the end of 1990 and that the withdrawal will be a key issue when President Vaclav Havel visits Moscow next month. Alexander Dubcek, president of Czechoslovakia's parliament, said the government is drawing up new laws to protect human rights. _ Solidarity leader Lech Walesa said POLAND's drastic economic plan will fail without immediate outside financial help. Representatives of 6,000 striking miners who shut down mines Tuesday met with the finance minister to discuss their demands for higher pay. _ European Community Commission President Jacques Delors said the EC must provide greater economic aid to the East Bloc nations. _ At the military strategies meeting in Vienna, the United States' top military officer, Gen. Colin Powell, said no members of the Warsaw Pact have suggested pulling out of the alliance despite the changes in Eastern Europe. Gen. Nikolaj Chervov, head of the directorate of the Soviet general staff, disclosed that a key policy-making body of top Communist officials of the alliance would likely be disbanded.

DOC.HEAD: Hearing Ordered in Poindexter's Efforts to Subpoena Reagan
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs with separate order by Greene after 8th graf pvs, Poindexter, scheduled
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday ordered a hearing in connection with John Poindexter's effort to subpoena former President Reagan as a witness at Poindexter's upcoming trial. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene said next Tuesday's court session will focus on whether a president or former president may be subpoenaed to be a witness at a trial under any circumstances. Greene asked that lawyers for Reagan, Poindexter, the Justice Department and the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office address possible alternatives to bringing Reagan to court to testify during Poindexter's trial. Alternatives might be having Reagan give a videotaped deposition or giving written responses to questions. Poindexter is seeking court approval to subpoena Reagan's testimony, asserting that the president authorized some of the activities in the Iran-Contra affair for which the ex-national security adviser now is accused of crimes. The judge said the lawyers should address what kind of showing Poindexter must make regarding the ``materiality or necessity'' of Reagan's testimony before the former national security adviser is allowed to subpoena his ex-boss. Reagan's lawyers have cited ``substantial constitutional questions'' about subpoenaeing the former president's testimony and they are asking that a decision be put off until prosecutors complete their case against Poindexter. Poindexter, scheduled to go to trial Feb. 20, is charged with conspiracy, obstructing Congress and three counts of making false statements in the Iran-Contra scandal. On another matter, Greene ordered independent counsel Lawrence Walsh, whose office is prosecuting Poindexter, to provide by Monday the former president's written answers given to a federal grand jury that investigated the Iran-Contra affair. Greene will decide whether to turn over the written answers to Poindexter. Reagan's answers, given while he was still president, have never been publicly disclosed. In connection with a separate subpoena, Reagan was ordered by Greene to turn over to the court by Jan. 7 portions of the former president's diaries pertaining to Iran-Contra matters. Greene is expected to rule on whether the excerpts will be turned over to Poindexter in preparation for his trial.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysia Withdraws as Host of Meeting Because Israel Present
DOC.TEXT: Malaysia has withdrawn its offer to host the 46th annual session of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) after failing to resolve problems over the presence of Israel, which is an observer at the meeting. The state news agency Bernama quoted foreign ministry officials as saying the Malaysian government informed the Bangkok-based ESCAP of its decision last month. The ministerial-level meeting will be held instead in June in Bangkok, Thailand's capital. The Kuala Lumpur meeting had been scheduled for March 19-28, the officials said. Malaysia has no diplomatic relations with Israel and is a strong critic of Israeli actions against the Palestinians, who have battled for 25 months against Israel rule and are pressing for an independent homeland. Israelis are not allowed to visit Malaysia. The officials said problems had arisen over the use of name plates identifying the seating for Israel at the meeting and the use of the Israeli flag. To overcome the problem, Malaysia requested that no name plates be used for observer countries that would instead be grouped under a single observer tag. However, ESCAP said observer name plates had been used at all previous sessions and that the Kuala Lumpur meeting would follow precedent, the officials said. The Malaysian Cabinet then decided to withdraw Malaysia's offer to host the session, the officials said. Malaysia offered to host the session last March.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troops Authorized to Shoot to Halt Warring Bands in Caucasus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with details of permission to shoot, Iran warning not to deal harshly with Soviet Azerbaijan. Picks up 7th, `The Kremlin ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOS18, MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin Wednesday told the thousands of soldiers it sent to the Caucasus to shoot if need be to halt bands of Azerbaijanis and Armenians fighting each other in hills around the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. Thousands of Armenian refugees poured from the southern republic of Azerbaijan, many beaten or chased from their homes by angry mobs. Some blamed the attacks on Azerbaijanis who earlier fled ethnic violence in Armenia. The death toll rose to 58, mostly Armenians, and the number of injured to 169 in five days of civil warfare, an Interior Ministry official said. The evening TV news show ``Vremya'' ran a statement from the KGB and the interior and defense ministries, which control troops in the area, that said: ``Risking their lives, they have so far refrained from using arms against criminals to prevent bloodshed. ``However, a sharp increase in outrageous attacks has made the situation unbearable,'' and the soldiers now were permitted to use their weapons in accordance with military rules and Soviet law. Four burned bodies were found in Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, the official news agency Tass said Wednesday. Eighteen Armenian residents were injured in Azerbaijan the past 24 hours. The violence erupted Saturday with anti-Armenian riots in Baku. Fighting rapidly spread to Nagorno-Karabakh and nearby areas of Azerbaijan, with the belligerents using helicopters, armored vehicles, machine guns and other arms seized from government arsenals or offered by compatriots. It was the worst fighting between mainly Moslem Azerbaijanis and mostly Christian Armenians since their decades-old feud over Nagorno-Karabakh erupted in violence two years ago. The enclave, populated mainly by Armenians, has been ruled by Azerbaijan since 1923 and the current troubles were sparked by its demand in February 1988 to be annexed by Armenia. It has about 160,000 people. Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Wednesday that Islamic fervor was behind events in Soviet Azerbaijan, and warned Moscow not to deal harshly with the Shiite Moslem upsurge, Tehran radio reported. The broadcast, monitored in Cyprus, quoted Khamenei as saying ``anyone who thinks or pretends that the motives behind these movements are ethnic or nationalistic is making a big mistake. These sentiments are Islamic, and Soviet leaders should face this fact with realism.'' The Kremlin has empowered local officials to ban demonstrations and strikes, impose curfews, censor the media, confiscate weapons, disband unofficial organizations and detain people for up to 30 days. Interior Ministry officials said they could not recall such measures being imposed since World War II. Foreign reporters have been barred from the region. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent 11,000 army and internal security troops to the southern region Tuesday, but they have been slowed by Azerbaijanis who erected barricades on roads and at a military airfield. The reinforcements ``haven't helped yet because they haven't started to act,'' said Dmitri Seleznyov, spokesman for the Interior Ministry in Moscow. Troops engaged in at least one battle Tuesday, when an armed group tried to seize five armored personnel carriers near the village of Tazikend. Soldiers fired on the group, wounding two men, Tass reported. ``Since then, attempts to take APCs have stopped, because before this they weren't used to having weapons used against them,'' Seleznyov said. Reinforcements also were sent to the nearby border with Iran, Tass said. More than 7,000 Armenians have been evacuated from Baku, many in ferry boats across the Caspian Sea. In Baku, a handful of Soviet soldiers for nearly three hours held back a crowd of 5,000 people trying to prevent the detention of 10 nationalists who broke into the apartment of a Russian family, Tass said. They finally agreed to release the 10, and led the Russians and an Armenian family out of the house, protecting them with shields. In Armenia, residents broke into police stations and other buildings seeking weapons, Seleznyov said. About 50,000 people attended a rally in the Armenian capital Yerevan to hear reports about the fighting, said Armenian activist Karen Shakhbazyan. Azerbaijanis staged protests in Baku and elsewhere to demand they be armed and allowed to defend their claim to Nagorno-Karabakh, newspapers and officials said. Azerbaijanis continued their rail blockade of Armenia's 3.5 million people, cutting short fuel and other supplies. Azerbaijan has 6.9 million people. The Soviet government and the Communist Party issued a joint statement of condolence to families of the dead. In Moscow, a 49-year-old Armenian woman spoke sadly of the night Azerbaijani thugs beat her in front of her 15-year-old son. ``They are killing us,'' said Alisa Arakelova, her face swollen and black from a fractured jaw, her left wrist and two fingers broken and encased in plaster, and fingernails blackened and smashed. She escaped Baku for Moscow after the attack in her apartment, just days before ethnic hatred erupted in the latest, most deadly round of two years of ethnic violence in the Caucasus. Armenian refugees milling about the Moscow office of the Armenian republic traded horrendous stories of atrocities, but none claimed to be direct witnesses. Many blamed Gorbachev for failing to halt the violence that has torn the two southern republics for nearly two years. Both Arakelova, interviewed at the Armenian office, and the government newspaper Izvestia said much of the violence in Baku involves Azerbaijani refugees from Armenia forcing Armenians from their apartments so they will have a place to live. Izvestia said tens of thousands of Azerbaijanis who fled ethnic violence in Armenia in late 1988 remain without homes or jobs in Baku. Arakelova, an Armenian who has lived her entire life in Baku, said some Azerbaijani men broke into her apartment a week ago and ``they began beating me with everything they could find,'' including a brick and a heavy wooden pole. She fled that night, and her hometown a few days later, not even stopping to find the identity papers she must produce to check into a Soviet hotel. ``They took all my property, and there is somebody living in my apartment already,'' she said. She said the police advised them to leave, and said they have lost control of the city. Ambartsyum Galstyan, an Armenian activist reached by telephone in Yerevan, said soldiers were advising Armenians in villages along the border between the republics to evacuate, leading them to fear that the government has decided to solve the ethnic violence by permanently separating the two populations. ``Vremya'' showed elderly Armenian women being treated for injuries in Yerevan and said 72 of the evacuees from Baku were hospitalized, including 20 in grave condition. In Tbilisi, capital of neighboring Georgia, 3,000 Armenians rallied at the House of Government to show support for their brothers in Azerbaijan, activist Sergei Dandurov said in a telephone interview. Protesters also shouted their support for independence for Georgia and Armenia.

DOC.HEAD: Iran's Khamenei Says Islamic Zeal Behind Soviet Unrest
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt, and AM-Iran-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Wednesday that Islamic fervor was behind events in Soviet Azerbaijan, and warned Moscow not to deal harshly with the Shiite Moslem upsurge, Tehran radio reported. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Khamenei as saying ``anyone who thinks or pretends that the motives behind these movements are ethnic or nationalistic is making a big mistake. These sentiments are Islamic, and Soviet leaders should face this fact with realism.'' Official reports from Soviet Azerbaijan and Armenia say at least 58 people have been killed in violence over who should control of Nagorno-Karabakh. The region contains mostly Christian Armenians, but has been part of predominantly Moslem Azerbaijan since 1923. Moscow on Monday enforced a state of emergency in parts of both republics and sent in Red Army units and KGB troops to protect citizens from violence. Khamenei praised the ``admirable courage'' of Soviet authorities in allowing free expression to Islam, but warned they should not ``through wrong analysis respond harshly and oppressively to these Islamic sentiments.'' The animosity between Armenians and Azerbaijanis flared into violence Saturday when some Azerbaijanis in Baku went on the rampage against Armenians living there. The clashes were preceded by demonstrations in Azerbaijan, when hundreds of Soviet Moslems gathered on the bank of the Aras river which forms part of the frontier with Iran, and demanded an open border and free trade with their kin on the other side. The Soviet Azerbaijanis are bound by a common language, culture and religion with their brethren across the frontier, who constitute a third of Iran's 55 million people. Tehran radio reported more than 70 Soviet Moslems swam across the river for short visits with their Iranian kin since the religious upsurge on Dec. 31. The Tehran government has said it welcomes Soviet Moslems who would like to visit Iran, and free trade across the border. A Soviet delegation is expected to visit Iran soon to discuss tourist travel and trade between the Iranian and Soviet Azerbaijans.

DOC.HEAD: Boston University President Announces for Governor
DOC.TEXT: Boston University President John Silber announced Wednesday he plans to seek the Democratic nomination for governor, although he has a few quibbles with the party. Silber, 63, the university's president for 19 years, is entering his first political race. Being an outsider is a help, he said. ``Who is likely as governor to make the changes that are needed?'' Silber said. ``Those who have failed in the past to change the way things are done, or someone who comes in from the outside?'' The governorship became a wide-open race a year ago when Michael S. Dukakis announced he would not seek another term when his third term expires at the end of 1990. Silber is the fourth candidate to seek the Democratic endorsement. Silber, joined by his wife, his 95-year-old mother and five of his seven children, made his well-orchestrated announcement to several hundred supporters seated in the wooden pews of the historic Old South Meeting House. Silber acknowledged differences with the state's dominant party, although he said he has been a Democrat most of his life. ``In recent years, I have become increasingly dissatisfied with the direction of the Democratic Party,'' Silber said. ``It has become increasingly a party of very narrow special interests and single-issue politics.'' He has acknowledged voting for Republicans George Bush and Ronald Reagan in recent political elections and served as an adviser to President Reagan on commissions dealing with Central America. To win a spot on the Sept. 18 primary ballot, Silber needs at least 15 percent of the delegates elected to the party's June convention. The others seeking the Democratic nomination are Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, former state Attorney General Francis Bellotti and state House Taxation Committee Chairman John Flood. Former federal prosecutor William Weld, state House Minority Leader Steven Pierce, former Congressman Paul Cronin and former Metropolitan District Commissioner Guy Carbone are among those seeking the Republican nomination. With his emphasis on being an outsider, Silber joins several other Democrats in distancing himself from those who have guided the state through a difficult year with a budget crisis and Dukakis losing his bid for president. Silber as BU president has made enemies with expansion of his urban campus and with decisions such as a ban on overnight dormitory visitors of the opposite sex. He frequently is at odds with his faculty, where union organizing drives are a constant. The university trustees are scheduled to meet Thursday to discuss Silber's leave status from the 26,000-student school, said Tom Cashman, a university spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Some Fatal Attacks by Pit Bulls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `June 13 ...' to CORRECT location of attack to Morgan Hill, Calif., sted Santa Clara.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Pit Bull Attack
DOC.TEXT: The death Wednesday of a 70-year-old California woman who was mauled by her grandson's pit bull terriers was the latest in a continuing series of deaths and serious injuries caused by the tough canine breed. Two dogs mauled Marjee Lilly of San Diego on Tuesday at her grandson's home in Los Angeles. Authorities said she was trying to feed the dogs when they attacked. Here is a list of some other recent fatal pit bull attacks: April 6, 1987 _ Dr. William Eckman, 67, of Kettering, Ohio, is killed by two pit bulls while visiting another home. June 13, 1987 _ A pit bull trained for prizefighting and guarding a backyard marijuana crop kills 2-year-old James Soto after the boy wanders into a neighbor's yard in Morgan Hill, Calif. July 4, 1987 _ Robert Barbarita, 29, of Rochester, N.Y., is attacked by a pit bull while watching fireworks in a park. Barbarita died two weeks later from a blood clot that traveled from his badly bitten leg to his lung. Nov. 10, 1988 _ Graduate student Kevin B. Cull, 25, is attacked and killed by two pit bulls while walking up a driveway in Geneva, Ill., to meet friends. Dec. 11, 1988 _ Six-month-old Amber Vergara is fatally mauled by her father's pit bull at home in Canton, Ohio. May 4, 1989 _ Three-year-old Justin Webb is killed by his grandparents' pit bull while playing in their backyard in Clute, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Attempt To Build Office Complex Was Wake Up Call
DOC.TEXT: Plans by the university Thomas Jefferson founded that threatened to blot out a view of his home overlooking the Blue Ridge Mountains were ``the wake-up call'' for preservationists, a spokesman said Wednesday. The University of Virginia announced this week that it has decided against putting an $11 million office complex near the entrance to the house the third president built. It was the second time in about 10 years that a view of Jefferson's home, Monticello, had been threatened. The complex would have blocked the view from those driving on a nearby road. The house, which sits on a hill on the outskirts of Charlottesville, can now be seen from some distance away. The proposed complex would have been between the road and the house. ``The setting of Monticello was important to Mr. Jefferson and it's important to us,'' said Daniel P. Jordan, executive director of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation, which owns Monticello and the surrounding 2,000 acres. ``That was the wake-up call and we're concerned about protecting what's left.'' ``What this thing has done is alert Monticello to take care of its entrance,'' said Robert Carter, a foundation trustee. The complex was to have housed the state Department of Forestry and some other offices. It was not to have been part of the campus, which is on the other side of town. The foundation is trying to buy an easement from the university to provide permanent protection from future development, Jordan said. Other options include having the entrance designated a scenic parkway, he said. University spokesman William Fishback said the school Jefferson founded in 1819 is now considering half a dozen other sites. ``From an economic development standpoint, any community would be delighted to have a clean industry,'' Fishback said. Jordan said the foundation also is working with the Trust for Public Land, to develop a strategy to protect Monticello. That group helped protect Mount Vernon, George Washington's home. Monticello is depicted on the back of the nickel. ``About a decade ago, there was an attempt to change a cemetery along the corridor,'' Jordan said. ``They wanted to construct a mausoleum that would have been a replica of Monticello that provoked a furor and was beaten back.'' Jordan hailed the university's decision, saying ``it was the right decision and best for everybody, including the university.'' ``It's real important that our nation recognize that this was a tough decision for the university, and we commend their willingness to reconsider and their decision to look elsewhere,'' Jordan said. ``We think this shows sensitivity on their part, on this issue.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Claim of Two Professed Wiretappers
DOC.TEXT: A judge Wednesday threw out an $11 million claim by two fired telephone workers who contend their reputations were damaged when the company denied their accusations that it engaged in illegal wiretapping. Hamilton County Common Pleas Judge Fred Cartolano ruled that Leonard Gates and Robert Draise, both former Cincinnati Bell Telephone Co. employees, had not proved they were defamed by the company. Gates and Draise claimed they set 1,200 illegal wiretaps on telephones of criminal suspects, reporters and public officials from 1972 to 1984 at the direction of company supervisors or police. Cincinnati Bell denied the allegations and sued Gates and Draise for defamation. The two fired workers countersued for $11 million. A jury has been hearing the lawsuits since Nov. 20. The telephone company's suit against the pair is continuing. The judge said he based his decision on several factors, including Gates' and Draise's refusals to submit to polygraph tests. The judge also said he found inconsistencies in their allegations about when some of the wiretaps took place. Cartolano also cited an opinion by U.S. Magistrate Robert Steinberg, who said Gates was not a credible witness. Steinberg presided over Gates' employment case against Cincinnati Bell, which fired Gates in 1986. Gates said Steinberg's opinion should not have been considered, since the case has been appealed to the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The judge said Gates and Draise could be defined as public figures who sought out the media to press their claims of corruption at the phone company. ``At this time you're subjected to a higher standard of proof,'' Cartolano said. ``You must prove that the false statements (were) made with actual malice.'' Gates and Draise, who were acting as their own attorneys, argued that they were not public figures and that the media sought them out. ``I don't feel we're public figures,'' Gates said. ``We didn't ask to be sued. We only countersued because they were suing us.'' Cartolano ruled after Draise and Gates rested their case against the phone company. ``We are pleased with the judge's decision to dismiss Gates' and Draise's claim,'' Cincinnati Bell spokeswoman Cyndy Cantoni said. ``We'll have further comment after the jury rules.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Says Germans Do Not Want Discussion of Changing Borders
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Wednesday that the German people have no intention of reviving the national border issue because it could be divisive. Kohl has been criticized for refusing to call specifically for permanent confirmation of the current border between Poland and East Germany, leading some to fear a reunited Germany might seek to regain territory it ceded to Poland after World War II. In a speech before the French Institute of Foreign Relations, Kohl repeated his government's policy that the definitive establishment of the country's borders can only come in a freely negotiated peace settlement involving all of Germany. But he said most Germans do not want to raise the question of the country's borders _ an issue that has arisen since Poland and East Germany shed their hard-line governments last year and began instituting reform. ``The Germans _ and no one should doubt it _ have no intention of starting in tomorrow's Europe a discussion about frontiers that would necessarily compromise the order of European peace to which we all aspire together,'' he said. ``The Germans want a durable reconciliation with their Polish neighbors and, for that, the Poles must equally have the certitude of living within sure frontiers,'' he said. Kohl said this is why ``nobody wants to link reunification with the movement of existing borders _ borders which in a future Europe of freedom are bound to lose their importance.''

DOC.HEAD: Colombia Hands Over Two Wanted on U.S. Drug Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spellings in last two grafs, Ganger to Gamber and Barcos to Barco
DOC.TEXT: A brother and sister wanted on federal charges of running a cocaine-trafficking ring between Colombia and this country were extradited Wednesday by deputy U.S. marshals. Diana Maria Caballero Rangel Gamber, 29, and Roberto Caballero Rangel, 32, were turned over to U.S. marshals by Colombian authorities and flown to Greensboro, N.C., the Marshals Service said. The two were arrested Oct. 20 by Colombian authorities in Bucaramanga on federal drug trafficking charges steming from a 1988 indictment returned by a federal grand jury in Greensboro, N.C. They had been in custody awaiting extradition. The indictment charges that the two participated, along with 11 other defendants, in the cocaine-trafficking ring that operated over a 5 1@2-year period between Colombia and Florida, Arizona and the Carolinas. Among other things, Ms. Gamber is accused of delivering by automobile ``kilogram quantities'' of cocaine from Colombia to her brother in Phoenix. So far, 13 Colombians have been extradited to this country since last August, when Colombian President Virgilio Barco announced a crackdown on drug lords.

DOC.HEAD: Austrian Prince Heads Havel's Team of Consultants
DOC.TEXT: Karl Schwarzenberg, whose aristocratic family was the biggest private landowner in prewar Czechoslovakia, heads a team of consultants appointed by President Vaclav Havel, news media said Wednesday. The official CTK news agency said the team comprises important Czechoslovak personalities living abroad. Schwarzenberg is an Austrian citizen. No other names were disclosed, but it was believed the idea was to attract influential exiled Czechoslovaks to return home. The announcement did not give details on the corps of consultants. Schwarzenberg's full name is Karl Fuerst (prince) zu Schwarzenberg.
