Nobility titles were abolished and forbidden after the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian empire in 1918, when Austria became a republic. As chairman of the Vienna-based International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights, Schwarzenberg, 52, traveled frequently in communist Eastern Europe. He was sometimes denied a visa from some Soviet bloc countries, including pre-revolution Czechoslovakia. Schwarzenberg repeatedly intervened in behalf of the late Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov; Havel, and other former human rights activists in Eastern Europe. He has a good knowledge of Czech and is Havel's personal friend. His property in Austria comprises farm and forestland and a sprawling palace, including a first-class hotel, in downtown Vienna. After World War II, the huge landed property in Czechoslovakia of the Schwarzenbergs was impounded by the state and the family had to leave, as did other nobility with estates in Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Ruskin Spear Dead, Realistic Portrait Painter
DOC.TEXT: Ruskin Spear, who painted realistic and often satirical portraits of famous Britons, died after a short illness, his son said Wednesday. He was 78. Roger Spear said his father died Tuesday at his home in British Grove, Hammersmith, the west London district by the Thames River. The artist was born there and continually painted its people, street life and pubs in the manner of the Edwardian Walter Sickert, whose depictions of Camden Town in north London were the main influence in Spear's art. Spear was much liked for the humor of his often rough and striking pictures. Groups would gather round his works at the Royal Academy of Arts summer exhibition where Spear could be relied upon to produce an amusing portrait, sometimes uncommissioned. Margaret Thatcher exclaimed: ``It's terrible. Let's get away from it as fast as we can,'' when she saw Spear's portrait of her called ``True Blue'' before she became Prime Minister in 1979. Sir Winston Churchill said to him, ``Go away, you horrible man,'' after seeing his portrait by Spear. His commissioned portraits included actor Laurence Olivier as Macbeth, Archbishop of Canterbury Michael Ramsey and Tory politician R.A. Butler. When not in his studio, Spear was usually to be found in a Hammersmith pub. He once listed his recreations as painting, breathing and drinking. He taught at the Royal College of Art from 1952 to 1977 when a new generation of painters emerged, including David Hockney and Peter Blake. Spear had polio as a child and suffered from Parkinson's disease but he painted until the last weeks of his life.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun Gov't Orders Defiant Newspaper to Close, Protests Occur
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with Aoun prosecutor issuing subpoena against defiant newspaper editor and ordering paper shut down, quote, details. CORRECTS that other newspapers in enclave followed Aoun's order. Pickup 9th, `Hoss issued'; edits thereafter to trim
DOC.TEXT: Maverick Christian leader Gen. Michel Aoun on Wednesday ordered a newspaper closed for a week and the editor was subpoenaed after the paper continued to refer to President Elias Hrawi as head of state. ``From now on, critical tongues shall be cut off,'' Aoun told the daily crowd of cheering supporters outside his underground bunker of the presidential palace in Christian east Beirut. Other broadcast and print media have halted operations in protest of a directive Aoun issued a day earlier that prohibits the Lebanese media from referring to Hrawi as president and to Salim Hoss as prime minister. Hrawi and Hoss have been in office since November under an Arab League-backed peace plan that Aoun opposes. Aoun and Hrawi are Christians, and Hoss is a Sunni Moslem. Police ringed the offices of the conservative newspaper Ad-Diyar in east Beirut's Hazmiyeh district and enforced the weeklong suspension order of George Ghanem, the prosecutor general, an official statement said. The police withdrew after serving a subpoena to Ad-Diyar's editor Charles Ayoub. The action came after the paper published a front-page editorial in which Ayoub said following Aoun's instructions would mean ``suffocation. ... We do not want to divorce our freedom, betray our pen and desert our office.'' Ayoub's article was broadcast repeatedly by Moslem radio stations in Moslem west Beirut. Ghanem said he has started legal proceedings against Ayoub on a charge of ``infringement on national sovereignty,'' which is punishable by up to five years in prison under Lebanon's penal code. The statement mentioned no date for the trial. But Ayoub told The Associated Press he was subpoenaed to appear before a military examining magistrate within 48 hours. ``We have not been subjected to any inconvenience or harassment by the police but we are not going to appear tomorrow,'' Ayoub said. Edmond Rizk, information and justice minister in Hrawi's government, went on the government-run Channel 7 television station in west Beirut and ordered judicial authorities not to enforce Ad-Diyar's suspension. He called Aoun an imposter. Two radio stations _ Voice of Lebanon of the rightist Phalange Party and Voice of Free Lebanon of the Christian Lebanese forces militia _ maintained a newscast strike for a second day to protest Aoun's orders. In addition to Ad-Diyar, four other daily papers publish in the Christian enclave and six in Beirut's Moslem sector. The conservative Al-Anwar newspaper, based in the Christian suburb of Hazmiyeh near Aoun's headquarters, followed the general's instructions. The others in the enclave also obeyed the order. The nation's most prestigious newspaper, An-Nahar, protested Aoun's order by not publishing a Wednesday edition even though it is based in west Beirut. ``These new circumstances restrict us from publishing freely. . .. We will not publish again until these conditions change,'' said editor Francois Aql. The struggle for control of the media reflected a growing split within Christian ranks over the peace plan to end the Moslem-Christian civil war, which has killed more than 150,000 people. Lebanon's press has maintained its reputation as the freest in the Arab world despite 14 years of civil war. All political groups have been unfettered in expressing their opinions in print. Hoss issued a statement Wednesday saying, ``The freedom of the press is sacred in Lebanon.'' He said Aoun ``poses a threat to the Lebanese homeland.'' Aoun's 20,000 troops control the 310-square-mile Christian enclave, which includes Beirut's eastern sector and a narrow strip northeast of the capital. After he was elected president by Parliament, Hrawi dismissed Aoun as prime minister and army commander. But the recalcitrant general has held out in the Christian enclave and refused to leave the presidential palace. Aoun, who was appointed by former President Amin Gemayel as head of an interim military Cabinet Sept. 22, 1988, has declared the nation's one-chamber house dissolved to prevent the election of a new head of state while the Syrian army polices Lebanon. Aoun's opponents said his decision was unconstitutional, noting that only a president has the right to dissolve the legislature.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Two Counts Against State Senator
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday threw out two corruption counts against state Sen. Joseph Montoya, saying the bribery charges failed to meet a $5,000 threshhold required for federal prosecution. U.S. District Judge Milton Schwartz also said the charges covered executive department employees under another statute, but not state legislators. Montoya, chairman of the Business and Professions Committee, is the first lawmaker indicted in a four-year FBI ``sting'' of the state Capitol in which agents posed as businessmen and dispensed cash for political favors. In a ruling last week, Schwartz upheld 10 other counts, covering extortion, racketeering and money laundering allegations, but put off a decision on the bribery charges. The two counts stem from Montoya's videotaped acceptance of a $3,000 check from an undercover FBI agent, and a $500 contribution from a group of independent oil and natural gas producers. Schwartz said Wednesday that contending that the $5,000 threshhold had been reached, ``stretches the language (of the law) beyond a sensible reading.'' Montoya, 50, took the stand for the first time Tuesday, and was cross-examined by prosecutors Wednesday. He has denied he demanded money in return for votes or political favors. ``I never made that suggestion in any fashion, shape or form,'' the Democrat said when asked by defense attorney Michael Sands if he had ever implied that he would drop a bill opposed by the National Football League Players Association in exchange for financial support. However, Montoya acknowledged he benefitted personally from some campaign fund expenditures, including videotapes and investment newsletters. He insisted that nearly all the expenditures were motivated primarily by legislative reasons. ``Politics never leave my personal life and my personal life never leaves politics,'' he said. Prosecutors claim the legislator from the district east of Los Angeles put his vote and political influence up for sale in an attempt to become wealthy. Assistant U.S. Attorney John Panneton questioned how the lawmaker spent his campaign funds, and at one point recited the oath of office in which Montoya promised to uphold the law. It is illegal for state senators to spend campaign funds for personal use. Montoya acknowleged that among his campaign fund expenditures were $4,300 he spent for clothing. He also spent $20,000 in campaign funds to help pass Proposition 73, one of two campaign reform measures passed by California voters in June 1988. Among its provisions are restrictions on campaign contributions and honorariums. Montoya said he regarded the $3,000 check from the undercover agent as a legal honorarium for going to breakfast with undercover agent George Murray and Senate staffer John Shahabian, who was acting as an FBI operative in federal agents' 3{-year undercover probe of alleged Capitol corruption.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Airplane Hijacking Admits Guilt, Apologizes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with arraignment, admission of guilt and apology. Picks up 10th graf, `Crew members...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AT6
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of trying to hijack an America West airliner to Cuba said Wednesday he was ``guilty as charged'' and apologized for what he said was an act of desperation to escape death threats. Jose Manuel Gonzalez-Gonzalez, 39, of New Orleans, was charged with aircraft piracy and assaulting a flight attendant during Tuesday's 10:45 p.m. flight from Houston to Las Vegas. Passengers said Gonzalez-Gonzalez grabbed flight attendant Stacy Wood, 26, announced he had a bomb and demanded to go to his native Cuba. He was apprehended at Austin's Robert Mueller Municipal Airport by a police officer who climbed up an emergency chute and overpowered him. No bomb was discovered, but a device made of a toothpaste container and a ``flashlight-type article'' was found, said FBI agent Michael Wilson. `The facts speak for themselves. I'm guilty as charged,'' Gonzalez-Gonzalez told U.S. Magistrate Stephen Capelle at his arraignment. ``My intention was to leave this country. I was being chased with constant threat of being murdered.'' Gonzalez-Gonzalez said others wanted to silence him for things he knew, but did not elaborate. He also said he wanted to apologize to Ms. Wood and the other passengers on Flight 727. ``They were never in any danger,'' he said. ``I took this course out of desperation.'' He also praised Ms. Wood, saying, ``She fought bravely.'' If convicted of air piracy, Gonzalez-Gonalez faces 20 years to life in prison. The assault charge carries a maximum 10-year prison term, said FBI agent James Echols. Gonzalez-Gonzalez said he boarded the plane with $1,100, which he tossed away in the airplane. He said he didn't think he would need the money. Byron Sage, supervisor of the FBI office in Austin, said he didn't know how much of the money was recovered. He said Gonzalez-Gonzalez has been previously arrested for public intoxication, solicitation of a prostitute and drug possession in Louisiana. Gonzalez-Gonzalez, who said he had ``been on the run'' for three weeks from New Orleans, asked to be tried outside of Texas. He said he didn't want to return to Louisiana and wanted to be tried in Washington, D.C. The magistrate said that issue would be determined later. He ordered Gonzalez-Gonzalez held until another hearing Jan. 25. Gonzalez-Gonzalez said he came to the United States when he was 11 years old. He said he was not a U.S. citizen. Crew members and passengers said Gonzalez-Gonzalez appeared agitated before and during the flight of the Boeing 737, which the airline said was carrying 34 passengers and a five-member flight crew. ``Our people on the ground at the ticket counter did ask him if he was OK,'' said America West spokesman Dik Shimizu. ``He replied basically saying he did not fly often, and he was nervous, and he also had an ill relative.'' ``We do not feel by any means that they made a mistake. We are looking at it. They made a decision based on the information they had to work with. Obviously hindsight is always 20-20,'' said Shimizu. Robert Martin, 24, of Fontana, Calif., said Gonzalez-Gonzalez sat two rows in front of him on the plane and talked loudly, complaining about American television programs. After Gonzalez-Gonzalez grabbed the flight attendant, pilot Dick Nelson told him that they had to land at Austin to refuel. Once on the ground, the passengers and three crew members escaped through an emergency chute. Police Capt. Lloyd Polk went up an emergency chute and wrestled with Gonzalez-Gonzalez. ``I saw he had the stewardess so I took action immediately,'' Polk said early Wednesday. Gonzalez-Gonzalez, Ms. Wood and another flight attendant were treated for minor injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Dallas Neighborhood Tense in Wake of Child-Snatchings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to CORRECT to four snatchings sted six, DELETES reference to intruder calling victims by name, police say only happened once and intruder apparently got name from nameplate on door. Picks up 8th graf, `The parents...'.
DOC.TEXT: Life in a quiet, residential section of the city isn't the same since a nocturnal intruder snatched four sleeping girls from their homes. Officers patrol on foot, homeowners use security systems even when they're home and parents and school officials grapple with protecting children without traumatizing them. Since September, four sleeping girls have been taken from their north Dallas homes in the middle of night. A man sexually assaulted three of them, police say. Police say they believe the assailant has been spotted twice more, prowling outside girls' bedroom windows before being scared off by passers-by. The latest episode occurred a week ago, when an intruder carried an 8-year-old girl from her bedroom but dropped her outside the house, unharmed, after she screamed. Some neighborhood men have quit taking evening walks for fear people will suspect them. Other residents worry that someone will get shot accidentally as tensions rise. Some parents tell of changing the pink drapes in their daughters' rooms to white to avoid tipping someone to the location of girls' rooms. ``The parents are really struggling with how to protect their children and at the same time keep from instilling fears in their children so that they can't sleep at night,'' said Lori Messerschmidt, who has coordinated counseling for families in the neighborhoods where the attacks occurred. More than 500 parents from the middle- to upper-class neighborhoods came to meetings Tuesday at two schools to talk about the attacks with school officials and police. In the exclusive Bent Tree West development where the latest attack occurred, the homeowners' association passed out fliers asking parents to take safety precautions: locking doors, watching their children, using security systems even when they're at home. ``Our neighborhood knows each other, that's why it was so shocking,'' said Jane Hood, who lives in the development. ``But I think everybody on our street is remembering to lock their doors.'' Police said Wednesday they have no solid leads in the attacks. The victims, all elementary school-age girls, haven't been able to give good descriptions, although all say the attacker was a white man with dark hair, police said. Investigators say some of the victims have been in heavily secured homes, complete with elaborate alarm systems and fences. But in at least the last attack, an unlocked patio door provided the intruder an easy way in. In each case, a man has taken the children just outside the house and assaulted or tried to assault them there, never taking them far. ``It's a daring offense,'' said Deputy Police Chief Grant Lappin. Police are talking to crime watch groups and at schools to make sure parents and children protect themselves. They've set up special surveillance units and a task force to work on nothing but the child snatchings. Officers patrol the areas on foot day and night and have woken up several residents in the middle of the night to tell them to lock their doors, Lappin said. ``It's our belief that, despite the publicity, that there are still some people in the area that are not aware of what is happening,'' said police spokesman Ed Spencer. ``Some officers up there on foot patrol on Sunday observed quite a few unlocked garage doors.' While parents want their children to be aware, they worry about traumatizing them. ``You have to choose your words carefully,' said Meg Sherard. ``I have a 10-year-old daughter, and you have to be careful that you don't get the children so paranoid that they think someone's going to break into the house and take them. ``So I've maintained a low-key approach, but I pick them (from school) and I don't let them outside in the front yard,'' she said. ``And if they're in the back, fenced in, I'm always in a place where I can see them.''

DOC.HEAD: Legislative Assistant to Thornburgh Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The top legislative aide to Attorney general Dick Thornburgh said Wednesday night she is resigning because she considers herself unsuited to be the Justice Department's spokeswoman on Capitol Hill. Assistant Attorney General Carol Crawford, blamed privately by department officials and legislative aides for an abrasive style that has hurt Thornburgh on Capitol Hill, said she told the attorney general last week of her plans to leave on Feb. 1. ``There is no eloquent way of saying this, This is not the right job for me,'' Ms. Crawford said in a telephoen interview. ``The functions of this position are not really functions that I enjoy or I am particularly well suited for.'' Aides to members of Congress, who spoke on condition of anonymity, have said Ms. Crawford has alienated lawmakers by refusing requests for information and taking a confrontational stance on a number of issues. One Democratic aide said Ms. Crawford antagonized House Appropriations Committee members by suggesting cuts in other departments, notably at the Commerce Department, so that the funds could be allocated to the Justice Department. ``She was still wearing her OMB hat,'' said the aide, referring to Ms. Crawford's previous position as associate director at the Office of Management and Budget, a post she held for 3{ years. The Office of Legislative Affairs was also faulted for refusing to honor the Appropriations Committee's request that the FBI delay plans to scale back field offices in Butte, Mont. and Savannah, Ga. The department had customarily deferred to the committee's objections to reprogramming money during a fiscal year. But Ms. Crawford informed Congress last June that the two FBI offices would be scaled back despite objections from lawmakers. The decision prompted Congress to attach a rider to a supplemental appropriations bill that prohibited further reorganization at the Justice Department until the end of the 1989 fiscal year. The measure delayed until recently Thornburgh's plan to merge 14 organized crime strike forces into U.S. attorneys offices. Ms. Crawford expressd surprise that she was criticized for being antagonistic. ``One of the functions of the person in ths position is to deny members of Congress or staff information that they are not permitted to have,'' she said. ``I can't think of anybody I've had unpleasant relations with,'' she said, but noted that ``there is a natural tension between the Justice Departmen an the Conress.'' ``I am mostly a mouthpiece,'' she said. ``If they don't like something you are saying, they are going to blame you.'' But she said she had tried ``to improve relations with Congress.'' Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said Ms. Crawford ``brought on some talented people.'' ``The office appears to be functioning well,'' said Runkel, who declined to comment on criticism of Ms. Crawford's performance. Ms. Crawford said her decision was not prompted by any pressure from Thornburgh and she has no immediate plans for another job.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Viewing Site Closed; Spectators Discouraged
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: NASA discouraged people Wednesday from trying to watch Friday's pre-dawn landing of the space shuttle Columbia after flooding from recent storms closed the public viewing area. ``It's going to be cold, it's going to be dark and you won't see a thing'' when Columbia touches down at 2:55 a.m. Friday, said spokeswoman Nancy Lovato of the National Aeronautic and Space Administration. ``I would sure advise people who want to see a shuttle landing to wait for a daylight landing.'' Recent storms dumped heavy rain and snow on Southern California, leaving standing water and mud on parts of Rogers Dry Lake, including the east shore where up to 500,000 spectators have gathered on the normally hard-packed clay to watch shuttles land, Lovato said. ``The dirt roads are impassable,'' she said. ``The Air Force decided to shut that site down.'' People may go to the so-called hillside site near NASA's facilities on this Mojave Desert military base, but Lovato said the site is 6 miles from concrete Runway 22, where the shuttle will land. At the very best, spectators will briefly see the shuttle as it hurtles past the runway lights; shuttles lack running lights, so Columbia will not be visible as it approaches. Columbia's landing will end a 10-day mission during which the shuttle's crew launched a Navy communications satellite and retrieved an 11-ton science satellite for return to Earth. Friday's landing will be only the second time a shuttle has set down in complete darkness. It also will be the heaviest shuttle ever to land. A National Weather Service snow advisory was in effect Wednesday for portions of Southern California above 2,000 feet, including Edwards Air Force Base. But forecasters said the latest storm would leave the region Thursday. Lovato said the forecast for Columbia's landing time calls for mostly clear skies, with very light winds, and possibly some scattered clouds at 5,000 feet and broken clouds at 8,000 feet. Temperatures were expected to be below freezing. Another storm front is expected Friday afternoon or Saturday, Lovato said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says Ready to Open Air Links and Borders With Iran
DOC.TEXT: Preparations have been completed for starting daily flights to Tehran and opening the land borders with Iran for visits by Moslem pilgrims, the government said Wednesday. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted an unidentified Iraqi Airways official as saying four jumbo jets were ready to leave for Tehran to transport as many as 1,500 Iranian pilgrims daily to Iraq as soon as Iran agreed. Interior Minister Samir Mohammed Abdel-Wahab said in an interview with the magazine Alef Ba that the decision for the air and land links was based on a proposal by President Saddam Hussein last month. Saddam proposed new direct talks to revive the stalled peace negotiations with Iran, Iraq's foe in an eight-year war that halted with a cease-fire in August 1988. Saddam also proposed an exchange of prisoners of war, the opening of air links between Baghdad and Tehran and visits by pilgrims to religious sites in both countries. Tehran, which insists on talks under United Nations auspices, called the proposal a ``deception,'' and said it fell short for not calling for an Iraqi troop withdrawal from Iranian territory captured during the Iran-Iraq war. Tehran Radio, monitored in Cyprus, said Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati addressed a conference of Iraqi opposition groups Wednesday. The conference closed with a resolution pledging to overthrow Saddam's government, it said. Also Wednesday, 50 sick and disabled Iraqi POWs released by Iran arrived in Baghdad aboard a plane chartered by the International Red Cross. Akram al-Witri, a Foreign Ministry legal adviser, said Iraq would reciprocate by releasing 20 Iranian sick and disabled prisoners on Thursday. There was no explanation why Iraq would not release an equal number of prisoners. The Red Cross has registered some 50,000 prisoners held by Iran and more than 19,200 by Iraq. But United Nations officials and diplomats estimate the two sides hold about 100,000 POWs between them. The Red Cross secured an agreement to repatriate ailing prisoners immediately after a U.N.-sponsored cease-fire halted the Persian Gulf war on Aug. 20, 1988. But the deal collapsed after the exchange of only 400 disabled and wounded prisoners with both sides accusing each other of falsifying the number of captives seeking asylum. U.N.-sponsored peace talks launched a few days after the cease-fire have been deadlocked mainly over the troop withdrawal issue and Iraq's demand for the demarcation of the border to give it sovereignty over the Shatt-al-Arab waterway, its main outlet to the sea.

DOC.HEAD: US Soldiers Stray into Costa Rica
DOC.TEXT: Three helicopters carrying more than 100 U.S. troops landed in Costa Rica this week, apparently after becoming lost while trying to find a western Panamanian town, public security ministry officials said. Ministry spokesman Carlos Jimenez said the soldiers who landed Monday night told civil guardsmen they were trying to reach El Progreso, a Panamanian town about two miles from the Costa Rican border, where they had been told troops loyal to deposed Panamanian strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega were hiding. They apologized and left when told they were in Costa Rica, he said. Residents said other helicopters overflew the area. Iria Herrera Arguedas said she yelled at eight soldiers approaching her house not to hurt her children. An American soldier speaking Spanish told her they were lost and not to be afraid, she said. She said the soldiers stayed about 25 minutes and left after civil guards told them where El Progreso was.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Called Mexican Attorney General Over `Drug Wars'
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government was so concerned about reaction to NBC-TV's ``Drug Wars'' miniseries that a top Justice Department official called Mexico's attorney general the day after the first episode aired, the attorney general said Wednesday. ``He asked me how I was taking it,'' Enrique Alvarez del Castillo told reporters. Laughing, the attorney general said he had replied with a Mexican profanity and added that he had appreciated the gesture. The miniseries based on the death of Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena in 1985 was broadcast Jan. 7, 8 and 9; it caused a controversy in Mexico because of its graphic portrayal of corruption in the Mexican legal system. Mexican officials thought it would deal a blow to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's efforts to change Mexico's image, while U.S. officials feared Mexican anger and hurt pride would inhibit relations, especially in the fight against drug trafficking. Officials of both nations have insisted that is not happening and U.S. officials have praised the Salinas' administration efforts to fight drug trafficking and corruption. Mexican officials are quick to point out that 36 tons of cocaine has been seized since Salinas took office 13 months ago, more than was seized the preceding 10 years combined. Drug kingpins Rafael Caro Quintero and Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo were sentenced in December to 40 years in prison without parole for the Camarena killing. Alvarez, who was governor of Jalisco when Camarena was kidnapped in the state capital Guadalajara, said he found the miniseries' portrayal of Mexican justice ``irritating'' but emphasized that it had not affected relations and that the governments were keeping things on an even keel. As an example of the close U.S.-Mexico relationship under Salinas and Bush, Alvarez said he had received a sympathetic telephone call he received from a top U.S. drug enforcement official on behalf of U.S. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh. The call came after the first episode of ``Drug Wars'' was broadcast in the United States and on Mexico City's cable system, Alvarez said. At a news conference, Alvarez said the government is ``interested'' in press reports that allege Camarena was involved in drug trafficking himself, but that it is not reopening the Camarena investigation. U.S. officials have indignantly denied the reports, which originated with a dispatch by the government news service Notimex. On Tuesday, Alvarez had said there was no independent corroboration of the allegations, which were repeated on a Mexican television program that purported to point out ``falsehoods'' broadcast by NBC. Alvarez noted 26 others were convicted with Caro Quintero and Fonseca and said he did not expect any more indictments. At another news conference, members of a U.S. congressional delegation minimized the impact of the NBC miniseries. ``It was just like a soap opera, like `Lonesome Dove,' `Dynasty' or `Dallas' and that's how people will regard it,'' said Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, who represents a border district. But Rep. Ronald D. Coleman, D-Fla., said the program properly did not gloss over problems within Mexico's law-enforcement establishment. ``For us to forget that you have bad guys here just like we have bad guys in the United States does a disservice to the many Mexicans who have lost their lives fighting the drug problem and a disservice to the Americans who have also lost their lives,'' Coleman said. ``It over-dramatized it, it stretched the truth. But the kernels of truth were there. All of those people are real people and we can't forget that,'' Coleman added.

DOC.HEAD: UN Chief Writes Ethiopian President on Relief Deliveries
DOC.TEXT: Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar has written to Ethiopia's president, stressing the need to work out arrangements so relief deliveries can begin soon to northern Ethiopia, a spokeswoman said Wednesday. She said the letter will be delivered personally to Marxist President Mengistu Haile Mariam by a representative of the secretary-general. Some relief agencies estimate 5 million Ethiopians could face starvation this year, most of them in rebel-controlled areas in the north. The region was hit by drought last year. Rebels in Eritrea and Tigre provinces have fought the government in Addis Ababa for years, seeking autonomy. The insurgencies also have disrupted supply lines intended to carry relief aid into Wolla. A U.S. congressional staff member, speaking in a telephone interview from Washington, said the rebels have agreed in principle to a plan that would let food and medical supplies move through government-controlled ports and cities, and into the areas where conditions are expected to be the most dire. He spoke on condition of anonymity. In 1984 and 1985, up to a million people died of starvation in Tigre and Eritrea; in 1987 and 1988, a huge international relief operation prevented a similar tragedy during another crop failure. Reps. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, and Bill Emerson, R-Mo., both members of the House Select Committee on Hunger, are leading an effort by U.S. lawmakers to get the Ethiopian government to approve a delivery plan. A spokesman for the U.S. Agency for International Development, the foreign aid branch of the State Department, said its office in Addis Ababa estimates 750,000 metric tons of emergency food are needed for 1990. Most of the food supplies sought by relief agencies are on hand or have been pledged, said John Riddle, the AID press officer for Egypt and Africa. Riddle said, ``It looks like in terms of what's pledged there is no shortage of food. Working out an agreement for delivery is the critical element left to be resolved. ``These things are always a problem when you're trying to get three warring parties to agree on anything.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Lehder Says he Paid Noriega Millions
DOC.TEXT: Convicted Colombian cocaine kingpin Carlos Lehder said in an interview televised Wednesday that he and associates paid deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega several million dollars for protection. ``I would not be able to go into exact details as to the extent of that protection ... because this would not be in my best interest,'' Lehder said in the interview conducted for the West German magazine Stern. A videotape of the interview _ conducted in November at the federal prison in Marion, Ill., but not yet published _ was broadcast by NBC News. Lehder said that for about 10 years, Noriega would take all drugs and drug paraphernalia seized in Panama and sell it to drug dealers in Colombia, Panama and the United States. Lehder was extradited to the United States in 1987 and is serving a sentence of life in prison plus 135 years. He was charged with running a large cocaine smuggling operation on a small island in the Bahamas. In the interview, Lehder praised Lyndon Pindling, prime minister of the Bahamas, as a marvelous, honest leader. Pindling has long denied allegations of drug corruption involving Lehder, and Lehder refused to comment on the relationship. ``It is possible that I knew the prime minister,'' he said. ``However, whether he was involved or not is an answer that he himself must give, not me.'' Noriega faces a February 1988 indictment in Miami of using Panama to protect cocaine shipments heading north and drug-processing chemicals and drug money headed south. He was arrested Jan. 3 following the U.S. invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Activists Arrested in Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs UPDATING with U.S. groups complaining about Nicaraguan bureaucracy.
DOC.TEXT: Four opposition activists were arrested for ``aggression, offenses and lack of respect'' regarding President Daniel Ortega as he was leaving a Sandinista rally, the Interior Ministry said Wednesday. An opposition candidate said police used tear gas Tuesday night to break up the demonstration in Granada, Nicaragua's second largest city, 28 miles southeast of Managua. Luis Sanchez Sancho, a spokesman for the United National Opposition coalition, accused police of attacking a small rally the coalition was holding, but conceded they had no permission to stage it. Julia Mena, 36, UNO candidate for National Assembly deputy for Region 4, said about 1,000 supporters had gathered for the rally on a street about three blocks from the hotel where Ortega was to dine. At about 6 p.m., riot police arrived and ordered the crowd to disperse, but stayed about a half-block away, she said. She said police then threw tear gas canisters to break up the gathering. People dispersed and police withdrew at about 6:30 p.m., she said. ``Later I found out there were some people arrested,'' she said. The government identified those arrested as Pedro Rafael Guzman, Roger Rafael Rocha, Alberto Jose Roman and Pablo Valencia Mora. The ruling Sandinista National Liberation Front and UNO are the main contenders in general elections scheduled for Feb. 25. Ortega is running for re-election against UNO presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, publisher of the only opposition newspaper, La Prensa. An Interior Ministry communique said Ortega was leaving the Sandinista rally for a dinner at a hotel about six blocks away when UNO sympathizers started the disturbance. ``The Sandinista police exhausted its persuasive resources in order to make them desist from their aggressive attitude, without result,'' it said. Police were ``forced to proceed with energy to dissolve the provocateurs and detain the main instigators.'' Diplomatic sources who witnessed the incident blamed UNO. They spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Although it's hard in such instances to say precisely who started it, it was mostly a provocation by UNO,'' one said. It was the first report of violence at a political gathering since a UNO march on Dec. 10 turned into a riot between Sandinista and UNO activists in Masatepe, a small town south of Managua. That riot led to eight political parties signing a code of conduct on Dec. 15 that calls on party activists to respect political foes and avoid violence. UNO did not sign. UNO spokesman Danilo Lacayo said Wednesday the bloc refused to sign the pact because Sandinistas continue to intimidate opposition activists. In Washington, two groups _ one Republican, one Democratic _ which use U.S. government funds to promote democracy overseas said the Sandinista government may be intentionally blocking creation of programs to educate Nicaragua's voters about democracy before the elections. Presidents J. Brian Atwood of the National Democratic Institute and Keith Schuette of the National Republican Institute wrote to Deputy Foreign Minister Victor Tinoco saying Nicaragua put up bureaucratic roadblocks to their efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Deadlocked on 13 Charges
DOC.TEXT: Jurors who have reached verdicts on 52 counts in the McMartin preschool molestation case said Wednesday they are deadlocked on the remaining 13 charges in the nation's longest, costliest criminal trial. Superior Court Judge William Pounders received a note from the jurors as they ended their day's deliberation and called a hearing for Thursday to discuss the deadlock and possibly opening the 52 sealed verdicts. In an interview Wednesday evening, Pounders said he would deal with the deadlocked counts first, either declaring a mistrial on those counts and reading the sealed verdicts, or sending the jury back to resume deliberations on the undecided counts. He said the verdicts could also be read before sending the jury back. However, the judge noted that ``The attorneys are hopeful all the counts will be resolved before we take any verdicts.'' Pounders said he would discuss the matter with attorneys before quizzing jurors on whether they want to deliberate further. The jurors are deciding whether Raymond Buckey, 31, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63, are guilty or innocent of charges they molested children at their family-owned McMartin Pre-School in Manhattan Beach. The jury that spent 2{ years hearing evidence in the case have agreed on 52 verdicts. They have all been sealed. None of the verdicts is official until it is announced in court and affirmed by the jury. Jurors are in their ninth week of deliberations. Buckey and his mother are charged with 64 counts of child molestation and the one shared count of conspiracy. One of the charges which apparently has divided the jurors is the conspiracy charge which names both defendants. Jurors asked twice for an explanation of how they could convict one defendant and acquit the other on that joint charge, but seemed perplexed after they received an explanation earlier Wednesday. After conferring with lawyers, Pounders told jurors they could convict just one of the defendants on the charge ``if you feel that the defendant conspired with one or more other persons.'' However, he noted the conspiracy count includes eight alleged overt acts, some of them naming only one defendant. A split verdict, he said, would require elimination of overt acts alleged against a defendant acquitted of the charge. It was at that point, he said, that some jurors began shaking their heads in confusion. Buckey and his mother were the only defendants required to stand trial after an 18-month preliminary hearing. Five women teachers who worked at the McMartin Pre-School had charges against them dismissed. Among those were Buckey's sister, Peggy Ann, and his grandmother, Virginia McMartin, who founded the prestigious but now defunct nursery school. On Tuesday, deliberations were halted at midday because a juror became ill. On Wednesday, the talks did not begin until 1 p.m. because another juror's child was ill. No alternates remain in the case and the judge has worried that losing one of the 12 remaining jurors would force a mistrial.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Say Aid Cuts Could Harden Israeli Stance on Arabs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf `There is' to UPDATE with army comment. Pickup 8th, `Other leaders...'
DOC.TEXT: Government leaders Wednesday said a reduction in U.S. aid could harden Israel's stance in efforts to arrange Palestinian-Israeli peace talks. They also said said a drop in funding from Washington could seriously hamper efforts to absorb a wave of Soviet immigrants expected to reach as many as 100,000 people this year. The comments came in response to a statement Tuesday by the Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, who said a 5 percent cut to big aid recipients such as Israel could free up money to support democracy efforts in Poland and Eastern Europe. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the idea was ``well worth looking at,'' triggering concern in Israel. The Jewish state receives $3 billion a year in military and civilian assistance from the United States, making it the largest American aid recipient. Vice Premier Shimon Peres, head of the left-of-center Labor Party, responded indignantly to Dole's remarks, noting Israel spends nearly a quarter of its budget on defense. ``There is totally no justification to deal a blow to us instead of just dividing it up a little bit with the Europeans,'' Peres told economists in Jerusalem. He called Dole's comments ``a very worrisome declaration.'' Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron said he, too, was worried over the idea of reduced U.S. aid. ``We and the United States enjoy strategic cooperation based on the assumption that a strong Israel is a cause of stability in the Middle East. As long as this is the basis, I hope very much that the United States would not cut its military and economic aid,'' Shomron said on Israel Television. Other leaders said the talk of cutting aid seemed to be an attempt to persuade right-wing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to bend on his refusal to involve the PLO in peace talks. The issue has long delayed progress on Middle East peace efforts. ``I have no doubt that the remarks (by Dole) are serious and ... that if there will be no political progress, then this mood could yield tough consequences,'' such as aid cuts, Communications Minister Gad Yaacobi of Labor said. But he said such a move would be a mistake. ``By past experience, we know that Israel's reaction to such steps is a hardening of its positions,'' he said. ``I am worried this will be counterproductive.'' Israel often digs in its heels in response to outside threats, including criticism from allies such as the United States. ``We understand the new needs of the U.S. in East European countries, the new developments, but these developments also affect us,'' Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told Parliament. Finance officials noted that inflation has eroded U.S. aid by about 40 percent in the last decade and that much of a $1.8 billion package in civilian aid was going toward debt repayment to the United States. ``Any major cut in aid is going to create a very tough situation for us because we are already pushing our budget to the limit,'' said David Naveh, director of the Finance Ministry's International Division and Investment Authority. Netanyahu also told reporters: ``A strong Israel is a secure Israel and one that is more able to progress along the course of peace. This is something I think is in the interest of American policy as well, and I would hope very much that all sides of the equation be taken into account.'' Netanyahu noted that less U.S. aid could hurt efforts to house, feed and make jobs for thousands of new Soviet immigrants. Hundreds of newcomers have been arriving on a daily basis. ``We understand the new needs of the U.S.in East European countries, the new developments, but these developments also affect us,'' Netanyahu said. ``It's a very difficult time. We have a great migration and defense needs.'' The government is trying to raise $1 billion immediately for the immigrants, hoping the United States will provide about half the sum and the rest will come from American and European Jewry.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Trial Date Set; Another Co-defendant Extradited
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Wednesday scheduled Manuel Noriega's drug trafficking trial to begin in early March after attorneys for the deposed dictator's co-defendants demanded a speedy trial. But U.S. District Judge William M. Hoeveler noted that the trial on charges brought in a February 1988 indictment in Miami would be complex, and expressed strong doubts it would actually start that soon. The trial date was set shortly after Noriega issued a statement denying prosecution claims that one of his co-defendants, Luis del Cid, headed Panama's intelligence agency or served as his right-hand man. Hoeveler set the trial for the week of March 5 after he continued the bond hearing for del Cid to give his defense more time to respond to new allegations by prosecutors. ``We will set the date for that week,'' Hoeveler said, ``but of course, there will be further motions and we will just have to see what will happen.'' Del Cid's attorney, Samuel Burstyn, reminded the judge that he has yet to rule on motions calling for separate trials for del Cid and several other co-defendants. Outside the courtroom, Noriega attorneys Steven Kollin and Frank Rubino, refused to comment when asked whether they would be ready to conduct their client's defense in court by the first week in March. ``Sam wants to try his case,'' was Rubino's only comment. Del Cid, 46, has pleaded innocent to charges of collecting bribe money and acting as a liaison between Noriega and drug traffickers who allegedly used Panama as a conduit for drug shipments to the United States. He faces 70 years in prison and $550,000 in fines if convicted on all counts. Also Wednesday, another Panamanian co-defendant named along with Noriega in a federal indictment in Tampa surrendered to FBI agents in Panama and was extradited to the United States. Enrique Pretelt, 47, charged with trying to smuggle more than 1 million pounds of marijuana to the United States, was being held in Florida on Wednesday night and was scheduled to make an apperance in a Tampa courtroom Thursday, said Justice Department spokesman Michael W. Robinson in Washington. During Wednesday's bond hearing in Miami, Burstyn read Noriega's statement on del Cid, who surrendered and was taken into custody on drug charges after the U.S. invasion of Panama last month. Burstyn said prosecutors, who have called del Cid ``one of Noriega's right-hand men,'' were using his supposed status as an intelligence director to argue he should not be given bond. Burstyn told the judge that prosecutors had erred, and pulled out Noriega's statement. ``At no time was Lt. Col. del Cid the head of G-2 or intelligence. At no time was he my personal secretary or attache,'' the document read in part. Previously, Burstyn has pointed to what he calls discrepancies in the February 1988 indictment against Noriega and del Cid, saying they undercut the reliability of the witnesses responsible for much of the evidence considered by the grand jury. Rubino said both he and Kollin were present when the statement was taken in a courthouse jail cell. Later Wednesday, Hoeveler delayed his ruling on del Cid's bond for a second time, giving defense attorneys 10 days to respond to evidence raised Tuesday by Assistant U.S. Attorney Myles Malman. Hoeveler set no date to recovene the hearing, and del Cid remained jailed at the federal Metropolitan Correctional center south of Miami without bond.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Says States May Tax Merchandise Sold by TV Preachers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines a0730 and a0786 and fixes writethru sequence; picks up 6th graf a0730: Other states...
DOC.TEXT: Religious items sold by television evangelists through the mail or at crusade appearances may be taxed by states just like any other merchandise, the Supreme Court ruled Wednesday. The court said such taxes do not violate religious freedom, and unanimously upheld lower court rulings that forced the Louisiana-based Jimmy Swaggart Ministries to pay $183,000 in back taxes to California. ``Now we have the real threat of intrustion of government into the religious ministry of churches and synagogues,'' Swaggart said in Baton Rouge, reading from a prepared statement a few hours after the ruling. ``The immediate impact of this decision on Jimmy Swaggart Ministries will not be disastrous because we have been in this battle for 10 years and have prepared for the consequences,'' Swaggart said. ``Most churches probably have not prepared for it.'' Most states tax the proceeds of at least some mail order sales to their residents, but California and Virginia appear to be the only states that do not exempt religious organizations. Other states searching for additional tax revenues now could follow California's lead. ``California's non-discriminatory sales and use tax law ... imposes no constitutionally significant burden on (Swaggart's) religious practices or beliefs,'' Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote for the court. The tax at issue was imposed on the sales of religious books, tapes and other merchandise sold by Swaggart's organization from 1974 through 1981. Swaggart did not challenge California's taxing T-shirts, mugs, bowls and crown-of-thorns replicas sold by his ministry. Mail-order sales from Swaggart's base in Baton Rouge, La., to California consumers during those years totaled $1.7 million. Sales of merchandise at California crusades totaled $240,000. Swaggart's challenge of the tax had been supported by an array of religious groups _ from Hare Krishnas to mainline Protestants. Lawyers for the National Council of Churches, representing most Protestant denominations, called the California tax ``a serious threat ... a tax on the dissemination of religious messages, and thus a forbidden tax on the exercise of religion.'' Backing California's authority to impose such a tax were two organizations not usually allied in court _ the American Civil Liberties Union and the National Conference of State Legislatures. Swaggart's lawyers had relied heavily on a 1943 high court ruling that overturned the convictions of Jehovah's Witnesses who violated a city ordinance requiring all people engaged in door-to-door canvassing to get licenses and pay fees. The Jehovah's Witnesses were distributing religious literature, and the 1943 ruling said, ``This form of religious activity occupies the same high estate under the First Amendment as do worship in the churches and preaching from the pulpits.'' But Wednesday's decision drew a distinction between those fees and the California tax. ``Our concern (in the 1943 ruling) that a flat license tax would act as a precondition to the free exercise of religious beliefs is simply not present where a tax applies to all sales and uses of tangible personal property in the state,'' O'Connor wrote. The justices also rejected Swaggart's argument that the tax fosters a constitutionally impermissible ``excessive entanglement'' between church and state. Under a 1967 Supreme Court ruling, mail order businesses are exempt from a state's taxes if they do no more than ship orders there. But they can be taxed by that state if they have stores, outlets or certain other business contacts there. The justices, citing a procedural flaw, did not rule on Swaggart's arguments that the 1967 ruling should shield his organization from the California tax. Swaggart is free to raise that argument if he challenges his California tax bill for any other year than the eight covered by Wednesday's ruling. In two other unanimous decisions, the court: _Ruled that a New Jersey corporation accused by a competitor of bribing Nigerian government officials to win a contract in that country may be sued in U.S. courts. _Said a Denver union official convicted of embezzling may not be forced to repay the union from his own pension benefits.

DOC.HEAD: China Hardens Line Again Toward Hong Kong
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new material, details. CLARIFY that Lu Ping was referring to civil servants in some comments on restrictions. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: China on Wednesday further hardened its line toward Hong Kong by deciding that top officials in the post-1997 government could not possess the right to live abroad, Hong Kong government radio said. A top Chinese official also announced that Hong Kong civil servants with British passports would not be allowed to seek British consular protection while in the territory after it returns to Chinese rule in seven years. Local newspapers quoted Lu Ping, deputy secretary-general of the Basic Law Drafting Committee, which is writing Hong Kong's post-1997 blueprint, as saying civil servants would not be allowed to renounce their Chinese citizenship. In London, the British Foreign Office said it was ``seeking clarification'' of the announcement. The announcements threw into doubt a British plan to offer passports to 50,000 key Hong Kong professionals and officials, including civil servants. The passports were being offered as a security net for Hong Kong residents. Confidence in China's promise to retain Hong Kong's free-wheeling economic system for 50 years evaporated after the bloody June 4 crackdown on a movement for democracy in Beijing. The moves marked new restrictions on the territory's future political system. Last month, China outlawed ``subversive groups'' from operating in the territory after 1997. The Basic Law Drafting Committee decided in Canton that the territory's chief executive, its principal officers and all its executive councilors could not possess the right of abode in another country. Government radio said the committee still must decide whether to ban the territory's two top judges and all its legislators from possessing the right to live abroad. Under the Basic Law, Hong Kong's top officials are already prohibited from holding a foreign passport. The move by the committee thus marked a further restriction on politicians' activities, prohibiting them from holding, for example, a U.S. ``green'' card or a residence permit for Canada or Britain. Britain has said it hopes the passport package will boost confidence by encouraging key residents to stay in the territory by giving them a last resort. But China says the package violates the 1984 agreement under which Britain will hand the colony back to China. Lu said the British Consulate in Hong Kong would be prohibited from helping Hong Kong civil servants with British passports after 1997. He said that without the right of abode in Britain, Hong Kong's people would settle in Hong Kong. ``Now you, Britain, grant them right of abode, so just in case they commit corruption offenses or get into trouble, they can flee Hong Kong,'' Lu said. Lu's statement directly contradicted assurances made Tuesday by British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, who said all Hong Kong residents with British passports would be granted consular protection. China does not recognize dual nationals. The committee is expected to finish drafting the Basic Law in four days. Then it will go to China's parliament, the National People's Congress, for a largely ceremonial vote in March. Still to be decided are questions concerning the percentage of Hong Kong's 60 legislators to be directly elected after the 1997 transfer of power. China has said the maximum will be around 30 percent but Hong Kong politicians want at least 50 percent to be voted in. Currently, no legislators are directly elected.

One of the world's largest banks pleaded guilty in a $32 million cocaine money-laundering case, but critics call the plea bargain a ``slap on the wrist'' that won't discourage such illicit banking practices. The focus of the case now shifts to evidence that may link one of the bank's top officials to ousted Panamania dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. As part of Tuesday's plea, Luxembourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International (BCCI) must forfeit a record $14 million in assets frozen by the U.S. government. It also must cooperate against other defendants _ including one of its bankers who once claimed to be Noriega's personal banker. Amjad Awan, a former Latin American assistant division director for BCCI, told a U.S. Senate panel in 1988 he managed Noriega's secret accounts at the bank's Panama branch that held up to $23 million.

President Bush is offering sneak previews of his maiden State of the Union address in speeches and appearances around the country that seek to highlight his agenda for ``a world at peace.'' Bush has been laying down the basic themes that aides say he will sound in the annual presidential speech to a joint House-Senate session on the evening of Jan. 31. He highlighted key domestic priorities _ strengthening the Clean Air Act, a lower capital gains tax, the war on drugs and crime, education and an overhaul of farm programs _ in a kickoff speech last week to the American Farm Bureau in Orlando, Fla. A few days later, Bush's address to the Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce laid down his basic defense position: he would not ``naively cut the muscle out of our defense posture'' despite a relaxation of tensions in Eastern Europe.

Amid a veil of secrecy surrounding his House ethics committee investigation, Rep. Barney Frank is putting out word that he is confident his public career can survive intact. No information is expected from the committee on its probe of Frank's involvement with a male prostitute until at least Jan. 23, when Congress returns from its holiday break. There may be more fuel added when Penthouse magazine publishes an interview next month with prostitute Stephen Gobie, who had a relationship with Frank. In the meantime, Frank, D-Mass., has kept up his work pace on Capitol Hill. Frank has led a Democratic move to cut defense spending and shift the funds into deficit reduction and domestic programs. President Bush singled Frank out at a recent bill-signing ceremony for his work on housing legislation. ``If you're being complimented by the president you must be doing something right,'' said Rep. Joseph Moakley, D-Mass.

For a metropolis that normally hums along like a well-tuned engine, a few inches of unaccustomed snow had Tokyo sputtering. Fast became slow. Safe became slippery. The international airport closed for two hours. Bullet trains performed like popguns. You couldn't set your watch according to the normally tick-tock commuter trains Tuesday _ they were running late. Snowball fights were still in progress in schoolyards this morning as the city of 12 million, chilled by almost-freezing temperatures and with a light blanket of snow glistening in the sun, approached normal speed after a day on tiptoes. Tokyo, on Japan's Pacific coast and 3 degrees latitude south of Washington, D.C., often has a snowless winter. Skiers who equip their cars with chains for the mountains are among the few Tokyoites ready to venture out in the snow.

DOC.TEXT: The pension board of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America has spurned church orders to divest from firms doing business in South Africa. But the denomination's interim policy group, the church council, is examining ``possible options'' for dealing with the board's refusal to comply with an action last August by the denomination's assembly. It had ordered the pension board to get rid of holdings by September 1991, in all companies with direct or indirect business in South Africa as a protest to its apartheid system of racial separation. The pension board in October asked that the assembly action not be implemented, saying it would jeopardize income, break trust with pension members and make the board liable for damages. A report on possible courses of action comes before the church council at its April meeting.

Roman Catholic leaders are to conduct their annual ``national prayer vigil for life'' here Jan. 21-22, marking the anniversary of the 1973 Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. At the same time, the Office for Pro-Life Activities of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops distributed materials stressing that opposing abortion was part of a consistent ethic of life. ``The consistent ethic sustains us in our efforts on behalf of the unborn and on behalf of all whose lives are threatend or diminished,'' said ther Rev. John W. Gouldrick, director of the pro-life office.

Two Chinese students told News Network International that since China's brutal crackdown last June on a pro-democracy movement, students have been converting to Christianity virtually ``by the dorm.'' The ``rate at which students turn to Christ is literally a dormitory at a time,'' the students were quoted by the religious rights network. ``Some departments within certain colleges have changed their whole atmosphere because so many have become Christians.''

Several public television stations and the interfaith network, VISN, will be part of a worldwide telecast this Saturday and Sunday of an international conference in Moscow of religious and parliamentary leaders on protecting the environment.

The Lilly Endowment has passed out another batch of grants totalling $791,000 to strengthen governing boards at 40 North American seminaries. Fred Hofheinz, Endowment program director for religion, said: ``We act on the conviction that strong religious leaders and scholars emerge from strong seminaries, and the vitality of seminaries depends in great measure on the performance of the trustees who govern them.'' Similar grants were made earlier to another 75 seminaries.

After meetings with Soviet officials in Moscow, leaders of B'nai B'rith, said it plans to establish nine provisional units of the Jewish service organization in that many cities across the Soviet Union.

A United Methodist bishop says congregations in that big but shrinking denomination are not evangelizing as much as they should be held accountable for it. Bishop George Bashore of western Pennsylvania told a recent denominational congress on evangelism: `We are developing processes for the evaluation of clergy throughout our denomination, but I believe we are much more cavalier in calling our congregations to accountability for what they are doing.'' The United Methodist Church has 8.9 million members, making it the nation's second largest Protestant denomination, but the membership has declined steadily for 25 years from an all-time high of 11 million in 1965. Bashore said, ``We need to redirect resources from places that aren't taking off to churches that will take off in the name of Jesus Christ.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Issue a Loser for Republicans
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: When Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater and his strategy team look at the abortion issue, they see a loser. So they are urging GOP candidates to deal with it early in the campaign year and try to put the subject to rest. They figure that in 1990 state or congressional campaigns in which abortion becomes the dominant issue in the final weeks before the Nov. 6 elections, Republican candidates who campaign against abortion rights probably will be defeated. That's an ironic judgment in a party pledged by platform to oppose abortion, and led by a president who enforced his own opposition with three vetoes late last year. Despite those positions, President Bush and Atwater both maintain there is plenty of Republican room for abortion rights advocates. Those crosscurrents are likely to come up at Republican National Committee meetings today and Friday, with anti-abortion Republicans pressing to put the party out front on their issue. The numbers would indicate there is more mileage in Atwater's pragmatic approach to the abortion issue. The abortion rights argument clearly worked to Democratic advantage in the handful of 1989 elections, notably in the election of Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder. This year, with the House, 34 Senate seats and 36 governorships to be filled, the GOP problem could worsen. Pollsters Peter Hart, a Democrat, and Robert Teeter, a Bush Republican, see the issue as one that could offer an important opening to the Democrats in 1990. In a poll they conducted for NBC News and the Wall Street Journal, voters said they would prefer abortion rights candidates by a margin of nearly two to one. That survey, conducted in November, showed that in a contest between a candidate favoring women's right to an abortion and a candidate who wanted to ban most abortions, 48 percent would be more likely to vote for the pro-choice candidate. Twenty-five percent said they would more likely vote for the anti-abortion candidate. The rest said they would base the choice on other issues, or weren't sure. People who identified themselves as Republicans leaned that way, 39 percent to 33 percent. Asked which party could better deal with the abortion issue, voters said Democrats, 29 percent to 21 percent. Bush used vetoes to block two appropriations bills that would have provided government funds to pay for abortions for poor women pregnant because of rape or incest; the poll indicated that voters disagree. It showed 75 percent favored public funding of such abortions, 20 percent opposed. Atwater says he is advising candidates to be clear, concise and quick in spelling out their abortion views. Having done so, he says, they should stand firm on that position and move on to other issues. ``So I tell candidates `Stake your position out loudly and clearly. Don't back off.' And the second piece of advice I'm giving them is `You define your position. Don't let your opponent define your position for you.''' Atwater and other party leaders maintain that the voters will accept differences and vote for a candidate anyhow, on other issues, but that they don't like politicians who waffle or shift sides. Perhaps. But thre's a lot of shuffling and shifting going on among politicians in both parties as the campaign year begins. And the issue is not likely to be pushed off, or even down the agenda by candidate efforts to get it out of the way early. It is too emotional, and it has been recharged by the 1989 Supreme Court decision empowering states to impose some restrictions on abortion. In most states, legislatures are meeting for the first time since that ruling. All of that points to an escalating debate in the 1990 campaign. That is not promising for a GOP effort to settle the issue early and put it aside.

DOC.HEAD: Recession, Inflation, Stagflation?
DOC.TEXT: Which statement best describes the state of the economy? (a) We're in a recession; (b) Inflation remains a serious threat; (c) ``Stagflation'' is here; (d) All of the above. The answer depends on where you live or work, many experts maintain. ``It's a very difficult economy to analyze,'' says Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. in New York. ``Whether you're in a recession or have to worry about inflation has to do with a lot of different things.'' He points out, for example, that the manufacturing sector, which includes the nation's automakers, easily could be described as suffering a recession, or a period of declining business activity. The financial services and defense industries also appear to be in trouble. The service sector, on the other hand, continues to show growth. Energy production and agriculture have picked up, too, but housing remains a toss-up from region to region, Kellner says. Where does this leave the average person trying to decide how to invest or borrow? A bit confused. Investment advisers urge consumers to ignore every little economic blip and focus on long-term goals. ``Too many investors in America are looking at the one- or two-year window. They need to look at the five- to 15-year potential for growth,'' says Denver money manager Scott L. Shires. ``If you can work your way through the soothsayers, you'll do well in blue-chips (stocks) and quality residential property.'' Robert K. Heady, publisher of Bank Rate Monitor, a North Palm, Beach, Fla., publication that tracks interest rates among banks and thrifts, agrees: ``Each time an economic number comes out it's the heart attack of the hour.'' For instance, recent worries about inflation, due partly to reports showing a jump in food and energy prices, have pushed up interest rates in the bond market _ even as consumers and business were digesting a Jan. 8 drop in the prime lending rate. The inflation news helped to temporarily lift some consumer mortgage rates. The rates had been on the decline amid concerns the nation might be falling into a recession. The Federal Reserve had been loosening credit policies to prevent that from happening. Economists say both conditions, when combined, produce ``stagflation,'' a period when prices continue to rise even as the economy weakens. ``Some newspapers have used recession, inflation and stagflation in their headlines _ all in the same week,'' complains Heady. For the short-term investor, money market accounts are probably the safest bet these days, investment advisers say. Even though interest rates have been declining since last spring because of an overall economic downturn, rates on these accounts have fallen the least among savings vehicles. ``The banks are trying to attract volatile money in a period where people are unsure of where interest rates are going,'' Heady says. The average yield on a money market account last week was 6.33 percent, down only 0.29 percentage point from April 26, Bank Rate Monitor says. Rates on bank certificates of deposits fell about 1.5 percentage points during the same period. The average rate on a one-year CD was 7.93 percent last week, down from 9.51 percent in April, while the rate on a five-year CD fell 1.29 percentage points to 7.91 percent. Investment advisers say those considering a CD might do better locking in a rate now than waiting, since most economists expect rates to continue dropping for awhile. Heady says he expects CD rates to drop between 0.30 and 0.40 percent point in the next eight weeks alone, in continued response to the Jan. 8 prime rate cut to 10 percent from 10.5 percent. The prime was also cut a half percentage point in July. For borrowers, rates haven't fallen as much as those on savings accounts. New car bank loans fell only 0.42 percent to 12.12 percent from the end of April to last week, and Heady expects the decline in response to the prime-rate cut will be between 0.10 to 0.15 percentage point in the next eight weeks. Personal loan rates actually rose, to an average 17.16 percent from 16.99 percent, as did rates on credit cards, to 18.65 percent from 18.09 percent, Bank Rate Monitor says. While mortgage rates have remained below 10 percent for several months, some analysts predict they could rise this spring as the home-buying season comes into full swing. The average rate on a 30-year conventional mortgage was 9.90 percent last week, down 0.02 percentage point from the previous week, says HSH Associates, a Butler, N.J., publication that tracks mortgage rates.

DOC.HEAD: After 50 Years in Exile, Albanian King Still Dreams of Going Home
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: By GREG MYRE
DOC.TEXT: From a rustic suburban house with a yard full of overgrown weeds, five dogs and a rusting pickup truck, the man who would be king of Albania plots a return to the homeland he scarcely knows. King Leka I, an exile for all of his 50 years, believes the rapid political reforms in Eastern Europe will light a fire in long-isolated Albania, the last hard-line Stalinist state in the region. If a revolution comes, Leka said in an interview, he would be proud to follow the footsteps of his father, the self-made monarch King Zog I. If the people don't want a king, he'd settle for the chance to return to the country he left in 1939, when he was 3 days old, to escape invading Italian troops during World War II. ``My only home is Albania,'' said Leka, who has lived in seven countries and speaks eight languages. ``But I've learned to feel at home wherever I have my family and my dogs.'' He's 6-feet-8-inches tall, with glasses and a full head of graying hair. For a meeting at his home, he wears a pistol and a combat knife in his holster, and his military-style shirt has an Albanian crest pinned on his collar. Leka, in a statement issued in December, called on Albanians inside and outside the country to ``rise up, acting in unity and cohesion against the tyrannical and atheist regime that has for so long misruled our beloved homeland.'' He said the message has been broadcast to Albania from radio stations in Yugoslavia's adjacent Kosovo region, and also has been reported on Radio Moscow and the Voice of America. Albania's Communist Party chief, Ramiz Alia, says he will resist reforms in the rigidly controlled nation, the poorest and most rural in Europe. The country has been largely cut off from the outside world since the Communists came to power in 1946 under Enver Hoxha, who ruled until his death in 1985. The Communist Party daily newspaper, Zeri I Populit, recently accused Albanian exiles of trying to foment an uprising that would bring Leka to power. Yugoslav newspapers have published reports of unrest in Albania, which have not been confirmed and which the Albanian government has denied. Leka said that more than four decades of repressive rule will make it difficult to mobilize opposition forces. But he and his supporters have offices in France and elsewhere in Europe, and maintain clandestine contacts with government and military figures disgruntled with the Communist leadership, he said. Because Albania is such a closed society, no accurate measure of Leka's support within the country can be made. But he believes he could serve as a unifying force among Albanians opposed to Communist rule and is confident of his stature despite his family's long absence. But for now, Leka can do little more than wait. Leka and his Australian-born wife, Susan, left Spain in 1979 when communist states put pressure on the Madrid government. Leka claims the communist governments acted on behalf of Albania because he had been building strong support inside and outside his homeland. A year later, the couple rented a ranch-style house at the end of a dirt road here in the far northern suburbs of Johannesburg, intending to stay only six months. During his exile, Leka's backers have included the late President Anwar Sadat of Egypt, the late Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi of Iran, Saudi Arabia's King Faisal and Belgium's King Baudouin. He honored their support in naming his 8-year-old son, the crown prince, Leka Anwar Zog Reza Baudouin. He has used his contacts to support himself as a businessman, exporting minerals and heavy machinery to the Middle and Far East. He also travels extensively to maintain contacts with the estimated 3 million ethnic Albanians who live outside the country's borders, a number almost equal to those inside. ``It has been difficult to wear several different hats _ to try to be a businessman and lead a normal family life and to head an opposition movement,'' said Leka. Leka's father, the head of an Albanian clan, became Albania's prime minister in 1922 when he was still in his 20s. In 1928, the National Assembly gave him a title that translated into ``prince,'' according to Burke's Royal Families of London. However, Zog proclaimed himself ``His Majesty King Zog I,'' and the constitution called for his son to succeed him. Zog died in France in 1961, and Leka was sworn in by the government-in-exile. ``I am the king in exile, and I believe one day I will return,'' said Leka.
