DOC.HEAD: Soviet Dissident Writer Speaks on Empire's Decline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tuesday in 6th graf is Jan. 23.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Soviet dissident Natan Sharansky languished nine years in the gulags for speaking his mind. Now he's getting paid to talk. Jailed in 1977 on charges of spying after speaking out on human rights and easier emigration for Soviet Jews, Sharansky focuses on the crumbling of communism and the decline of the Soviet empire in a U.S. lecture tour. But rather than lionizing Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev as a champion of democracy, Sharansky credits comrades who were imprisoned for their beliefs. ``If the dissidents didn't struggle 20 years ago, we could never celebrate what we're celebrating now. The dissidents and their supporters in the West are the midwives of glasnost and perestroika,'' the 41-year-old author said in an interview. ``Millions of people are freely expressing their beliefs. There is such a hole in this iron wall that nobody can ever rebuild it again. There is no question communist ideology has failed.'' Sharansky recounted the horrors of Soviet prisons in his 1988 book, ``Fear No Evil,'' published by Random House. He plans about 10 paid lectures a year to talk about Soviet restructuring under a contract with the Harry Walker Agency of New York, a speakers bureau. He launched the tour on Jan. 16 at the University of California at Davis, and made stops in Santa Barbara, Calif., and Toronto. He is to appear in New Orleans on Tuesday. Other cities on the tour will be announced later in the year. For Sharansky, the breakdown of the old order in the Soviet bloc was the most exciting moment since his release from prison after nine years of a 13-year sentence for spying, a charge that he and the United States have denied. ``We dissidents had such deep beliefs in our hearts that sooner or later this system had to become bankrupt, morally, socially, economically and politically. Nobody could expect it to go so quickly,'' he said. ``Gorbachev is a loyal communist. His aim was to save the communist system by changing it. He deserves credit for one thing: He was the first Soviet leader to say that communism would lose to capitalism if urgent changes weren't made in the economy. ``He had to decide between saving the economy or saving the empire. There is no way to save both of them. He let Eastern Europe go its own way, but I don't think he had a choice.'' Sharansky also noted: ``There are dissidents still in Soviet prisons who were jailed for saying the same things as Gorbachev.'' Now living in Israel with his wife and two daughters, Sharansky is amazed at the speed of change, a stark contrast to the tedious days in prisons when he played mental games of chess or sang Hebrew songs on the cold concrete floor of his punishment cell. ``I told my wife that by the time our youngest daughter grew one tooth, two more dictators in Eastern Europe had fallen down,'' said Sharansky, looking relaxed in a sweater and open-collared blue shirt. Sharansky asked to leave the Soviet Union in 1974. He was detained, although his wife, Avital, was allowed to leave a day after they were married. She worked tirelessly for his release after he was sentenced to prison camps, even meeting with President Reagan to plead her husband's case. Reagan and Gorbachev arranged for his release at a summit meeting, and Sharansky passed to freedom in a prisoner exchange on a frozen Feb. 11, 1986. He crossed Glienicke Bridge through a section of the Berlin Wall. And he rejoiced when the wall opened last November. ``The events of the last year were the realization of our wildest dreams,'' he said. ``For me, the wall opened for a moment and then it closed. Now, it's falling apart.'' He was a comrade of Soviet dissident and Nobel Prize-winning physicist Andrei Sakharov, but was denied permission to visit the Soviet Union for Sakharov's funeral in December. Sharansky, who has a street marker near the United Nations named after him, now works for immigrant absorption in Israel. He dropped his Soviet name, Anatoly, to use his Hebrew name, Natan, in 1986. As chairman of the Soviet Jewry Zionist Forum, he helps Soviet Jews find housing and jobs. In December, his group received a $20 million gift from a billionaire American banker to assist in resettlement. ``We are seeing the biggest exodus of Jews in modern history. They are afraid to stay in the Soviet Union because of anti-Semitism. It's absolutely inevitable this exodus will continue,'' Sharansky said. ``There is practically no place for Jews in the Soviet Union in the future.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Jan. 22

DOC.SECOND: AM-AP Arts: Soviet Rock Opera, Adv 23,1189
DOC.NOTE: $adv23
For Release Tuesday AMs, Jan. 23, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Soviet Rock Opera Reflects Changing Times
DOC.TEXT: ``Junon and Avos,'' the first Soviet rock opera, has come to New York with the original cast and new optimism. In the concluding scene, the narrator tells the audience that the opera's Russian hero and his Californian lover tried to bridge the distance between the two countries with love. The entire cast of 60 then sings ``Hallelujah'' with such abandon that the plot's tragic finish is all but forgotten. ``Eight years ago, when we sang `Hallelujah' about a Soviet-American love affair, it was virtually an act of sedition,'' Yelena Shanina, the lead female singer, recalls of the early days of the production. ``Now, it's celebrating a new beginning.'' Even the name of the opera has changed with the times. To the orginial title, ``Junon and Avos,'' producers Lucy Jarvis and Pierre Cardin have attached a subtitle: ``The Hope.'' Whether the good feelings and exotic music will succeed in filling New York's City Center Theater for a five-week run is still uncertain. A spokesman said ticket sales were slow before the Jan. 5 opening but have picked up since the first reviews _ favorable though not ecstatic _ appeared. Regardless of whether the $2 million production is a commercial success, its arrival represents the culmination of an extraordinary political journey. When it somehow squeaked past the censors in 1981, the opera caused a sensation in Moscow. Though set in 1806, it contained a thinly disguised caricature of Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev as a doddering old man with a chest full of medals and a gold mask with huge eyebrows. That, alone, might have ensured a throng of Soviet theatergoers. But Andrei Vosnesensky, a leading Soviet poet, added two other politically daring elements in his libretto. One was a reverent treatment of religious symbols, including words from the Russian Orthodox mass. The other was an implied message that the Soviet Union shared the blame for an impasse in relations with the United States. That message was expressed through the story of Count Nikolai Rezanov, who courageously sails off to explore trading links with California _ then a Spanish colony _ and falls in love with the governor's daughter. ``Junon and Avos,'' named for Rezanov's two ships, ends in tragedy as politics and illness foil Rezanov's mission and separate him from his lover, the beautiful Conchita. She waits 35 years for his return, then enters a convent when she learns he died before obtaining the czar's permission to marry her. Vosnesensky says the plot is loosely based on historical truth. There was, indeed, a Count Rezanov who helped found the Russian-American Trading Co., traveled to California in 1806 and died in Siberia on his way home. But the rest of the story is pure fiction. Vosnesensky now acknowledges that he conceived it, following the outline of his earlier poem, ``Avos,'' as a metaphor for the strained Soviet-American relations of the Brezhnev era. ``My hero, historical Count Rezanov, was not a great fighter for freedom. But I have put in his mouth all the words of our intellectuals,'' Vosnesensky said in an interview. ``When he says `The Russian empire is a prison,' our audiences understood what I was saying. Now it's OK just to say it. But in 1981 it wasn't OK. So I put the words in Rezanov's mouth, and it worked.'' It didn't work right away, however. Vosnesensky and director Marc Zakharov repeatedly modified the opera in an effort to gain permission for it to open at Moscow's Lenin Komsomol Theater. After the authorities had rebuffed them for the second or third time, Vosnesensky recalls, he began to despair. ``I was worried, but Zakharov said to me, `There is one more person I know who can help us.' So I didn't ask questions. I got in his car, we went to the main cathedral of Moscow, and we lit candles to the Virgin Mary. ``I don't know whether maybe Zakharov called someone else that night. But the next morning, `Junon and Avos' was allowed.'' Timothy Ryback, a Harvard University researcher who has written a book about rock 'n' roll in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, says that despite official condemnation, rock music had developed a huge following in Russia by the end of the 1960s. Nevertheless, ``Junon and Avos'' is believed to have been the first full rock opera to receive a public staging in the Soviet Union. Cardin, the French fashion designer who has set up clothing factories in the Soviet Union, heard about the show and asked to see it while on a three-day business trip to Moscow in 1982. It was not playing that weekend, and the Komsomol Theater was busy with another show. So the Ministry of Culture, eager to please the famous designer and perhaps secure business links with his fashion empire, moved the entire set and company to a vacant theater 25 miles outside Moscow. There, the ministry staged a command performance on little more than a day's notice, much to Cardin's embarassment, he said. Enraptured by the music _ an eclectic mix of folk melodies, thumping electric guitars and Gregorian chants arranged by contemporary composer Alexei Ribnikov _ Cardin decided on the spot to try to bring the show to his Paris theater, Espace Cardin. Soviet cultural officials tried to persuade him to take the Bolshoi Ballet or the Moscow Circus instead, but he held firm and eventually got his wish after appealing to Brezhnev's successor, Yuri Andropov. ``I say I want to make something young, for the young people,'' Cardin recalled. ``I tell them the Bolshoi, that is from before the Revolution.'' Then, just a few days before the show's Paris opening in September 1983, a Soviet fighter pilot shot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007, with 269 people aboard, after it apparently strayed into Soviet air space over the Sea of Japan. Suddenly, Cardin began to worry about bombings and security. ``My friends say to me, `Pierre, you cannot do this (opera) now, because if you do that, your theater _ poof _ bomb. People were so mad. But I say I make this only for talent, for respect for the Russia. I am not a politician,'' Cardin said. Although the Paris production went off without a hitch, Cardin hesitated bringing ``Junon and Avos'' to the United States until superpower relations began to improve under Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. The arrangements in New York were made by Jarvis, a New York television and theatrical producer who took the Broadway musical ``Sophisticated Ladies'' on a seven-week tour of the Soviet Union in 1988. She and Cardin say the production might travel to San Francisco and Japan. ``I am not a politician,'' said Cardin. ``But maybe with art, you can build something stronger than with politics.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, Jan. 23

DOC.TEXT: Business sales and inventories both rose in November but economists noted that slower sales the following month could worsen the December situation. The Commerce Department said Tuesday that inventories rose 0.5 percent to a seasonally adjusted $796.8 billion in November after rising 0.3 percent a month earlier. The November figure was slightly higher than the 0.4 percent increase originally reported. Business sales were up 0.7 percent to a seasonally adjusted $523.6 billion, after falling a revised 0.5 percent in October. That revision compared with the initially reported 0.7 percent drop.

U.S.-made car and truck sales rose 27 percent in early January, giving an upbeat start to a year analysts predict will be sluggish. The eight automakers said Tuesday they sold cars and light trucks at a daily rate of 32,539 during the Jan. 1-10 period this year, compared with a 25,629-a-day pace during the same time in 1989. Car sales rose 29.8 percent in early January, compared with the year-earlier period. Truck sales rose 22.8 percent.

Bankruptcy court filings show that banks and Wall Street firms that invested in Campeau Corp.'s expansion into American retailing are among 50,750 creditors who are owed billions of dollars. The filings by Campeau divisions Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., released Tuesday, list $9.1 billion in total assets and $7.7 billion in total liabilities. Toronto-based Campeau, which bought Federated and Allied with billions of dollars in borrowed money in the late 1980s, placed them under bankruptcy court protection Monday because of the crushing debt burden.

Refiners boosted their profit margins by 46 cents a gallon and local retailers added 9 cents to their margins at the peak of last month's heating oil crunch, the Energy Department reported. The increases in margins, which are the difference between buying and selling prices without regard to other costs that determine actual profits, were disclosed Tuesday as part of a Senate committee hearing into an average 54 percent runup in home heating oil prices in New England in December. The figures are the first government data indicating that both producers and local heating oil dealers, among others, took advantage of the worst December cold snap in 70 years to boost profits.

AT&T has blamed its largest service outage ever on a computer glitch in a new system designed to bolster its long-distance network, and moved quickly to make amends with customers. More than half of the calls placed on American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s nationwide network during the trouble Monday did not go through, the company said Tuesday. AT&T said it traced the glitch to a computer in New York City that helps direct calls through the vast telephone network. Officials said it was not caused by a computer virus or sabotage.

The Supreme Court, in one of two suits arising from strikes against airlines, has refused to allow a machinists union walkout at Eastern Airlines spread to commuter railroads. The court Tuesday also refused to revive a suit brought by Trans World Airlines flight attendants, who accused TWA owner Carl Icahn of sex bias in seeking wage cuts and other concessions that triggered a 1986 strike.

Several U.S. airlines are raising air fares to offset jet fuel costs, following a move taken earlier by American Airlines and marking the second such hike in two weeks by major carriers. USAir and Northwest Airlines said Tuesday they planned to increase by 10 percent selected one-way discount fares often used by business travelers. American, which announced plans Monday for a 10 percent hike on similar fares, also plans to add a $6 one-way fuel surcharge effective Feb. 9 on all tickets.

Five big banks have reported sharply mixed results for the 1989 fourth quarter and year, reflecting strength in their corporate and consumer finance businesses and weakness caused by shaky real estate loans and Third World debt. Severe quarterly declines were reported Tuesday by Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover Corp., and Mellon Bank Corp., while Security Pacific Corp. and Wells Fargo & Co. reported big earnings increases. New York-based Citicorp, the nation's biggest banking company, said it lost $784 million or $2.52 a share in the quarter ended Dec. 31, vs. earnings of $747 million or $2.19 a share a year earlier.

Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., which owns 49.6 percent of Subaru of America Inc.'s outstanding shares, has proposed to buy the remaining common for $147 million. Fuji Heavy said Monday it would pay $6 per share for the remaining stock. At $6 a share, Subaru of America's 48.5 million outstanding shares of common stock are worth about $291 million.

The stock market pulled out of its recent slide Tuesday with an afternoon rally spearheaded by blue-chip issues. The Dow Jones industrial average, down 91.30 points in the two previous sessions, rebounded 23.25 to 2,692.62. The dollar was mixed in lackluster trading. Bond prices fell. Orange juice futures prices rose sharply; soybean futures fell sharply; energy futures were broadly mixed; precious metals slipped; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Securities Group Agrees To Study Single System
DOC.TEXT: Faced with complaints that arbitration is biased against small investors, Wall Street officials have agreed to consider establishing a unified system to resolve disputes between stockbrokers and their customers. The proposal, made by the Securities Industry Association, would remove arbitration from control of the nation's stock exchanges and other self-regulatory organizations to a single industrywide body. ``I don't think it would be detrimental to take a look at whether it could be feasible,'' said John Katovich, general counsel of the Pacific Stock Exchange. ``We're certainly aware of some of the criticisms that have been made of the system.'' Arbitration has come under increased scrutiny following a Supreme Court decision last May upholding the constitutionality of contracts requiring brokerage customers to settle disputes in arbitration rather than in court. Plaintiffs' lawyers claim the current system is biased against investors because it is run by the stock exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealers, and because arbitration panels contain at least one industry representative. Meeting Tuesday in San Francisco, the Securities Industry Conference on Arbitration endorsed studying the plan to set up a unified arbitration system or any other alternative to the current structure. The group said the study should focus on the costs of arbitration, funding, legal status and government oversight of any program, Katovich said. Katovich said the study likely would be conducted by the Securities Industry Association, whose president, Edward I. O'Brien, initially made the proposal last month. No timetable for the study was set. Arbitration panels typically are composed of two independent arbitrators and one from the securities industry. Unlike litigation, arbitration is not governed by complex rules of evidence and panels make their decisions based on the facts presented. Proponents say arbitration is quicker and faster than litigation and investors do just as well as they would in recovering losses in court. Opponents say the process is skewed in favor of the industry and investors' appeal rights are limited. ``There's a reluctance in industry people to do anything that is going to cause them to be criticized by anyone else in the industry,'' said William F. Davis, a Los Angeles lawyer who handles arbitration cases. ``The exchanges, though they are public, are basically composed of people in the industry,'' he said. ``There's a built-in bias there.'' With several major court rulings and the stock market's 1987 crash, the number of arbitration cases soared in the 1980s. A total of 6,100 cases were filed in 1988 compared with just 830 in 1980. Investors won 48 percent of the 1,561 cases decided in 1988. In an independent study of about 100 cases decided in a three-month period last year, plaintiffs recovered about half of their total alleged losses. The NASD and the New York Stock Exchange handle more than 90 percent of the cases. The American Stock Exchange, Boston Stock Exchange, Chicago Board Options Exchange, Midwest Stock Exchange, Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, Pacific Stock Exchange and Philadelphia Stock Exchange also run arbitration programs. O'Brien has said that setting up a single arbitration system would reduce costs to the exchanges and the securities firms that finance the self-regulatory organizations. He said the industry spends $12 million to $15 million a year on arbitration. He also has said that a unified system within the industry would eliminate disparities in the quality of arbitrators. Katovich said the arbitration group also would consider any other possible alternatives. For instance, Wall Street could decide to remove the process from industry control entirely to an organization such as the American Arbitration Association or set up an independent regulatory organization. The Securities and Exchange Commission last year approved a series of reforms designed to address some of the complaints. It required the exchanges to publicize awards in specific cases and required brokerage to highlight arbitration agreements in customer contracts. Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the House telecommunications and finance subcommittee of Energy and Finance Committee, last year introduced legislation that would ban pre-dispute arbitration agreements altogether.

DOC.HEAD: T-Bill Interest Rates Rise
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Tuesday's auction to their highest level in three weeks. The Treasury Department sold $7.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.68 percent, up from 7.57 percent last week. Another $7.6 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.54 percent, up from 7.44 percent last week. The rates were the highest since Dec. 26, when three-month bills sold for 7.77 percent and six-month bills averaged 7.64 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.94 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,805.90 and 7.95 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,618.80. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.78 percent last week, down from 7.82 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp Names President, Makes Other Appointments
DOC.TEXT: Richard Braddock, head of Citicorp's consumer banking business since 1985, has been named president and chief operating officer of the nation's biggest banking company, Citicorp announced. The Citicorp board of directors chose Braddock, 48, to become the company's first president since 1983, when William Spencer retired from that post after more than 40 years with the company. Over the past several years, the post of president essentially was split among the executives heading Citicorp's three core sectors: retail banking, institutional banking and investment banking. Braddock, who is a director of Citicorp and its chief subsidiary, Citibank, had been sector executive in charge of Citicorp's worldwide retail banking unit since 1985. In 1984 he was put in charge of the U.S. consumer banking division. John S. Reed, 51, has been chairman of Citicorp since 1984, when he was promoted from vice chairman. Citicorp also announced Tuesday that Lawrence M. Small, who had been sector executive running the institutional bank, was named vice chairman and chairman of the board's executive committee. Citicorp said Michael A. Callen, sector executive for the global investment bank, will be responsible for both the investment and institutional banking for industrialized countries. Alan S. MacDonald, who has most recently been group executive resonsible fo the North American investment bank, was named sector executive for Citicorp's corporate and investment banking activities in developing countries. Citicorp said the management reorganization recognizes the growing role of the company's consumer business and the need to split the sophisticated corporate finance business that characterizes Citicorp operations in Europe, North America, Japan and Australia from its more traditional international business in developing nations. Some banking analysts said they weren't sure why Citicorp decided to fill the vacancy left by Spencer, although they praised Braddock's appointment. ``Rick Braddock is one of the best in the business. He has a long range of experience, especially on the marketing side of banking,'' said James J. McDermott Jr., of Keefe Bruyette & Woods in New York. ``It's not surprising,'' he was named president. McDermott said Braddock had headed a sector that was expected to earn $800 million this year.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Cuts Short Government Attempt To Blunt Razor Merger
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has denied a Justice Department request to immediately freeze Gillette Co.'s planned acquisition of part of Wilkinson Sword's international razor blade business. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Hogan refused Tuesday to issue a temporary restraining order, saying Gillette has stated that no action would be taken without a 10-day notice in advance to the government. ``The government shall be permitted to renew its motion for a temporary restraining order at anytime'' if the companies don't adhere to their promise to give advance notice, said Hogan. The Justice Department is challenging the proposed transaction on anti-competitive grounds, alleging a violation of the Clayton Act, which bars acquisitions that may substantially reduce competition. By acquiring Wilkinson Sword's razor blade business outside the 12-nation European community, Gillette would account for over 53 percent of the razor blades sold in the United States, says the Justice Department. The judge ordered the companies to respond to Justice Department requests for information and documents by Jan. 29, saying that the government has raised ``potentially serious antitrust'' matters concerning the transaction. Hogan also said the government may take depositions of officers and employees of the companies. Boston-based Gillette plans to gain ownership of Wilkinson Sword's razor blade business outside Europe, with title to Wilkinson's assets in the United States transferred to Gillette as part of the deal.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico, Commercial Banks to Sign Debt Refinancing Package Feb. 4
DOC.TEXT: The government of Mexico and a committee of its commercial bank creditors will sign a refinancing package on Feb. 4 in Mexico City that will reduce the country's $48 billion bank debt, the two sides announced. Mexico and the banks reached final agreement last week on the refinancing, which will cut $7.5 billion from the country's commercial bank debt and knock nearly $2 billion from the country's annual interest bill of $9 billion. It is the first refinancing completed since Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady outlined a plan last year that offered to forgive some debt for countries that agree to make significant changes in their economies. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has invited senior executives of the 15 banks on the advisory committee for Mexico to attend a signing ceremony in the capital, William R. Rhodes of Citibank, co-chairman of the committee, said in a statement Tuesday. The rest of the approximately 450 banks participating in the package can sign the loan documents Feb. 7 in New York, Citibank said. Details still have to be completed on a bridge loan of up to $1.2 billion from a group of 25 to 30 banks to provide guarantees for the refinancing, a crucial element of the package, a banking source close to the negotiations said. Under the package, banks are agreeing to forgive part of Mexico's debt or accept below-market interest rates in exchange for guarantees of repayment, provided by funds from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, Japan's Export-Import Bank and the Mexican government. The four institutions are providing a total of $7.3 billion to guarantee the package, but they aren't contributing all of the money at the outset, said the banker, who asked not to be named.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Up Overall, Automakers Credit Incentives
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Car and truck sales jumped 27 percent in the first 10 days of this year, prompting U.S. automakers to say their recipe for success works: Increase incentives. But one industry analyst called the figures misleading because they are being compared to a year-ago period when sales were weak. On Tuesday, the eight major companies with U.S. assembly plants said they sold cars and light trucks at a daily rate of 32,539 during Jan. 1-10, compared with a 25,629-a-day pace during the same period in 1989. Car sales rose 29.8 percent in early January and truck sales rose 22.8 percent. The increased sales come against a backdrop of decreased production. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. together have part or all of 13 assembly plants idled this week to slow the flow of cars into dealerships. ``My supply of vehicles has dwindled substantially,'' said sales manager Bill Griffith of Hayes Chrysler, Plymouth and Dodge in Lawrenceville, Ga., near Atlanta. Chrysler's car sales rose 14.4 percent in early January, while the company's truck sales, which include minivans, jumped 43.7 percent. Griffith said he has noticed an increase both in sales and in the number of people entering his showroom. The most popular vehicles are the minivans, Griffith said. ``The solid increases in sales are the direct result of the guaranteed rebates,'' said James P. Holden of Chrysler's sales and marketing division. He referred to the No. 3 automaker's pledge that if it increases its rebates later this year, customers who buy using the current incentives will receive a check for the difference. Analyst Mary Ann Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. of New York agreed, saying incentives that started in December on the Dodge Caravan and Plymouth Voyager minivans boosted consumer interest in the vehicles. ``The minivan has become very popular and Chrysler's strategy to protect their crown jewel is working,'' she said. GM's car sales rose 40.4 percent in early January over the year-earlier period, despite production being scaled back by the automaker. GM truck sales rose 28.4 percent. ``GM's recent adjustments in production schedules and improvements in vehicle selling rates are evidence of the corporation's commitment to balancing inventories with consumer demand,'' said J.B. Fitzpatrick, vice president of marketing. Sudol said the overall increase in auto sales was surprising. ``It's a flaky kind of year. Traditionally, January is not a robust time for sales, but there's a lot of noise coming from the automakers about incentives,'' said the analyst, adding that she believes the sales increase won't last. ``The economy is just not generating enough new jobs and enough higher-paying jobs to keep the sales going,'' Sudol said. ``Most people who've bought cars in the last five years are still paying for them.'' Early-January sales appear high because they are compared with a year-ago period that was unusually low, Sudol said. In December 1988, automakers were offering a variety of incentives that expired with the end of that year. ``It is not an easy comparison to make, since the first 10 days in 1989 were so poor. You always get a pay-back period whenever there are incentives,'' she said. Ford's sales increased the least among the Big Three automakers, rising 15.4 percent for cars and 10.9 percent for trucks. In 1989, automakers saw car and truck sales slump 5.5 percent to 14.6 million from 1988's 15.4 million. Even so, 1989 was the automakers' seventh-best selling year on record.

DOC.HEAD: Indirect Effects of Big Retail Bankruptcy Case Possibly Widespread
DOC.TEXT: Although CampeauCorp. plans to keep its coast-to-coast department store empire running while it reorganizes its shattered finances, the bankruptcy case could have far-reaching consequences. Experts say the financial imbroglio eventually could endanger jobs of some of the 100,000 employees at Campeau's 258 stores around the country, lessen the immediate trend toward price-cutting competition among department stores, and prompt investors to be more critical of proposed retail deals. ``This is a once-in-a-lifetime kind of thing for all of us in this business,'' said one 30-year veteran of the retail trade, who asked not to be identified. ``The ramifications are so widespread. The domino effects are remarkable and difficult to conceive.'' By seeking bankruptcy court shelter from creditors on Monday, Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. can continue operating, covering payrolls and meeting suppliers' bills while restructuring their debts. The fate of the chains depends on how they untangle their balance-sheet problems. In filing the largest retailing case ever under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code, Federated and Allied said their liabilities total $7.7 billion while their assets amount to $9.1 billion. There's no guarantee that Federated and Allied would be healthy even after they complete a bankruptcy court-supervised reorganization, experts said Tuesday. Lewis S. Rosenbloom, an attorney who is head of the bankruptcy department at the Chicago law firm Winston & Strawn, said the success of any restructuring could be affected by such factors as the stores' ability to continue getting credit. Retailers generally buy merchandise on credit, so if credit dries up, manufacturers may refuse to ship, leaving stores short of inventory and customers disenchanted. Business hasn't been booming at U.S. department stores in recent months but analysts say Campeau-owned stores largely have been moneymakers. However, profitability at Allied and Federated was eroded by their enormous debt payments. The chains, including such famous retailing names as Bloomingdale's, Rich's and Lazarus, mostly are regarded as well-run retailers from a merchandising standpoint. ``I don't think there is a division there that loses money,'' said Monroe Greenstein, an analyst at Bear Stearns & Co. Individual stores operating in weak markets might be liquidated in a reorganization, possibly jeopardizing local jobs. However, Greenstein said, closing poor performers would enhance overall operations. Analysts said that in terms of the retail industry's health, the pluses will probably outweigh the minuses of the Federated and Allied reorganization. Richard Baum, of Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. Inc., said the stiff price competition that marked the Christmas shopping season _ and affected profits for many retailers _ will ease. Allied and Federated stores no longer must mark down prices to prop up sales in order to generate enough income to meet heavy debt payments. Another impact could be from sales of Allied and Federated stores. Bankruptcy reorganizations often involve asset sales to satisfy creditors' claims and there is speculation some of the nine Allied and Federated chains could be put on sale. The 17 stores in the New York-based Bloomingdale's division already are on the auction block. But even if the retailing environment improves, divesting portions of Allied and Federated could be tough, especially because many other department stores are on the market. Besides Bloomingdale's, other chains looking for buyers include Saks Fith Avenue and Marshall Field's, both owned by BAT Industries PLC, and Bonwit Teller, owned by L.J. Hooker Corp., which is operating under bankruptcy court supervision. Sanford C. Sigoloff, a turnaround expert who has been running L.J. Hooker, a subsidiary of Australia's Hooker Corp., said, ``It's a very unstable time right now.'' L.J. Hooker failed in its effort late last year to find a buyer for its upscale B. Altman & Co. department store chain and was forced to liquidate it. Retailing property development also could be affected by the Campeau case. Developers and investors who provide financial backing might not want to build new complexes when big stores needed to anchor shopping malls are facing uncertain futures. Richard Echikson, chairman of Millburn, N.J.-based Retail Consultants Inc., a company that advises on retail property investments, said a slowdown in development of new sites might not be all bad. He said there aren't many prime U.S. locations left and there are plenty of existing shopping malls that could be refurbished. Also, malls don't automatically go under when their main stores run into trouble, he said. The glitzy Mall at Short Hills in Short Hills, N.J., still had a terrific Christmas even though its four anchors are two Campeau-owned stores and two owned by Hooker, including an Altman's that has closed. Developers say Federated and Allied stores are better off back in the hands of retailing experts rather than in Campeau's. Allied and Federated were split from their Toronto-based parent as part of restructuring steps leading to the bankruptcy filing. ``It's probably going to hurt mall development in the short-term but in the long-term it would help,'' said Frank Pasquerilla, chairman and chief executive officer of Crown American Corp., one of the country's biggest shopping mall developers. ``When the dust settles, retailing will be back in the hands of retailers.''

DOC.HEAD: Miller Has Saved Other Companies
With PM-Campeau, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: G. William Miller, the former treasury secretary and Federal Reserve Board chairman, has taken on a new challenge: turning around the troubled Campeau Corp. retail operations. Miller, 64, was named chairman and chief executive officer Tuesday of Campeau's U.S. subsidiary. His appointment came a day after the retailing giant, owner of 258 department stores, filed for bankruptcy protection. In Miller, the American chain-store operation, which was given operating independence from its Toronto-based parent last week, has turned to a man viewed as a savior by other once-failing companies, including Chrysler Corp. But Miller doesn't lack for critics, especially from his days at the Fed and then as Jimmy Carter's treasury secretary. At Treasury, Miller oversaw the government loan program that brought Chrysler back from the brink. As a merchant banker later, he has revived companies large and small, earning millions, often in the form of stock which has increased dramatically in value. Unlike an investment bank or a commercial bank, a merchant bank takes a long-term stake in the companies it is advising. Miller formed one, G. William Miller & Co., after leaving Carter's cabinet. ``I'd like to move from being quarterback, so to speak, to being coach,'' he said. He has close ties to the wealthy Ojjeh family, headed by Syrian-born Akram Ojjeh, and other Middle East investors, for whom he has engineered several acquisitions. Several years ago, creditors were about to pull the plug on steel-oriented Korf Industries, of Charlotte, N.C., when the company approached Miller for help. He launched a restructuring program that included the sale of steel mills and replacement of debt by stock. The firm now is principally owned by Kuwaiti interests. At the time, he compared the rescue of Korf, which he renamed Georgetown Industries, to his role at the Treasury during the Chrysler crisis: ``Sell off assets to raise cash, work with lenders to pay off debt, reduce debt, convert debt to equity ... We end up with a company that has a sturdy balance sheet.'' In the Korf-Georgetown case, Miller reduced debt from $265 million to $40 million in just two years. Miller could not be reached for an interview Tuesday over his ideas for Campeau (U.S.) Inc., which will be renamed Federated Stores Inc. Lisa Astudillo, his assistant, would say only that he was traveling. Miller, a former chairman of Textron Inc., has long been a director of Federated, and remained a director of the new unit created by Campeau, even though he had resisted the takeover. During that battle, he assailed the acquisitions trend of the decade, saying, ``The largest company gets thrown in turmoil and employees suffer.'' Yet, he has never been ready to call for government intervention, either to halt takeovers or give takeover targets more defenses. And during his pre-Carter days at Textron, the conglomerate whose products range from zippers to helicopters, he certainly wasn't shy himself on the acquisitions front. Born March 9, 1925, in Sapulpa, Okla., Miller grew up in Borger, Texas, studied marine engineering at the Coast Guard Academy and served from 1945 to 1949 as a Coast Guard officer. He received a law degree from the University of California at Berkeley in 1952, and joined a law firm in New York City, where one of his first assignments was to help Royal Little, the founder of Textron, make an acquisition. Little was so impressed with the young lawyer that he asked Miller to join Textron for a one-year trial. Four years later, at age 35, Miller became president of the company. In 1974 he was made chairman, a post he held until Carter named him chairman of the Federal Reserve in 1978. A little over a year later, Carter made him treasury secretary. Since leaving the government, Miller generally has shunned the limelight, though he continues to serve a wide variety of civic organizations. For decades, he has been active in minority affairs, and is crediting with helping move more women into the nation's boardrooms, including Textron's.

DOC.HEAD: President of Campeau Units Says They Can Restructure Successfully
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. can restructure their debt and emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection without selling groups of stores or greatly reducing their work force, says James M. Zimmerman, president of the two retail operations. ``If we run good stores during this Chapter 11, customers will look right through this issue,'' Zimmerman said Tuesday. ``We believe the shopper will separate the two issues and view the bankruptcy as corporate mumbo jumbo stuff.'' The scope of the indebtedness that drove Federated and Allied to seek federal bankruptcy court protection took about 6,000 pages of court filings to detail. The two Campeau Corp. retail divisions listed $9.1 billion in assets and $7.7 billion in debts owed to 50,750 creditors, ranging from investment houses that made speculative investments to fund the buyouts of the divisions to clothing companies that supplied their goods. In its bankruptcy court petition filed Monday and released Tuesday, Federated listed $2.8 billion in secured debt and $794.8 million in unsecured debt, most of it carried by bondholders. Allied listed $586 in secured debt and $700 million in unsecured debt, with the parent Campeau Corp. listed its the biggest bondholder at $100 million. On Tuesday, G. William Miller, 64, a Federated director, former U.S. treasury secretary and Federal Reserve Board chairman, was named chairman and chief executive officer of the U.S. operations. He succeeds John W. Burden III, who was said to have quit effective Jan. 31 ``to pursue other interests.'' Ronald W. Tysoe, president of Campeau Corp. and Campeau (U.S.), the U.S. operation, will phase out his responsibilities at the Canadian parent to concentrate on the U.S. retail operation, which will change its name to Federated Stores Inc., the company said. Zimmerman will remain as president and chief operating officer of Federated and Allied, and the management teams at all department store chains will continue in place, the company said. Zimmerman said Federated and Allied are not looking to sell divisions to pay creditors, other than previously announced plans to sell Federated's New York-based Bloomingdale's division. ``This is a reorganization, not a liquidation,'' Zimmerman said. ``Our objective is to maximize the treatment of all the creditors, but we have a bias toward keeping the companies intact ... and restructuring the debt. ``Because of our tax structure, it is not efficient to sell off divisions one at a time as a way to produce cash,'' he said. Zimmerman said some layoffs are possible, but large numbers are not expected. ``We have a serious capital structure problem,'' he said. ``A major mistake was made in the accumulation of too much debt on the part of Campeau during the takeover. That has to be fixed.'' Miller said holders of high-yield ``junk'' bonds Campeau sold to finance its takeover of Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988 should expect to take losses. ``They bought speculative securities, and they had high interest rates which were compensation,'' Miller said on NBC's ``Today'' show. ``I think the marketplace has already reflected in the discounts at which they are selling the fact that they probably will not be paid in full.'' In listing its unsecured bondholders, Federated and Allied did not say whether the creditors owned the bonds themselves or were holding them for clients as trustees. Federated said First Boston Corp. is its largest creditor, holding $428.8 million in bonds. But Jack Cowell, a managing director for the New York investment house, called Federated's figure ``vastly inflated.'' ``The figure is well over $100 million off,'' he said. Cowell said First Boston bought many of the bonds at lower market prices, investing about $75 million to $100 million in Federated bonds. After First Boston, Federated listed State Street Bank-Custodian c@o Independent Election Corp. of America at $159.9 million, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. at $108.3 million and PaineWebber Funding Inc. at $96.1 million. After Campeau, Allied listed First Boston Corp. at $97.5 million and Manufacturers Hanover Trust at $38.4 million. Among the largest trade creditors listed by some of the store groups were Liz Claiborne, with $1.4 million owed by Lazarus and $381,076 by Abraham and Straus; $450,780 owed to Sony Corp. of America by Lazarus; $402,456 owed to Fieldcrest Cannon Inc. by Lazarus; $401,605 owed to Parfums Stern Inc. from Maas Brothers and $301,151 from Burdine's; and $346,303 owed to Farberware by Maas. Federated's stores are Abraham and Straus, Bloomingdale's, Burdine's Lazarus, and Rich's. Allied operates The Bon Marche, Jordan Marsh, Maas Brothers and Stern's. Monday's filing was the largest under Chapter 11 by an American retailer, affecting about 100,000 employees and 258 stores in the United States. It also was the second-largest ever by a non-financial company after Texaco Inc., which sought court protection in April 1987.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Moves to Shore up Credibility, Compensate Customers
LaserPhoto NR1
DOC.TEXT: AT&T is seeking to regain its ``aura of invulnerability'' following a nine-hour outage to long-distance service nationwide that was traced to a bug in a new software program. AT&T Chairman Robert E. Allen on Tuesday said he believed the outage in a call-switching network was a ``one-time hit.'' During a news briefing at the sprawling Network Operations Center, Allen announced plans for a discount day on which all of AT&T's approximately 80 million long-distance customers could make calls at reduced rates. The company had not decided about the amount of the discount or when it would be offered. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. officials said other options for compensation were being reviewed, and billings would be adjusted to reflect the outage, but details were not given. Allen said the advertising campaign was designed to show that AT&T is still ``the right choice'' as it battles to maintain its 70 percent share of the market. Some analysts said the disruption could be a boon to AT&T's rivals. ``The conventional wisdom among telecommunications managers is that you don't get fired for choosing AT&T because it has this aura of invulnerability,'' Frank Governali, an analyst with First Boston, told The New York Times on Tuesday. ``That wisdom changed yesterday. The failure of AT&T's network helps give the perception that the other guys can do just as well.'' The problem was discovered mid-afternoon Monday and corrected nine hours later. Until it was fixed, more than half of the calls placed on its nationwide network did not go through, the company said. AT&T said said the problem stemmed from a bug, or ``logic'' problem, inadvertently written into the software in a computer in New York City that helps direct calls through the vast network. The problem spread to more than 100 switching centers. ``This is not a virus,'' said spokesman Gary Morgenstern. ``It was a human error in writing the software.'' Allen said he could not estimate losses to AT&T or its customers. ``We estimate we lost many thousands of calls during the outage and thousands of potential bookings,'' said Karen Ceremsack, an Eastern Airlines spokeswoman. The problem had minimal effect on reservations for Marriott's 530 hotels worldwide, said chain spokesman Roger Conner in Omaha, Neb. ``Our feeling is that it affected us financially very little, if at all,'' he said. ``It's not a matter to disenfranchise us in terms of our satisfaction with AT&T.'' AT&T has insurance to cover customers' losses stemming from the trouble with its 800-number toll-free service, but does not have coverage for business customers using regular long-distance circuits. ``We don't have any liability in that sense,'' Allen said. ``We have to look at each customer on a case-by-case basis.'' Neither MCI Communications Corp. nor US Sprint, AT&T's main competitors, plan to change their marketing strategies to capitalize on AT&T's problem, spokesmen said. But US Sprint spokesman John Landsberg in Kansas City, Mo., noted an increase in the number of calls for information on its service. ``People are taking a look at having an alternative carrier to AT&T,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: GM Orders Advertising Trimmed
With PM-Auto Sales, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp., facing forecasts of sagging car sales, expects to advertise less and cut sponsorship as part of an overall plan to slash spending, according to a published report. The Detroit News said Tuesday it obtained an internal GM memo called the ``1990 Quick Start Program,'' which said the carmaker would cut or delay media spending by 25 percent in the first six months of this year. The memo also said that GM would reduce sponsorships in motor sports and related activities by 20 percent, the newspaper said. ``We're looking at a lot of things,'' said Phil Guarascio, GM executive director of advertising. ``I don't think the door is closed on (cutting) anything.'' Spokesman Terry Sullivan confirmed the memo Tuesday, but said he had no details on specific cuts and said there was no firm target for cuts. GM does not disclose its advertising budget. The nation's largest automaker launched a $13-billion cost-cutting program in 1987, and last week it confirmed another round of cuts that published reports put at $1 billion. Sullivan said daily operating budgets in all departments companywide are being reviewed in search of ways to cut or more efficiently handle costs. ``I think the key there is the term `cut' or `defer,''' he said. ``Defer, it just means hold off spending for a time period and then see if we really need it and how important it is to us. I mean everything in general, I don't just mean advertising.'' Car sales were slow in 1989, and the Big Three automakers have shut down or slowed production at 13 U.S. plants this week to lighten the 90-day supply of cars on hand. Incentives launched in 1989 to try to get rid of slow-selling cars have proven costly. GM on Tuesday reported a 40 percent increase in car sales and 28 percent increase in truck sales for the first 10 days of January.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Pleads Guilty in Global Money Laundering Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Trial resumes 9 a.m. EST; lead prospects uncertain. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: One of the world's largest banks pleaded guilty in a $32 million cocaine money-laundering case, but critics call the plea bargain a ``slap on the wrist'' that won't discourage such illicit banking practices. The focus of the case now shifts to evidence that may link one of the bank's top officials to ousted Panamania dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. As part of Tuesday's plea, Luxembourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International (BCCI) must forfeit a record $14 million in assets frozen by the U.S. government. It also must cooperate against other defendants _ including one of its bankers who once claimed to be Noriega's personal banker. Amjad Awan, a former Latin American assistant division director for BCCI, told a U.S. Senate panel in 1988 he managed Noriega's secret accounts at the bank's Panama branch that held up to $23 million. Defense attorneys are trying to exclude any testimony linking Awan with Noriega, including statements they say Awan gave involuntarily after his arrest. If the government insists on interjecting Noriega into the case, defense attorneys have threatened to request sensitive government files they say would show the U.S. government was aware of Noriega's ties to drug smuggling. Charges were dropped late Tuesday against one of six bankers charged. Proceedings against the remaining bankers and two Colombians continued before U.S. District Judge W. Terrell Hodges and are expected to last five months. Jury selection is not expected to begin until later in the week. Besides the $14 million forfeiture, the largest ever by a financial institution in the United States, BCCI S.A. and BCCI Overseas Ltd. received suspended fines and five years of government-supervised probation. If convicted of all charges, $45 million in fines could have been imposed. BCCI Overseas Ltd. pleaded guilty to 26 counts of money laundering. Seven other counts were dropped. The other BCCI subsidiary pleaded guilty to three counts of money laundering. Twenty-four other counts were dropped. Hodges accepted the plea but did not set a date for sentencing. He imposed a gag order to prevent parties in the case from commenting. ``I think it's a good deal,'' said Bonnie Tischler, head of the U.S. Customs Service in Tampa. BCCI, the world's seventh-largest privately held bank, is a $20 billion institution with offices in 73 countries, including the United States. ``It's pretty outrageous,'' said Scott Malone, Washington bureau chief of the monthly newsletter, Money Laundering Alert. ``It's just a slap on the wrist. All they have to do is return the proceeds of their crime and pay no penalty. ``It sends the wrong signal to bankers all over the world. ... Many bankers in Switzerland, Montevideo and elsewhere are probably snickering in their martinis,'' Malone said. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., who conducted the Senate hearings also lambasted the penalty. ``We send drug people to jail for the rest of their life, and these guys who are bankers in the corporate world seem to just walk away, and it's business as usual,'' said Kerry, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on narcotics. ``To simply let this bank go on doing business after giving up its drug profits is to slap it on the wrist while a whole lot of other people in the criminal justice system have a different standard applied to them,'' Kerry told CBS News. ``My impression is when banks engage knowingly in the laundering of money, they should be shut down. It's that simple, it really is.'' The indictment resulted from a two-year ``sting'' during which an undercover agent conned his way into an international money laundering network, authorities said. Later, agents helped direct profits from cocaine sales in American cities to Colombia through Panama, eventually building a global laundering operation worth an estimated $32 million, investigators said. The agents said BCCI bankers taught them how to use cash to buy certificate of deposits, then use the CDs as collateral for loans. The loan proceeds were wired into accounts controlled by the agent or smugglers, prosecutors said. The branches used reportedly included locations in France, Panama, Uruguay, the Bahamas, Luxembourg and England. Customs agents claimed the money was intended mainly for Colombian drug traffickers, including the Medellin cartel. The defendant dropped late Tuesday was Iqbal Ashraf, 39, a manager of BCCI's Los Angeles office. His attorneys successfully moved to suppress statements given without counsel present. ``When we lost that, we just didn't have enough evidence left (against him),'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Rubenstein.

DOC.HEAD: Japan To Limit Auto Exports
With PM-Auto Sales, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan will voluntarily limit its auto exports to the United States to 2.3 million passenger cars again in fiscal 1990, Trade Minister Hikaru Matsunaga said today. The limit is the same as in the current fiscal year, which ends March 31, although actual exports this year are expected to be only 2 million because of increased overseas production by Japanese automakers. Japan began voluntary auto export restraints in fiscal 1981 in response to pressure from the U.S. government to help U.S. automakers recover. They have been considered obsolete for several years, however, because Japan's actual auto shipments have been less than the quotas. Matsunaga said the decision was made after considering auto market conditions in Japan and the United States, including the yen-dollar exchange rate. When the export restraint started, Japanese automakers had a big price advantage over U.S. companies, but the rise of the yen against the dollar since 1985 has made Japanese cars more expensive overseas. Matsunaga also said that ``Most capital investments by Japanese automakers in the last few years have been aimed at increasing production efficiency and product quality, not increasing production capacity.'' But still, keeping the quotas is regarded as politically important while U.S.-Japan friction continues over Japan's $50 billion annual surplus in trade with the United States. Today's announcement was virtually identical to last year's, when the government said the export quota should be kept even though exports to America were declining. Japanese car companies have turned increasingly to producing autos in the United States, although some U.S. lawmakers have argued that Japanese cars built in the United States should be considered imports.

DOC.HEAD: Mahlmann Re-Elected Chairman of Chicago Board of Trade
DOC.TEXT: Karsten ``Cash'' Mahlmann has been re-elected to a fourth consecutive one-year term as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade in the exchange's first contested election in a decade. Mahlmann, 52, the head of one of Chicago's leading commodity trading firms, turned back a spirited challenge from Leslie Rosenthal, a millionaire and veteran trader who had called for rapid change in the world's largest futures exchange. Mahlmann defeated Rosenthal by a vote of 630-524, CBOT officials reported late Tuesday. ``I am very gratified by the membership endorsement that has been handed to me by this vote, and I am pleased the membership will allow me to lead for another year,'' said Mahlmann, the managing partner of Stotler & Co., the exchange's third-largest clearing member firm. Rosenthal, 56, managing partner of Rosenthal Collins Group, was not immediately available for comment. The election took place against a backdrop of turbulence during the past year at the CBOT, marked by an ongoing FBI investigation into trading fraud and complaints about the exchange's handling of July's soybean market crisis. Exchange officials estimated that nearly 75 percent of the CBOT's 1,402 full members and 739 associate members _ who get one-sixth of a vote _ cast ballots Tuesday. William F. O'Connor, chairman of O'Connor & Co. who is viewed as a Mahlmann ally, was elected vice chairman, defeating Donald Andrew, senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. _ 685 to 458. The race for chairman pitted Mahlmann against Rosenthal, who campaigned on a platform calling for maximizing exchange profits and increasing member income. Rosenthal's proposals included introducing new exchange products and the possible sale or refinancing of the CBOT's landmark building in the heart of the financial district, with profits going to the members. Mahlmann opposed selling or refinancing the exchange's Loop building, saying the tax liability for members would be too high under current law. Rosenthal, who served as CBOT chairman in 1981 and 1982, is known for his daring, aggressive style. Mahlmann, who is considered more cautious and low-key, stressed continuity in his campaign and building on the accomplishments of his past three terms. Mahlmann portrayed himself as the best choice for seeing the CBOT through upcoming congressional hearings on exchange issues _ such as the reauthorization of its regulatory agency, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission _ and the federal probe that so far has resulted in the indictment of 47 traders and a clerk in the CBOT and Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Hunts Selling Home
DOC.TEXT: The 68-year-old mansion owned by Nelson Bunker Hunt, who recently emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, is up for sale, according to a report published today. The Dallas Times Herald said the Hunt and his wife Caroline intend to move into a smaller home. The asking price on the six-bedroom, six-bathroom house, which overlooks Turtle Creek and features marble fireplaces and a garden room, reportedly is $2.8 million. The home was valued in papers filed in the Hunts' bankruptcy case at $1.8 million. The Hunts bought the house in 1962 from George McGhee, who was named ambassador to West Germany by President Kennedy. Because of the bankruptcy proceedings, they were forced to turn over holdings valued at more than $220 million. Hunt also had to give up his annual salary of $300,000 and income from widespread holdings. But because Texas law grants homeowners an unlimited exemption for a homestead in bankruptcy proceedings, the Hunts won't have to give any proceeds from the sale to creditors. The Hunts' financial problems began in 1980 when Nelson Bunker Hunt and his brother, William Herbert Hunt, lost $1.5 billion speculating in the silver futures markets. The silver losses were compounded by falling real estate prices and the collapse of the oil market. The brothers filed for protection from their creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in September 1988, shortly after a New York jury found the Hunts had conspired to corner the silver market. The Hunts emerged from bankruptcy proceedings earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: Volcker Urges China to Keep Economy Open
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Paul A. Volcker urged China on Wednesday to keep its economy open to the world. Volcker, guest speaker at a three-day conference on central banking, said he hoped China's open-door policy would continue because international cooperation in monetary matters was ``irrelevant if you have a closed society.'' The conference, sponsored by the U.N. Development Program, the International Monetary Fund and the People's Bank of China, focused on such areas as the role of monetary policy and the functions of the central bank. Chen Yuan, deputy governor of the People's Bank, China's central bank, told a news conference that one thing learned from Volcker and other participants was ``how to resist strong demand for funds from local governments and enterprises.'' Volcker, head of the Fed from 1979 to 1987, was known for sticking to a tight money policy in the face of strong political pressure in a winning battle against inflation. In late 1988, China began restricting credit and took other austerity measures in a drive to bring inflation under control. The government succeeded by late 1989 in bringing the inflation rate under 10 percent, compared to 30 percent a year earlier, but at a cost of rising unemployment and thousands of factories having to shut down or reduce production because of lack of operating funds. ``In the long run, inflation is destructive for growth and unemployment,'' said Volcker, who now teaches economic policy at Princeton University. ``There's a great deal to be said for giving priority to stabilizing prices.'' Chen acknowledged that under the current ``retrenchment'' policies, the government has given priority to price stability rather than the pricing reforms Western economists say are crucial for a modern, market-oriented economy. ``But that doesn't mean we have stopped price reform,'' Chen said, pointing to new pricing systems in the coal and transport industries. Richard D. Erb, deputy managing director of the IMF, also praised China for its ability to rein in inflation, saying there were very few nations that have achieved China's level of growth ``without having severe deterioration in terms of inflation.'' Erb said the speakers at the conference, including Central Bank of Mexico Governor Miguel Macera and former National Bank of Belgium Governor Jean Godeaux, stressed the need for a central bank with autonomy and accountability and a commitment to competition among financial markets and price and wage flexibility.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Production, Capacity Utilization Up in December
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to include utility production figure
DOC.TEXT: Industrial production rose 0.4 percent in December, the second consecutive monthly gain, as unseasonably cold weather fired up output by utilities, the government said today. Despite the 6.3 percent gain in utilities, manufacturing production remained sluggish, also partly because of the weather. The slow pace was reflected by the loss of 25,000 factory jobs and an unchanged 40.7-hour average work week. The manufacturing sector, particularly durable goods _ items such as cars and household appliances expected to last more than three years _ has been affected by the Federal Reserve Board's tight rein on credit designed to curtail inflation since many such items are financed by loans. In its report today, the board said December's gain in production followed a revised 0.3 percent advance in November, up from the 0.1 percent reported initially. Output had declined 0.4 percent in October and 0.1 percent in September. ``The extremely cold weather in December caused a sharp rise in utility output, but also resulted in some production disruptions, particularly in petroleum refining and construction supplies,'' the Fed said. ``Aircraft production returned to normal in December following the settlement of a strike'' at the Boeing Co., it said. In another report, the central bank said the operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose 0.2 percentage point to 83.3 percent in December, reflecting the increase in the production rate. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels. ``A surge of five percentage points in the operating rate for utilities, which was the largest in the 23-year history of this series, resulted from the abnormally cold temperatures experienced in December,'' the Fed said. ``Elsewhere, utilization in manufacturing edged down 0.1 percentage point, while the rate for mining fell nearly a percentage point.'' Factory use had remained unchanged at 83.1 percent from October to November. The rate posted 10-year highs of 84.3 percent in December 1988 and January 1989. The operating report is watched as a barometer of future inflation. The closer U.S. industry gets to full operating capacity, the greater difficulty it has producing enough to meet demand, leading to shortages and price increases. Analysts general consider an operating rate of 85 percent or above as an indication of inflationary pressures. Production at manufacturing plants making both durable and non-durable goods rose 0.2 percent in December after advancing 0.4 percent in November and falling 0.5 percent in October. Production at plants manufacturing durable goods edged up 0.2 percent, compared with a 0.4 percent gain in November and a 1.5 percent decline in October. Non-durable manufacturing fell 0.1 percent in December after rising 0.3 percent in November and 0.7 percent in October. Output at mines fell 1.2 percent, after a 0.3 percent hike in November. The Fed said its industrial production index in December stood at 142.8 percent of its 1977 base, up from 142.3 percent a month earlier. In the capacity utilization report, the Fed said the manufacturing plant operating rate slipped to 83.1 percent in December from 83.2 percent in November. The rate had peaked at 84.7 percent in January 1989. The rate at factories producing durable goods edged up 0.1 percentage point to 81.1 percent. The rate at factories producing non-durable goods dipped 0.4 percentage point to 85.8 percent. The operating rate at mines was up 0.1 percentage point to 83.4 percent, while it shot up five percentage points to 86.3 percent at utilities.

The stock market got off to a weak start this morning, struggling to overcome disappointing economic and earnings news. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials showed a loss of 10.88 at 2,681.74 by 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Volume on the Big Board came to 22.26 million shares after the first 30 minutes of trading. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.45 to 187.92. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 0.32 to 368.73. Market analysts said a widening in the U.S. trade deficit to $10.5 billion in November from $10.25 in October was discouraging but didn't spark a slide in bond prices, which could comfort stock traders. A separate report on industrial production indicated the manufacturing sector continued sluggish. Production posted a gain for the second month in a row, rising 0.4 percent in December, boosted by higher utility output due to unusually cold weather. Blue-chip stocks could be headed for a rough ride today after leading an afternoon rally on Tuesday. Market bellwether IBM fell \ to 99~ after the computer giant reported unexpectedly poor fourth-quarter earnings of $1.04 a share compared to $3.97 a share in 1988's final quarter. Other losers among actively traded blue chips included Philip Morris, down ] to 39, American Telephone & Telegraph, down [ to 43, General Electric, down \ to 63 and Merck, down \ 72~. Aristech led the Big Board's list of actively traded issues, adding | to 25\. On Tuesday the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 23.25 points to 2,692.62. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 8 to 7 on the NYSE, with 793 up, 709 down and 463 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: Government Says Oil Providers Showed Big Profit Margins During Cold
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, The figures, to CORRECT day to Tuesday sted Monday
DOC.TEXT: Local heating oil dealers and major oil companies took advantage of record heating oil demands in the December cold snap to sharply boost their profit margins, the government says. Refiners boosted their margins _ the difference between their buying and selling prices _ by 46 cents a gallon above October levels as part of an average 54 percent runup in heating oil prices in New England last month, the Energy Department said. Local distributors also increased profit margins by 9.3 cents a gallon, although more than half the increase happened in the first week of January, after the worst of the cold temperatures, according to the data. The figures, presented Tuesday to the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, are the first government data indicating that producers and local heating oil dealers among others took advantage of the coldest December in 70 years to boost profits. Representatives of both the refining industry and local retailers said the margin figures alone are misleading because they exclude higher, profit-eating operating costs in scrambling to keep consumers supplied. ``Since the middle of November, my wholesale cost has increased 59 cents per gallon while my retail price has increased by 47 cents,'' said Robert Wesson, a Waterbury, Conn., home heating oil dealer, testifying on behalf of the Petroleum Marketers Association. Helmut Merklein, head of the department's Energy Information Agency, said the extent of actual profits from the December freeze will not be known until May after oil companies file quarterly income statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission. ``We know that the American consumer was the loser; we don't know who the winners are yet,'' said John Easton, assistant energy secretary for energy emergencies. Since the first of the year, average refiner margins and wholesale prices on heating oil sold in New England have dropped about 22 cents a gallon, according to the new data. Average retail prices are also down, but by a smaller 17 cents a gallon to an average $1.29{ as of last Thursday. Meanwhile, jobbers are now enjoying a peak margin of 38 cents a gallon compared with a current margin of 36.4 cents a gallon for refiners. Edwin Rothschild of Citizen Action, a consumer energy policy group, said local dealers may try to build or maintain higher profit margins now that wholesale prices are falling. However, he blamed the bulk of the increase on major oil companies who ``seized on the colder-than-normal weather to drive prices to the highest levels in history,'' predicting they will reap $850 million in profits. Charles J. DiBona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, said some of the refineries' increased price margin was absorbed by higher operating and transportation costs. The committee was told of one case in which the price of a tanker to carry heating oil from a Texas refinery to New York jumped from $800,000 to $2 million at the cold wave's peak. ``Nevertheless, industry profits probably rose ... just as they fall in a glut,'' DiBona acknowledged. Glenn F. Tilton, president of Texaco Refining and Marketing, said profits his company made on price increases the third week of December will likely be offset by losses on 24 million gallons it bought at 95 cents each the last week of the month. With much of the country enjoying warmer weather, many gallons remain unsold and wholesale prices are now in the range of 76 cents to 86 cents a gallon, said Tilton. ``Not surprisingly, no one is asking why prices have dropped or expressing concern that we may have to sell product for less than its purchase price,'' he said.
