DOC.HEAD: Trade Gap Hit $10.5 Billion in November
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 7th graf, At the, with Fitzwater comment
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit widened in November to $10.5 billion, its worst showing in 11 months, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said that while imports declined by $593 million to $40.69 billion, U.S. exports dropped a larger $843 million to $30.19 billion. The trade deficit is the difference between imports and exports. The government blamed much of the setback on the Boeing aircraft strike, which severely cut into exports of expensive commercial airliners. But private analysts were still disheartened by the deficit figure. Many had been looking for a slight improvement following a sharp deterioriation in October. ``The trade report is most distressing,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``Even accounting for civilian aircraft, U.S. exports are going nowhere. The U.S. is simply not competitive on goods.'' The Bush administration was more upbeat in its assessment, with Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher saying officials were still looking for ``continued moderate improvement in the trade deficit'' this year. At the White House, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``The deficit is moving in the right direction. We think are policies are sound _ no plans to change them.'' In other reports today, The Federal Reserve Board said output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose 0.4 percent in December, a modest gain it attributed to the return of striking Boeing workers and unusually cold weather that boosted utility output. The increases helped push the operating rate for U.S. industry to 83.3 percent of capacity last month. The October trade deficit totaled $10.25 billion. Both October and November represented the worst performance since a $10.8 billion deficit in December 1988. For the first 11 months of 1989, the U.S. trade deficit ran at an annual rate of $111 billion, compared with a deficit of $118.53 billion in all of 1988. Many economists believe that America's trade deficit will increase in 1990, reversing a two-year trend of improvements. This is an unsettling forecast for the Bush administration, which is counting on continued growth in exports to bolster the U.S. economy and dampen demands in Congress for protectionist trade legislation. The 2.7 percent drop in U.S. exports left them at their lowest level since last March. Almost half of all economic growth in the past two years has been supplied by a boom in export sales. But economists are worried that these strong increases are in danger of stalling out in 1990, in part because the dollar was rising in value most of last year. A stronger dollar makes U.S. goods more expensive on overseas markets. On the import side, the 1.4 percent November decline represented a drop from an all-time high set the previous month. Economists said U.S. consumer demand for foreign goods is showing little sign of slackening. In addition, the country is growing more dependent on foreign oil. Petroleum shipments climbed to $4.38 billion in November, the highest total in six months, as the number of barrels imported rose 2 percent to 8.42 million barrels daily and the price climbed by 24 cents to $17.33. As usual, the biggest trade deficit in November was with Japan, $4.0 billion, down from $4.9 billion in October. The deficit with members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries totaled $1.8 billion, while the deficit with Canada was $1.2 billion. Other large deficits included $1 billion with Taiwan, $800 million with China and $700 million with Western Europe. Many economists are pessimistic about the nation's trade prospects, believing that the deficit will grow in 1990 because of the dollar's strength during the past year. David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, predicted America's trade deficit would rise to $115 billion this year, up from an expected $110 billion for all of 1989. ``I don't think we are going to get any improvement in trade in 1990,'' Wyss said. ``We are running bigger and bigger deficits with (Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong) and with oil prices going up, we are hurting with OPEC as well.'' Samuel Kahan, chief economist for Fuji Securities Inc. of Chicago, said that for the trade gap to narrow more, U.S. consumption will have to slow considerably while overseas growth accelerates, boosting foreign demand for U.S. products. He said neither of these events was likely to occur, especially because interest rates are rising in many countries. ``The trade balance pretty much has stalled out,'' he said. Many analysts were predicting the trade deficit will average around $9.5 billion per month for the foreseeable future until the dollar begins to decline further.

DOC.HEAD: Cathay Pacific, Parent Buy 35 Percent of Hong Kong Dragon
DOC.TEXT: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. and its parent have purchased a combined 35 percent stake in Hong Kong Dragon Airlines Ltd., the airlines announced Wednesday. Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong's largest airline, bought 30 percent of Dragonair for 294 million Hong Kong dollars, or about $37.7 million, while its parent Swire Pacific Ltd. has acquired 5 percent for 49 million Hong Kong dollars, or $6.3 million. Dragonair, the British colony's No. 2 airline that has been losing money since its founding in 1984, also said that China's state-owned China International Trust and Investment Corp. is raising its stake in Dragonair from 27 percent to 38 percent. While Dragonair will remain an independent airline, Cathay Pacific will name some of its key executives to provide technical and administrative services, the airlines said. The two carriers will cooperate closely, with Dragonair continuing to concentrate on serving as a regional airline with strong emphasis on routes between Hong Kong and China, Swire said in a statement. Cathay Pacific has operated as an international airline.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Open Mixed; Grains Continue Lower
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices opened narrowly mixed today on the Chicago Board of Trade after a steep decline in the previous session. Grain futures continued to edge lower. Some of the support for soybeans stemmed from Tuesday's weekly Agriculture Department export inspections report. The USDA said it inspected 9.4 million bushels of soybeans for export last week, a number slightly higher than the markets had expected. Wheat inspections also were above expectations while corn inspections were about as anticipated. Soybean futures fell sharply on Tuesday, largely in reaction to beneficial precipitation in soybean-growing areas of the United States and South America. Wheat traders ignored the USDA's confirmation this morning that the Soviet Union had been awarded 525,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. The announcement had been expected since Monday. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to { cent lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.98 a bushel; corn was { cent to 1 cent lower with March at $2.41} a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent lower with March at $1.41} a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 1 cent higher with January at $5.58{ a bushel. Cattle futures were higher while pork futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .05 cent to .30 cent higher with February at 77.90 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .35 cent higher with January at 83.50 cents a pound; live hogs were .13 cent lower to .23 cent higher with February at 49.57 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .27 cent lower with February at 55.35 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled mostly lower on Tuesday; pork bellies were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: States May Tax Sales of Merchandise Sold by Television Evangelists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 15-20, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: States may tax the sales of religious books, tapes and other merchandise sold by television evangelists, the Supreme Court ruled today. The court unanimously upheld taxes imposed by California on the Louisiana-based Jimmy Swaggart Ministries, ruling that forcing the TV preacher's organization to pay such taxes does not violate religious freedom. ``California's non-discriminatory sales and use tax law requires only that (Swaggart's ministry) collect the tax from its California purchasers and remit the tax money to the state,'' Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote for the court. ``Collection and payment of the generally applicable tax in this case imposes no constitutionally significant burden on (Swaggart's) religious practices or beliefs,'' she said. The decision upheld rulings that forced Swaggart's organization to pay California $183,000 in back taxes and interest for the years 1974 through 1981. The justices were told during oral arguments in October that California is the only state imposing such taxes on religious organizations. But now that the tax has been upheld, other states are free to do the same. Most states have laws requiring payment of sales taxes on goods bought by their residents through the mail, but many of those states do not actively seek to enforce those laws. For the years at issue in the case, mail-order sales from Swaggart's base in Baton Rouge, La., to California consumers totaled $1.7 million. Sales of merchandise at California crusades totaled $240,000. During the oral arguments, Swaggart's lawyer, Michael McConnell, told the court, ``This ministry is not in the business to make money. The purpose of all this is to spread the gospel.'' He said such taxation must be prohibited ``unless we are to say that all religious leaders are charlatans.'' But O'Connor wrote for the court that the California tax ``is not a tax on the right to disseminate religious information, ideas, or beliefs per se; rather it is a tax on the privilege of making retail sales of tangible personal property.'' Swaggart's challenge of the California tax was supported by an array of religious groups _ from Hare Krishnas to mainline Protestants. Lawyers for the National Council of Churches, representing most Protestant denominations, called the California tax ``a serious threat ... a tax on the dissemination of religious messages, and thus a forbidden tax on the exercise of religion.'' Backing California's authority to impose such a tax were two organizations not usually allied in court _ the American Civil Liberties Union and the National Conference of State Legislatures. In other action, the court: _ Ruled unanimously that a doctrine restricting U.S. court review of foreign policy does not automatically shield American corporations from being sued for allegedly bribing foreign government officials. The court permitted a lawsuit against W.S. Kirkpatrick & Co., a New Jersey corporation accused of bribing Nigerian government officials to win a contract in 1982 for development of a medical center at Kaduna Air Force Base in Nigeria. The so-called act of state doctrine, a rule adopted by the federal courts, is designed to bar U.S. courts from inquiring into the validity of a foreign government's acts committed within its own territory. _ Ruled that a union official convicted of embezzlement may not be forced to repay the union with his own pension benefits. The court, in a case from Colorado, unanimously threw out a $275,000 judgment awarded to the Sheet Metal Workers against a former chief executive officer of a union local. In the evangelist-taxes case, Swaggart's lawyers had relied heavily on a 1943 high court ruling that overturned the convictions of Jehovah's Witnesses who violated a city ordinance requiring all people engaged in door-to-door canvassing to get a license and pay a fee. The Jehovah's Witnesses were distributing religious literature, and the 1943 ruling said, ``This form of religious activity occupies the same high estate under the (Constitution's) First Amendment as do worship in the churches and preaching from the pulpits.'' But today's decision drew a distinction between those fees and the California tax. ``Our concern (in the 1943 ruling) that a flat license tax would act as a precondition to the free exercise of religious beliefs is simply not pressent where a tax applies to all sales and uses of tangible personal property in the state,'' O'Connor wrote. The case is Swaggrt Ministries vs. California Board of Equalization, 88-1374.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Earnings Tumble in 4th Qtr
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, The company... with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that company announced charge of $2.3 billion, actual charge was $2.4 billion; ADDS 10 new grafs to UPDATE with stock price, quote, background.
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. today announced fourth-quarter earnings fell 74 percent, largely because of previously announcd restructuring costs aimed at making the world's biggest computer company more profitable. IBM said earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31 totaled $600 million or $1.04 a share, compared with $2.3 billion, or $3.97 a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue totaled $20.5 billion, up 2.3 percent from $20 billion. The company attributed the decline mostly to a previously announced charge against its fourth-quarter results to reflect the expenses of restructuring its U.S. business, which has been in a prolonged slump. IBM on Dec. 5 announced it expected a $2.3 billion charge against earnings due to the restructuring, although today it stated the charge actually came to $2.4 billion. IBM's earnings are scrutinized because they reflect broader trends in the computer business. The company is the largest manufacturer of of information processing equipment and systems and is a historical leader in shaping the direction of the industry. For the year, IBM said earnings fell 40 percent to $3.8 billion or $6.47 a share, from $5.8 billion or $6.47 a share in 1988. Revenue totaled $62.7 billion, up 5.1 percent from $59.7 billion. IBM stock was up 12{ cents to $100.25 a share in mid-day New York Stock Exchange trading following the earnings report. The company on Dec. 5 announced a restructuring aimed at cutting costs and enhancing its share price. The program included plans to cut 10,000 more jobs _ IBM's fourth job-cutting program since 1986 _ and repurchase $4 billion worth of its own stock. The $2.4 billion charge against earnings stemmed from costs of the job cuts and related steps. IBM also stated that its earnings and revenue were hurt by the strengthening of the U.S. dollar during the quarter. IBM has been squeezed because of sluggish spending by customers, increasing competition and the personal computer revolution, which is cutting into sales of the big mainframes and minicomputers that account for most of its profits. John F. Akers, IBM's chairman, said in a news release that demand for IBM products and services continued to be strong in 1989, pointing to growth on non-U.S. business revenue. He also said the company expanded business alliances and strengthened product and services offerings. ``These initiatives, coupled with our continuing drive to reduce our costs and expense structure, will enable us to take advantage of the growth opportunities we see for our business while enhancing shareholder value,'' Akers said. IBM expanded rapidly in the early 1980s but has been cutting back since 1985, when it became apparent that the industry's rapid 15 percent annual growth was slowing. The job cuts announced in December are intended to reduce the company's U.S. workforce to 206,000 by the end of 1990, a reduction of more than 37,000 from 1985 levels. IBM had 387,000 employees worldwide at yearend 1988 and has been cutting jobs abroad as well. The cuts are to occur through attrition and early retirement incentives.

DOC.HEAD: Turns A Profit After Losing Money
DOC.TEXT: Genentech Inc., a leading biotechnology company that has foundered financially, reported $15.5 million in fourth quarter earnings Wednesday, vs. a loss of about the same amount a year earlier. Genentech also reported a 24 percent jump in fourth-quarter revenues compared to the same period last year, and officials attributed the growth to increased sales of its heart attack drug and human growth hormone. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1989, Genentech said it earned $15.5 million, or 18 cents per share, compared with a loss of $15.4 million or 18 cents a share a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenues totaled $111.4 million vs. $89.4 million for the fourth quarter of 1988, a 24.6 percent increase. The company said sales of its much-touted heart attack drug, Activase, increased 63 percent to $56.7 million, up from $34.7 million for the same quarter last year. Genentech's other marketed product, a human growth hormone sold under the brand name of Protropin, posted fourth-quarter net sales of $34.3 million, up from $31.7 million. For 1989, Genentech reported net income increased 114 percent to $44 million, or 51 cents per share, compared to $20.6 million, or 24 cents per share, in 1988. Revenues for 1989 were up 20 percent to $400.5 million from $334.8 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Holiday Corp. Shareholders Approve Merger
DOC.TEXT: Holiday Corp. shareholders today approved a plan to sell the Holiday Inn hotel system to Bass PLC of Great Britain for $2.2 billion. With the approval Bass acquires 55 owned or leased properties as well as franchise agreements, joint venture agreements and management contracts covering 1,400 Holiday Inn hotels in North America. Holiday will run its profitable casino business and its newer hotel brands, Embassy Suites, Hampton Inn and Homewood Suites, under a new subsidiary, Promus Companies, Inc. The agreement calls for Promus shareholders to receive a $30-per-share cash dividend. ``We believe this proposal not only creates maximum value for our stockholders, but also positions each of the hotel brands for growth by their respective owners,'' said Michael D. Rose, chairman and president of Holiday Corp. Today's vote was 16,696,795 for and 69,684 against, with 251,504 shares abstaining. Terms of the sale call for Holiday Corp. stockholders to draw one-quarter share of Bass stock for each of their Holiday Corp. shares. Holiday Corp. said the sale is subject to approval by gaming regulators in Nevada and New Jersey, but is expected to be complete by the end of the month. Bass has more than 7,300 pubs and other food and drink outlets in the United Kingdom. The company also brews Bass, Carling Black Label and other beers and has annual sales approaching $6 billion. In 1988, Bass bought the rights to franchise Holiday Inn hotels outside North America. As the result of that and other purchases it already owns 14 Holiday Inn hotels in the southeast United States and is a major franchisee in Canada. Holiday has sold off numerous assets in recent years while concentrating on property management rather than ownership. The sale will allow it to retire $2.1 billion in outstanding debt, much of which stems from the company's financial recapitalization in 1987, the company said when the deal was announced in August.
The stock market showed a small gain today, shrugging off what analysts described as disappointing economic andCTS penultimate graf, Rangel said ... to eliminate reference to ``C minus.''

The president of the liberal Americans for Democratic Action today blasted the Bush administration for its invasion of Panama and said it also has failed to be ``kinder and gentler'' to the poor. ``Americans should be prepared to fight and die for what is right,'' Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., the ADA president, told a news conference. ``The question I ask is whether it was morally and constitutionally right.'' The comments came as part of what the 47-year-old Americans for Democratic Action, often called the nation's leading liberal group, described as a first-year report card for President Bush. Rangel also said that House Democratic leaders often regard former congressman Bush as a friend and thus are too soft on his policies. He said the news media have enjoyed the spectacle of the Panama invasion and that as a result ``the press hysterically supports the tattering of the Constitution.'' Rangel said he was unimpressed by the Bush administration's war on drugs. ``I don't see anything to knock, I don't see anything to support,'' he said. He expressed disappointment in national drug policy director William Bennett. ``I don't know where Bill Bennett is,'' he said. ``Obviously the president has done a lot of things right if you are middle class and white and really involved in military maneuvers,'' Rangel said. ``I give the president an A for military preparedness, holding down the minimum wage and staying out of getting involved with the homeless. ...''

DOC.HEAD: Neil Bush Matter Expected to be Resolved Soon, Official Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS New 5th graf, In an ..., with Bush denying wrongdoing. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators negotiating with President Bush's son to settle alleged banking law violations anticipate the matter will be resolved late this week or early next week, an official said today. Enforcement officials met with Neil Bush several times last week in Washington to discuss allegations stemming from his role as a board member of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver, said Karl Hoyle, a deputy director of the Office of Thrift Supervision. After the thrift institution failed in December 1988, regulators blamed the collapse on management's decision to invest heavily in Colorado's ailing commercial real estate market. They also cited an unusually large number of transactions between officers of the thrift and borrowers. Neil Bush, who owned an oil exploration firm, JNB Exploration, had business deals with two of Silverado's major borrowers. Bush was a director of Silverado from 1985 until August 1988, when his father won the Republican presidential nomination. In an interview last week, he denied any wrongdoing and said he had ``nothing to hide.'' Three top officers of Silverado _ its chairman, chief executive officer and chief financial officer _ have already agreed to accept a thrift office order banning them from working again at a bank, S&L or credit union. Hoyle said Bush has not yet agreed to settle the matter, but he said he anticipated a settlement or a decision by regulators on whether to move against Bush absent a settlement by early next week. Bush would not have to admit wrongdoing as part of the settlement. Hoyle said the agreement would not preclude regulators from pursuing criminal charges against Bush in the future if that is indicated. It also would not interfere with the right of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. to pursue a civil suit against Bush and other Silverado officers to recover part of the taxpayers' losses. Bush's mother, first lady Barbara Bush, told reporters Tuesday, ``I'm sorry for him. He hasn't done anything wrong. ... He's cooperating in every possible way.''

DOC.HEAD: Workers Reject Latest Ford Offer; Strikes Close Three Ford Plants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with union leaders rejecting latest Ford offer. No pickup. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Union leaders today rejected a two-year pay offer from Ford Motor Co. Ltd. and called a strike vote for next week. The company said it already has laid off more than 10,500 workers because of wildcat strikes. Ford's latest offer was a 10.2 percent pay raise in the first year and a choice between 8 percent, or the inflation rate-plus-2.5 percent, in the second year. It was rejected during talks at the company's London offices. Outside, about 500 Ford workers staged a noisy demonstration urging managers to increase their offer. If the union votes Tuesday to reject the proposal, union members will begin an all-out strike beginning with the final shift Jan. 26, officials said. About 9,000 employees already were off the job today, some for a 24-hour strike and some continuing indefinite strikes begun Monday. Ford said it responded by laying off more than another 10,500 employees. It employs 32,000 workers at 22 British plants. Most earn an average of $371 a week. The latest offer was an improvement over Ford's previous offer of a two-year deal of a 10.2 percent pay raise in the first year and 7.5 percent in the second year. The company estimated the strikes would cut production by 2,400 vehicles, or $15 million a day. ``We had an understanding from the trade unions at last week's talks that there would be no industrial action taking place, certainly not before talks started today, and although these strikes are unofficial, we are very disappointed,'' said a Ford spokesman, who requested anonymity. An engine plant in Bridgend, Wales, engine and final assembly operations at Dagenham, east London, and an assembly plant at Halewood, in northwest England, were brought to a standstill, Ford said. Production was disrupted at other plants. Jack Adams, chairman of the national negotiation committee's trade union side, said: ``They will certainly have to improve the offer and if there is not an agreement today there will be a dispute.'' Last month, workers voted 4-to-1 for an all-out strike if necessary.

DOC.HEAD: Hacker Didn't Mean to Cause Any Damage, Friend Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with testimony today; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, Muus testified ... A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Cornell University graduate student accused of crippling a federal computer network wanted to break into the system but had no intention of causing any damage, a friend testified today. ``He wanted to make a virus that would spread over the network, but there was never any question of having it do anything bad,'' Paul Graham, a Harvard graduate student and friend of Robert T. Morris, told jurors this morning. Graham testified that Morris told him in October 1988 he had discovered a bug, or flaw, in the Internet network. ``I think he had just discovered it. He had to tell someone about it. He was very excited,'' Graham said. Graham said that he believed Morris just wanted to break into university computers, but that his friend must have known there were other computers on the Internet system, such as business and military facilities. Graham testified he didn't tell anyone about Morris' plan because it was told to him in confidence and ``at this stage I didn't know how close he was.'' In testimony Tuesday, a computer specialist said researchers at an Army lab, fearing that a foreign enemy was trying to steal weapons information, shut down their computers for nearly a week after the runaway program, variously described as a ``virus'' or ``worm,'' appeared. Michael Muuss, leader of the Advanced Computer Systems team at the Army Ballistics Research Laboratory, said the Aberdeen, Md., installation shut down its computers after the rogue program showed up in their system Nov. 2, 1988. ``Our specific concern was that it was an attack by a foreign power,'' he said. ``We had a real fear that someone had broken in and was trying to take data inside and send it to somebody outside, or that it would modify data.'' However, defense attorney Thomas Guidoboni suggested that Army officials overreacted. The suspended Cornell University graduate student's computer tampering trial is in its second week of testimony. Guidoboni said Morris, 25, of Arnold, Md., created the worm as an experiment and made a mistake that allowed it to go berserk. Morris did not intend to cause any damage, he said. Prosecutors were expected to conclude their case today against Morris, who is accused of crippling an estimated 6,000 computers. If convicted, Morris could receive up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Muuss testified that the Army lab shut down 200 computers linked to Milnet, a global network carrying unclassified military information, when Morris' worm infected one machine hooked up to another network, known as Internet. Milnet carries information such as computational chemistry and data on improving projectiles and armors. The research center disconnected itself from Milnet and two supercomputers at Aberdeen were shut off to outsiders for six days while a team worked to eradicate the worm, Muuss said. Guidoboni asked why the shutdown lasted so long when most universities attacked by the worm were operating within a few days. ``At a university, the end result may have been that someone didn't get a paper published,'' said Muuss, who added that his computers contained information on the evolution of weapons to 20 years in the future. ``Protecting defense information is a critical part of the defense business,'' he said. ``We had to certify that no data was stolen or modified and make sure our system could resist such an attack if it happened again.'' Muuss acknowledged under cross-examination that computer security at the lab had been improved because of the worm's invasion. Jurors also listened to testimony from computer system managers at Purdue University, Carnegie-Mellon, Georgia Tech and the University of Rochester. Some witnesses said although no data was permanently lost or damaged, the worm was costly in terms of eradication and follow-up investigations. But Daniel Nydick, a systems manager at Carnegie-Mellon, said he got rid of the worm simply by crawling under his computer and unplugging it.

DOC.NOTE: $adv19
For Release AMs Friday, Jan. 19
DOC.HEAD: Out On A Limb Where It Is Comfortable
DOC.TEXT: While many fellow economists are contemplating a soft landing if not a recession for the economy in 1990, Russell Redenbaugh, an experienced forecaster, is preparing for a soft takeoff. A soft takeoff is a safe one, although perhaps undramatic. It is not a sudden ascent; its characteristics are moderation, sustainability, steadiness. It is a positive, reassuring economy. In more specific economic terms it means growth of between 2 percent and 3 percent, accompanied by moderation of the extremes and negatives that marred the 1980s. It means lower inflation, lower interest rates, a lower federal budget deficit. It means more exports and a reduction in the trade imbalance. It is one accompanied by lower capital gains taxes and rising returns on capital. It is an economic situation that, Redenbaugh says, professional economists with a negative outlook have ``grossly misread.'' Because they have misread events, he says, they have come to ``patently wrong conclusions.'' That is, they are talking about economic deterioration, obsessed with ``a handful of gloomy statistics for specific sectors of the U.S. economy,'' unable to measure an historic event that he calls the key indicator. To him, the key to the immediate economic future is the freeing of the Eastern European economies from 40 years of deindustrialization, a discontinuity that ``the economics profession ... cannot comprehend.'' Redenbaugh knows that his forecast puts him way out on a limb, especially in the conservative business in which he operates, but he claims to like it there, saying ``I feel comfortable; it's never crowded.'' Most economists and investment advisers run in a herd, he says, adding: ``In this business you must have an aversion to crowds. Crowds are comfortable, but they never produce good results.'' Redenbaugh needs results, is measured by them, and expects to get them as chief strategist for Cooke & Bieler, Inc., a Philadelphia-based asset management firm for Fortune 500 pension funds and profit-sharing accounts. He believes that recent economic events will produce a real peace dividend, an immediate expansion of commerce, and a lengthening investment horizon that, as a consequence, will means higher price-earnings ratios for stocks. He isn't entirely alone in his optimism. Edward Yardeni of Prudential-Bache is probably as far out on a limb. And the Conference Board said today that the U.S. economy is rebounding rather than eroding, with exports leading the way. But if you attended a convention of economists almost anywhere this month you might not be pleased with what you heard. Based on their published reports, almost any uplifting news would be balanced off with depressing reminders. Redenbaugh believes many professional economists are unable to deal with changes in Europe because it doesn't fit their ``orthodoxy of using statistical models to explain everything.'' He contends they want to say something to the effect that ``Three out of the last four times when the Iron Curtain collapsed the following happened,'' which is, of course, absurd. While the suddenness of the collapse of managed economies in Europe amazed Redenbaugh, he had suggested it might happen, although more slowly, in a paper one year ago. At that time he said economic considerations were dismantling the Iron Curtain and undermining Communist ideology, and that if the Soviet Union was to survive it would have to abandon Marxist economic systems. What has since occurred, he says, is now the key factor in economic forecasting, whether or not it fits the conventional forecasting models. As the 1990s begin, he states, ``it is not the health of the economy that is questionable, for it is healthy; it is the health of the economics profession that is questionable.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv AMs Friday, Jan. 19.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says American Corporations May Be Sued for Foreign Bribery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for a Scotus-Business Rdp.
DOC.TEXT: A unanimous Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that American corporations may be sued for allegedly bribing foreign government officials. The court permitted a lawsuit against W.S. Kirkpatrick and Co., which has been accused of bribing Nigerian government officials to win a contract in 1982 for development of a medical center at Kaduna Air Force Base in Nigeria. The could held that a doctrine restricting U.S. court review of foreign policy does not automatically shield corporations from such suits. The act-of-state doctrine is designed to bar U.S. courts from inquiring into the validity of a foreign government's acts committed within its own territory. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the court, said the doctrine does not bar a court from deciding the suit since ``the validity of no foreign sovereign act is at issue.'' The case might embarrass the Nigerian government, Scalia said. But that alone is not enough reason to kill the lawsuit. ``Act-of-state issues only arise when a court must decide ... the effect of official action by a foreign sovereign,'' he said. ``The act-of-state doctrine does not establish an exception for cases and controversies that may embarrass foreign governments, but merely requires that, in the process of deciding, the acts of foreign sovereigns taken within their own jurisdictions shall be deemed valid.'' Scalia noted that over the years the interpretation of the doctrine has changed so that recently the high court has used it to guarantee separation of powers between three branches of government. The idea is to assure that courts will not interfere improperly in the president's conduct of foreign affairs, Scalia said. He noted that the administration of President George Bush, and particularly the State Department, do not oppose the suit against the Kirkpatrick company. The company was sued by Environmental Tectonics Corp., another American corporation. Environmental Tectonics submitted a lower bid than Kirkpatrick for the Nigerian project and said it would have won the contract but for Kirkpatrick's bribery of Nigerian officials. The Justice Department investigated the contract, prompting the company and its chief executive, Harry Carpenter, to plead guilty to one count of violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. Kirkpatrick was fined $75,000. Carpenter was accused of paying Benson ``Tunde'' Akindele, a Nigerian citizen, a ``commission'' to be turned over to Nigerian government officials. The commission was 20 percent of the value of the contract. A lower-court judge threw out Environmental Tectonics' civil suit, but it was reinstated by the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, and the Supreme Court was upholding that reinstatement. In other business-related cases, the court ruled that a union official convicted of embezzling may not be forced to repay the union with his own pension benefits. The court unanimously threw out a $275,000 judgment won by the Sheet Metal Workers International Association against Curtis Guidry, former chief executive officer of the union's Local 9 in Denver. Guidry, head of the local from 1964 to 1981, pleaded guilty in 1982 to embezzling more than $377,000 from the union. The union said it was missing nearly $1 million of its funds. While Guidry was in prison, the union sued in federal court and was awarded $275,000. A federal judge ordered Guidry's pension benefits placed in a special trust to repay the union, and the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the ruling. But the Supreme Court said Wednesday that the federal Employment Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) protects the pension benefits of even dishonest union officials. Justice Harry A. Blackmun, writing for the court, said the law ``reflects a considered congressional policy choice ... to safeguard a stream of income for pensioners ... even if that decision prevents others from securing relief for the wrongs done them.'' ``There may be a natural distaste for the result we reach here,'' Blackmun said. But it is the job of Congress and not the courts to correct it.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: A late rally carried shares prices to a modest gain for the session Wednesday on the London Stock Exchange. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 24.8 points, or 1.1 percent, to close at 2,373.9. The Financial Times 30-share index rose 19.6 points to close at 1,895.3. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 13.04 points to close at 1,294.63. Volume came to 427.2 million shares, down from 480.7 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.NOTE: $adv21
For release Sunday Jan. 21
DOC.HEAD: Chairman of Korean Conglomerate Writes Best Selling Book on Work
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The national best seller is written by the founder of one of South Korea's largest conglomerates, an unabashed workaholic who says he shaves and eats breakfast in his car to save time. Kim Woo-choong heads Daewoo Group, maker of products ranging from Leading Edge computers to Pontiac LeMans exports to the U.S. market. Kim says he wrote the book to tell young people how to find inspiration and direction in life. Or as the suggested title for the English version suggests, ``Work!!!'' In South Korea, one of the fastest growing Asian countries, the drive to succeed and make money is a passion. Kim's position as head of a conglomerate with 1988 sales of $17.2 billion hasn't hurt his credibility as an author. ``Nothing comes free in this life and nothing is accidental,'' writes Kim, 53-year-old father of four. ``The more you dig, the deeper the hole. And the deeper the hole the more water from the well. That's what it's all about.'' More than 900,000 copies of ``It's a Big World and There's Lots to be Done'' have been published since it came out last August. By this month the book was in its 89th printing. South Korea's largest bookstore named it one of the five best sellers of the decade. Daewoo says it has even sold the rights to a professor in China for a Chinese version. Although the book has been translated into English, Daewoo is looking for a U.S. publisher, and negotiations are under way for publication in other countries. The 211-page paperback sells for $4.50 and features 39 essays with pithy fatherly advice on school, working women, choice of jobs, relationships and making money. His commentary is full of personal anecdotes ranging from his school life (``not exemplary'') to religion (``better than not having one'') to observations on why nations in southern Europe waste so much time napping. Kim says he doesn't exercise, takes no vacations, sleeps five hours a night and spends the rest of the time working and making business deals. He wrote the book nights while waiting out a shipyard strike last spring. ``My generation didn't eat well and couldn't dress well, but look at the Korea that we've built,'' he says, advising young people not to become smug by the country's new consumerism and leisure time. ``Days are too short for me,'' he writes. ``I wish they were 30 or 40 hours long. I sometimes shave and wash with a towel in the car on the way to work. I even occasionally have breakfast in the car.'' He holds staff meetings before or after the regular workday and prides himself that at Daewoo, which means ``Big House'' in Korean, a 9 to 5 workday can mean 5 a.m. until 9 p.m. ``Wasting time is worse than wasting money, for you can always make more money,'' says Kim. ``When it comes to making money, I'm an expert.'' As founder and chairman of Daewoo, Kim oversees 70 overseas offices and 93,000 employees involved in trade, construction, shipbuilding, the manufacture of cars, industrial robots, telecommunications, consumer electronic products, textiles and home appliances. The book skips over the ways Daewoo rose from a small textile exporter to the world's 46th largest industrial company in 22 years, omitting mention of its ties to past authoritarian governments, low wages, easy bank credit and protectionist barriers that allowed Daewoo and other conglomerates to grow. ``There's a frantic trend nowadays to think only in terms of immediate profits,'' Kim writes. ``People are looking for comfort and satisfaction rather than having a fighting spirit to overcome difficulties and succeed in the long run.'' He advises Korean women to stamp out sex discrination by considering a job professionally, not ``a bus stop on the way to marriage.'' ``You have to find places that people have never been to and you have to do things that people haven't done before,'' he advises both sexes. ``Of course there's danger in pioneering. Pioneers take paths that haven't been paved.'' ``There is too much egocentricism,'' he says. ``If everyone's an egoist, then there's always going to be trouble.'' He recommends forming close lifetime friendships, a code followed closely among Korean businessmen who often judge each other by the schools they've attended. Although Kim exalts nonstop work, he encourages day-dreams. ``Dreams are like the rudder of a ship setting sail. The rudder may be small and unseen, but it controls the ship's course.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday Jan. 21

DOC.HEAD: State, Bottling Company Reach Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The maker of Coca-Cola has agreed to pay $50,000 to the state and provide consumers with $50,000 in coupons in a settlement of a price-fixing complaint, the attorney general's office said Wednesday. The agreement with Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Consolidated of Charlotte, N.C., was announced one day after the attorney general's office filed a complaint in U.S. District Court accusing the company of conspiring to fix soft drink prices from 1982 to 1985. Judge Charles Haden has tentatively approved the settlement, the attorney general's office said. Under the settlement, the bottling company will affix a minimum of 250,000 20-cent coupon stickers to 2-liter bottles of Diet Coke, Diet Sprite and caffeine-free Diet Coke on the soft drinks it distributes in West Virginia from Feb. 20 to March 31. The coupons can be redeemed at the retailer where the products are purchased. If the full $50,000 is not issued through the coupons, the company will pay the state the difference, the attorney general's office said. The company distributes soft drinks in most of West Virginia.

The stock market drifted lower in an erratic session today, faced with what analysts described as disappointing economic and earnings news. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 11.09 to 2,681.53 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers slightly outnumbered gainers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 706 up, 754 down and 490 unchanged. Analysts said a widening of the U.S. trade deficit to $10.5 billion in November from $10.25 billion in October caught some market participants off guard. A separate report on industrial production was interpeted as evidence that manufacturing remained sluggish. A rising 0.4 percent increase in December was attributed in large measure to a cold weather-induced bulge in output by utilities. Brokers also said an earnings report from International Business Machines provided little assurance for investors who have been waiting uneasily for fourth-quarter profit figures from many companies. IBM, which said its fourth-quarter earnings shrank to $1.04 a share from $3.97 a share in the like period a year earlier, dipped ] to 97|. Aluminum Co. of America fell 4[ to 68| on word of lower quarterly profits. Among other actively traded blue chips, American Express dropped \ to 32[; Philip Morris \ to 39[, and American Telephone & Telegraph \ to 42~. Aristech Chemical was the volume leader, up { at 25[. A management-led group has proposed a buyout for $26 a share. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost .46 to 187.91. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .58 at 368.99. Volume on the Big Board came to 141.64 million shares with an hour to go.
