For release Sunday Jan. 21 or thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Great Northern, Georgia-Pacific Fighting Nasty Takeover Battle
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: One giant U.S. paper company's hostile attempt to buy another has developed into a multibillion-dollar emotional brawl, peppered with accusations of mismanagement, lies and coverups. Georgia-Pacific Corp.'s $3.8 billion offer to acquire Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. has become a war with several fronts, ranging from courts to full-page newspaper advertisements aimed at swaying shareholders. The focus of the fray has moved to Georgia Pacific's attempt to oust Great Northern's board at a special shareholders meeting in Portland on March 2. ``It's pure fighting,'' said George B. Adler, a securities analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. ``It sounds like a political campaign.'' If the merger succeeds it will create the nation's largest paper and forest-products company, with operations in every state but Alaska. Great Northern employs 20,000 workers nationwide and had estimated sales of $3.9 billion in 1989, of products ranging from corrugated shipping containers to the yellow sheets used in adhesive Post-it Notes. Ever since Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific announced Oct. 31 it would pay $58 a share for Great Northern, then raised the price to $63 a share, the takeover has been a dominant story in Maine, a lumber state not known as a corporate battleground. The only point all sides agree on is the stakes are high. Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. envisions ``a very high-quality strategic business combination,'' better able to compete globally. Great Northern Chairman William R. Laidig says the deal would create a ``highly leveraged junk company'' that would run afoul of antitrust laws. Hahn is confident the merger will proceed, saying 75 percent of Great Northern's stock has been tendered by shareholders. Laidig calls Great Northern's chances of staying independent ``excellent.'' Mainers are perhaps paying closest attention to the fight because two company mill towns, Millinocket and East Millinocket, and 2.1 million acres held by Great Northern are caught in the cross fire. Natives' ingrained suspicion of any out-of-state corporation with interests in Maine and their hopes of preserving the vast northern woods have inflamed their passions. ``Whether this is right or wrong, Georgia-Pacific does not have the quality of reputation that Great Northern has,'' said Dave Smith, a University of Maine history professor. ``Part of it is because Great Northern's here and Georgia-Pacific is `from away.''' Great Northern was founded and incorporated in Maine, although its corporate office is now in Norwalk, Conn. Georgia-Pacific points to two decades of ownership of more than 500,000 acres of Maine and a mill in Woodland as evidence it is a good corporate citizen, but its merger attempt has faced intense scrutiny in Maine. During the week that Georgia-Pacific announced it was going after Great Northern, Hahn said, his company disclosed its intentions to top government officials in states where Great Northern has major holdings: Wisconsin, Georgia, Virginia, Arkansas, Mississippi and Maine. Maine officials immediately sought written assurances that jobs would be protected and sensitive woodlands would not fall into the hands of developers. When Georgia-Pacific offered assurances in letters, conference calls and lengthy meetings at the State House in Augusta, the Maine officials said the response was not good enough. ``We have not really encountered the level of concern or questions that developed in Maine in other states,'' Hahn said in a telephone interview. He said Georgia-Pacific, with 44,000 employees and projected 1989 sales of $10 billion, intends to improve Great Northern's Maine assets. Great Northern, which has refused to even discuss the merger with Georgia-Pacific, has gotten plenty of public relations mileage out of the uncertainty the deal has raised. Lawyers are fighting part of the battle in U.S. District Court in Portland, where Georgia-Pacific challenged Maine's anti-takeover law and Great Northern's ``poison pill'' bylaws intended to thwart a hostile takeover. Great Northern's responses allege Georgia-Pacific has violated federal securities laws by masking secret plans to sell the Maine woodlands and mills as its executives waged a campaign of cynical propaganda to mislead Mainers and make the deal more politically palatable. Great Northern alleges Georgia-Pacific Executive Vice President A.D. ``Pete'' Correll Jr., who has often visited the state to promote the deal, privately told consultants the Maine properties were ``losers'' and ``dawgs'' that would be sold to make the merger more affordable. Great Northern later accused Hahn of lying when he said Georgia-Pacific had ruled out sales of the Maine properties. Actually, Great Northern said, Georgia-Pacific told its bankers privately that it would sell the mills. Georgia-Pacific said it had studied the possibility of selling the Maine properties, but Hahn concluded the sales weren't necessary. ``It's unfortunate that these kinds of allegations have been made,'' Hahn said. ``As far as the personal attack goes, I personally feel it was unconscionable.'' Correll said he had no recollection of referring to the Maine properties as ``losers'' and ``dawgs,'' although that is certainly not how he views them today. Correll, too, was surprised by Great Northern's allegations. ``I'm not normally called a liar in the press,'' Correll said. ``We're not that kind of company. I'm concerned that both Great Northern and Georgia-Pacific's image has been harmed.'' Georgia-Pacific, meanwhile, has accused Great Northern's directors of seeking to entrench themselves in high-paying jobs at shareholder expense and setting up lucrative ``golden parachute'' payments for executives to be paid if the merger goes through. Great Northern has denied the accusations. Great Northern's stock was selling around $40 a share prior to the takeover offer, so shareholders would make a healthy profit if the deal proceeds, Georgia-Pacific says. Georgia-Pacific also accuses Great Northern of financially starving the aging Millinocket mill, saying Georgia-Pacific will offer workers a better future. Great Northern claims $4.5 billion in credit assembled by Georgia-Pacific would leave the merged company drowning in debt. Analysts agree the debt would be a concern, although several said the merged company probably would survive. ``It's safe to say that this company would end up either at the bottom end of the investment grade or the top end of the junk bond grade,'' said Nelson Noel, an anlyst with Moody's Investor Service. ``I don't think the company is going to fall into the junk, junk category.'' The other hurdles faced by Georgia-Pacific are a federal antitrust suit filed by Great Northern in Bridgeport, Conn., and an antitrust suit filed in state court by Maine Attorney General James E. Tierney. Georgia-Pacific does not view those lawsuits as serious threats, Hahn said. Analysts say that other large paper companies are eyeing the outcome. Although corporate raiders have gone after paper makers in the past, this is the first time a competitor has waged such a fight. ``There would be a feeling that if the courts and the Justice Department and the FTC would allow this merger, some others would consider making some acquisitions,'' Noel said. End advance foor Sunday Jan. 21.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean, Corn Futures Retreat; Wheat Gains
DOC.TEXT: Soybean and corn futures prices fell slightly Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as rain continued in the Midwest. Wheat futures closed slightly higher. The action marked the fourth consecutive daily decline in the soybean market, where attitudes have turned bearish due in part to increased rainfall in the U.S. corn and soybean belt and in southern Brazil, an important soybean-producing region where the new crop is in the early stages of growth. The rise in wheat futures reflected sentiments that recent losses were not justified by supply-and-demand factors, including Tuesday's Agriculture Department export-inspections report. The USDA said it inspected 22.6 million bushels of wheat for export last week, a number higher than the market had expected. Soybean inspections also were above expectations while corn inspections were about as anticipated. At the close, wheat futures were { cent to 3\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.00{ a bushel; corn was } cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.41} a bushel; oats were 2{ to 4 cents lower with March at $1.39\ a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 2 cents lower with January at $5.57\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Recalls 625,000 Cars and Light Trucks
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. on Wednesday recalled about 625,000 of its 1989 and 1990 cars and light trucks with certain 2.2- or 2.5-liter engines so it can replace a valve cover and valve cover gasket. The No. 3 automaker said the gasket may move and cause an oil leak. If the oil leak is in a certain area, an engine fire could occur, the company said. There have been no reports of injuries or accidents because of the problem, Chrysler said. The recall involves cars equipped with engines with carburetors rather than fuel-injection systems. They were made between early-September 1988 and mid-September 1989. They were sold as Chrysler LeBaron, LeBaron GTS; Dodge Dynasty, Daytona, Lancer, Shadow, Spirit, Aries, Omni, Caravan and Dakota; Plymouth Sundance, Acclaim, Reliant, Horizon and Voyager. Owners will be notified by mail and repairs will be performed free of charge.

DOC.HEAD: Imports Down In November
DOC.TEXT: Steel imports in November decreased 13 percent from October, representing 18.9 percent of the domestic supply, an industry association said Wednesday. Steel imports in November totaled 1.49 million tons, compared with 1.7 million tons in October and 1.8 million tons in November 1988, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported. Imports for the first 11 months of the year fell 16 percent to 16.29 million tons, compared with 19.47 million tons in the same period a year earlier. The American Institute for Imported Steel, which represents leading steel importers and exporters, said imports for the first 11 months amounted to 15.7 percent of domestic demand when semifinished steel bound for U.S. mills was excluded. Steel exports in November totaled 251,373 tons, the importers' group said. In November 1988, American steel manufacturers exported 242,806 tons.

DOC.HEAD: AMR Blames High Fuel Costs For Lower Quarterly, Annual Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Skyrocketing jet fuel prices in December shot down AMR Corp. profits last year, the parent of American Airlines said Wednesday in reporting a 66.7 percent fall in fourth-quarter earnings. The fourth-quarter decline pulled down AMR's annual earnings 4.6 percent below the record level of 1988 despite record passenger traffic. For the three months ended Dec. 31, AMR said its net profit dropped to $38.9 million, or 57 cents a share, from $116.7 million, or $1.87 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. The fall occurred despite a 9.2 percent increase in fourth-quarter revenue to $2.59 billion from $2.37 billion. AMR Chairman Robert Crandall began in September to predict lower earnings for AMR and the airline industry because of rising labor costs and AMR's own expansion plans. In addition to those conditions, jet fuel prices began rising sharply in December as cold weather and refinery problems raised the cost of petroleum products. American, the nation's largest airline, has twice raised fares in recent weeks to help offset fuel costs, as have its competitors. But ``even the latest round of (fare) increases does not come close to covering the costs,'' said American spokesman Al Becker in Fort Worth. American's fuel costs in the fourth quarter were up 30.2 percent from 1988. In the last week of December, jet fuel cost around 96 cents a gallon, a 65.5 percent jump over the year. The company said the fuel price rises accounted for 27 percent of its increased expenses. ``Despite record profitability during the first nine months of 1989, an extraordinarily rapid rise in fuel costs during the final quarter of the year badly penalized the full-year results,'' Crandall said in a statement. For all of 1989, AMR's profit fell to $454.8 million, or $7.15 a share, from $476.8 million, or $7.66 a share, the previous year. Full-year revenue jumped to $10.48 billion from $8.82 billion in 1988. During the fourth quarter, AMR escaped an attempted $7 billion buyout by New York billionaire Donald Trump, whose offer collapsed after troubles arose with a proposed employee buyout of United Airlines parent UAL Corp. Becker would not disclose how much AMR spent fighting off Trump, or its effect on earnings. Last month, AMR announced a $471 million deal to buy the prized Latin American routes and certain other assets of Eastern Airlines and its parent Texas Air Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Pinola to Retire as First Interstate Chief
DOC.TEXT: First Interstate Bancorp said Wednesday that Chairman and Chief Executive Joseph J. Pinola would be succeeded by company President Edward Carson on June 1, after Pinola's 65th birthday. William E.B. Siart, who heads First Interstate of California, will succeed Carson as president of the parent company, the 10th largest bank holding company in the country. Pinola's retirement this spring had been widely expected, and the naming of Carson was seen as a sign of continuity. ``Carson has been in the shadow of Pinola for a long time, but he's also been the right-hand man,'' said Dan Williams, a banking analyst at Sutro & Co. in San Francisco. ``It makes sense.'' It was the second orderly top-level change announced at a big Los Angeles bank in two days. Security Pacific Corp., the fourth biggest U.S. banking concern, said Tuesday that its top two managers, chief executive Richard J. Flamson III and chief operating officer George F. Moody, were being replaced by their heirs apparent, Robert H. Smith and Jerry A. Grundhofer. In his 12 years as First Interstate's chief, Pinola aggressively pursued interstate expansion, presiding as First Interstate swelled to its present $58 billion in assets, operating 28 banks in 14 states and franchising banks in 11 other states. But Pinola leaves at a time when First Interstate has been hammered by huge losses at its subsidiaries in Arizona and Texas, where the real estate market has collapsed. First Interstate added $400 million to its reserves in December as it tried to get the Texas losses off its books as quickly as possible. Six months earlier, it had set aside a $350 million reserve against Arizona losses. Putting those problems behind is clearly the greatest task confronting the 60-year-old Carson, who joined First Interstate of Arizona in 1951, became its chairman in 1977, and was promoted to president of the parent corporation in 1985. ``We made mistakes'' when the Texas and Arizona real-estate markets were booming, Carson said in a telephone interview from Arizona. He said First Interstate has tightened lending practices to try to prevent over-aggressive lending, even in boom markets. ``Our strategy has been developing over the last three years,'' he said. ``We're trying to get rid of those suboptimal performers and improve or help the good performers to be higher.'' The big writedowns also have depressed First Interstate's stock price, causing many analysts to regard it as a takeover candidate. Williams noted that First Interstate would be by far the cheapest of the big California banks for any Eastern bank hoping to enter the lucrative markets in California. But Carson said First Interstate was not interested in a merger, which he said was not in the best interest of shareholders ``We are not interested at the present time, based on the fact that we have an extremely valuable franchise with a lot of synergies available to us,'' he said. As an example, he said that First Interstate is well-positioned to take advantage of computer technologies that continue to break down the barriers between states. ``For example in Utah, we had a bank that really was not doing very well, basically because Utah is an over-banked state _ I think they have more banks per capita there than anywhere else in the United States,'' Carson said. ``On the other hand, we have a very profitable bank in Nevada, and therefore we have gone as far as we can go to combine those banks,'' doing away with nearly all the Utah administrative staff. ``Technology and other advances have allowed us to bring together the operations of those two banks into a very profitable combined unit,'' Carson said. ``If you expand that to the Northwest, the Southwest, you can see that there would be tremendous opportunities.'' California ``obviously will remain a stand-alone operation,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: $adv21
For release Sunday Jan. 21
DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Forges Ahead with Bigger, More Complex Selloffs
LaserGraphic planned
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is proceeding with bigger, more complicated sales of state-owned companies in a privatization program that has more than tripled the number of British shareholders. Helped by the booming stock market of the 1980s, Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative government has raised $53 billion by selling such industries and services as steel, gas and telephones. Next in line is electricity. Not all the flotations have succeeded, and Mrs. Thatcher has faced a barrage of accusations that she is giving away the nation's assets. Harold Macmillan, the late prime minister, once likened it to an impoverished family selling off its heirlooms. But privatization has become one of the most striking features of Mrs. Thatcher's decade in office, and a powerful weapon in her crusade to bury British socialism. The prime minister, who believes companies perform better when the government isn't running them, has overseen the transformation of stodgy nationalized industries into thriving competitive businesses. A prime example is British Airways PLC, or BA, which, as Business Week described it, has been turned from ``Bloody Awful'' into ``Bloody Awesome.'' But Mrs. Thatcher's aim isn't just to resuscitate ailing industries, but to create an army of small shareholders who, having tasted the thrills of the stock market, won't ever want to re-elect the socialist Labor Party. Ten million Britons now own stock _ roughly as many as belong to trade unions _ and 13 percent of the adult population has bought into the privatized companies, Treasury figures show. Mrs. Thatcher has used the sales' revenue to convert budget deficits into surpluses and to cut the income tax rate to just 40 percent for top earners and 25 percent for the rest, a postwar low. Even some of Mrs. Thatcher's ideological adversaries admire her for the privatization campaign. Hugo Young, for example, political columnist for the left-leaning Guardian newspaper, has praised her for reducing the role of government in British life. Privatization has been so successful, its supporters say, that Britain has become an exporter of privatization know-how, copied by countries as diverse as Japan, Turkey, France and Chile. But critics say Mrs. Thatcher has become too radical during her third consecutive term, taking her privatization program too far. They say the government is selling Britons what they already own as taxpayers, or underpricing shares to ensure success. Particularly contentious is the sale of water and electricity, which critics say should remain state-owned, at least for reasons of national security. Moreover, they say, many privatized industries remain monopolies, insufficiently regulated to protect consumers. But investors have bought shares enthusiastically and generally have profited. The government has reserved most of the shares for the British public _ 64 percent in British Gas PLC's case _ selling the rest to British institutions and foreign investors. A shareholder who bought 100 British Gas shares for $219 each in December 1986 could have sold them at a 34 percent profit as soon as they began trading, or have kept them and be 76 percent richer today, plus dividends. Sweeteners included paying for the shares in installments, bonus shares or vouchers for free gas. The one big flop was the sale of the government's one-third interest in British Petroleum Co. PLC. That $12 billion sale, the largest so far, coincided with the October 1987 stock market crash, and many of the shares were left in the hands of stockbrokers. The most recent selloff, of the 10 water authorities of England and Wales, was widely expected to fail, because the stock market faltered badly last October, and water seemed too vital a commodity to expose to market forces. But the $8 billion sale proved the second most popular privatization after gas, drawing 2.7 million applications for shares. The government began privatization by selling relatively small companies like Cable and Wireless PLC. Then it moved to privatizing utilities in one piece, like British Gas, which fetched a record 4.7 million share applications. Now it is going even further, restructuring utilities as well as selling them. Selloffs must be approved by Parliament, but the Conservatives' large majority virtually assures assent. The government spent years and billions of pounds grooming its targets for the competitive world. It wrote off their debts, injected them with capital, closed plants and laid off workers. For instance, the government wrote off $2.6 billion in losses in British Steel PLC, which cut its work force from 186,000 in 1978 to 51,600 in 1987. The steel giant has gone from a net loss of $2.9 billion in 1979, which got listed in the Guinness Book of World Records, to an after-tax profit of $909 million in its first year in the private sector. The government also has spent more than $160 million on advertising campaigns and publicity gimmicks to promote privatizations. In one memorable stunt, men rappelled down the side of a high-rise building unfurling huge banners that revealed the price of BP shares. The privatization program has been so successful that the opposition Labor Party, which was responsible for nationalizing most of the now privatized companies, has abandoned its pledge to renationalize them. ``It's an acknowledgement that we're in a different world,'' said Labor lawmaker Doug Henderson. But Henderson remains critical. ``Privatization has been done by and large on the cheap to make sure that they were sold. If you get a bargain most people, take it. They got a bargain on gas, telecommunications, and water.'' Shares of the water companies, for example, soared to premiums as high as 64 percent on the first day of trading on Dec. 12. Others say consumers have enjoyed some advantages from the privatization _ a wider choice of telephones at cheaper prices, for example. But some groups want tighter regulation. ``It really doesn't matter who owns state utilities. What does matter is that they tend to be natural monopolies and that they need to be regulated in such a way that they do not screw consumers,'' said Wendy Toms, spokeswoman for the National Consumer Council. Privatization also has exposed some commercial crown jewels to foreign takeovers, creating some nationalist backlash, as happened when Ford Motor Co. of the United States acquired British luxury car maker Jaguar PLC in November. The government had gone against its own free-market principles by retaining ultimate control in privatized companies to protect them from foreign control. But it made Jaguar's takeover possible by waiving its ``golden share,'' and has indicated it might relinquish other such blockers. Next on the list is the sale of the electricity industry, which could raise more than $32 billion, dwarfing all the other privatizations. The government also hopes to privatize British Rail and British Coal.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday Jan. 21

DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Bankers Group Complains About FHLMC
DOC.TEXT: A trade group representing mortgage bankers complained Wednesday that the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. is shirking its responsibility to finance low-cost apartments. Earlier this month, the company, known as Freddie Mac, tightened its standards for buying multifamily housing loans from lenders. Freddie Mac, which is congressionally chartered but stockholder owned, provides money for housing by purchasing mortgages from lenders and packaging them into securities, which are then sold to investors. Last year it acquired more than $1.4 billion in mortgage loans on more than 20,000 apartments. On Jan. 2, the agency said it would only purchase mortgages on apartments when the borrower has made at least a 30 percent down payment. And, unless the borrower has made at least a 40 percent down payment, the agency is requiring the original lender to make good on the loan in the event of a default. Earlier rules required only a 15 percent down payment. Warren Lasko of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said the new rule represented a ``complete withdrawal'' from Freddie Mac's commitment to finance affordable rental housing. ``We believe that a federally chartered agency has an obligation to follow a steady stable course in meeting its public purposes,'' Lasko said, complaining that the decision was made suddenly without open discussion. However, John Nash, a spokesman for Freddie Mac, the new rule was ``an act of prudent management'' taken to reduce Freddie Mac loan losses. Half of the losses in the first nine months of 1989 were from apartment loans, he said. ``Our assignment, as defined by Congress, was not to purchase loans that go into default. We will certainly continue to support affordable housing,'' he said, adding that the agency hoped this year to increase the amount of multifamily mortgages it purchased.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau Bankruptcy Judge Is Former Newspaperman
LaserPhoto CS10
DOC.TEXT: The judge who will oversee the bankruptcy reorganization of Campeau Corp.'s department store empire has a reputation as a quietly efficient jurist _ but in this mammoth case he also may want to fall back on his reputation for humor. Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., who has been a U.S. bankruptcy judge for 14 months, also is an amateur poet who two years ago presented to the City Council a tongue-in-cheek ode on the merits of a proposal to include bronze, winged pigs in a sculpture marking Cincinnati's 1988 bicentennial. Critics said the pigs _ a reference to Cincinnati's 19th century prominence in hog butchering _ made the city look silly. Part of Aug's 18-line verse read: ``I've heard a recent nasty rumor; Cincinnati has no sense of humor; Now the question's grown so big; Shall we adopt the flying pig?'' The pigs eventually were retained. Aug, 43, faces a more arduous task in guiding the reorganizations of Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. Six thousand pages articulating the largest Chapter 11 filing in U.S. retailing history was filed with Aug's court Monday. Riding on the fates of the Cincinnati-based divisions of Campeau are 100,000 employees and 258 department stores nationwide, including the locally based, 14,000-employee Lazarus chain. Aug, who also has worked as a private attorney and newspaperman during his career, is no stranger to the federal bench or bankruptcy cases. He was appointed in 1976 to an eight-year term as a U.S. magistrate in Cincinnati and was reappointed in 1984. Magistrates handle arraignments and certain cases under supervision of federal district court judges. Aug became one of Cincinnati's two federal bankruptcy judges on Dec. 1, 1988, when he filled a vacancy created when Judge Randall J. Newsome transferred to a similar job in San Francisco. Aug handled some bankruptcy cases as a Cincinnati lawyer from 1974 to 1976 as an attorney in private practice, and before then was a staff attorney with the federal courts in Washington. His father, J. Vincent Aug Sr., is a Cincinnati lawyer. Aug declined a request by The Associated Press for an interview because he did not wish to comment on the Federated-Allied case, an aide said. Martha Perin, executive director of the Cincinnati Bar Foundation and former director of the Cincinati Bar Association, described Aug as low-key but efficient. ``He's very capable, quiet, very unassuming but very diligent,'' she said. Aug was born in Indianapolis and educated in Cincinnati schools. After graduating from St. Xavier High School, he went to Georgetown University, where he received a bachelor's degree in 1968. He served two years with the Peace Corps in Kenya, then was a newspaper reporter in 1970 for The Cincinnati Post. He received his law degree in 1973 from the University of Cincinnati and took a job that year as a staff attorney with the Judicial Panel on Multi-District Litigation in the federal court system's Washington administrative office. Aug served as a columnist for The Cincinnati Enquirer from 1978 to 1983, was an adjunct faculty member at the University of Cincinnati College of Law from 1982 to 1985, and was president of the Cincinnati chapter of the Federal Bar Association in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Buy More Subsidized U.S. Wheat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, bgng, ``The seventh ... to UPDATE with announcement of US-Soviet meeting. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 525,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices for delivery in March under a long-term grain supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the wheat was sold by four private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Dickerson said 511,650 tons of wheat remain in the Soviet Union's current EEP allocation of 2 million tons announced on Dec. 19. Only wheat has been approved for sale to the Soviets under the price subsidy program. The seventh year of the U.S.-Soviet grain agreement began on Oct. 1. With the latest sales, the Soviet Union has bought about 2.3 million tons of wheat for 1989-90 delivery and more than 11 million tons of corn, plus some soybeans and soybean meal. All of the wheat was sold under EEP arrangements. Meanwhile, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced the next round of negotiations with the Soviets on a new agreement will be in Vienna on March 21-22. The current pact will expire on Dec. 31. In 1988-89, the sixth year of the agreement, the Soviet Union bought about 5.4 million tons of wheat and more than 16.3 million tons of corn, plus soybeans, soybean meal and grain sorghums. All but about 700,000 tons of the wheat was bought under EEP. A metric tons is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The 525,000 tons are equal to 19.3 million bushels worth around $73 million at recent U.S. farm prices. Dickerson reported the subsidies at an average of $18.73 per ton, or about 51 cents per bushel. The EEP arrangement allows private exporters to sell wheat and other designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices in order to meet foreign competition. The exporters then collect free government surpluses of grain or other products as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest wheat was sold by J. Aron & Co., 250,000 tons; Louis Dreyfus Corp., 150,000; Harvest States Cooperatives, 100,000; and Cargill Inc., 25,000.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell to an eight-week low Wednesday under a barrage of late selling attributed to disappointing economic and earnings news. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 33.49 to 2,659.13, its lowest close since it stood at 2,656.78 on Nov. 22. Since the average hit a record closing high of 2,810.15 in the first session of 1990 on Jan. 2, it has retreated 153.37 points, or 5.46 percent. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 649 up, 867 down and 462 unchanged. Analysts said a widening of the U.S. trade deficit to $10.5 billion in November from $10.25 billion in October caught some market participants off guard. A separate government report on industrial production seemed to signal that manufacturing remained sluggish. The 0.4 percent increase posted for December was attributed in large measure to a cold weather-induced bulge in output by utilities. Brokers also said earnings reports from International Business Machines and Alcoa provided little assurance for investors who have been waiting uneasily for fourth-quarter profit figures from many companies. IBM, which said its fourth-quarter earnings shrank to $1.04 a share from $3.97 a share in the like period a year earlier, dropped 1\ to 98~. Aluminum Co. of America, another component of the Dow Jones industrial average, fell 5~ to 66~ after the company came in with lower quarterly profits. Alcoa's news appeared to drag down other basic-industry stocks as well. Phelps Dodge dropped ~ to 59; International Paper ] to 52[; Dow Chemical 1] to 67~, and DuPont 1| to 121|. Elsewhere among actively traded blue chips, American Express dropped | to 31}; Merck 1[ to 72; Philip Morris ~ to 38{, and American Telephone & Telegraph | to 42{. Caterpillar Inc., which is expected to post its results for the fourth quarter on Thursday, lost 2[ to 54~. Aristech Chemical was the volume leader, up { at 25[. A management-led group has proposed a buyout for $26 a share. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 170.47 million shares, against 186.07 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 202.03 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $22.39 billion, or 0.68 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.51 to 186.86. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 3.84 to 387.99, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 3.35 at 337.40. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slumped 1.48 to 438.68. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 368.06, down .35.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices Drop
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices tumbled Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in response to an industry report that showed a sharp rise in petroleum supplies. ``I was shocked, flabbergasted by the report,'' said Peter Beutel, energy analyst for Elders Futures Inc. The report by the American Petroleum Institute, a trade association representing major oil companies, said inventories of crude oil, heating oil and gasoline in the nation's storage tanks grew substantially during the week ended Jan. 12, while refineries continued to pump out refined products at a brisk pace. ``We're seeing runs of a million barrels a day. It's the biggest I've seen since I started looking at these statistics in 1982,'' Beutel said. Heating oil for February delivery plunged 3.51 cents to 60.52 cents a gallon, while the March contract fell 1.64 cents to 57.82 cents and April lost 1.13 cents to 55.45 cents a gallon. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for February delivery dropped 2.88 cents to 61.42 cents a gallon, March was down 2 cents to 61.82 cents and April closed at 61.78 cents, down 1.92 cents. The February contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, closed down 68 cents at $22.10 a barrel. All other crude contracts also lost ground. Analysts said the rise in gasoline stocks was the biggest surprise, since recent indicators suggested demand for gasoline was on the rise after warmer weather halted the heating oil rally. ``The market reacted violently to the unexpected build in gasoline,'' said Michael Broder, energy broker for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Particularly surprising was the rise in refinery utilization, he said. ``I think it caught the industry by surprise,'' Broder said. API statistics, released after the close of trading on Tuesday, showed gasoline stocks rose 5 million barrels to 214.9 million barrels, heating oil and other distillates increased 2 million to 108.4 million and crude oil was up 2.9 million barrels to 345.1 million.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Earnings Tumble in 4th Qtr
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf For the... to CORRECT percentage drop for full year earnings to 34.4 percent sted 40 percent.
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. said Wednesday its fourth-quarter earnings fell 74 percent, due to restructuring-related costs that some analysts said were bigger than expected. The world's biggest computer company posted a profit of $600 million, or $1.04 a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31. That was down from $2.3 billion, or $3.97 a share, in the same period a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue totaled $20.5 billion, up 2.3 percent from $20 billion a year earlier. IBM attributed the decline mainly to a $2.4 billion charge against fourth-quarter pre-tax profit to pay costs associated with cutting 10,000 jobs and restructuring other aspects of its U.S. business, which has been in a prolonged slump. IBM in December had projected a charge of about $2.3 billion, amounting to about $2.25 a share, against expected earnings. The actual charge came to some $2.58 a share, analysts said. ``I was surprised in that $1.04 (a share in profit) was lower than I expected but only because the company took a larger-than-expected one-time charge,'' said William Easterbrook, an analyst with Kidder Peabody & Co. ``It has to do with a greater number of people taking voluntary severance,'' he said. IBM stock fell $1.25 a share to $98.87{ on the New York Stock Exchange Wednesday. For the full year, IBM earnings fell about 35 percent to $3.8 billion, or $6.47 a share, from $5.8 billion or $9.80 a share in 1988. Revenue totaled $62.7 billion, up 5.1 percent from $59.7 billion a year ago. IBM also attributed the lower earnings to a strong dollar, which makes its business less competitive overseas, and growth in leasing of its equipment, which reduces short-term earnings because customers pay on a periodic basis. In addition to the job cuts in the restructuring plan announced Dec. 5, IBM also said it was repurchasing $4 billion of its own stock. IBM spokesman Peter W. Thonis said the company had not changed its earlier projection of $500 million in costs for ``separation payments'' and still expected to reduce its U.S. work force to 206,000 from the current 216,000. Thonis said the cuts _ IBM's fourth job-cutting program since 1986 _ would be completed by the end of March. The cuts were being made through attrition and early retirement incentives. He also said the results of the restructuring were within IBM's expectations. By 1991, the computer giant expects to reduce costs and expenses by about $1 billion as a result of the restructuring, he said. ``That works out to about $1 in earnings per share and we will see some of that benefit starting in 1990,'' he said. IBM's earnings are scrutinized because they reflect broader trends in the computer business. The company is the largest manufacturer of information processing equipment and systems and is a historical leader in shaping the direction of the industry. Industry growth, which had slowed substantially in recent years, now appears to be stabilizing. IBM Chairman John F. Akers said growth in overseas revenue was strong in 1989 and while U.S. revenue grew more modestly, it nevertheless recorded its first gains in four years. ``Demand for IBM's products and services remains good,'' Akers said, adding that the restructuring would produce a more competitive company in the 1990s. Analysts generally agreed, saying IBM's recent cost controls could result in a good payoff in the 1990s. Most said they would continue to recommend IBM stock to investors. ``They're finally taking serious steps in organizing the company and changing the cost structure,'' said Barry Bosak, analyst with Smith Barney Harris Upham & Co. ``They have a better product compliment than they have had in recent years. My assessment is there are no real negatives.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slips After News of Wider Trade Deficit; Gold Also Falls
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: An unexpected widening of the U.S. trade deficit sent the dollar falling against most foreign currencies Wednesday. Gold prices were mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold rose $1.70 to $412.50 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $412.90, up $3.10 from late Tuesday. Foreign exchange dealers said investors were concerned because the poor trade performance in November was partly due to a drop in exports. Some analysts believed the decline indicated a further slowing of the U.S. economy. The Commerce Department said the trade deficit grew in November to $10.5 billion, its worst showing in 11 months. Imports declined by $593 million to $40.69 billion, but exports dropped $843 million to $30.19 billion. The government blamed much of the increase on a strike at Boeing Co., which severely cut into exports of expensive commercial airliners. But private economists were still disappointed by the figure. Ronald Holzer, chief foreign exchange dealer with Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, said any possible upward moves by the dollar were being limited by traders' skeptical view of the economy. However, he said, the U.S. currency was ``beginning to base at these levels.'' Although the trade news pushed the dollar lower, foreign exchange traders largely focused on the West German mark and other currencies Wednesday, Holzer said. Overseas dealers said continuing tensions in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe gave the dollar some underlying support. The dollar did manage a gain against the British pound. In London, one pound cost $1.6525 late Wednesday, cheaper than late Tuesday's $1.6560. In later New York trading, the pound was quoted at $1.65235, down from $1.6585 late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.6873 West German marks, down from 1.6950; 1.5055 Swiss francs, down from 1.5116; 5.7325 French francs, down from 5.7630; 1,256.50 Italian lire, down from 1,262.25; and 1.16515 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16375. Other late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared to Tuesday's late rates, included: 1.6905 West German marks, down from 1.6945; 1.5023 Swiss francs, down from 1.5160; 5.7250 French francs, down from 5.7635; 1.8990 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9195; 1,254.75 Italian lire, down from 1,261.50; 1.1640 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1648. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 145.52 Japanese yen, down from 145.75 yen Tuesday. In London trading, the dollar closed at 145.45 yen, and in New York, it rose to 145.395 yen from late Tuesday's 145.30 yen. Gold prices fell below $410 a troy ounce in moderate trading in Europe, piquing the interest of New York traders, who then moved bullion higher. The late bid price for gold in both London and Zurich was $409.75 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's $413.25 in London and $413 in Zurich. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $410.35 bid, down from $415.45. Silver was also mixed. The metal rose 2.6 cents on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $5.256 a troy ounce, after falling earlier in London to $5.23 from late Tuesday's $5.25.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Plunge As Supplies Build
DOC.TEXT: Oil and gasoline futures prices plummeted Wednesday after an industry report showed an increase in U.S. stocks of petroleum products after several weeks of declining supplies. On other commodity markets, precious metals futures rose, livestock and meat futures were higher, and grains and soybeans were mixed. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 68 cents lower to 4 cents higher with the contract for delivery in February at $22.10 a barrel; heating oil was .60 cent to 3.51 cents lower with February at 60.52 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was 1.45 cents to 2.88 cents lower with February at 61.42 cents a gallon. The sell-off followed Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute supplies report, which showed sharp increases in stocks of crude oil, gasoline and petroleum distillates last week. Crude oil stocks rose by 2.9 million barrels, gasoline stocks increased by 5 million barrels and distillates, which include home heating oil, climbed by 2.1 million barrels, the API reported. The API also said refinery activity rose 6.8 percent, a huge increase and a strong contrast to recent weeks in which refining operations were slowed by cold-weather damage to equipment in the Gulf states and a variety of other refinery problems elsewhere. Energy futures had risen sharply over the past two months, largely as a result of strong demand for heating oil caused by unusually cold weather in Europe and then in the United States. But warmer temperatures have prevailed since the new year began, and demand has eased. ``The weather pattern we've had so far in January has been a contributing factor,'' said Michael Rothman, vice president of energy securities and futures research at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc. ``But the return to normal refinery operations, as reflected in the API report, is really what you're seeing reflected in today's market.'' Gold and silver futures finished moderately higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, boosted late in the session by reports that the Soviet Union planned to send more troops to Azerbaijan, a southern Soviet republic where fighting between Armenians and Azerbaijanis is escalating. Gold futures settled $1.50 higher across the board with February at $413.70 a troy ounce; silver was 2.3 cents to 2.7 cents higher with March at $5.308 a troy ounce. Livestock and meat futures rose on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, led by sharp increases in cattle futures linked to tight supplies of market-ready animals and relatively light slaughter rates. Live cattle finished .35 cent to .62 cent higher with February at 78.22 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to 1.02 cents higher with January at 83.87 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .43 cent higher with February at 49.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .73 cent to 1.82 cents higher with February at 56.42 cents a pound. Soybean and corn futures fell slightly on the Chicago Board of Trade as rain continued in the Midwest. Wheat futures closed slightly higher. The action marked the fourth consecutive daily decline in the soybean market, where attitudes have turned bearish due in part to increased rainfall in the U.S. corn and soybean belt and in southern Brazil, an important soybean-producing region where the new crop is in the early stages of growth. Wheat futures settled { cent to 3\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.01 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.41{ a bushel; oats were 2\ cents to 4 cents lower with March at $1.39{ a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 2 cents lower with January at $5.57{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Northeast Bancorp Stock Falls By 17 Percent Following Earnings Report
DOC.TEXT: Shares of Northeast Bancorp Inc. tumbled by 17 percent on Wednesday after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss that reflected the impact of a declining New England economy. The bank holding company's shares fell $9.50 a share to $46 in national over-the-counter market trading. Northeast posted a net loss of $25,853 in the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with a profit of $10.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The company increased its provisions for possible loan losses to $71 million from $13 million during the quarter, due to deteriorating loan quality. Loan chargeoffs totaled $39 million during the quarter. Earnings for the entire year fell to $632,000, or 8 cents per share, from $34.6 million, or $4.39 per share, in 1988. Company spokesman John C. Kline attributed the stock price plunge to the fourth-quarter financial report. ``I think people were reacting to the numbers more than anything else,'' he said. ``That's the only thing I can determine.'' Northeast Bancorp has an agreement to be acquired by Bank of New York Co., pending changes in state laws prohibiting acquisitions by non-regional banks. That agreement is to expire Aug. 15. A number of New England banks have felt the effects of declining real estate values, bad real estate loans, and a general downturn in the region's economy. Northeast Bancorp said it has been conservative in lending money since 1987, especially in real estate, which allowed the company to avoid many of the loan problems experienced by other banks. But it said the problems finally caught up with the company's businesses, which include Union Trust Co., Connecticut's third-largest commercial bank; NBI Mortgage Investment Corp.; UT Finance Ltd.; and Fairfield Properties Inc.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Trade Deficit Up Again
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts new 5th graf with stock market close, picks up 5th graf pvs, However, in better ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: America's trade deficit widened to $10.5 billion in November, its worst showing in 11 months, as U.S. exports took a tumble caused in part by a strike at Boeing, the Commerce Department said Wednesday. The Commerce Department said that while imports dipped slightly from an all-time high set in October, U.S. exports sales declined even more, falling to their lowest level since last March. As a result, the trade deficit, the difference between imports and exports, rose 2.4 percent. The increase, coming on the heels of an even worse 20 percent surge in the October deficit, left private economists disheartened about the chances for further improvement in the country's trade performance any time soon. Wall Street reacted to the trade report with disappointment as well, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down by 33.49 points to close at 2,659.13, its lowest closing since Nov. 22. However, in better economic news, the government reported Wednesday that industrial production rose 0.4 percent in December, its best showing since August, while the operating rate at American factories, mines and utilities rose 0.2 percentage point to 83.3 percent of capacity. Much of the strength was attributed to a return of striking Boeing workers and a record jump in utility usage, caused by unusually severe weather in December. But analysts, noting that industrial production figures for September, October and November were all revised upward, said the new-found strength in U.S. industry provided further evidence that the current economic slowdown should not worsen into a recession. For the first 11 months of this year, the U.S. trade deficit has been running at an annual rate of $111 billion, only a marginal improvement from the $118.53 billion deficit for all of 1988. Many economists are forecasting that the trade deficit this year will begin rising again, reflecting a growing U.S. dependence on foreign oil, a further slowdown in U.S. export sales abroad and continued demand by American consumers for foreign products. ``The trade report is most distressing,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``The United States simply is just not competitive on goods. We are not selling enough overseas and Americans keep on buying imports.'' Michael K. Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm, said he was not looking for any improvement in the trade deficit either this year or in 1991 saying, ``A balanced trade sector is just not going to happen. We like imports too much.'' The Bush administration, which is counting on continued solid growth in exports to bolster the domestic economy, was more upbeat in its assessment of the November trade report. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher said the administration was still looking for ``continued moderate improvement in the trade deficit'' in 1990. The trade improvement over the past two years has accounted for almost half of total U.S. economic growth. But with the export boom showing signs of running out of steam, many analysts are predicting that the overall economy will grow at just half the rate turned in during 1989. The November trade deficit, and a revised $10.25 billion imbalance in October, were the worst imbalances since a $10.8 billion deficit in December 1988. The 2.7 percent drop in exports, to $30.19 billion, included an $895 million decline in commercial airplane exports, caused in large part by the 45-day strike at Boeing, which ended on Nov. 21. However, analysts noted that even without the big drop in airplane shipments in November, export sales have been basically flat since last June. Imports totaled $40.69 billion in November, down only a slight 1.4 percent from their all-time high set in October. While shipments of autos from Japan fell by 14.1 percent during the month, America's foreign oil bill climbed to $4.38 billion. The number of barrels imported daily edged up to 8.42 million while the price per barrel rose by 24 cents to $17.33. Economists are predicting even higher oil bills in the future as America's dependence on foreign oil increases. The American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade group, reported Wednesday that foreign imports rose to 46 percent of total supplies in 1989, the second-highest level on record. As usual, the biggest trade deficit in November was with Japan, $4.0 billion, even though the total represented a decline from a $4.9 billion October deficit. Other large deficits were recorded with Canada, $1.2 billiion; Taiwan, $1 billion, China, $800 million, and Western Europe, $700 million.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Trims Production at 3 Plants; Affecting 2,254 Workers
DOC.TEXT: Production rates at three Chrysler Corp. assembly plants will be cut in March, resulting in the indefinite layoffs of more than 2,000 workers, the company said Wednesday. Spokesman Doug Nicoll blamed the moves on slow sales. The cuts are due at Chrysler's plants in Belvidere, Ill.; Newark, Del.; and Toledo, Ohio, which make some of the company's most profitable cars and Jeeps. The reductions come in addition to previously announced temporary and indefinite layoffs that will affect more than 25,000 Chrysler workers in February. Chrysler will close its Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit Feb. 2, affecting 1,700 workers, and eliminate the second shift at its St. Louis car plant, involving 1,900 employees, beginning Feb. 12. Other layoffs are temporary. The Belvidere factory assembles the Chrysler New Yorker, Salon, Fifth Avenue and Imperial and the Dodge Dynasty cars, which carry the highest per-car profit in the No. 3 automaker's lineup. The Newark plant makes the Plymouth Acclaim, Dodge Spirit and the Chrysler LeBaron sedan. Jeeps, which make up a large portion of Chrysler's light truck sales, are made at its Toledo plant. Nicoll said 750 salaried and hourly employees will be affected at Belvidere, 780 will be laid off at Newark and 724 will lose their jobs at Toledo. He did not have a breakdown of salaried and hourly employees at the plants. A survey last year of automotive plant capacity by Autofacts Inc. of Philadelphia showed hourly workers make up between 84 and 90 percent of the employees at each of the plants. Production rates at the Belvidere and Newark plants will be trimmed by 12 percent and Jeep production at Toledo will be cut by about 8 percent, Nicoll said. Each of the three plants will shut down completely for the week of March 19. ``When they come back up the week of the 26th, they will come up at lower production rates,'' Nicoll said. Nicoll declined to give assembly line speeds, but the Autofacts' survey showed that production rates were between 60 and 65 vehicles an hour at each plant.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturers Say Process Is Still Too Long
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Despite efforts to improve the government's drug-approval process, it still takes too long to push new drugs through the regulatory maze, manufacturers said Wednesday. It takes about 10 years to move a new drug from development through testing on patients to approval from the Food and Drug Administration, the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association said. ``Given the overriding importance of new drug therapy, that 10-year-period _ including the 32{ months of review time at FDA _ is too long and must be shortened,'' said Gerald J. Mossinghoff, president of the trade association. ``We think there's some opportunity'' to cut down the review time as well as the time in clinical trials, Mossinghoff told reporters. Mossinghoff said the FDA needs more employees, better facilities and better pay for its employees. FDA spokesman Bill Grigg said the review time for totally new drugs is longer than for other drugs because they are more complicated to process. He also said it includes about six months during which the agency waits for more information it requests from drug sponsors. Mossinghoff also said that while the generic drug scandal has been a ``major distraction'' at the agency, it does not appear to have hampered the processing of applications to sell generica drugs, which are copies of drugs on which patents have expired. However, it did more than halve the number of generic drugs approved last year. In 1989, 265 generic drugs were approved, compared with 684 in 1988. Jay Molishever, spokesman for the Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association, said the result is a ``clogging of the pipeline'' that is hurting consumers as well as innocent generic drug companies. ``It should return to normal levels,'' he said. ``How quickly that happens, we don't have an indication yet, but definitely we think the low point has been reached.'' The scandal has seen convictions of three generic drug company executives and bribe-taking convictions of three FDA employees. The investigation also uncovered evidence that some drug companies had cheated on FDA safety tests, prompting recalls of dozens of generic drugs, including clones of some popular drugs. Drug makers won approval to sell 23 new drugs last year, compared with 20 in 1988. During the past decade, the highest number of approvals in one year was 30 in 1985 and the lowest was 14 in 1983. The drugs in this category are considered ``new molecular entities,'' which means they are not related in chemical structure to existing drugs. Overall, the FDA approved a total of 87 new drugs, most of which are chemically related to drugs already on the market, and 113 products not counted as drugs, such as vaccines, called ``biological products'' by the agency. In 1988, the agency approved 67 new drugs and 41 biologics.

DOC.HEAD: Second Publisher Asked To Return, Not Print Confidential Documents
DOC.TEXT: Accounting Today said Ernst & Young asked the newsletter Wednesday to return secret documents about the accounting giant, which won a court order halting their publication at another newsletter last week. Accounting Today, a twice-monthly newsletter based in New York, said it had no plans to return the documents and would publish them in its Feb. 5 edition, mailed to subscribers Jan. 30. ``We got a nice note from them today, hand-delivered, to return the documents and not to talk about them,'' said Robert Crane, Accounting Today editor. ``We will not respond. We will plan to go ahead with what we intended to do anyway.'' The documents, evidently leaked by someone inside the Big Six accounting company, apparently contain sensitive details about compensation to the partners of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young, the firms that merged last June. Ernst & Young won a court order Jan. 8 preventing Bowman's Accounting Report of Atlanta from printing a front-page article containing the information, just as the newsletter was going to press. A hearing on that order by New York Supreme Court Judge Beatrice Shainswit was scheduled for Thursday morning. Ernst & Young officials did not immediately return telephone calls seeking comment on Accounting Today's plans. Carl D. Liggio, an attorney representing the accounting firm in the Bowman's case, was in a meeting and unavailable to comment, a secretary said. Judge Shainswit's order only applies to Bowman's. The accounting firm would have to get another order to stop Accounting Today from publishing the material. The case has attracted enormous attention from news organizations, which claim the judge's order violated the constitutional guarantee of press freedom. Ernst & Young claims the issue concerns privacy rights. The Associated Press, New York Times, Atlanta Journal-Constitution, Wall Street Journal and other media groups have joined Bowman's in charging that order was an unconstitutional. The hearing originally was scheduled for next Monday but was expedited at the newsletter's request. Crane did not explain how his newsletter obtained the information, but said he did not believe the content to be very significant outside of the accounting profession. Crane said he believed Ernst & Young was reacting more to what the accounting firm felt was a violation of its internal affairs. ``You have to keep in mind that accountants take confidentiality very seriously,'' Crane said. ``In this instance, one of their own leaked proprietary information.''

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders OK Holiday Inns Sale to British Company
DOC.TEXT: Holiday Corp. shareholders gave overwhelming approval Wednesday to the $2.2 billion sale of the Holiday Inns motel chain in the United States to Bass PLC of Great Britain. Holiday Inns, which became known as ``America's innkeeper'' was begun in Memphis in 1952. Michael D. Rose, chairman of Holiday Corp., Holiday Inns' corporate parent, said he expects the sale to be completed within a month, although state gaming commissions in New Jersey and Nevada still must give their approval. After the sale, Holiday Corp. is to spin off a new company to run its profitable Harrah's Casino-Hotels and its newer hotel brands, Embassy Suites, Hampton Inn and Homewood Suites. The new corporation will be called The Promus Companies Inc. and its shareholders are to draw a $30 cash dividend. Holiday Corp. shareholders also will get one-quarter share of Bass stock for each of their Holiday shares. ``We're obviously delighted with the shareholder vote,'' Rose said. ``We anticipated the vote would be this way and now the next step is to get to closing and to send out the dividends and start our future as The Promus Companies.'' The Holiday shareholder vote was 16.7 million for the sale and 69,684 against, with 251,504 shares abstaining. With the sale, Bass will acquire 55 owned or leased properties as well as franchise agreements and other management arrangements covering 1,400 Holiday Inn hotels in North America. Bass has more than 7,300 pubs and restaurants in the United Kingdom. The company brews Bass, Carling Black Label and other beers and has annual sales approaching $6 billion. It bought the rights to franchise Holiday Inns outside North America in 1988 and currently owns 14 Holiday Inns in the southeastern United States. Bass is a major Holiday Inn franchisee in Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Ameritech Posts Increased Profit for Final Quarter and Year
DOC.TEXT: Ameritech reported on Wednesday a 7.1 percent profit increase for the final quarter of 1989, and a tiny advance for the year. ``This past year saw increased calling volumes in our regulated business and continued healthy growth in our unregulated businesses,'' said William L. Weiss, chairman and chief executive officer. For the quarter, net income increased to $331.7 million, or $1.22 a share, from $309.7 million, or $1.15 a share, during the final three months of 1988. Revenue rose to $2.6 billion from $2.5 billion. Earnings for the year were $1.238 billion, or $4.59 a share, up from $1.237 billion, or $4.55 a share, in 1988. Revenues in 1989 were $10.2 billion, compared with $9.9 billion the previous year. Ameritech is the parent of Bell companies serving Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin.

DOC.HEAD: Aircraft Shipments Up
DOC.TEXT: The nation's general aviation manufacturers shipped 1,535 planes in 1989, a 27 percent increase over the 1,212 aircraft delivered in 1988, the industry's trade association reported on Wednesday. This is far below, however, the 17,050 piston and jet aircraft delivered in the peak year of 1979. D. Larry Moore, chairman of the General Aviation Manufacturers Association, told a news conference that because the industry shipped fewer large jets and more single-engine piston aircraft last year, net billings fell to $1.8 billion, six percent less than the $1.9 billion reported in 1988. Moore noted that a decade ago the industry shipped more than 16,000 piston aircraft, more than 14 times the number of such planes shipped in 1989. ``The primary cause of this decline in unit shipments is the product liability crisis, which continues to damage the industry,'' Moore said.

DOC.HEAD: Alcoa Earnings Drop 24 Percent in Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Aluminum Co. of America said Wednesday its earnings dropped 24 percent in the fourth quarter, partly due to a decline in shipments and an increase in the cost of raw materials. Alcoa, the world's largest producer of aluminum, operates in 18 countries. For the three months ended Dec. 31, Alcoa's net profit fell to $164.7 million, or $1.88 a share, from $218.7 million, or $2.47 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. The decline occurred despite a 2 percent increase in fourth-quarter revenue to $2.69 billion from $2.65 billion. Alcoa Chairman Paul H. O'Neill said the earnings erosion reflected the continuing trend of an economic slowdown that began in mid-1988. The company also attributed the fourth-quarter drop to lower prices for ingots, the molds in which metals are cast, and for most fabricated products. ``Operations in Australia and Brazil accounted for 42 percent of Alcoa's 1989 earnings compared with 25 percent in the prior year, mainly due to strong prices for alumina and ingot for most of the year,'' O'Neill said. Alcoa owns 51 percent of Alcoa of Australia, the world's largest producer of alumina, or aluminum oxide. Alcoa's fourth-quarter shipments decreased 6 percent to 635,000 metric tons from 676,000 in the same period of 1988. For all of 1989, the company's net profit rose nearly 10 percent to a record $944.9 million, or $10.67 a share, from $861.4 million, or $9.74 a share. Full-year revenue increased to $11.16 billion from $9.93 billion in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Phillips Announces $280 Million Writedown; Earnings Expected to Drop
DOC.TEXT: Phillips Petroleum Co. will take a $280 million after-tax writedown on its offshore California investments that will cause the company's fourth-quarter earnings to plunge, company officials said Wednesday. ``We regrettably must take this step, even though production of California's offshore resources could help slow the nation's growing dependence on imported oil,'' said C.J. Silas, Phillips chairman and chief executive officer. The investments include the oil-rich Point Arguello field off the coast of Santa Barbara, Calif., which could hold as many as 500 million barrels of oil. Phillips holds 40 percent and 50 percent interests in the blocks that are part of the field. Silas said the writedown was prompted by delays in getting regulatory approval to transport oil from the field by tanker. Those delays are largely the result of opposition by several area environmental groups. He said the writedown applies to Phillips' interests in Point Arguello and associated production, transportation and onshore processing facilities, suspended exploratory wells in the Rocky Point field and some other offshore California leases in which Phillips has interests. ``Suspension of the project can only further increase the U.S. trade deficit and have a negative effect on the economy,'' Silas said in a news release. Silas said the writedown will be charged against fourth-quarter 1989 earnings, which will be released Jan. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Geldermann Re-elected Chairman of Chicago Mercantile Exchange
DOC.TEXT: John T. Geldermann on Wednesday was re-elected chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. He was selected to his second consecutive one-year term by the exchange's Board of Governors in an unchallenged election. While Geldermann's election was unchallenged, there was a spirited contest for the chairmanship of the cross-town Chicago Board of Trade. The members of the board on Tuesday re-elected Karsten ``Cash'' Mahlmann to his fourth consecutive one-year term. He defeated Leslie Rosenthal _ 630-524. Geldermann, 64, has served on the Merc's Board of Governors since 1968 and was its chairman from 1974 to 1975. With his father, Godfrey J. Geldermann, he cofounded the firm that is now Geldermann Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of ConAgra and a clearing member firm of the Mercantile Exchange, the nation's second largest futures market. The tradition at the Merc in recent times has been for the Board of Governors to select a chairman for three consecutive one-year terms.

DOC.HEAD: CenTrust Says Proposed Merger With New York Thrift Dropped
DOC.TEXT: CenTrust Bank, Florida's largest savings and loan, said Wednesday that it is calling off a proposed merger with New York-based Ensign Bank because the two struggling thrifts were uncertain of government approval. But CenTrust said it plans to continue its attempt to gain regulatory approval of its proposed sale of 63 of its 71 branches to Great Western Bank in Beverly Hills, Calif. CenTrust has said the proposed merger with Ensign, a thrift with eight offices in South Florida, would have placed the combined institutions near, but still short of, federal capital requirements. The latest development came a day after Miami-based CenTrust reported a net loss of $97.3 million in the fourth quarter. CenTrust said the proposed merger would have resulted in the formation of a new, restructured holding company and a capital infusion from Hamilton Holding Co., the parent of Ensign Bank. Ensign is owned by Miami billionaire Ted Arison, the majority owner of the Miami-based Carnival Cruise Lines and the NBA's Miami Heat. Both thrifts decided it would be best to terminate the proposed merger because they were uncertain it would be approved by the federal Office of Thrift Supervision, CenTrust said in a statement Wednesday. CenTrust and Ensign will each file separate capital plans in connection with federal capital requirements, according to the statement. CenTrust said it expected its capital plan to include the proposed sale of the 63 branches. On Tuesday, CenTrust Chairman David L. Paul said the large fourth-quarter loss was partly due to government-ordered ``excessive'' loss reserves on securities and to overall thrift industry problems. The loss for the quarter ended Sept. 30 compared with a loss of $2.7 million for the same quarter in 1988. CenTrust, which said it had assets totaling $9 billion Sept. 30, also reported a loss of $119.5 million for fiscal 1989. That compared with a profit of $50.1 million the previous year. Some analysts predicted more large losses were in CenTrust's future. ``I believe these numbers could go even higher,'' said Miami banking consultant Ken Thomas. ``As of Dec. 31, I believe they may have to write off another $100 million.'' CenTrust has been ordered by regulators to sell its expensive art collection, a yacht and limousines, all used by Paul. The OTS, which recently slapped Paul with a cease and desist order, has alleged he squandered CenTrust's assets on such things as corporate aircraft, the yacht and hefty salaries.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Freeze Cost Florida Citrus Growers $400 Million
DOC.TEXT: Florida citrus growers lost more than $400 million from the Christmas freeze, and the lower crop and juice yields decimated the industry's control of the U.S. orange juice market, according to a state economic report released Wednesday. The two-day freeze cut Florida's orange crop to its smallest in 25 years. The freeze reduced the crop by 29 percent to 92 million boxes and the grapefruit crop by nearly 14 percent to 38 million boxes, according to the state Department of Citrus report. The early-season freeze over the Christmas weekend crippled the industry because more than 80 percent of the crop, then estimated at 174 million boxes, had not been harvested. ``As a result of Florida's reduced crop prospects in 1989-90, Florida is expected to supply less than one-half of the orange juice required by the U.S. market in the forthcoming season,'' said Bob Behr, the economic and market research director for the state agency. Last season, Florida citrus and its related industries brought in an estimated $8.5 billion in revenue. The smaller crop and lower juice yield means Florida can supply about 40 percent of the U.S. orange juice market, down from its 71 percent share a year ago, said Behr, who updated the 1989-90 citrus outlook for the Florida Citrus Commission during the commission's meeting here. Florida's share of the market will be offset by Brazilian imports. Brazil supplied about 35 percent of the market a year ago and will easily supply more than 50 percent this year, Behr said. ``Supply should be sufficient to meet the market, but supplies will be slightly less than what was available last year,'' Behr said. ``I don't really see a major shortage of orange juice.'' While wholesale prices for frozen concentrated orange juice supplied by private-label companies have risen about 27 percent from levels prior to the freeze, retail prices are expected to rise modestly by about 8 percent. The higher prices are not expected to deter most consumers and consumption is expected to fall just 1.2 percent, Behr said. Florida's citrus industry has been hit by several freezes this decade, with the tree-killing cold of 1983 and 1985 cutting the state's citrus-production by more than 200,000 acres. In Lake Wales, U.S. Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla., told state citrus leaders he opposed any reduction in the tariff on Brazilian citrus imports. ``Florida citrus has suffered enough,'' Graham said. ``The freeze was bad enough. We don't want to drown in imports.'' The Brazilians have asked for a 50 percent reduction in the tariff, but Graham is urging President Bush not to reduce it.
